Headline: Microsoft is firing employees in 3 departments, set to take more actions to save costsMicrosoft has started another round of job cuts, impacting staff across departments such as security, sales, gaming, and experiences.
Content: Microsoft has started another round of job cuts, impacting staff across departments such as security, sales, gaming, and experiences, as reported by Business Insider. This comes shortly after the company announced plans to lay off some employees, with sources indicating that less than 1 per cent of the workforce will be affected. The layoffs are part of Microsoft's efforts to tighten its spending as the company navigates through economic challenges. Alongside these cuts, Microsofts consulting division has paused hiring and will delay filling vacant roles, according to a memo obtained by CNBC. Derek Danois, a senior executive in the consulting unit, asserted in the memo that careful cost management is crucial, adding that internal meetings should be conducted remotely to avoid unnecessary travel expenses. The report says that top executives are asked to approve any travel to customer sites to ensure spending is aligned with the companys priorities. The memo also mentions that Microsoft plans to cut marketing and external resource costs by 35 per cent, further underlining the companys focus on controlling expenses. This wave of layoffs follows an earlier move by Microsoft in early 2023 when it let go of 10,000 employees as part of a cost-cutting strategy under CEO Satya Nadella. The company was responding to broader economic shifts and market conditions. Additionally, in January 2024, Microsofts gaming division, following its $75.4 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, laid off 1,900 workers to reduce overlapping roles. Microsoft isnt the only tech giant making such decisions. Meta has also confirmed plans to dismiss certain underperforming employees as part of its restructuring. These cost-saving measures show the growing trend among tech companies to streamline operations amidst the current market challenges. Microsoft is also planning to fire underperforming employees. While the company has confirmed the news, it has not disclosed the exact number of workers affected.A Microsoft spokesperson acknowledged the upcoming layoffs and reiterated the company's focus on high-performance talent. The spokesperson stressed that when employees fail to meet performance expectations, appropriate actions are taken. As part of its strategy, Microsoft evaluates staff performance across multiple levels, even reaching some senior employees at level 80.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 16, 2025

Headline: Dreame AirStyle review: Smart hair-styler that is high on features and low on priceWe know hair-dryers and stylers can be smart. We have seen some earlier from Dyson. Now, we get one from Dreame. It's called AirStyle and it offers tons of features, performance to match and all of that at a relatively affordable price. In this Dreame AirStyle review we find it can match more expensive hair-stylers.
Content: What do you think of when you hear the word hair-styler? Probably a dumb device that can dry as well as help shape your hair while you are frantically going through your morning on a weekday. That is also probably accurate. But we have seen that companies like Dyson are changing this perception of hair-dryers and hair-stylers. They are giving smarts to these devices. One such company, apart from Dyson, and the products of which we are now starting to see in India, is Dreame. Earlier, at India Today Tech, we reviewed the Dreame L10s Pro Ultra Heat, a robot house-cleaner, and we were quite impressed with it. It was a premium, pricey product and an excellent automatic robot-cleaner for users who could afford it. Now, we are reviewing the Dreame AirStyle, a hair styler. There are a lot of similarities between the product philosophy of Dyson and Dreame. Recently, when Dreame launched its AirStyle  and yes, the name itself gives you deja vu, instantly making you think of the Dyson Airwrap  I was curious to see what Dreame had to offer. More than the name it's the pricing which roused my interest. The Dreame AirtStyle is Rs 24,999, almost half of the price of its more expensive competitor. This raises the obvious question of how. As in how can Dreame price something this low and does this mean it has a lot of cost-cutting? Does the lower price also mean a more cumbersome and ineffective user experience? Well, Ive used the AirStyle for about a week now and Im impressed. The Dreame AirStyle offers multiple attachments, is easy to use and clean, and comes in premium packaging. But of course, there are also areas where it is definitely not as premium as the Dyson one. Lets take a closer look.Premium design, easy to clean The Dreame AirStyle comes in this cream colour option with a metallic brass finish. Of course, it is made of plastic. But the paint job, which is extremely slick and premium, gives it stunning looks. The design of the hair-styler is minimalist. It weighs around 1 kg, which is not too heavy and is similar in weight to the Dyson Airwrap. Although using it with one hand while styling does give a workout for your arm.    In the box, there are five attachments, including a dryer, auto-wrap barrel, smoothing brush, round volumising brush, and flyaway attachment. All of these you can easily attach, remove, and even clean with water after styling your hair. The build quality of the attachments is quite sturdy, although they too are made of plastic. The AirStyler comes in an antique-looking suitcase box, which is easy to carry around and looks quite premium.   Using the Dreame AirStylerWell, it works as intended  effectively and fuss-free. Using the device is a pretty straightforward process. You pick the attachment you want to use, turn on the power, select air pressure and heat, and go.For the air pressure, there are three settings  low, medium, and high  that you can use as per styling requirements. Dreame also includes a user guide to help you set the settings according to your hair type and styling needs. The heat setting is really handy and includes cool air, medium heat, and high heat, which you can use as needed.   In my use, I often used the dryer attachment, which requires air pressure and heat at max. I have thin and long hair, and the AirStyler helped me dry them around 95 per cent in about 1520 minutes, which is quite impressive. However, to style, you need slightly damp hair, so after 5 to 10 minutes of drying, you can switch to the different styler attachments.advertisementNow, given I have thin and somewhat wavy hair, I also used the volumising attachment and the flyaway attachment. Both work extremely well and do the job effectively. Do understand that the AirStyler is not that compact, so it takes quite a while. Also, you need to switch arms to cover both sides. It's quite a workout and can take some time before you are done with it. In other words, on hurried mornings while you are rushing to reach the office quickly, you will not have time to style your hair.While the performance is there, as well as the feature set, I do notice that the AirStyler doesnt feel as refined as Dyson Airwrap. For example, the auto-wrap curler in the AirStyle lacks the option to switch the wrap direction, which makes it slightly cumbersome compared to the Airwrap. Another difference is the carrying box. The Airwarp box is just so much more premium compared to the AirStyler box. One important bit to remember here is the price. The AirStyler sells for less than half the price of the Airwrap, so the differences I talk of feel more like nitpicks and can be overlooked.   Dryer attachment of Dreame AirStyleadvertisementDreame AirStyle review: Is it worth it?If you want a good hair styling tool under Rs 25,000 with multiple attachments that also doesn't damage your hair with heat, the Dreame Airstyler is a good option. It's easy to clean, comes with a portable case, and offers both cool and hot air settings, making it an affordable alternative to more expensive options like the Dyson Airwrap. Additionally, the Airstyler is currently available at a more affordable price on Amazon, making the deal even more attractive. It is selling for Rs 19,999. Headline: Realme 14 Pro series launched in India, price starts at Rs 24,999Realme 14 Pro series is now in India with two variants, the Realme 14 Pro and the Realme 14 Pro+. The sale will go live on January 23.
Content: Realme has officially launched its next-gen series in India  the Realme 14 Pro series. The series includes two variants: the Realme 14 Pro and the Realme 14 Pro+. At a starting price of Rs 24,999, the series features several premium features. Before we dive deep into the features and specs of the phones, let's look at the prices of the series.   advertisementRealme 14 Pro series: India price and availabilityThe Realme 14 Pro series has now launched in India. The price begins at Rs 24,999, but after bank discount, the price drops to Rs 22,999. The first sale starts from January 23 at 12 noon onwards. Here is the price for both the phones.Realme 14 Pro The Realme 14 Pro series has now launched in India. The price begins at Rs 24,999, but after bank discount, the price drops to Rs 22,999. The first sale starts from January 23 at 12 noon onwards. Here is the price for both the phones. Realme 14 Pro - 8GB+128GB is priced at Rs 24,999 - 8GB+256GB is priced at Rs 26,999. The company is offering Rs 2,000 bank offer, making the prices effectively at Rs 22,999 and Rs 24,999, respectively.    Realme 14 Pro+ - 8GB+128GB is priced at Rs 29,999 - 8GB+ 256GB is priced at Rs 31,999. - 12GB+ 256GB is priced at Rs 34,999. The company is offering up to Rs 4,000 bank offers.    Additionally, Realme is also offering limited-time time pre-book offers. The phones will be available on Flipkart, realme.in and all retail stores.Realme 14 Pro series design language Realme has officially revealed the design of its Realme 14 Pro series, which introduces a colour-changing rear panel, a first for the brand. The series will be available in two striking finishes: Suede Grey and Pearl White.    The Suede Grey model features a premium vegan leather back, while the Pearl White variant boasts an innovative cold-sensitive technology that alters the colour of the rear panel when temperatures drop below 16C, transitioning into captivating shades of blue. This unique feature is exclusive to the Pearl White model. Additionally, Realme is launching two India-exclusive colour options: Jaipur Pink for the Pro model and Bikaner Purple for the Pro+ variant. Both phones showcase a sleek design with a circular rear camera module, where the triple-camera setup is arranged in an eye-catching fidget spinner-like pattern.Realme 14 Pro: Key specs and features The base model of the series, the Realme 14 Pro features a 6.77-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate. It comes with a quad-curve display that peaks brightness of 4500nits.    Under the hood, this model is powered by a MediaTek Dimensity 7300 Energy 5G chipset, coupled with the 8GB RAM. It runs on Realme UI 6.0 OS, which is based on Android 15. It comes in two storage variants: 128GB and 256GB. It packs a 6000mAh battery with 45W SUPERVOOC charging speed.    For optics, the Realme 14 Pro features a 50-megapixel primary camera and a 16-megapixel front camera.   advertisementRealme 14 Pro+: Key features and specsThe Realme 14 Pro+ is equipped with a quad-curved 6.83-inch AMOLED display, offering a 1.5K resolution for an immersive viewing experience, complemented by slim bezels for a flagship-like appearance.   The phone is powered by the Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chipset and runs on Realme UI 6.0, based on Android 15. The devices come with a robust 6000mAh battery and support 80W fast charging. Headline: Apple CEO Tim Cook says he used to work at a burger restaurant at the age of 14During an interview on the Table Manners podcast, Apple CEO Tim Cook shared that his first job involved delivering newspapers at the age of 11, followed by flipping burgers at a fast-food chain called Tastee-Freez when he was just 14 years old.
Content: Apple CEO Tim Cook has shared his early working experiences, revealing how they shaped his approach to leadership and hard work. During an interview on the Table Manners podcast, Cook shared that his first job involved delivering newspapers at the age of 11, followed by flipping burgers at a fast-food chain called Tastee-Freez when he was just 14 years old. Cook, who grew up in the small town of Robertsdale, Alabama, explained that his parents instilled the value of hard work in him, which has remained a guiding principle throughout his career. He said that the lessons from his early jobs have stayed with him, helping him approach challenges with dedication and perseverance. Despite coming from humble beginnings, Cook went on to pursue industrial engineering at Auburn University, and after graduation, he worked at tech firms like IBM. In 1998, Apple co-founder Steve Jobs personally invited Cook to join Apple as Senior Vice President of worldwide operations, marking the beginning of his journey at the tech company. When Jobs passed away in 2011, Cook took over as Apples CEO. In the interview, Cook also discussed his daily routine, talking about the importance of starting his day early. He revealed that he begins working before 5AM, using the early morning hours to focus on key tasks before the day becomes busy. This quiet time, he said, allows him to manage his workload more effectively. While Cook continues to lead Apple with the same dedication he developed in his younger years, he hinted at future retirement plans. However, he asserted that his version of retirement wont involve completely stepping away from work. Instead, Cook plans on staying active and mentally engaged, as he doesnt see himself slowing down entirely. Additionally, though Cook didnt offer details on upcoming Apple products, he mentioned that there are several exciting projects in development.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 16, 2025

Headline: iPhone SE4 likely to arrive in April: FaceID, 48-megapixel, Apple Intelligence and more upgrades expectedThe iPhone SE4 is speculated to launch in early 2025 with significant upgrades, including a 48-megapixel camera and Face ID, aligning with Apple's flagship features. Rumours also suggest a possible rebranding to 'iPhone 16E' and a price under Rs 50,000 in India.
Content: The affordable iPhone range from Apple has always been a hit amongst users. However, after 2022 -- with the launch of iPhone SE3-- Apple seemed to go on a hiatus as far as launching its new generation of iPhone SE is concerned. While nothing official has been announced or hinted at by the Cupertino giant about the future of this affordable series yet, the buzz around the iPhone SE4 has significantly increased in the past few months. This surge in interest follows reports from analysts like Bloomberg's Mark Gurman and Ming-Chi Kuo, who stated that Apple is likely to launch the new-generation iPhone SE4 in early 2025. Not only is the launch of the iPhone SE4 highly anticipated, but it is also speculated to feature significant upgrades over its predecessor. These upgrades could include Apple's latest A18 series chip, a larger 48-megapixel camera, and the long-awaited transition from Touch ID to Face ID. Recent reports even suggest that the affordable iPhone might be rebranded as the "iPhone 16E" to align with Apple's latest flagship naming conventions.iPhone SE4 design and display upgrades One of the most notable upgrades the new iPhone SE4 is expected to bring is its design. Drawing inspiration from the iPhone 14, the new SE is rumoured to feature a 6.1-inch OLED screen, slim bezels, and no physical home button. Apple is reportedly replacing the physical button with Face ID, making the affordable iPhone more secure, akin to its flagship counterparts. There were earlier rumours that the iPhone SE4 might feature the Dynamic Island. However, subsequent reports dismissed these claims, suggesting that Apple will likely reserve this feature for its premium flagships. Still, the iPhone SE4 might include the customisable Action Button feature introduced with the iPhone 15 Pro series, replacing the traditional mute switch. Additionally, in line with these design changes, the iPhone SE4 is expected to weigh slightly less at approximately 165g. Leaked CAD renders and unofficial images suggest a sleeker, more modern design, with colour options including Midnight, Starlight, and Product RED.iPhone SE4 performance upgrades In terms of performance, the iPhone SE4 is rumoured to receive the biggest ever upgrade yet. According to Bloomberg's Mark Gurman, the device will likely be powered by the A18 series chipset, bringing it closer to the iPhone 16 series in terms of performance. The phone is also rumoured to debut with Apple's in-house 5G modem, making it the first Apple device to feature the company's proprietary modem technology. The SE4 is expected to receive a power boost with RAM options of up to 8GB and storage configurations ranging from 128GB to 512GB. With the new chipset and increased RAM, the iPhone SE4 might also incorporate Apple Intelligence features, making it the most affordable iPhone to offer Apple's AI suite.iPhone SE4 camera upgrades The iPhone SE4 is also expected to feature significant improvements in the camera department. It may feature a single rear lens with a 48MP sensor, a notable upgrade from the 12MP sensor of the iPhone SE3. Additional features like Cinematic Mode, Smart HDR, AI photography, and Portrait Mode are anticipated. However, the device might not include Night Mode, despite the upgraded sensor.iPhone SE4 battery and charging upgrades Under the hood, the iPhone SE4 is rumoured to house a 3,279mAh battery, a significant increase from the 2,010mAh battery in its predecessor. Charging speeds are expected to reach 20W via cable and 12W wirelessly. In compliance with EU regulations, the iPhone SE4 will reportedly adopt a USB-C charging port.iPhone SE4 pricing in India Pricing will play a crucial role in the success of the iPhone SE4. Reports suggest it could be priced under Rs 50,000 in India (approximately $429 in the US). However, a slight increase to $499 is also predicted. With the rumoured rebranding of the iPhone 16E and its numerous upgrades, a marginally higher price than the iPhone SE3 is anticipated.When is the iPhone SE4 launching? As for the launch timeline, Mark Gurman has hinted at an early 2025 release, stating that mass production began in December 2024. Headline: Apple CEO Tim Cook says Apple Watch saved his father's lifeApple CEO Tim Cook has recently shared a personal life story on how an Apple Watch saved the life of his father years ago.
Content: In a rare personal interview, Apple CEO Tim Cook recently shared a bunch of details about his personal life, his daily routine, what he likes to eat for breakfast, how he starts his day, what wine he likes, and his favourite restaurant. This was in an interview with Table Manners with Jessie and Lennie Ware. While the podcast interview episode aired on Wednesday, this was recorded during Cook’s visit to the UK in December 2024.  As Cook spoke about flipping burgers at the age of 14, having a paper route at the age of 11, or coming from a very humble background, Cook also revealed something very interesting and personal about his family. The Apple CEO has on many occasions shared stories of how an Apple Watch shared someone’s life. He has spoken about anecdotes that people send to him by email and how he truly feels happy and grateful when he reads these stories. During the Table Manners interview, Cook recounted a similar story, except this was about his own father.  On being asked whether the Apple CEO ever had a medical alert on his Apple Watch, Cook said, “I haven't, but my father, when he was alive, he fell in the house, and he was living alone”. “And the other thing the watch does is send a notification to your family and to emergency services if you fall, it detects the fall because of the accelerometer,” he said. “It notified emergency services, and they came out to the house. He [Cook’s father] didn't respond to the door and so they kicked the door down — and it was a good thing they did because he was not conscious at the time.”  At this point of the story one would assume Cook’s father is feeling proud of his son for working at a company that created a product that is his life. But things are never that simple with parents, are they? The podcast interviewer asked Cook: So, was he proud of you? “No, he was focused on the door, to be honest,” said Cook. “He was more upset, they kicked out my door!” During the interview, Cook also revealed that he starts his day before 5.00 AM, answering emails in the quiet early hours, which he finds the most controllable part of his day. He works at Apple Park four days a week and from home on Fridays. Cook loves Chardonnay, dark chocolate, and hiking, and he frequents national parks. He recently went caving in Slovenia. For meals, he enjoys fish, cashew cereal, and dining at Ethel’s Fancy in Palo Alto. While hinting at future Apple projects, Cook shared that his ideal last meal would feature hamachi crudo, branzino, broccolini, and chocolate dessert.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Jan 16, 2025Also read |  Apple CEO Tim Cook says he used to work at a burger restaurant at the age of 14Also read |  Microsoft is firing employees in 3 departments, set to take more actions to save costsAlso read |  Elon Musk is hiring for software engineer role, says there is no need for a degree

Headline: First DMs from Brad Pitt, then Rs 7 crore loss and divorce: Here is how a woman fell prey to online scam More elaborate and complex online scams are on the rise with the help of AI tools, which allow easy impersonation. In one such scam a French woman not only lost Rs 7 crore but she also rushed into a divorce after getting DMs from "Brad Pitt."
Content: Most of us are obsessed with our favourite celebrities. Sometimes, some of us, go to great lengths — from sending overly expensive gifts to even getting tattoos celebrating our idols. But in this digital age, where we are surrounded by all sorts of cyber threats, now scammers targeting the celebrity-obsessed crowd. The latest victim of such a scam is a 53-year-old French interior designer named Anne. She lost around Rs 7.5 crore after getting herself entangled in a romance scam involving a fake account that was impersonating Hollywood actor Brad Pitt. At the same the DMs she received from this “Brad Pitt” probably expedited her divorce proceedings that she was already part of before scammers targeted her.    The scam began when Anne received an Instagram message from a profile named “Jane Etta Pitt,” claiming to be Brad Pitt’s mother. The scammers started a conversation with Anne and told her that “Jane” wanted to set her up with her son Brad, who had supposedly recently divorced Angelina Jolie. For Anne, this was more than a dream come true.  Soon, another fake account claiming to be Brad Pitt himself messaged Anne. As she was also going through divorce, she was already emotionally vulnerable and getting a proposal from Brad Pitt by his mother made her start fantasising about a life with the Hollywood heartthrob. Soon after Anne was swept into romantic conversations with the impersonator. To make the relationship seem genuine, the scammers even sent her love messages, AI-generated videos showing “Brad Pitt” talking to her, and other convincing gestures.Scammers exploit a rocky relationship Anne, who was emotionally vulnerable because of her ongoing divorce from her millionaire husband, fell deeper into the trap. The scammers exploited her emotional state, building trust through frequent affectionate messages. Although Anne never spoke to real Brad Pitt on the phone, the consistent messaging on social media convinced her that the relationship was real. Meanwhile, to further solidify the illusion, the scammers claimed to have sent Anne expensive gifts from luxury brands like Chanel and Hermes. They then asked her to pay 9,000 Euros – around Rs 8 lakh in customs fees to receive the items. And Anne paid for it. Once Anne was completely drawn in the trap, the fraudsters then began asking her for more money. They fabricated a story about Brad Pitt needing funds for kidney cancer treatment and claimed his bank accounts were frozen due to his fictional divorce from Angelina Jolie. The scammers even sent Anne AI-generated images of Brad Pitt appearing to be in a hospital bed to further manipulate her. Believing she was helping her celebrity lover, Anne ended up sending a staggering 850,000 euros — approximately Rs 7.5 crore. It was only when Anne saw real photos of Brad Pitt with his current partner, Ines de Ramon, that she realised she had been scammed. By then, her life savings were gone.Romance scam on rise While Anne’s story has made headlines, it’s not an isolated case. Romance scams involving fake celebrity profile – and many using Brad Pitt’s name names –  are on the rise. For instance, in another reported case from September 2023, Spanish authorities arrested five individuals for defrauding two women of 325,000 euros – around Rs 3 crore. These scammers posed as Brad Pitt on WhatsApp and targeted victims through fan pages dedicated to the actor. In this scam as well ,the scammers users similar tactics, including emotional manipulation and fabricated stories, to extract money from the victims. While romance scams are not new and we have seen cases of people being duped by their alleged love interests they met on the internet, now with the advance technology like artificial intelligence the scams are becoming more sophisticated, convincing and hard to escape. Scammers are using AI-generated content, like realistic images, videos, and voice simulations, to create highly believable personas to trick their targets.How to protect yourself If these scams are so well knit and  even professionals are falling into them,  then how can you stay safe? Well, be skeptical online. You see, making friends and lovers online is becoming a trend. However due to this increased digital footprints, scammers are now impersonating themselves. So in case you are up online talking to a new friend or unknown individual reaches out to you – be sceptical.  If you receive unsolicited messages from people claiming to be celebrities or their associates, cross-check profiles and verify their authenticity through official sources. Also never send money to strangers. More importantly do not transfer money to someone you haven’t met in person, regardless of their story or urgency. And to keep your bank account safe, do not share sensitive details that could be used for manipulation or extortion. If you suspect you’re being targeted, report the incident to the relevant authorities and the platform used for communication. This will help others to stay safe. Headline: Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and moreHere are the best premium flagship phones you can buy in India this January. The list includes the OnePlus 13 5G and three more devices.

Headline: Poco X7 goes on sale for Rs 21,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skipShould you buy the Poco X7 in the sub-Rs 25,000 price segment? We give you the top 4 reasons you should go for it and 1 reason you may want to hold off on your purchase.
Content: Poco has kicked off the new year with its latest X7 series. We recently published an article on the Poco X7 Pro and why it’s worth considering. In this article, we’ll focus on its more affordable sibling — the Poco X7. Priced from Rs 21,999, the phone promises a blend of solid performance, impressive design, and reliable everyday features. But is it the right choice for everyone? Here are the top four reasons to buy the Poco X7 and one reason you might want to think twice.advertisementPoco X7 5G: 4 reasons to buySolid build with IP69 ratingPoco has stepped up its game when it comes to the design and durability of the X7 series. The Poco X7 brings back the brand’s iconic yellow colour, paired with a premium faux leather finish that feels good to hold and keeps fingerprints away. The large camera island adds a bold, modern touch, though the prominent Poco branding on the back might not appeal to everyone. What truly stands out is the phone’s dust and water resistance, which comes with IP66, IP68, and even IP69 ratings — something rare at this price point. Combine that with Gorilla Glass Victus 2 protection on the display — a feature usually reserved for pricier devices — and you’ve got a phone that’s built to last.  Solid build with IP69 rating Poco has stepped up its game when it comes to the design and durability of the X7 series. The Poco X7 brings back the brand’s iconic yellow colour, paired with a premium faux leather finish that feels good to hold and keeps fingerprints away. The large camera island adds a bold, modern touch, though the prominent Poco branding on the back might not appeal to everyone. What truly stands out is the phone’s dust and water resistance, which comes with IP66, IP68, and even IP69 ratings — something rare at this price point. Combine that with Gorilla Glass Victus 2 protection on the display — a feature usually reserved for pricier devices — and you’ve got a phone that’s built to last.  Immersive multimedia experience The Poco X7 shines when it comes to multimedia consumption. The 6.67-inch AMOLED display with a 1.5K resolution delivers vibrant colours and sharp visuals. It supports Dolby Vision, HDR10, and the full DCI-P3 colour gamut, making it perfect for watching your favourite shows or scrolling through social media. The 120Hz refresh rate ensures smooth scrolling, while the 3,000 nits peak brightness makes the display easy to view, even under direct sunlight. The stereo speakers are another highlight, providing loud, clear sound without distortion, even at higher volumes. Whether you’re watching movies, gaming, or just browsing, the Poco X7 offers one of the best multimedia experiences in its price range. Good battery life The Poco X7 comes with a large 5,500mAh battery, which easily lasts a full day. Of course, it is not as good as the X7 Pro’s mammoth 6,550mAh battery, but it gets the job done. From streaming videos to using social media, you can go about your day without constantly worrying about plugging in. While the 45W charging speed isn’t the fastest — especially when compared to the 67W charging on its predecessor, the Poco X6 — it’s still quick enough to fully charge the device in a reasonable amount of time. You can charge the phone from 0 to 100 per cent in about an hour, which is decent for a device in this price bracket. Decent camera performance On the camera front, the Poco X7 doesn’t disappoint, at least when you are shooting in good light. Its 50-megapixel Sony LYT 600 primary camera captures vibrant, sharp images with a good level of detail. While colours are slightly boosted, they don’t feel unnatural, and the images turn out appealing. The 8-megapixel ultra-wide lens adds versatility, and the 20-megapixel front camera clicks decent selfies, although some facial smoothing might not please everyone. Compared to some of its competitors like Nothing Phone (2a), the X7 holds its ground well. Its daylight images are often more vibrant and appealing, and its portrait shots offer good edge detection and colour reproduction.Poco X7 5G: 1 reason to skip Android 14: Should’ve been Android 15 for a new phone Here’s where the Poco X7 stumbles. The phone comes with HyperOS atop Android 14 out of the box, which is disappointing considering Android 15 is already available on its pricier sibling, the Poco X7 Pro. What’s more, Poco promises three years of major updates, but in reality, this means only two Android updates, since it already ships with Android 14. This means the phone will likely only go up to Android 16, leaving buyers with fewer updates than some competitors in the same segment. At a starting price of Rs 21,999, the Poco X7 5G offers plenty of value with its durable build, stellar display, reliable cameras, and decent battery life. It’s a solid choice for those seeking a phone that can handle everyday tasks with ease. However, the limited Android updates might give some buyers pause. If you can look past this shortcoming, the Poco X7 is still a fantastic device that ticks most of the right boxes.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 16, 2025Also read |  Poco X7 Pro goes on sale for Rs 27,999: 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skipAlso read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Poco M7 Pro 5G review: Strong on the fundamentals

Headline: Realme 14 Pro+ review: A knight in shining armourPriced at Rs 29,999, the Realme 14 Pro+ highest variant in the new series. The phone is compact, light and packed with premium features. While on paper it aces the game, is it as good in real-life? Let's find out in this India Today Tech review.
Content:
After just 5 months of launching the Realme 13 Pro series, the company is back with its latest Pro models – the Realme 14 Pro and Realme 14 Pro+. I have been using the 14 Pro+ for over 2 weeks and I love it. I know, strong words for a review, but I did some thorough testing to back my claims. At a starting price of Rs 29,999, the phone sports premium features, including a bit gimmicky but interesting colour-changing rear panel, 6,000mAh battery and a 50-megapixel camera. Let’s dive into the details. 

 



Realme 14 Pro+
advertisementThe Realme 14 Pro+ and its shining armourThe Realme 14 Pro series’ design is hard to miss. Barring the centre-aligned round camera island, the 14 Pro’s design has received quite the overhaul. This is especially true for the Pearl White variant. The Realme 14 Pro+ comes in three colours: Pearl White, Suede Grey and Bikaner Purple. While others look good too, the Pearl White has my heart. This variant’s rear panel has a texture similar to that of a pearl. But that’s not all. The Realme 14 Pro+ features a temperature-sensitive, colour-changing rear panel, exclusive to the white variant. The panel changes colour when exposed to cold temperatures — specifically, below 16 degrees. Blue waves start to appear on the panel, giving it the look of a pearl in the ocean. Fortunately, the phone launched during Delhi winters, making it easy for me to test this feature. However, during the scorching Delhi summers, the only way to activate the colour change would be by pouring cold water on the phone. But even then, the effect will quickly revert to the original colour. To keep the blue waves visible, the sub-16-degree temperature needs to be consistently maintained.

 



Pearl white variant in normal conditions vs in cold temperature (right to left)
But, for context, this is not the first phone that changes its rear panel with temperature. Vivo has been doing it since 2022 with the Vivo V25 and the Vivo Y100 among the first phones to feature the tech. In addition to the colour-changing back, the Realme 14 Pro+ also has some functional upgrades to the design. The phone has a compact form factor and a slim profile. It is just 7.99mm thick and sits perfectly in the palm. 
 


Coming back to the rear panel, the Realme 14 Pro+ features a circular island that houses a triple-camera lens. Unlike its predecessor, the camera arrangement looks like a fidget spinner. The module is outlined by a thick golden rim, which compliments the design and the frame perfectly. Bright and gorgeous display The Realme 14 Pro series’ design is hard to miss. Barring the centre-aligned round camera island, the 14 Pro’s design has received quite the overhaul. This is especially true for the Pearl White variant.  But, for context, this is not the first phone that changes its rear panel with temperature. Vivo has been doing it since 2022 with the Vivo V25 and the Vivo Y100 among the first phones to feature the tech.  In addition to the colour-changing back, the Realme 14 Pro+ also has some functional upgrades to the design. The phone has a compact form factor and a slim profile. It is just 7.99mm thick and sits perfectly in the palm. 
 


 Coming back to the rear panel, the Realme 14 Pro+ features a circular island that houses a triple-camera lens. Unlike its predecessor, the camera arrangement looks like a fidget spinner. The module is outlined by a thick golden rim, which compliments the design and the frame perfectly. Bright and gorgeous display The Realme 14 Pro+ features a beautiful 6.83-inch AMOLED display with 120Hz refresh rate. The brightness is impressive and I faced no issue reading text on the phone under the direct sun. 
 


I have been using the phone as my primary device and I enjoyed my time with it. Thanks to the 1.5K display resolution, binge watching Netflix, scrolling Instagram and playing graphic-demanding games have been a delight on the phone. The Realme 14 Pro+ features a quad-curved display, giving it a subtle curve that makes the bezels appear slimmer, which in turn makes the display look even larger. But the curve on the phone is also prone to accidental touches. Frequently, while scrolling through Instagram, my hand would unintentionally tap on icons towards the corners of the screen. That’s no fun.Great performance, better batteryThe Realme 14 Pro+ is a smooth runner. Under the hood, it packs a Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chipset, and it runs on Realme UI 6.0 OS, which is based on Android 15. At this price, I will not say that it is the best performer, but it is definitely impressive. The phone handles day-to-day tasks pretty well. These tasks include, using social media apps, watching YouTube videos and other OTT platforms, reading articles on the phone and of course, answering and receiving calls. But all of this can be easily handled by an entry-level smartphone as well. So, what does the Realme 14 Pro+ bring to the table? The mid-budget smartphone can easily pull off tasks you would expect from a more premium smartphone. For example, graphic-intensive gaming. I played Call of Duty for an hour without any lag or heating issues. Cherry on top: the phone sports a dedicated game engine that helps customise your gaming experience. 

 



The dashboard shows a drawer of apps and you can add more apps to it as well.
advertisementTo further push the limits of the phone, I ran a few benchmark tests. On Geekbench, the phone clocked 1176 for single-core, and 3195 for multi-core. And that’s a decent score. To consider the competition, the Redmi Note 14 Pro+ scored lower than the Realme 14 Pro+, as it noted 1079 and 3009 for single and multi-score, respectively. These scores indicate that the phone is capable of smooth single-threaded tasks like browsing and app usage, as well as multi-threaded performance for gaming and multitasking. 
 


advertisementThat said, in real-life scenarios, the Realme 14 Pro+ struggled sometimes while multi-tasking. For instance, after a tough gaming session, when I immediately switch to Instagram, the phone took a few seconds to open the app. Overall, though, the Realme 14 Pro+ performs well. Backing this performance is also a solid 6,000mAh battery, which lasted me for an entire day. During my tests, I used the phone for an entire day after playing high-graphic games, watching Netflix and hours of scrolling social media. To put things in perspective, the battery dropped only 8 per cent (from 33 per cent to 25 per cent) after playing the Call of Duty for 40 minutes, and it dropped only 7 per cent (from 22 per cent to 15 per cent) after two episodes of Netflix’s Nobody Wants This (1 hour). 

 



Realme 14 Pro+ supports a Type-C charging port
advertisementWith 80W charging speed, the Realme 14 Pro+ takes an hour to charge up to the brim, from 0 per cent to 100 per cent. Personally, I am a little less concerned about the charging speed, but the battery drain. I think the Realme 14 Pro+ offers one of the best battery capacities in the sub- Rs 30k price segment. Decent rear camera but shutter speed could have been betterThe Realme 14 Pro+ features a triple-camera system, which consists of a 50-megapixel rear camera, a 50-megapixel periscope lens and an 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera shooter. 

 



The Realme 14 Pro+ boasts a triple-flash setup
The rear camera clicks crisp and vivid images. For its sub-Rs 30k price segment, the phone delivers a good image quality. In day-light, the Realme 14 Pro+ captures shots with real-life colours, sharpness and has an eye for detail. 
 


Even during the night, the phone does not disappoint. It clicks edgy pictures and shows vibrant colours. 
 


The Portrait mode is also true to its nature. The edge-detection, which is the most questionable in this price-range, works decently. 
 


I played around with almost all of its camera modes and most of them are impressive. It largely has a decent shutter speed, but when it comes to action shots and low light shots, there is sometimes a lag between the frame you want to click and the frame you end up clicking. Besides that there is nothing to complain about in the Realme 14 Pro+’s camera.Here are the camera samples: Realme 14 Pro+: Should you buy it? The Realme 14 Pro+ is priced at Rs 29,999 for the 8GB RAM and 128GB storage. At this price tag, the phone comes with a few high-end features. It sports a quad-curve display, a 50-megapixel rear camera, a 6,000mAh battery and a Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chip. Don’t forget the colour-changing rear panel. After a long time, I have tested a phone that feels equally good on paper and in real life. The Realme 14 Pro+ is definitely worth considering. To put things in perspective, the battery dropped only 8 per cent (from 33 per cent to 25 per cent) after playing the Call of Duty for 40 minutes, and it dropped only 7 per cent (from 22 per cent to 15 per cent) after two episodes of Netflix’s Nobody Wants This (1 hour). 

 



Realme 14 Pro+ supports a Type-C charging port
 With 80W charging speed, the Realme 14 Pro+ takes an hour to charge up to the brim, from 0 per cent to 100 per cent. Personally, I am a little less concerned about the charging speed, but the battery drain. I think the Realme 14 Pro+ offers one of the best battery capacities in the sub- Rs 30k price segment. Decent rear camera but shutter speed could have been better The Realme 14 Pro+ features a triple-camera system, which consists of a 50-megapixel rear camera, a 50-megapixel periscope lens and an 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera shooter. 

 



The Realme 14 Pro+ boasts a triple-flash setup
 The rear camera clicks crisp and vivid images. For its sub-Rs 30k price segment, the phone delivers a good image quality. In day-light, the Realme 14 Pro+ captures shots with real-life colours, sharpness and has an eye for detail. 
 


 Even during the night, the phone does not disappoint. It clicks edgy pictures and shows vibrant colours. 
 


 The Portrait mode is also true to its nature. The edge-detection, which is the most questionable in this price-range, works decently. 
 


 I played around with almost all of its camera modes and most of them are impressive. It largely has a decent shutter speed, but when it comes to action shots and low light shots, there is sometimes a lag between the frame you want to click and the frame you end up clicking. Besides that there is nothing to complain about in the Realme 14 Pro+’s camera. Here are the camera samples: Realme 14 Pro+: Should you buy it?  The Realme 14 Pro+ is priced at Rs 29,999 for the 8GB RAM and 128GB storage. At this price tag, the phone comes with a few high-end features. It sports a quad-curve display, a 50-megapixel rear camera, a 6,000mAh battery and a Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chip. Don’t forget the colour-changing rear panel. After a long time, I have tested a phone that feels equally good on paper and in real life. The Realme 14 Pro+ is definitely worth considering. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 Slim is going to be thin but just how thin will it be? Leak reveals detailsSamsung is expected to launch the Galaxy S25 Slim, its thinnest smartphone ever, at the Galaxy Unpacked event next week on January 22.
Content:
Samsung is set to host its Galaxy Unpacked event on January 22, where it is expected to unveil four new smartphones, including the traditional lineup: the Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and Galaxy S25 Ultra. However, the fourth device promises to be something special. Samsung is rumored to announce the Galaxy S25 Slim, which is believed to be the slimmest phone ever released by the company. Speculation about this "Slim" phone has been circulating for quite some time. Interestingly, Apple is also rumored to be working on something similar for this year. But the burning question remains: just how slim will this phone be? The latest leak on the Galaxy S25 series might finally have the answer.  In a new report, Smartprix and OnLeaks have shared some high-quality 5K renders of the Galaxy S25 Slim.  Looking at the renders, the Galaxy S25 Slim lives up to its name, measuring a mere 6.4mm in thickness without the camera module and 8.3mm with it — an impressive feat when most phones fall between 8mm to 10mm before adding a camera bump. For context, the Galaxy S25 Ultra is expected to be 8.2mm thick without the bump, making the Slim a standout.  

 



A render of the Galaxy S25 Slim. (Image: Smartprix X OnLeaks)
 Samsung’s pursuit of slimness doesn’t compromise screen size. The Galaxy S25 Slim is expected to feature a 6.7 to 6.8-inch display, fitting into a compact frame measuring 159 x 76 x 6.4mm, according to reports. By comparison, the Galaxy S25 Ultra measures 162.8 x 77.6 x 8.2mm, making the Slim 3.8mm shorter, 1.6mm narrower, and 1.8mm thinner.   Design-wise, the Galaxy S25 Slim stays true to the S25 series aesthetic. It features a metal frame, a glass back, and a triple rear camera setup. The bezels are ultra-thin, aligning with the rest of the lineup. The flat frame complements flat volume rockers and a power button, while the bottom houses a USB-C port, a single speaker grille, and a microphone.   The Slim’s flat display mirrors the design choices seen across the S25 series, offering a uniform yet sleek appearance. In terms of slimness, it dethrones Samsung’s previous record-holder, the Galaxy A8, which was 4.9mm thick but packed only a 3,050mAh battery. The Galaxy S25 Slim manages to combine its ultra-thin profile with a larger battery and cutting-edge internals, proving that slim doesn’t mean sacrificing functionality. The Galaxy S25 Slim is set to be unveiled at the Galaxy Unpacked event next week. However, reports suggest that the phone will go on sale some time later this year. We willl know about the timeline of the phone's launch and sale at the event on January 22. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 key specs and AI features leaked online ahead of January 22 launch eventNew leaks suggest that Samsung's Galaxy S25 series will launch with improved cameras, powerful AI tools, and better integration with Google's Gemini assistant.
Content:
Samsung is all set to launch its Galaxy S25 series on January 22, 2025, and fresh details from Brazilian publication, Technoblog, have given us a clear picture of what to expect. The upcoming devices promise some interesting upgrades, particularly in AI and camera technology, which could be a big draw for users. According to the leaks, the key highlight of the Galaxy S25 Ultra, as expected, will be its camera setup. It retains the 200-megapixel primary camera and a 50-megapixel periscope with 5x optical zoom from the previous Ultra model, along with a 10-megapixel telephoto lens with 3x optical zoom. The big upgrade here is the 50-megapixel ultra-wide camera, replacing the older 12-megapixel sensor. This change comes after some criticism of the previous model's ultra-wide camera's performance. The front-facing camera, as with other models, will have a 12-megapixel sensor.

Credits: Tecnoblog
 As for endurance, the Galaxy S25 Ultra will feature a 5,000 mAh battery. Samsung claims that it can last up to 31 hours of video playback, which is similar to previous models in the Ultra range. The Galaxy S25+ and S25, on the other hand, will share a similar camera setup, including a 50-megapixel main sensor, a 10-megapixel 3x telephoto lens, and a 12-megapixel ultra-wide camera. For selfies, there will be a 12-megapixel front camera on both devices. The S25+ will retain the same 4,900 mAh battery as its predecessor, ensuring up to 30 hours of video playback. All phones in the Galaxy S25 series will reportedly be powered by the new Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, paired with 12GB RAM as standard, which should offer solid performance for day-to-day tasks, multitasking, and gaming. In addition to hardware upgrades, leaks suggest that Samsung will be introducing new AI features in the upcoming Galaxy S25 series. One of the key highlights is the Brief feature, which offers personalised summaries of your day. The morning brief will give you a weather forecast, your daily schedule, and an energy score if you have a Samsung wearable. During your commute, it will start navigation and music playback when you enter your vehicle, and the evening summary will provide an overview of your daily activity, including memorable moments in the form of photo collages.

Credits: Tecnoblog
 Additionally, the integration of Google’s Gemini AI assistant with Samsung’s own apps is a solid development. Users will now be able to ask Gemini to read content from apps like YouTube and interact with Samsung apps, such as Samsung Notes. This opens up new possibilities for voice-driven interactions and seamless integration between Samsung’s software and Google’s AI technology. While the Galaxy S25 series doesn’t bring any major redesigns, these updates give us an idea about the company’s seriousness when it comes to AI and camera enhancements.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 16, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Poco M7 Pro 5G review: Strong on the fundamentalsAlso read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skip

Headline: Ex Infosys employee says worked there for 9 years, had only Rs 35,000 monthly salaryA former Infosys employee from Bengaluru took to Reddit to share his candid experiences of working at one of India's largest IT firms. Referring to the work environment as "unchained slavery," the anonymous writer detailed the issues he encountered, including low wages, low salary hikes, rigid working hours and more.
Content: A former Infosys employee from Bengaluru took to Reddit to share his candid experiences of working at one of India's largest IT firms. Referring to the work environment as "unchained slavery," the anonymous writer detailed the issues he encountered during his nine-year tenure at the company. He left Infosys in 2017 and is now employed at an IT giant based in Bengaluru's Ecospace. In his post, which has gone viral, he has compared Infosys with current workplaces, painting a critical picture of Infosys' corporate culture. In the post, the person who claims to be an ex-employee of Infosys joined the company as a fresher in 2008 and stayed there for almost a decade. During this time, he says he was paid very less compared to industry standards. He revealed that his last salary at the tech company for Rs 35,000 monthly. "When I left Infosys after nine years, my monthly salary was Rs 35,000. Today, I earn Rs 1.7 lakh, nearly 400 per cent more," he revealed. He also mentioned that whenever he refers former Infosys colleagues to his current company, they usually receive an 80-100 per cent hike in pay, revealing how underpaid employees at Infosys continue to be. Another aspect the former employee highlighted was the disparity in benefits. He noted that in his current organisation, transportation and parking are free, while at Infosys, employees had to pay out of pocket for these services. "I paid Rs 3,200 monthly for transport at Infosys, while parking also came at an extra cost," he shared. The cafeteria, too, showed a marked difference, with subsidised prices at his new company. For instance, a fruit juice that costs Rs 15-20 at his current workplace would have set him back Rs 40 at Infosys. The post further touched on what the ex-employee called the "myth of progression" at Infosys. While the company promoted employees within sub-levels, such as from 4B to 4A, there were no big salary hikes or changes in responsibilities. In contrast, promotions at his current company come with real pay hikes of 15-25 per cent and additional responsibilities.  "Infosys relied on single-digit annual salary hikes of 4-6 per cent, which made it difficult to earn a competitive salary over time," he added. One of the biggest challenges he faced during his time at Infosys was the 90-day notice period, which he described as a barrier to switching jobs. He noted that many prospective employers were unwilling to wait three months for an employee to join. In his current company, the notice period is only two months, which he feels is more reasonable and allows for smoother job transitions. Another issue he raised was Infosys' rigid work-hour policies. Employees were required to spend a mandatory number of hours on campus, tracked through ID card swipes. This led to what the writer called "absurd scenarios," where employees would visit the campus on weekends just to meet their required hours. Finally, the ex-Infosys employee criticised the company’s emphasis on philanthropy while, according to him, neglecting employee welfare. He wrote employees often joked that the company should redirect some of its charitable efforts toward better salaries and benefits for its workforce. He also pointed out the lack of "market corrections" in salaries at Infosys, contrasting it with his current employer, which periodically adjusts salaries to align with market trends.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 16, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: Google tells EU it won't add fact-checks to search results: ReportGoogle expressed its unwillingness to abide by the EU's censorship laws in a letter written to Renate Nikolay, Deputy Director General under the EU's content and technology wing.
Content: Tech giant Google has conveyed to the European Union (EU) that it will not add fact checking features to search results and YouTube videos, a US media report claimed on Thursday.  The tech firm will also not use them while ranking or removing content on its platform, despite EU law requirements. An Axios report cited, to back its claim, a letter written to Renate Nikolay, Deputy Director General under the EU's content and technology wing by Google's representatives. The EU Code of Practice, introduced in 2022 for online platforms, trade associations and the advertising industry, requires them to keep under check fake claims, misinformation, motivated propaganda among others. The Code was originally enacted in 2018. Notably, Google has never added the fact-checking feature under its content moderation policy.  Kent Walker, Google's global affairs chief termed the fact-checking integration enacted by the European Commission's Disinformation Code of Practice "not appropriate or effective" for services offered by Google, expressing the tech giant's unwillingness to commit to it, the Axios report added. The European Commission is the executive body of the EU, which ensures that the bloc's policies and laws are implemented across Member States. It also deliberates on international agreements on the EU's behalf. To further affirm Google's stance on EU fact-checking law, Walker referred to the company's existing policy with regard to content moderation, calling it adequate and cited various elections that were held around the world last year to back his claim.   "Google will continue to invest in improvements to its current content moderation practices, which focus on providing people with more information about their search results through features like Synth ID watermarking and AI disclosures on YouTube," Axios quoted Walker as saying in the letter. The development came a week after social media major Meta's chief Mark Zuckerberg asserted that EU data law required only big tech outlets to conform to its fact-checking rules and remove objectionable content.  "Europe has an ever-increasing number of laws institutionalising censorship and making it difficult to build anything innovative there," Zuckerberg was quoted as saying by Reuters. Last week, Meta said it would halt efforts to fact-check and scale down policing of speech across major platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, and Threads. As EU data law suggests, the code required Google to include fact-check results alongside its search results and videos on YouTube. It would also require Google to add a fact-checking feature to its ranking systems and algorithms. The EU's Digital Services Act (DSA) was brought into effect in 2022 in the wake of, as the Commission claims on its official website, fake news on vaccines, false healthcare information, hoaxes with misleading claims and conspiracy theories put many lives in danger during the Covid-19 pandemic.Published By: Vivek Published On: Jan 16, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Apple launches Apple Store app in IndiaApple has launched a new Apple Store app in India, which will let you buy Apple products directly from the official Apple app. The app is available on the App Store for free.
Content:
Apple has launched the Apple Store app in India, which has been available in its other markets for years. The app is available for download on the App Store. The app is meant to streamline access to Apple’s products and services in the country, which is in addition to the physical store, authorised sellers and third-party retailers that the customers have access to.  “At Apple, our customer is at the centre of everything we do, and we are thrilled to introduce the Apple Store app to reach even more users in India, further deepening our connections,” said Karen Rasmussen, Apple’s head of Retail Online. “With the Apple Store app, customers will discover a new and seamless way to shop for all our incredible products, receive personalised support, and really experience the best of Apple,” she added. The Apple Store app also has a bunch of customisations of users in India. For instance, it has a products tab, which allows users to explore Apple’s lineup of devices and accessories, learn about trade-in programs, and access financing options. There is also a For You tab, which shows tailored recommendations and a quick-access section for saved or favourited items. There is also a Go Further tab on the app. What it does is: After a purchase, customers can connect with Apple Specialists for online Personal Setup sessions, access tips via short videos, or join Today at Apple sessions at local stores to unlock their devices’ full potential.   The app also brings Apple’s customisation features to India, allowing users to engrave devices such as AirPods, iPads, and Apple Pencils with names, initials, or emojis in various languages. Customers can also configure Macs with upgraded specifications or personalise their Apple Watch orders.   With the Apple Store app, Indian customers can choose between home delivery and in-store pickup, making it easier than ever to access Apple’s products.  
The introduction of the Apple Store app comes at a time when Apple is increasing its investments in the Indian market. Beyond its partnerships with authorised resellers and third-party retailers, Apple opened its first physical stores in Delhi and Mumbai in April 2023. In the press note, Apple has also confirmed that it will be opening new stores in Bengaluru, Pune, Delhi-NCR, and Mumbai soon.  This digital expansion through the app signifies Apple’s intent to offer the same premium experience for Indian consumers that it offers in other countries. By combining personalised shopping, customisation options, and convenient delivery or pickup methods, Apple is setting new standards for customer engagement in India. Headline: Crash Detection on Apple Watch helps save man after passing out while drivingA man from Easthampton credits his Apple Watch with saving his life after a terrifying car crash left him trapped upside down in a neighbour's swimming pool.
Content: A 55-year-old man from Easthampton, Massachusetts, credits his Apple Watch for saving his life after a terrifying car crash left him trapped upside down in a swimming pool. Brent Hill was driving home on December 16 when he suddenly began to feel unwell. Moments later, he blacked out completely. The next thing he knew, he was slowly regaining consciousness, disoriented, and unable to make sense of his surroundings. Hill’s car, which had veered off the road, had smashed through a neighbour’s garage before plunging into their swimming pool. Surveillance footage from a nearby camera captured the harrowing moment when his car accelerated uncontrollably, likely caused by his foot pressing the accelerator as he passed out. As he regained consciousness, Hill was shocked to hear what he initially thought was a voice from the afterlife. In reality, it was his Apple Watch that had detected the crash and called emergency services. The voice from the watch reassured him that help was on its way, giving him a glimmer of hope in a desperate situation. “If emergency services had not contacted me through that watch and coached me through it, there’s no way I would’ve got out of there,” Hill said. He recalled hearing faint noises outside the car but couldn’t comprehend them properly. “I knew there was commotion, but I didn’t know where I was. That voice from the watch kept me calm. Without it, I probably would have drowned.” Thanks to the Apple Watch's crash detection feature, emergency responders arrived quickly and rescued Hill before the situation worsened. Although the crash left him with minor injuries, Hill believes it could have ended much worse without the watch’s intervention. Neighbour Elizabeth Laprade-Appelquist, whose garage and pool bore the brunt of the crash, was astonished when she learnt how the Apple Watch played a key role. “My husband called 911, but they were already speaking to the driver through his watch. It was incredible to hear how it all worked out,” she said. Hill hopes his story encourages more people to understand the value of technology in emergencies. “This feature saved my life. It’s a reminder that these devices are more than just gadgets; they can be lifesavers.” This incident adds to the growing number of reports highlighting how smartwatches, especially the Apple Watches, have repeatedly proven how invaluable technology can be in such critical moments.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 17, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skipAlso read |  Poco M7 Pro 5G review: Strong on the fundamentals

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 could be the first phone to support Hey GeminiThe Samsung Galaxy Unpacked event is scheduled to take place on January 22, 2025. The event is expected to unveil the next-gen Galaxy S series. With the launch, the rumour has it that the Galaxy S25 series could be the first one to debut with the 'Hey Gemini' wake words.
Content:
For the longest period of time, Google has been going around with "Hey Google" for its AI assistant, but this might change soon. With the launch of the Samsung Galaxy S25 series this month, Google might shift its wake words to 'Hey Gemini'. If this holds to be true, then the upcoming series will be the first one to debut with a new call for its assistance. For context, Gemini AI on Android currently lacks its own dedicated wake word, relying instead on "Hey Google" as the primary hotword for both Google Assistant and Gemini (depending on your default setting).  Google debuting its features with a Samsung phone should not come as a surprise. The trend of introducing a new Google AI-feature into a high-end Samsung device started a year back, when the Galaxy S24 series debuted with Circle to Search. But here is a thought: Is Google, by working with Samsung to load AI smarts in its phones, undermining its own Pixel phones? Hey Gemini: Google might release its wake words this month Hints of a possible "Hey Gemini" hotword have surfaced before, though not in the context of smartphones. Toward the end of last year, Google introduced its Android XR platform, designed to power next-generation VR/AR devices such as Samsung's "Project Moohan" headsets and smart glasses, with Google Gemini integrated at its core. 
 


 Teaser videos for Android XR revealed that the platform is built to leverage the "Hey Gemini" hotword, particularly since it is not expected to support Google Assistant. While it was initially unclear if this wake word would remain exclusive to the "Android platform built for the Gemini AI era," new evidence suggests that it could soon be extended to smartphones—possibly during the Galaxy Unpacked event, scheduled for January 22.  This speculation stems from a leaked Galaxy S25 marketing document, highlighting the series' advanced AI capabilities. The leak, published by the Brazilian outlet Tecnoblog, includes promotional materials for Samsung's flagship series. Samsung Galaxy S25 series: What to expect The upcoming Galaxy S25 series is set to introduce notable upgrades, particularly in AI capabilities and camera technology, which are expected to appeal to users. Here is the gist of what is expected to arrive, but if you want to read in detail, we have also got you covered (read here).  According to leaks, the standout feature of the Galaxy S25 Ultra will once again be its impressive camera system. While it retains the 200-megapixel main camera, a 50-megapixel periscope with 5x optical zoom, and a 10-megapixel telephoto lens with 3x optical zoom from its predecessor, the major enhancement lies in the ultra-wide camera. Samsung has replaced the previous 12-megapixel sensor with a new 50-megapixel ultra-wide camera, addressing past criticisms of its performance. The front-facing camera will continue to feature a 12-megapixel sensor across the lineup.  Beyond hardware, the series is expected to debut new AI-driven features. Among them is the "Brief" feature, which delivers personalised daily summaries. In the morning, it offers a weather forecast, a rundown of your schedule, and an energy score if paired with a Samsung wearable. During commutes, it can initiate navigation and play music upon entering your vehicle. At the end of the day, it provides an overview of your activities, including photo collages of memorable moments.  Additionally, the integration of Google’s Gemini AI assistant with Samsung apps marks a significant development. Users will be able to leverage Gemini for tasks like reading content from YouTube or interacting with Samsung Notes, enabling more seamless and voice-driven interactions between Samsung’s ecosystem and Google’s AI technology. Headline: iPhone 16 Pro available with big discount: Should you buy it or wait for iPhone 17?The iPhone 16 Pro is selling at a big discount on Amazon, making it one of the best deals on a premium flagship smartphone. But should you buy it right now or wait for the iPhone 17?
Content: If you’ve been waiting for the perfect moment to upgrade to the iPhone 16 Pro, now might just be the right time. Apple’s latest and greatest flagship phone is currently available at a discounted price on Amazon. The base 128GB model, originally priced at Rs 1,19,900, is now selling for Rs 1,12,900. But the savings don’t end there — thanks to some attractive exchange offers, you could potentially bring the price down to as low as Rs 77,400. Yes, you read that right. Amazon is offering a flat discount of Rs 7,000 on the iPhone 16 Pro, bringing the price down to Rs 1,12,900. On top of this, the exchange offer allows buyers to save up to Rs 35,500 depending on the phone they trade in. For example, if you’re trading in an iPhone 13 Pro, you could receive an exchange value of up to Rs 31,000, further reducing the price to Rs 82,900. Similarly, if you own an iPhone 13 Pro Max in good condition, you could potentially qualify for the full Rs 35,500 exchange benefit, effectively bringing the cost of the iPhone 16 Pro down to an impressive Rs 77,400. The exact exchange value will, of course, vary based on the condition and market value of your existing handset. To check how much your device qualifies for, simply head over to Amazon, select your desired iPhone 16 Pro colour variant, and explore the exchange offer for your device. You’ll be able to see the estimated value Amazon is offering for your phone. All in all, with the current discount and the lucrative exchange deals, this is an excellent opportunity to snag the iPhone 16 Pro at a considerably reduced price. But, should you buy it, or should you wait for the iPhone 17 coming later this year? iPhone 16 Pro: Should you buy it or wait for iPhone 17? While this is the right time to buy the iPhone 16, Apple will unveil the iPhone 17, including the iPhone 17 Pro, in September this year. Based on the leaks and rumours, the iPhone 17 series is expected to bring a host of upgrades over the iPhone 16 series, enhancing both performance and user experience. Apple’s iPhone 17 series is shaping up to be one of the most exciting updates in years, with several major design and hardware changes rumoured to be in the pipeline.  Apple is reportedly working on a slimmer iPhone model — iPhone 17 Air. This device is expected to be around 6.25mm thick, making it significantly thinner than the current iPhone 16 Pro, which is 8.25mm. If true, this would make the iPhone 17 Air the thinnest iPhone Apple has ever produced.  Significant design updates are expected for the iPhone 17 Pro models. Apple is rumoured to be ditching the titanium frame introduced with the iPhone 15 Pro series and returning to aluminium. This shift would also bring a new half-glass, half-aluminium back panel, with the bottom half remaining glass to support wireless charging. Not only could this make the Pro models more durable, but it would also mark a departure from the all-glass backs used since the iPhone X. The camera module is also set for a redesign. While current camera bumps are square, leaks suggest the new Pro models might feature an elongated oval or rectangular shape made from aluminium. However, other sources claim the camera layout will remain triangular, keeping things similar to existing designs but with a fresh twist. Speaking of cameras, the iPhone 17 Pro Max is expected to pack a trio of 48-megapixel sensors for the primary, ultra-wide, and telephoto cameras. Meanwhile, all iPhone 17 models are said to feature a 24-megapixel front-facing camera, a big jump from the current 12-megapixel lens. Some models may even include a mechanical aperture, allowing users to adjust the light intake for more control over depth-of-field in photos. Another big change that's expected is the expansion of ProMotion. Apple’s 120Hz refresh rate technology has been exclusive to Pro models, but it is expected to make its way to the standard iPhone 17 and iPhone 17 Air in 2025. This could potentially make way for features like always-on displays across the lineup. The iPhone 17 Pro models are expected to come equipped with the A19 Pro chip, paired with 12GB of RAM. Meanwhile, the standard iPhone 17 models are likely to feature the A19 chip with 8GB of RAM, offering solid performance for everyday use. As for pricing, the iPhone 17 Pro is rumoured to start at $999 in the US. If Apple follows its current pricing trend, this could translate to Rs 1,19,900 in India, matching the launch price of the iPhone 16 Pro in the country. The leaks surrounding the iPhone 17 series, along with details about the current iPhone 16 Pro, make the upcoming lineup seem like a major upgrade. That said, buying the iPhone 16 Pro now still has its advantages. With Apple’s trade-in program likely to offer attractive deals for upgrades next year, it could be a smart investment for those who want the latest tech now. Plus, the iPhone 16 Pro already delivers a premium experience, powered by iOS 18, ensuring top-notch performance and features for immediate use.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 17, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Poco M7 Pro 5G review: Strong on the fundamentalsAlso read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skip

Headline: Apple releases iOS 18.3 beta 3 for developers, includes updates in Notification Summaries, Camera Controls and moreApple has launched the third beta of iOS 18.3, bringing notable updates and improvements in Notification Summaries, Camera Controls, and more.
Content:
Apple has rolled out the third beta of iOS 18.3 to developers, introducing several fixes and refinements across apps and features to improve the user experience. The first two betas of iOS 18.3 were relatively light and primarily focused on bug fixes. However, the newest beta brings a few notable updates to features such as Notification Summaries, Camera Controls, Messages, and PDF editing. Let’s take a quick look at everything new in the latest iOS 18.3 beta 3. Notification Summary One of the major upgrades in the third beta is for Notification Summaries. For the News and Entertainment categories, Apple has temporarily disabled notification summaries. Apple Intelligence will no longer summarize news notifications until further refinements are made, allowing the company to improve the accuracy and reliability of summaries in future updates. Apple has also noted in the Settings app that this feature remains in beta and is subject to potential errors. Additionally, Apple has introduced a clearer setup message for Notification Summaries. The new message cautions users that “summarization may change the meaning of the original headlines,”  as noted by MacRumors. With this update, summarized notifications are now italicized to differentiate them from standard notifications, providing better visual clarity. Moreover, with iOS 18.3 beta 3, users can manage Notification Summaries directly from the Lock Screen. Swiping on a notification and selecting the “Options” button now provides an interface to disable summaries for specific apps, offering a more convenient customization experience. These updates are currently in beta and will soon be available to users across iOS 18.3, iPadOS 18.3, and macOS Sequoia 15.3. Upgrades in Camera Control For iPhone 16 users, Apple has included a new feature in the Camera Control settings. The previous “AE/AF Lock” option has been renamed “Lock Focus and Exposure,” making it more intuitive for users unfamiliar with technical photography terms. This new setting allows users to lock focus and exposure with a light press and hold on the Camera Control button, mimicking the functionality of DSLR cameras. Genmoji Integration in Messages In the Messages app, Apple has added a new entry for Genmoji creation. Accessible via the “+” button in any conversation, the Genmoji option directs users to the creation interface, providing another way to personalize conversations with custom emojis. Previously, Genmoji creation tools were only accessible through the emoji keyboard button. With the iOS 18.3 beta 3 updates, this feature is now easier to access. PDF Editing Warning The latest beta introduces a new alert for PDF editing. When cropping a PDF through the screenshot interface, users are warned that cropped content is not fully removed from the document. The message reads: “Content outside the cropped area won’t be visible in most PDF viewers, but it can be made visible in some apps”. Availability The iOS 18.3 beta is currently available to registered developers. It will soon be available for public beta testers and, eventually, all users. Interested users can download it via the Apple Developer Center or as an over-the-air update on devices enrolled in the beta testing program.
