Headline: iOS 19 tipped to feature visionOS inspired camera interface designiOS 19 will reportedly be getting a camera UI redesign, which is expected to be showcased at the upcoming WWDC 2025 in June.
Content: Apple could reportedly be planning a big update for its iPhone’s camera app in iOS 19, bringing it closer to the minimalist design seen in its visionOS operating system, used in the Apple Vision Pro. The reported camera UI redesign, which is expected to be showcased at the upcoming WWDC 2025 in June, promises a more intuitive and immersive experience for iPhone users, focusing on simplicity and ease of use. While the new look is still in development, leaks have started to surface, giving us an idea of what to expect. According to tipster Jon Prosser, the iOS 19 Camera app will be getting a complete redesign. The interface will reportedly feature translucent menus that will allow the viewfinder to take centre stage. This means users will have more space to focus on capturing photos or videos, while settings will be condensed or, you can say, features will be neatly tucked away in expandable panels. These changes are expected to mirror the interface of visionOS. Additionally, one of the key goals of iOS 19 is to make the camera interface less overwhelming. The new design will hide some of the less-used features under expandable toggles. For instance, when switching between photo and video modes, the app will display additional settings like depth control, panorama, and exposure adjustments.  When recording video, the top of the screen will showcase resolution and frame rate controls, making it easy to adjust on the fly without needing to jump into submenus. The camera app will also allow users to select different modes, such as slow motion, time-lapse, action, posture etc., from a clear and easy-to-navigate menu. This overhaul will likely make the camera app more consistent with other Apple products, including the Vision Pro, and could be a sign of further UI updates across the rest of iOS 19. Although Apple has yet to confirm these changes, these early leaks sound exciting, especially for users who are eager to see how the design elements of visionOS will be adapted for the iPhone. The transition from iOS 18, which did not feature a visionOS inspired design, could be a big leap forward in terms of user experience.  The official reveal of iOS 19 is expected to take place during Apple’s WWDC 2025 in June. A beta version will likely follow shortly after, with the full release of the update arriving in September, coinciding with the launch of the iPhone 17 series.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skip

Headline: Sam Altman declares AGI is just Twitter hype, says cut expectations 100xAfter much anticipation, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman stated that AGI is not one of the themes that is coming soon on its AI-platforms.
Content:
On December 31, 2024, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman posted on X (formerly Twitter), asking for suggestions to improve its AI platforms. After going through the comments, he deduced that one of the most common themes (suggested by the users) for improving openAI is to introduce AGI (Artificial General Intelligence). Since then, rumours started churning that OpenAI is eyeing to integrate AGI into its platforms. Fuelling up these rumours, Altman also penned down a note in his blog post (titled Reflections) 2 weeks ago, stating that the company is confident about creating AGI. But now, after much anticipation, Altman has finally cleared the air, whether AGI is coming to town or not.  He posted that the company is planning to release "cool stuff" next month, but AGI is not a part of this regime. He also said that these rumours were only based on Twitter (now X) hype and nothing more. Since the hype was so out of control, he urged users that even though OpenAI is planning to launch interesting updates and features, they need to cut down their expectations 100 times. 
 


 But why is AGI such a distant thought for OpenAI, even though it is the next step? Artificial General Intelligence or AGI is defined as an AI system that can tackle any task just like a human would. After AGI, we get to artificial superintelligence (ASI), which is AI that exceeds the capabilities of the human mind. Right now, we are working on AI chatbots like ChatGPT that uses natural language processing to create human-like conversational dialogue. In the same blog post, he said, "As we get closer to AGI, it feels like an important time to look at the progress of our company. There is still so much to understand, still so much we don’t know, and it’s still so early. But we know a lot more than we did when we started." This signifies that OpenAI still has a lot to work on to achieve the AGI-level. Now, the question is: If not AGI, then what is coming for OpenAI? OpenAI to launch AI-agents soon Someone who keeps tracking the headlines would think that GPT-5 must be the next step for OpenAI. However, a few recent reports have suggested that the next flagship model is still in the pipeline, with no decided launch date. Rather, the company is seeking to be working on an AI super-agent, and it may release as early as January 30. There is also a new report by Axios that claims that OpenAI is meeting with the US government officials regarding the launch. 

Altman said in the blog, "We believe that, in 2025, we may see the first AI agents “join the workforce” and materially change the output of companies. We continue to believe that iteratively putting great tools in the hands of people leads to great, broadly-distributed outcomes."  This AI agent is a sophisticated software system that can perform complex tasks on its own, with minimal human supervision. It can make decisions on your behalf, adapt and react to different situations, analyse large amounts of data and multiple options. It is basically able to mimic human intelligence when you give it a goal-oriented task. And from what the reports suggest, it said AI super agent that OpenAI is working on will be capable of addressing complex problems with the proficiency of a doctoral graduate. Read more about the upcoming OpenAI AI-agent here.  Hence, we can say that this AI-agent is a step closer to AGI. With this speed, we can also deduce that AGI is also not that far from becoming a reality. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra India launch in 2 days: 8 things to knowThe Samsung Galaxy S25 series will finally arrive in India in two days as the launch event is set for January 22. Here are 8 things that you should know based on the leaks so far.
Content: The Samsung Galaxy S25 series will finally arrive in India in two days as the launch event is set for January 22. The company is likely to announce three models in its 2025 flagship series - standard, Plus and Ultra. There have been rumours of a new Slim model as well, but it is reportedly to debut after a few months. Out of the three models, the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra is tipped to receive maximum upgrades in comparison to its predecessor. If you are planning to buy the upcoming Ultra version, here are 8 things that you should know based on the leaks so far.advertisementSamsung Galaxy S25 Ultra India launch in 2 days: 8 things to knowAny design changes?The Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra will continue to offer a phablet-style design. The leaks suggest that the new phone will have 2-3 major design changes. One is that the bezels around the screen will be more slim and the second one is that we could see rounded corners in the latest model. The Galaxy S25 Ultra is also said to have a slimmer profile (8.2mm) compared to the Galaxy S24 Ultra and it should also feel lighter (219g), according to the leaks. Headline: TikTok banned and unbanned in US, Trump talks of 50% sale: Story in 5 pointsIn the past 24 hours, TikTok died and returned to the US. Why was it removed, why was it revived, what is the new US President Donald Trump's role in it? Here is everything you need to know about the TikTok drama in quick 5 points.
Content:
The TikTok ban in the US has been dramatic, to say the least. In just 24 hours, TikTok and other apps owned by Chinese company ByteDance, were banned and unbanned in the country. And in between that time, the new US President Donald Trump was involved, there was talk about selling 50 per cent ownership of TikTok in the US, Elon Musk suggesting “something needs to change”, and more. There are also questions about why the app was being banned in the first place, and why was it suddenly unbanned? If you are looking for a quick lowdown on everything that has happened around the TikTok ban in the US, you have landed at the right place. Here is a 5-point explainer on everything that you need to know about the TikTok drama. advertisementWhy was TikTok being banned in the US?For a few weeks, TikTok was facing a deadline for January 19 for a ban in the US. The threat of ban was over national security concerns that were tied to its parent company ByteDance. The US government claims that the TikTok parent company has tied with the Chinese government and it fears that its apps could be collecting data from American users like their location, phone records, messages, etc.This has been a longstanding issue. Authorities in the US were also pushing ByteDance to sell TikTok’s US operations, however, the company decided on shutting down its operations in the US entirely, unless the US Supreme Court overturned the ban. The ban didn’t lift, so TikTok was shut down in the US on Sunday morning. For a few weeks, TikTok was facing a deadline for January 19 for a ban in the US. The threat of ban was over national security concerns that were tied to its parent company ByteDance. The US government claims that the TikTok parent company has tied with the Chinese government and it fears that its apps could be collecting data from American users like their location, phone records, messages, etc. This has been a longstanding issue. Authorities in the US were also pushing ByteDance to sell TikTok’s US operations, however, the company decided on shutting down its operations in the US entirely, unless the US Supreme Court overturned the ban. The ban didn’t lift, so TikTok was shut down in the US on Sunday morning. The US Supreme Court, last week, passed a ruling which upheld the law signed by US President Joe Biden in April, to ban TikTok in the country. How was Donald Trump involved in this?  Interestingly, the timing of TikTok’s ban in the US coincided with the transition to a new administration in the country. The Biden White House passed enforcement responsibility to President-elect Donald Trump on January 20. During his victory rally, Trump announced that he will "save" TikTok. On Monday, Donald Trump said he is putting out an executive order to delay the enforcement of the TikTok ban. Soon after, TikTok was again made available on app stores in the US. TikTok had also put up a post thanking Trump for “providing the necessary clarity and assurance” after the company got a green flag for reviving the app in the country.Why does TikTok need to sell 50 per cent of its ownership to the US? However, Trump also said that he would only “approve” TikTok in the country on the condition that the US owns 50 per cent of the app. He said this was necessary to save jobs in the US and ensure that the US does not give its business to China. What did Elon Musk say about the TikTok ban? In this mix of drama, Elon Musk is right at the centre. Musk says he does not support the ban. However, he did slip in that his support is despite the fact that China has banned X in the country. He says that is “unbalanced”, and that “something needs to change.” “I have been against a TikTok ban for a long time, because it goes against freedom of speech. That said, the current situation where TikTok is allowed to operate in America, but X is not allowed to operate in China is unbalanced. Something needs to change,” he wrote in a post on X.
 


 While there has not been any confirmation around this, the speculation is that Elon Musk may be in line to buy the 50 per cent stake in TikTok. His suggestion about change and there being a lack of balance could also be seen as a hint at the same.Why was the TikTok ban lifted in the US? Within 24 hours of a ban being imposed on TikTok, it was lifted. Why? Because Donald Trump said that “we have to save it”. During his victory rally on Sunday, Trump passed an executive to delay the ban. However, he did it on the condition that ByteDance would sell 50 per cent of TikTok’s ownership to the US. 
Despite being temporarily saved from a ban in the country, TikTok’s future is still uncertain. As the Trump administration is taking over, the focus will be on ByteDance  finding a balance between addressing the US government’s security concerns and Trump’s expectations about 50 per cent ownership of the app in the US. Whether the platform will be sold, banned, or face new regulations is yet to be seen. Headline: Apple could copy Android phones by bringing vapour cooling chamber to iPhone 17A recent leak claims that the upcoming iPhone 17 series will feature vapour chambers, replacing the traditional cooling sink.
Content: Apple is anticipated to bring its next-gen iPhone 17 series later this year, most likely in September. While there is no official word out yet, the rumours and leaks have painted a good enough picture of the upcoming iPhone 17 phones. Based on the rumours, Apple is focusing on revamping the series over its predecessor. This includes bringing a new entry -- the iPhone 17 Air. A recent leak has now added another bullet point to the list of what is new in the rumoured iPhone 17 series. This leak indicates that the upcoming series might feature a vapour cooling chamber and do away with the heat sinks.  Apple has been using heat sinks for a long period of time, whereas Android phones were the OGs using vapour cooling champers. Now, iPhones will also be a part of this gang soon, as reported by the GSMArena. Previously, it had been rumoured that only the iPhone 17 Pro Max would get a VC cooling system. However, the latest leak claims all models of the iPhone 17 series are up for this change. That being said, it will be interesting to see how the iPhone 17 Air will fit the VC system at just 6mm thickness.  For context, vapour chambers are enclosed metal components containing a small amount of liquid, typically de-ionized water. When the chipset generates heat, the liquid evaporates, turning into vapour that spreads across the chamber's surface. This process helps distribute heat efficiently, cooling the device effectively. The VC cooling system is not the only upgrade coming to all the models. The non-Pro iPhone 17 variants are also rumoured to finally get high-refresh-rate screens. It remains to be seen whether those panels will be 90Hz or 120Hz.iPhone 17 series: What to expect The latest rumours suggest that the iPhone 17 series will bring a significant redesign across the entire lineup. While the iPhone 16 attempted a similar update for the base and Plus models, the iPhone 17 series is expected to feature a camera bump reminiscent of Google Pixel devices. Overall, it looks like Apple is trying to break the narrative of bringing same design and pattern every year.  Additionally, the lineup is rumoured to introduce a new anti-reflective display, said to be more scratch-resistant than the current Ceramic Shield. Apple is reportedly working on a "super-hard anti-reflective layer" to enhance durability and better withstand daily wear and tear.   The higher-end iPhone 17 models are expected to come equipped with 12GB of RAM, while the standard model may feature 8GB. Furthermore, all iPhone 17 variants are rumoured to include an upgraded 24-megapixel front-facing camera with a six-element lens, a notable improvement over the current 12-megapixel selfie camera.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Also read |  iPhone 17 may get 120Hz display but there's a catchAlso read |  Apple is rumoured to release either iPhone SE 4 or iPhone 17 Air in 2025Also read |  iPhone 17 Air price details leaked, will cost less than Pro modelsMust Watch

According to a report by Axios, if this number is combined with his other assets, he would now rank among the 25 richest people in the world.  

 



Screenshot from CoinGecko
 As mentioned above, Trump owns 80 per cent of the tokens. Which means, out of the total 1 billion tokens that were issued, 200 million are being traded actively by the public.  The new $TRUMP memecoin takes you back to Donald Trump’s first term in the US as president, when a lot of concern was raised about how people could be benefiting him personally by staying at his Washington Hotel and contributing to his personal wealth. The crypto token, however, is a newer and a more direct way of adding to Trump’s wealth. First, he listed a meme stock where he owned more than half the shares, and now the meme coin is a new avenue for him to generate funds with lesser accountability.  But there is an interesting twist in the story here. Enter the first lady Melania Trump. Hours after Donald Trump released his memecoin, his wife, Melania Trump launched her own memecoin called  $MELANIA, late on Sunday. Her memecoin was able to briefly cause a crash in Donald Trump’s token, which saw a decline by 50 per cent. As of Monday morning, Melania Trump’s memecoin jumbed 2000 per cent in value and is trading at $0.1261.

Headline: Apple is planning to launch MacBook Air with OLED display, but not very soonA new report reveals that Apple is planning to launch a MacBook Air with an OLED screen in 2029. This decision is likely due to the slower-than-expected sales of the 2024 launched iPad Pro, which features an OLED screen.
Content:
Last year, Apple finally introduced OLED displays—Ultra XDR Retina Display—in iPad Pro models. With this, the next Apple device expected to get the OLED display is the MacBook. While MacBook Pro models are said to get the OLED display by 2026, Apple is reportedly planning to wait a few more years to bring OLED to the MacBook Air models. A new report by Korean publication The Elec notes that Apple has likely pushed the launch date for the first MacBook Air with an OLED display from 2027 to around 2029. According to the report Apple is planning to delay the launch of the OLED MacBook Air after receiving a cold response to the expected sales projections for the OLED iPad Pro. Earlier there were reports that with the OLED MacBook Pro in 2026, we might see OLED screens in the MacBook Air by 2027. However, now this new reports suggest that with the iPad Pro sales performance, Apple might be reconsidering its plans to offer premium OLED displays in the considerably budget-friendly MacBook Air lineup. While the introduction of OLED displays would definitely bring a better display experience with improved brightness, deeper blacks, and enhanced battery efficiency, this display technology is expensive and significantly impacts the overall production cost. Hence, Apple is likely to keep its plans for OLED on hold for the affordable MacBook Air models to align with both production costs and sales performance. However, while the OLED display might take a while to feature in the MacBook Air, Apple is considering upgrading the current LCD displays. According to the reports, Apple is planning to feature “oxide TFT” technology in its 2027 MacBook Air. This new tech will allow future MacBook Air models to offer better durability, improved visuals, and higher contrast compared to the current LCD displays.MacBook Pro with OLED on track coming next year  While the reports of no OLED in MacBook Air for the next two years might disappoint Apple users, Apple is said to bring OLED displays to MacBook Pro models soon. According to several reports, including one from Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman, the 14-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pro models launching in 2026 could feature OLED displays. Infact Gurman suggests that the 2026 MacBook Pros will be the “true overhaul” for Apple’s the MacBook Pro. These reports are further supported by predictions from Apple analysts Ming-Chi Kuo and Ross Young, who earlier have said Apple will phase out mini-LED displays in MacBook Pro models after the 2025 lineup. Additionally, the OLED technology will allow Apple to make MacBooks even thinner. For instance, the OLED iPad Pro introduced in 2024 became Apple’s thinnest device that year. Similar design changes are expected with MacBooks after the adoption of OLED technology. As for the 2025 MacBook Pro, Apple is likely to give few upgardes including better performance with the new M5 chip.MacBook Air with M4 launching in 2025 As for the upcoming MacBook Air, this year Apple is reportedly planning to update its 13-inch and 15-inch MacBook Air models with the new M4 chip in the coming months. These new MacBook Air models will continue to rely on LCD technology but are expected to offer improved performance and efficiency, while keeping the device powerful and competitive in their segment.

Headline: Samsung Galaxy A36 spotted on BIS certification website, likely to feature Snapdragon 6 Gen 3 chipA Samsung smartphone, tipped to be the Galaxy A36, with the model number SM-A366E/DS was listed on the BIS database. While the BIS listing itself doesn't reveal much about the Galaxy A36's specs, other certifications and benchmark numbers have already given an idea of what to expect.
Content:
Samsung is planning to launch its upcoming mid-range smartphone, the Galaxy A36 5G, globally. The phone is expected to be unveiled soon as it makes its way through key certifications. The Galaxy A36, expected to debut in global markets, including India, was recently spotted on the BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) certification website, indicating the phone will be launched soon in the country. A Samsung smartphone, tipped to be the Galaxy A36, with the model number SM-A366E/DS was listed on the BIS database. The DS in the model number stands for dual-SIM support. This same model has also been spotted on Samsung’s global support pages, including those in Kazakhstan and Russia, further confirming its association with the Galaxy A36.

Samsung Galaxy A36 BIS listing
 While the BIS listing itself doesn’t reveal much about the Galaxy A36’s specifications, other certifications and benchmark numbers have already given an idea of what to expect. For starters, the Galaxy A36 will likely be powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 6 Gen 3 processor. Geekbench listings reveal that the chipset features four cores clocked at 2.40GHz and four at 1.80GHz, paired with the Adreno 710 GPU for graphics. The Galaxy A36 scored 967 points in single-core and 2,750 points in multi-core tests on Geekbench. In comparison, the last-generation Galaxy A35, powered by the Exynos 1480 scored 1011 and 2905 in single-core and multi-core in our testing. Furthermore, the device is expected to come with 6GB of RAM in its base configuration, though higher RAM variants might also be available. Samsung will likely ship the Galaxy A36 with Android 15 out of the box, running on the latest iteration of its custom One UI 7 skin. Another notable feature of the Galaxy A36 is its charging capabilities. The IECEE certification has confirmed support for 45W wired fast charging, which is an upgrade over the 25W support seen in many of Samsung’s current mid-range devices.  Samsung is reportedly making some changes to the camera hardware as well. Unlike the Galaxy A35’s 13-megapixel front camera, the Galaxy A36 is rumoured to feature a new 12-megapixel selfie camera. Although the megapixel count is slightly lower, Samsung might focus on improving image quality through better sensors or software optimisations. While we await more concrete details, the multiple certifications give us somewhat of a clear idea of what to expect from the Galaxy A36. In comparison to the Galaxy A35, the upcoming model has a new processor, faster charging, along with an upgraded selfie snapper.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 20, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skip

Headline: US President Donald Trump signs executive order delaying TikTok ban by 75 daysIn the first few hours of swearing in as the 47th President of the United States of America, Donald Trump passed an executive order to delay the TikTok ban by 75 days.
Content: One of the first things that Donald Trump did after he was sworn in as the 47th US President was to sign an executive order delaying the TikTok ban in the country by 75 days. This basically means TikTok has close to two months to reassess how it can make its services in the US permanent again.  The executive order commands government agencies in the country to find a way that will save TikTok while protecting national security. Essentially, with the order, Donald Trump has asked the US Attorney General to hold off the TikTok ban for 75 days. “I am instructing the Attorney General not to take any action to enforce the Act for a period of 75 days from today to allow my Administration an opportunity to determine the appropriate course forward in an orderly way that protects national security while avoiding an abrupt shutdown of a communications platform used by millions of Americans,” the executive order reads. The ban was enforced under the Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act (PAFACA). The original deadline for the ban was January 19, when within a span of 24 hours, the app was banned and then unbanned in the US. “During this period, the Department of Justice shall take no action to enforce the Act or impose any penalties against any entity for any noncompliance with the Act, including for distributing, maintaining, or updating (or enabling the distribution, maintenance, or updating) of any foreign adversary controlled application as defined in the Act,” the order further reads. During his victory rally on Sunday, Donald Trump got the TikTok app unbanned in the US, hours after the TikTok services went dark in the country and all ByteDance apps were pulled down from the app stores. However, while helping revive TikTok services, Trump said that it would only allow TikTok to work in the country on the condition that it sells 50 per cent of its ownership to the US.  For the uninitiated, TikTok has been facing a threat of ban in the US over concerns about national security tied to its parent company ByteDance. The US government believes that TikTok’s parent company is working with the Chinese government, and could be sending out personal and sensitive data of US users to China.  At the moment, there is no update on how TikTok will continue to offer its services in the US, who will buy TikTok, or anything else. For now, what we know for certain is that TikTok services are currently available in the US, and will continue to be available for at least the next 75 days, which is April 6, 2025. Headline: Trump signs executive order to make Elon Musk's DOGE commission an official government serviceDonald Trump's executive order formalises Elon Musk's DOGE commission, aiming to reform federal agencies through cost-cutting measures and tech upgrades, but legal challenges and criticism cast doubt on its future success.
Content: US President, Donald Trump, has signed an executive order aiming to formalise the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), a commission led by billionaire entrepreneur, Elon Musk. The commission, which proposes big budget cuts and agency reforms, could soon become an integral part of federal operations. However, its legality remains uncertain as legal challenges loom.  The executive order renames the U.S. Digital Service (USDS) as the U.S. DOGE service while retaining its acronym. Originally set up by former US President, Barack Obama to modernise technology, the USDS will now focus on Musk’s DOGE vision. This includes a detailed software modernisation plan to improve outdated government IT systems and infrastructure.  At the signing ceremony, Trump outlined plans for DOGE teams within federal agencies. Each team, consisting of at least four members, will include a team leader, an engineer, an HR specialist, and an attorney. Agency heads have been instructed to establish these teams within 30 days and collaborate with DOGE to streamline operations.  A temporary organisation, the U.S. DOGE Service Temporary Organisation, has also been created. Its mandate is to advance Trump’s 18-month DOGE agenda, with a termination date set for July 4, 2026. Trump stressed that all DOGE-related initiatives must conclude by that date, ahead of the Ohio gubernatorial election in November, later that year. Despite Trump’s confidence in the plan, DOGE faces legal and political hurdles. Critics have already filed three lawsuits, accusing the commission of violating the Federal Advisory Committee Act (FACA), which mandates transparency and balanced representation in advisory groups. Democracy Forward has criticised it as a shadow operation lacking transparency. National Security Counsellors argue that DOGE bypasses proper advisory procedures. Meanwhile, Public Citizen, the State Democracy Defenders Fund, and the American Federation of Government Employees claim that DOGE’s members fail to represent the interests of ordinary Americans. These lawsuits argue that DOGE, under Musk’s leadership, did not comply with these requirements.  Elon Musk initially suggested that DOGE’s proposals could save up to $2 trillion by cutting waste, eliminating redundant agencies, and reducing the federal workforce. However, he later moderated these claims, acknowledging the complexity of such goals. Reports indicate that DOGE is exploring controversial measures, such as nullifying the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and restructuring it alongside the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC). Musk has also proposed eliminating the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), a move that experts have heavily criticised. The commission’s journey has not been without drama. Co-leader Vivek Ramaswamy left DOGE after reported disagreements with Elon Musk. He is now expected to run for governor of Ohio, raising further political stakes for the initiative.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Tune InAlso read |  US President Donald Trump signs executive order delaying TikTok ban by 75 daysAlso read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?

Headline: Apple likely to launch new iPad Air models with M3 chip in April 2025 A recent leak suggests that Apple will soon launch the new iPad Air lineup with 11-inch and 13-inch display with M3 chipset.
Content:
In the year 2025, Apple is expected to bring significant upgrades to its devices across the ecosystem. As we draw closer to the first phases of launches—Apple typically starts launches with spring events in March or April—the anticipation around what’s new is growing higher. For starters, in its spring launch, Apple is likely to announce the new lineup of iPad Air models, and a new report suggests that these models will feature the M3 chip. In one of his latest private posts on X— as reported by MacRumors—tipster Evan Blass shared an image of source code mentioning the names of the anticipated 11-inch iPad Air, 13-inch iPad Air, and iPad 11 models. This image suggests the possibility of these launches and the chipset these devices will come with. Although Blass has not shared the source, the image hints that Apple is likely to launch the new iPad Air lineup soon. The launch was earlier suggested by Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman, who stated that Apple is likely to launch the new iPad Air lineup around April 2025. Meanwhile, the leaked source code image by Blass indicates that the upcoming iPad Air models and the iPad 11 will feature the M3 chip—removing the possibility of the M4 chip, which was earlier speculated. Additionally, an earlier report by Gurman noted that the new iPad 11 will come with the A17 Pro chip and 8GB of RAM, which will allow these iPads to support the Apple Intelligence features and its AI units. Additionally, the iPad Air is also likely to arrive with a 90Hz display and could include Wi-Fi 7 support, a better mic array, and potentially Apple's own 5G modems, ditching the reliance on Qualcomm's chips. The iPad 11 is also expected to feature improved connectivity with Wi-Fi 6E/7, Bluetooth 5.3, and possibly 5G support. In addition to more improvements and powerful chipsets, the new iPad Air lineup and iPad 11 are also speculated to come with new Magic Keyboards. In one of his newsletters, Gurman shared that Apple is planning to launch a new Magic Keyboard for entry-level iPads. These keyboards will be updated and have some new features adopted from the 2024-launched Magic Keyboard for iPad Pro. This may include a thin and lightweight design with an aluminum palm rest, a larger glass trackpad, and a row of function keys with shortcuts for features like display brightness and volume. All the new iPad Air, iPad 11, and Magic Keyboard models are likely to arrive in Apple’s spring launch, which is possible in late March or early April. Along with the iPad Air refresh, the upcoming launch slot is also expected to bring the new-gen iPad SE—the iPhone SE4—with significant upgrades over its predecessor. With an A18 series chip, support for Apple Intelligence, a 48-megapixel rear camera, and Apple's in-house modem, the new affordable iPhone is expected to deliver an improved experience.

Headline: As Trump delays TikTok ban, China is reportedly working with US to keep TikTok runningPresident Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday seeking to delay by 75 days the enforcement of a ban of popular short-video app TikTok that was slated to be shuttered on January 19.
Content:
President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday seeking to delay by 75 days the enforcement of a ban of popular short-video app TikTok that was slated to be shuttered on January 19. While signing the order, Trump suggested the United States government should be a half owner of TikTok's US business in return for keeping the app alive and warned that he could impose tariffs on China if Beijing failed to approve a US deal with TikTok. China has reportedly given a strong hint that it is ready to secure some deal with the US for TikTok. "When it comes to actions such as the operation and acquisition of businesses, we believe they should be independently decided by companies in accordance with market principles," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said at a press conference. "If it involves Chinese companies, China’s laws and regulations should be observed." Mao noted that TikTok "has played a positive role in boosting US employment and consumption" and asserted that his country is hoping that "the US will earnestly listen to the voice of reason and provide an open, fair, just and non-discriminatory business environment for market entities from all countries." The executive order capped 48 hours of legal maneuvering and political intrigue that left millions of US TikTokkers struggling for answers about the fate of their app. The drama began Saturday when the short video app used by 170 million Americans was taken offline for users shortly before a law that said it must be sold by its Chinese owner ByteDance on national security grounds, or be banned, took effect on Sunday. The next day Trump said he had plans to "Save TikTok". Within hours, the company began restoring its service in the US, thanking the soon-to-be-inaugurated President for providing assurances to TikTok and its business partners that they would not face hefty fines to keep the app running. The app and website were operational on Monday, but TikTok is still not available for download in the Apple, opens new tab and Google app stores. Trump's order, signed hours after he was inaugurated on Monday, mirrors his earlier promises and directs the attorney general to not enforce the law to give his team time "to determine the appropriate course of action with respect to TikTok." But the legality of Trump's executive order is unclear. The law requiring the divestiture was passed by big majorities in Congress, signed by President Joe Biden, and upheld by a unanimous Supreme Court. The law also does not grant Trump authority to extend the deadline unless ByteDance has "binding agreements" to sell TikTok and it is unclear any agreements exist. 
Representative Frank Pallone said Trump's order is "circumventing national security legislation passed by an overwhelming bipartisan majority in Congress." The debate over TikTok comes at a tense moment in US-China relations. Trump has said he intends to place tariffs on China but has also indicated he hopes to have more direct contact with China's leader. While signing the executive order Monday evening, Trump said that he “could see” the US government taking a 50 per cent stake in TikTok and as part of that stake, the US could police the site. Trump added that if a deal isn't approved by China, "there's no value. So if we create that value, why aren't we entitled to like half?" He said the company could be worth hundreds of billions of dollars. The US has never banned a major social media platform. The law passed last year gives the Trump administration sweeping authority to ban or seek the sale of other Chinese-owned apps.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 21, 2025

Headline: iPhone SE 4 is coming with Dynamic Island, new leak suggestsThe iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to launch by March or April 2025. According to a new leak, the upcoming affordable iPhone could have a potential design inclusion that brings it closer to the flagship models.
Content:
The iPhone SE 4 has long been in the rumour mill and is expected to launch soon. The latest leak from tipster Evan Blass brings new information that’s sure to excite Apple fans. In a private social media post, Blass shared some interesting details about Apple’s next affordable iPhone, including hints of a potential design inclusion that brings it closer to the flagship models. According to the leak, a purported image of the iPhone SE 4 showcases the Dynamic Island — a feature that first debuted with the iPhone 14 Pro series and is now standard across the iPhone 15 and iPhone 16 line-up. This could be a solid addition to Apple’s budget line-up, giving it a look and feel that is in line with the current-generation iPhones, compared to the dated design of the iPhone SE, which still features thick bezels and a home button.

Credits: Evan Blass/ X (Twitter)
 Interestingly, Blass also shared what appears to be source code referencing the iPhone SE 4. This puts to rest rumours of the device being called iPhone 16E. However, the name in the code could still be a placeholder, so there’s no official confirmation yet. Apart from the design upgrade, the iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to come with a 6.1-inch OLED display, Face ID, a single 48-megapixel rear camera, and Apple’s latest 5G modem. Under the hood, it could pack an A18 chip and 8GB of RAM, thus having support for features like Apple Intelligence. If true, these updates could finally bring the SE model in line with the top-tier competition.  There’s also speculation about pricing. While the current iPhone SE starts at $429 (Rs 47,600 in India), the added features and design changes might push the price up a notch. Still, it’s expected to remain Apple’s most affordable iPhone. As for the release date, Ming-Chi Kuo has predicted a launch around March or April 2025, following the same timeline as previous SE models. This gives Apple fans plenty of time to speculate and debate whether Dynamic Island will indeed make its way to the SE. In the same leak, Blass also hinted at updates for Apple’s iPad line-up. New 11-inch and 13-inch iPad Air models, along with the next-generation entry-level iPad, could be unveiled in early 2025. The Samsung Galaxy S25 series will likely feature a Snapdragon chipset. This comes from a teaser from Snapdragon itself. This all but confirms that the Galaxy S25 smartphones will be powered by the company’s latest Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset. 
 


Galaxy S25 series pricing in India The Samsung Galaxy S25 series may cost more than the Galaxy S24 series. This is based on a recent leak that suggested that, in Europe, the Galaxy S25 base variant with 128GB storage will be priced at 964 euros, which is approximately Rs 85,000, the 256GB model is expected to cost 1,026 euros (around Rs 91,000), whereas the 512GB one could be priced around 1,151 euros (about Rs 1,01,000). Compared to the Galaxy S24, it launched in India with a price tag of Rs 79,999 for the 256GB variant, and Rs 89,999 for the 512GB model. For the Galaxy S25+, the pricing is expected to start at 1,235 euros, which would be somewhere around Rs 1,09,000 for the 256GB variant, while the highest variant with 512GB storage is said to cost 1,359 euros, which roughly translates to Rs 1,20,000. In comparison, the Galaxy S24+ price in India started at Rs 99,999 for the 256GB variant, while the 512GB model was priced at Rs 1,09,999. As for the Galaxy S25 Ultra, the base model will reportedly be priced starting at 1,557 euros, which in direct conversion would be around Rs 1,38,000, while the price of the top variant with 1TB storage is believed to be as high as Rs 1,70,000 approximately. For perspective, the Galaxy S24 Ultra was priced starting at Rs 1,29,000 for the base variant, and the top model cost Rs 1,59,999. Galaxy S25 series storage options Leaks have also revealed the storage options we can expect on the Galaxy S25 series phone. Reportedly, the Galaxy S25 will come in three storage variants: 128GB, 256GB, and 512GB options. The Galaxy S25+ is believed to skip the 128GB variant this year and come with only the 256GB and 512GB options. The Galaxy S25 Ultra, on the other hand, is rumoured to come in a 512GB and a 1TB variant. Galaxy S25 Slim-ness leaked One of the highlights of the Galaxy Unpacked event is expected to be the much-talked-about Galaxy S25 Slim. And as the name suggests, the device is expected to be the slimmest phone by Samsung yet. A recent leak revealed that the Galaxy S25 Slim will measure a mere 6.4mm in thickness –– that’s if you don’t include the camera module’s protruded thickness. If you include that, it would reportedly measure around 8.3mm. That is still quite impressive considering the  Galaxy S25 Ultra is rumoured to be 8.2mm thick even without the camera bump.Galaxy S25 series pre-reservations Samsung has officially opened the pre-reservations for the Galaxy S25 series devices in India. For a refundable amount of Rs 1,999, customers can pre-reserve their Galaxy S25 ahead of the official launch. Do note, this is not equivalent to pre-booking a device, you will still have to place an order for the device you want. However, this will ensure early access, and will also let you avail some discounts worth up to Rs 5,000. The pre-reservation benefits will be available both at online and offline stores. Headline: Samsung is said to launch 4 foldable phones in 2025Samsung's 2025 lineup of foldables will include the Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7, two expected names that will carry forward the Z-lineup. Alongside these two flagship foldable smartphones, Samsung may launch the Galaxy Z Flip FE. However, the real star of the show this year, though, is expected to be Samsung's first tri-fold device.
Content:
Samsung seems to have big plans for 2025, with reports suggesting that the company will release not two, not three, but four foldable devices. Among these will be its long-rumoured tri-fold phone, which could be the next big thing in the realm of foldable smartphones. Of course, foldables have come a long way since they first hit the market, with improvements in design, durability, and usability. However, the market for foldable phones hasn’t grown as fast as some might have hoped.  According to leaker, Jukanlosreve, citing a report by Korean outlet The Elec, Samsung’s 2025 lineup of foldables will include the Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7, two expected names that will carry forward the Z-lineup. However, there’s talk that the Galaxy Z Fold 7 might lose the S Pen digitiser. This would mean a thinner device, but also a stylus that needs charging — a detail that might divide fans.

 



Source: Jukanlosreve/ X (Twitter)
 Alongside these two flagship foldable smartphones, Samsung may launch the Galaxy Z Flip FE — wherein FE possibly stands for Fan Edition — aimed at making foldables more affordable. This move could help Samsung compete with brands like Motorola and Tecno, which are already offering relatively affordable flip-style foldables. However, the real star of the show this year, though, is expected to be Samsung’s first tri-fold device. This device is said to feature two hinges, which will allow for a much larger display than the Galaxy Z Fold 7. When fully unfolded, the screen could measure between 9.9 and 10 inches — putting it closer to Galaxy Tab space. For comparison, the Galaxy Z Fold 6 has a 7.6-inch inner screen. Production for this ambitious tri-fold phone is rumoured to start in Q2 2025, with a launch expected in Q3. This fits with Samsung’s usual second Unpacked event, typically held in late summer. However, with such a bold new design, there’s a chance it could arrive later than the other foldables. Samsung reportedly plans to produce around 200,000 units of this tri-fold device in 2025, suggesting the company is keeping expectations modest for now. After all, Huawei beat Samsung to the punch last year with the Mate XT, the first tri-fold phone, which had a hefty price tag of nearly CNY 19,999 (roughly Rs 2,37,000). However, Huawei’s offering is only limited to China, while in Samsung’s case, this phone will most likely make a global debut.  With these four devices, 2025 could be a critical year for Samsung to cement its dominance in the foldable segment. What would be the price? We are not sure for now, but, don’t expect it to be light on your pockets.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  OnePlus 13R at Rs 42,999: Top 4 reasons to buy, 1 to skip

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 launching tomorrow: India prices of all models leakedA tipster has leaked the potential India prices of the Samsung Galaxy S25 series models, with a note that the details are from the local retailers. The standard S25 model is said to cost over Rs 85,000 and the Plus model's price will exceed Rs 1 lakh in comparison to the previous generation.
Content:
The Samsung Galaxy S25 series will be announced in India on January 22, which is tomorrow. You can expect to see at least three flagship models at Samsung's biggest tech event of the year. These include Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+ and Galaxy S25 Ultra. While some reports have been claiming that the new Samsung Galaxy S series is set to receive a big price hike, very few leaks suggest that the new devices could be introduced at the same old prices. This has confused a lot of users who have been considering buying the upcoming phones. While we will get the official prices of the Galaxy S25 series at the Samsung Unpacked event, here is a look at the leaked prices of all the upcoming models for the Indian market. advertisementSamsung Galaxy S25 launching tomorrow: India prices of all models leakedTipster Tarun Vats has leaked the potential Indian prices of the Samsung Galaxy S25 series models, with a note that the details are from the local retailers.If we go by the leak, the Samsung Galaxy S25 will come with a starting price of Rs 84,999 for the 12GB RAM + 256GB storage model. The company is also said to offer a 12GB + 512GB model, which is tipped to cost Rs 94,999. Tipster Tarun Vats has leaked the potential Indian prices of the Samsung Galaxy S25 series models, with a note that the details are from the local retailers. If we go by the leak, the Samsung Galaxy S25 will come with a starting price of Rs 84,999 for the 12GB RAM + 256GB storage model. The company is also said to offer a 12GB + 512GB model, which is tipped to cost Rs 94,999. The Samsung Galaxy S25+ might be priced at Rs 1,04,999 for the 12GB RAM + 256GB storage model. The 512GB storage model could be sold at Rs 1,14,999. The Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra will reportedly be on sale with a starting price of Rs 1,34,999 for the 12GB RAM + 256GB storage model. The leak suggests that 16GB + 512GB model could cost Rs 1,44,999, whereas its 1TB storage model could be offered at Rs 1,64,999. Samsung Galaxy S24, S24+, S24 Ultra India prices -Samsung Galaxy S24 price was set at Rs 79,999 (8GB RAM + 256GB storage)
-Galaxy S24+ price started from Rs 99,999 (12GB RAM + 256GB storage)
-Galaxy S24 Ultra was launched at Rs 1,29,999 (12GB RAM + 256GB storage)Is Samsung Galaxy S25 series getting a price hike? With every generation, we have mostly seen a price hike of a few thousand rupees. So, the same could happen with the upcoming models as well, something which the above leak is also suggesting. It says that the price of the Samsung Galaxy S25 series could increase by Rs 5,000 in comparison to the Galaxy S24 series. Because of this, the standard model is said to cost almost Rs 85,000 and the Plus model's price will exceed Rs 1 lakh in comparison to the previous generation.  If we compare the prices of Apple's iPhone 16 Pro models with Galaxy S25+ and Ultra, Samsung is smartly keeping the prices on the lower side. However, if the company manages to retain old prices, it is likely to see better sales because of the greater value proposition that the new devices will be able to offer. Also, the leak suggests that the standard S25 model's price will be more than the iPhone 16, which is likely to make it tough for Samsung to justify the price if there are no big upgrades.  But, these are not the official prices, so people are advised to take these details with a pinch of salt. Also, Samsung is said to bring several upgrades with the upcoming Galaxy S25 series in terms of chipset, AI features, charging, design and a bit in the camera department. So, it remains to be seen whether Samsung will increase the prices of the new models or retain old prices to woo consumers. Content: While the OnePlus 13 is the company’s flagship smartphone, the OnePlus 13R is the perfect choice for those looking for a flagship killer. Headline: iQOO Neo 10R tipped to launch in India soon, may come under Rs 30,000The iQOO Neo 10R is expected to be part of the Neo 10 series, which also includes the Neo 10 and Neo 10 Pro models. The Neo 10R is expected to be iQOO's next smartphone to launch in India for under Rs 30,000.
Content: iQOO could soon introduce its next smartphone in India for under Rs 30,000, as per a recent leak from tipster Paras Guglani. The iQOO Neo 10R is expected to be part of the Neo 10 series, which also includes the Neo 10 and Neo 10 Pro models. Currently, the Neo 10 series is exclusive to China, but the Neo 10R 5G may be the first to make its way to Indian markets, potentially in February 2025. According to the leak, the iQOO Neo 10R is said to feature Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8s Gen 3 chipset and up to 12GB RAM, making it a strong contender in the sub-Rs 30,000 price segment. If the rumours hold true, the Neo 10R could give tough competition to the Motorola Edge 50 Pro and the recently launched Poco X7 Pro. While exact pricing details are not confirmed, the iQOO Neo 10R 5G is expected to fall below the Rs 30,000 mark. This will make it an attractive option for folks who want a phone with top-tier performance without the premium price tag associated with flagship phones. However, it remains unclear if all RAM and storage configurations will fit within this price range. The device is expected to launch in two colours — Blue White Slice (white) and Lunar Titanium (black/ dark grey).  The iQOO Neo 10R is expected to feature a 6.78-inch AMOLED display with a 144Hz refresh rate. The phone could come in two RAM and storage configurations — 8GB + 256GB and 12GB + 256GB. On the software side, it will feature Funtouch OS, possibly Funtouch OS 15 atop Android 15. Under the hood, the device is tipped to house a massive 6,400mAh battery with support for 80W fast wired charging. For photos and videos, the iQOO Neo 10R might offer a dual-camera setup on the back. This could include a 50-megapixel Sony LYT-600 sensor as the primary camera and an 8-megapixel ultra-wide-angle lens. In the front, there could be a 16-megapixel camera for selfies and video calls. Interestingly, iQOO’s Neo series for India has often been rebranded versions of its Chinese counterparts. For example, the Neo 9 Pro in India was a rebranded Neo 9 from China with the Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 chipset, while China’s original Neo 9 Pro used the Dimensity 9300+ chip. Following this trend, the Neo 10 Pro for India could be a rebranded Neo 10 from China powered by the Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 chip.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 21, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Apple's next device could be a wall-mounted device with home control, Siri and FaceTime supportApple is reportedly planning to launch a new smart home device. This device is likely to feature a big display and serve as a home command centre with Apple Intelligence features and Siri integration.
Content: 2025 is said to be a very significant year for Apple device launches. This year, the Cupertino giant is likely to launch around 20 new devices across the year, expanding its ecosystem. One of the highly anticipated devices is a smart digital assistant with a big display. This new device is rumored to allow Apple to expand its offerings in the smart home market and give users a dedicated smart device with a big display to control their smart home devices. According to Mark Gurman, this new smart device—codenamed J490—will feature a wall-mounted design with a big screen that will allow users to control smart devices, do video conferencing, and even offer smart AI-powered apps through Apple Intelligence and Siri for voice assistance. According to Gurman, this new device will feature a 7-inch display and will be squarish in shape, resembling an iPad and as big as two iPhone 16 Pro Max models placed side by side. The device is also said to feature thick bezels and a camera at the top for FaceTime—likely making the device seamlessly integrate with other Apple ecosystem devices.  It will also said to come with a rechargeable built-in battery and internal speakers. To power the device, Apple’s upcoming home device is said to arrive with a new dedicated OS, likely called ‘HomeOS,’ which, according to Gurman, “looks like a blend of the Apple Watch operating system and the iPhone’s recently launched StandBy mode.” Sharing more of the specifications, the report reveals that this new smart home control device from Apple will feature a touch interface similar to the Apple Watch operating system and the StandBy mode released for iPhone with iOS 17. This interface will not only allow users to operate other devices but will also serve as an aesthetic smart device on the wall. This much anticipated Apple device is also said to include adjustment modes that will respond to the distance between the device and the user—for instance, from a distance, the device might show time and updates, but when users come closer, it will offer control functions. All in all, the new smart device from Apple is expected to serve as a smart home hub and security device, including features like speakers to allow users to utilise it as a multipurpose device—whether in the living room, kitchen, or on a desk. Apple has also said to have designed various attachments for its smart home display device, including mounts to affix the screen onto walls. When is Apple launching its new smart display device? According to Gurman, citing sources close to the development, Apple has been working on this smart device for years. In fact, for the past three years, it has been trying to bring it to market. But the launch had been delayed. However, Apple is now likely to launch this new smart home device in March 2025 and introduce it as a command center for the home. The company may offer this new smart device in silver and black colour options.  Meanwhile, it’s not just the smart display that is rumoured. There are also reports about a smart doorbell that Apple is working on, and it might be possible for Apple to launch this display alongside attachments like the doorbell to offer an integrated home control centre. However, it is important to note that all these are speculations, and nothing has been confirmed by Apple as of now. Apple’s current smart home lineup includes the HomePod, HomePod mini, and Apple TV 4K. However, these devices do not support Apple’s latest Apple Intelligence. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 will feature Galaxy AI for free but only until 2025-endThe Samsung Galaxy S25 series will have Galaxy AI at the heart of the phones. While the AI features will be free at the time of launch, according to reports, customers will have to pay for the features after 2025.
Content:
Samsung will be hosting the Galaxy Unpacked event on Wednesday, January 22, at 11.30PM IST. At the event, the company is expected to launch three smartphones: the Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and the Galaxy S25 Ultra. Samsung also unveiled the highly-anticipated Galaxy S25 Slim, but that may only be available some time in May this year. Besides the phones, the South Korean giant may also talk about the next-generation Galaxy Ring. However, at the heart of any device the company launches at the event, will be Galaxy AI.  Galaxy AI is Samsung's own AI tools and software that are embedded across its devices, including smartphones and tablets. It powers several features on the device, like Bixby, Samsung voice assistant, contextual suggestions, image recognition, etc. These features are meant to make the experience on the device more intuitive and smarter. With the Galaxy S24 series, Galaxy AI debuted for the first time and the features and tools were available on the smartphones for free.  However, according to recently leaked marketing material that was first shared by Evleaks, this year, Galaxy AI will be available for free for Galaxy S25 users only until the end of this year. Starting in 2026, users may have to start paying for the features.  With the Galaxy S24, Samsung had promised to make Galaxy AI features available for free for two years. On the basis of that, the report seems legitimate. 
This also means that by 2026, all Samsung users –– whether using the Galaxy S24 smartphones, the Galaxy Z-series foldables or the upcoming Galaxy S25 series –– will no longer have free access to Galaxy AI.  Currently, it is unclear how Samsung will be charging for these features. There is no clarity about whether Galaxy AI will be available on a subscription basis or it will be a suite that you make a one-time purchase for. We will know about it all soon enough though, as the Galaxy Unpacked is just hours away.  As for subscriptions, Samsung is also rumoured to be kicking off its subscription plan for renting out the new Galaxy S25 series. However, this subscription plan is said to be made available only to customers in South Korea for now. Samsung has always offered an AMOLED panel, even with mid-range devices, so the Slim variant won't be an exception.New chipset?
