However, it is currently unknown whether the company is planning to offer this chip in selected markets. We could see Exynos 2400-powered Galaxy S25 Slim in some markets, but nothing is confirmed right now.A flagship camera? Leaked reports suggest the Galaxy S25 Slim might feature a 200-megapixel main camera, similar to the Galaxy S24 Ultra. While it is unclear if additional lenses will fit the device’s slim body, Samsung's upcoming ALoP (All Lenses on Prism) technology could enable a sleeker, thinner build with a good camera setup. Expected to debut at MWC 2025, this tech may allow the Slim to maintain high-end camera performance without compromising its slim design. But, there is no solid information on the camera bit, so users are advised to take the details with a pinch of salt.What could be its price? Will it be positioned in Galaxy S25 series? There is a rumour that the Samsung Galaxy S25 Slim could be a replacement for the Galaxy FE models. On the contrary, there are also reports suggesting that the company could position the new model among the flagship S25 series. It could be similar to what Apple is doing with the Plus model, offering a bigger display and battery compared to the standard iPhone model. Speaking of battery, rumours suggest that the S25 Slim could feature a capacity between 3,000mAh and 4,000mAh. It’ll be interesting to see how well that holds up for a flagship device — assuming this model is indeed being positioned as one. Realistically, the positioning depends on the specs that the Slim version will have and it is too early to talk about this because there are very less details about the smartphone. You can stay tuned to India Today Tech for all the updates.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 21, 2025

Headline: Trump says he is open to Musk buying TikTok if Tesla CEO wants to do soAfter delaying the ban on TikTok for 75 days, the newly appointed US President, Donald Trump stated that he prefers Elon Musk would take over.
Content: US President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he was open to billionaire Elon Musk buying social media app TikTok if the Tesla CEO wanted to do so. The short video app used by 170 million Americans was taken offline temporarily for users shortly before a law that said it must be sold by its Chinese owner ByteDance on national security grounds, or be banned, took effect on Sunday. Bloomberg News reported last week that Chinese officials were in preliminary talks about a potential option to sell TikTok's operations in the United States to Musk, though the company has denied that. Trump on Monday signed an executive order seeking to delay by 75 days the enforcement of the law that was put in place after US officials warned that under Chinese parent company ByteDance, there was a risk of Americans' data being misused. TikTok remained unavailable to download on Apple and Android devices in the United States on Tuesday afternoon. "I would be, if he wanted to buy it," Trump told reporters on Tuesday when asked if he was open to Musk buying the platform. "I have met with owners of TikTok, the big owners," Trump added. "So, what I am thinking about saying to somebody is 'buy it and give half to the United States of America.'" Free speech advocates have opposed TikTok's ban under a law passed by the US Congress and signed by former President Joe Biden. The company says US officials misstated its ties to China, arguing its content recommendation engine and user data are stored in the United States on cloud servers operated by Oracle, while content moderation decisions that affect American users are also made in the US. Musk, who spent more than $250 million to help Trump win November's presidential election, has said there was an "unbalanced" business environment between the US and China. "I have been against a TikTok ban for a long time, because it goes against freedom of speech. That said, the current situation where TikTok is allowed to operate in America, but X is not allowed to operate in China is unbalanced," Musk, who owns social media platform X, said over the weekend.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  As Trump delays TikTok ban, China is reportedly working with US to keep TikTok services runningAlso read |  As Donald Trump unbans TikTok in US, Elon Musk complains about X ban in China: Story in 5 pointsAlso read |  US President Donald Trump signs executive order delaying TikTok ban by 75 days

Headline: Meta will soon let you link WhatsApp with Instagram and Facebook accountsMeta has announced that in the coming months, users will be able to link WhatsApp to their Instagram and Facebook accounts.
Content:
WhatsApp will soon be linked to other Meta’s social media platforms, including Instagram and Facebook. Mark Zuckerberg’s company is working to build a seamless ecosystem, which will sync all three; Instagram, WhatsApp and Facebook. In a post, Meta announced that it is eyeing to integrate WhatsApp into its Account Centre. The change, rolling out globally “over the next few months,” will let WhatsApp users share status updates across Instagram and Facebook, as well as enable a single sign-on. 
 


 Meta states that the WhatsApp link won't be activated automatically, so it's up to you to choose whether to connect WhatsApp to the Account Centre. If you decide to do so, Meta will use your WhatsApp data to "provide, personalise, and enhance its products and services, including showing you ads," as explained on a help page about the update.  Additionally, it further ensures that even after users choose to link their WhatsApp account to the Account Centre, the chats and calls will remain end-to-end encrypted.  In the blog, Meta added that it is working on several such features that work across its apps. For example, the ability to manage avatars, Meta AI stickers and Imagine Me creations will soon be accessible in one place. Meta’s Account Centre  Meta's Account Centre, launched in 2020, is a central hub where users can manage and link their accounts across various Meta platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. It allows you to control settings related to your profile, login credentials, and preferences for cross-platform features like sharing content, messaging, and notifications.  The aim of connecting apps to Account Centre is that you can streamline your experience and manage your social media accounts from one place. How to connect to an Account Centre After you have updated your WhatsApp to the latest version, go to settings menu. Here you will find the option to add your account to Accounts Centre. If it's not available, it might not have rolled out in your region yet.
 


 To link accounts, tap the option, follow the instructions, and log in with your Meta account credentials if prompted. Now, as soon as this feature will be rolled out, you would also have to configure how you want to share updates, such as enabling WhatsApp Status posts on Facebook or Instagram. If you decide to stop using this feature, simply return to settings and unlink WhatsApp from Accounts Centre.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Apple's next device could be a wall-mounted device with home control, Siri and FaceTime supportAlso read  |  As Trump delays TikTok ban, China is reportedly working with US to keep TikTok services runningAlso read |  iPhone SE 4 is coming with Dynamic Island, new leak suggestsMust Watch

Headline: OpenAI announces Stargate Project, will invest $500B to develop AI data centresOracle, Nvidia, and OpenAI have come together to start a new company called the Stargate Project. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman says it will build new AI infrastructure for OpenAI in the United States.
Content:
In a groundbreaking move, at the Trump inauguration, OpenAI on Wednesday announced a new company called the Stargate Project, which is aimed at “building a new AI infrastructure” through an ambitious investment of $500 billion over the next four years. OpenAI announced the new company in a blog post, which also revealed that the Stargate Project will begin deploying an initial $100 billion immediately to build AI data centres for OpenAI in the United States.  Along with OpenAI, the Stargate project is backed by companies like SoftBank, Oracle, and MGX. The initiative will be led by SoftBank and OpenAI. The two companies will also divide responsibilities with SoftBank looking at the finances, and OpenAI handling the operations. As per the blog post, SoftBank’s CEO, Masayoshi Son will serve as chairman of the Stargate Project.   OpenAI has announced other partnerships as well for the Stargate Project. The company will be working with the likes of Arm, Microsoft, NVIDIA, and Oracle for the same. “As part of Stargate, Oracle, NVIDIA, and OpenAI will closely collaborate to build and operate this computing system. This builds on a deep collaboration between OpenAI and NVIDIA going back to 2016 and a newer partnership between OpenAI and Oracle,” OpenAI writes on the blog post.
OpenAI says that the initial construction is going on in Texas. The company is also looking at new sites for future offices.   OpenAI is confident that the company will bring great benefits to the US economy. “This infrastructure will secure American leadership in AI, create hundreds of thousands of American jobs, and generate massive economic benefits for the entire world. This project will not only support the re-industrialisation of the United States but also provide a strategic capability to protect the national security of America and its allies,” the company’s blog post reads. As for Microsoft, the company says that the new project will build on the “existing OpenAI partnership with Microsoft” and that the company will “continue to increase its consumption of Azure”. Microsoft also announced an update on its partnership with OpenAI late Tuesday. The company said that its agreement with OpenAI will stay intact until 2030, which includes Microsoft’s access to OpenAI’s intellectual property, their revenue-sharing arrangements, and exclusive rights to OpenAI’s APIs.   However, there was another significant update announced: There is a shift in Microsoft and OpenAI’s exclusivity agreement for additional capacity. In the blog post, Microsoft has announced that going forward, it will retain the “right of first refusal (ROFR)”, which means Microsoft will have the right of refusal on a new capacity that OpenAI wants to build.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Trump says he is open to Musk buying TikTok if Tesla CEO wants to do soAlso read |  TikTok banned and unbanned within 24 hours, Donald Trump talks of 50 per cent sale: Full story in 5 points

Headline: Samsung may launch its Vision Pro rival alongside Galaxy S25 series: ReportSamsung is expected to launch the Galaxy S25 series at the upcoming Galaxy Unpacked event on January 22, 2025. However, the phones may not be the only devices we see at the launch event.
Content: Samsung is all set to host the Galaxy Unpacked event in San Jose, California, on January 22, 2025. The company is expected to launch the Galaxy S25 series, including the Galaxy S25, S25+, S25 Ultra and possibly the long-rumoured S25 Slim, at the event. However, the phones may not be the only devices we see at the launch event. Reportedly, the company may also unveil its first XR headset, codenamed Project Moohan at the Galaxy Unpacked. This move comes at a time for the XR industry where Apple's Vision Pro launched last year. While generating excitement, it also highlighted areas for improvement in terms of user experience and accessibility.  Samsung, however, seems determined to avoid the same pitfalls with its Vision Pro rival. Project Moohan is being developed in collaboration with tech giants Google and Qualcomm. While Samsung is leading the development, Google is creating a dedicated Android XR operating system, and Qualcomm is lending its expertise to XR platforms. Together, the trio is aiming to address key challenges like comfort and a lack of engaging content, which have hindered the adoption of previous XR devices. At the Galaxy Unpacked event, Samsung is expected to showcase a prototype or possibly a teaser of the XR headset, giving visitors a first look at its capabilities. The headset is expected to hit the market later this year. Reports suggest it will also integrate Google’s generative AI service, Gemini, to offer a smarter and more intuitive user experience. XR technology is clearly on the rise, with Samsung aiming to take a headstart over the competition. But it isn’t alone in this race. Meta, which generated quite an interest with its Ray-Ban smart glasses, is reportedly working on new glasses featuring built-in displays, slated for release later this year. Meanwhile, Sony is set to launch an industrial XR head-mounted display on January 23, developed in collaboration with Siemens. Even Chinese smartphone makers like Vivo are entering the XR space, with plans to roll out devices of their own. Smart glasses are another area Samsung is exploring. Qualcomm previously confirmed that the company is working on XR-powered glasses. While there’s no word on whether Samsung will showcase these at Galaxy Unpacked, their development gives us an idea of the growing potential of wearable technology in the years ahead. Market research indicates that the smart glasses market is gaining momentum, with shipments expected to skyrocket from a few million units today to 20 million by 2030.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: What is JioCoin and how can you earn it for free?JioCoin is a blockchain-based reward token built on Ethereum Layer 2 technology, designed to reward users for their engagement across Jio apps and services.
Content: Reliance Jio recently announced its partnership with Polygon Labs, a leading blockchain technology company, to introduce JioCoin. For those who don’t know, JioCoin is a blockchain-based reward token that users can earn by engaging with different mobile or internet-based Jio apps and services using their Indian-based mobile numbers. The best part — users will be able to redeem their JioCoins across various Jio services. But, the question is, how do you earn JioCoins for free and how to use them? Here is everything you need to know. advertisementHow to earn and use JioCoin?As mentioned above, JioCoin is a blockchain-based reward token built on Ethereum Layer 2 technology and is listed on Polygon, a leading cryptocurrency platform. These tokens are designed to reward users for their engagement across Jio apps and services. The programme is exclusively available for users with Indian-based mobile numbers. While the official value of JioCoin hasn’t been disclosed, speculations suggest it could be around Rs 43 per token. Earning JioCoins is straightforward and revolves around using Jio apps. At the moment, the reward programme is only active on the JioSphere app, a web browser introduced by Jio. However, Jio plans to expand this feature to other apps like MyJio, JioCinema, JioMart, and more. As mentioned above, JioCoin is a blockchain-based reward token built on Ethereum Layer 2 technology and is listed on Polygon, a leading cryptocurrency platform. These tokens are designed to reward users for their engagement across Jio apps and services. The programme is exclusively available for users with Indian-based mobile numbers. While the official value of JioCoin hasn’t been disclosed, speculations suggest it could be around Rs 43 per token.  Earning JioCoins is straightforward and revolves around using Jio apps. At the moment, the reward programme is only active on the JioSphere app, a web browser introduced by Jio. However, Jio plans to expand this feature to other apps like MyJio, JioCinema, JioMart, and more. To start earning JioCoin, users must sign up for the JioCoins programme. This can be done through the profile section of the JioSphere app. For the unaware, JioSphere is a new web browser developed by Jio. It comes with features like personalised content, free VPN, ad blocker, and support for multiple regional languages. It is available on Android, iOS, Windows, Mac, Android TV, and other platforms, making it accessible across devices. Now, once you have signed up for the JioCoins programme, you can start earning JioCoin by performing various activities such as — browsing the web, watching videos and reading articles, playing games, using VPN and incognito mode, adding quick pages or cards to the home screen, searching the internet and customising settings.  As for how to redeem JioCoin, well, the exact details are yet to be fully revealed. JioCoins are expected to be usable across various Jio services. These may include recharging your mobile and broadband connections, grocery shopping on JioMart, OTT subscriptions, and more. In summary, JioCoins is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to explore blockchain technology while earning rewards. So, if you’re a Jio user, it might be worth downloading the JioSphere web browser and giving it a go.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: iPhone 17 Air design leak ahead of September launch: Here is everything we know so farThe leaked iPhone 17 Air design reveals a rectangular camera bump housing a single camera lens. This upcoming model is rumoured to be the slimmest iPhone in the Apple-verse. Let's look at what the leak suggests.
Content:
The iPhone 17 series is anticipated to hit the market globally in September. In 2025, the rumour has it that the company will release a new entry, iPhone17 Air, replacing the Plus model. While there are several speculations doing rounds online, a recent leak shows what the phone might look like. The leak shared on X (formerly Twitter) revealed the alleged rear panel of the iPhone 17 Air. Aligning with the previous rumours and leaks, a tipster, Majin Bu shared images of two of the back panel, featuring a rectangular camera bump. 
 


 In the leak, the tipster shared a hazy image of the alleged iPhone 17 Air's back cover. Even though he posted that it is the design of iPhone 17, the single camera lens indicates otherwise. For a long time now, the standard iPhones have been featuring a dual-camera and the iPhone 17 series is also expected to follow the same. Hence, the single camera lens cut out on the left side of the bar indicates this image belongs to the upcoming iPhone 17 Air. The leaked image also shows a pill-shaped, raised camera bar at the top, which is essentially the revamped design of the iPhone 17 series. The right side appears to house an LED flash and a small microphone opening.  Now, since the launch of iPhone SE 4 or 16e is approaching, X users have been speculating that this leak could also belong to it. And it seems plausible looking at the single-camera lens. However, the design language agrees more with the flagship series. Moreover, the iPhone SE 4 design was also leaked, and it looks a lot different from the iPhone 17 Air. That said, the exact details will only be revealed during the launch, most likely to take place in September. The iPhone SE 4 launch in April should also clear some air around it. iPhone 17 Air: What to expect from the slimmest iPhone Based on the rumours, the iPhone 17 Air is to feature a slim profile with just 5.5mm thickness. If this rumour comes out as the real dimension, the iPhone 17 Air will beat the iPhone 6 (slimmest for now). For this ultraslim design, Apple might cut a few edges, including removal of physical SIM tray, a single camera lens and a smaller battery. It is also interesting to note that the iPhone 17 Air will be in direct competition with the Samsung Galaxy S25 Slim, expected to launch in May.  The iPhone 17 Air is also rumoured to feature a 6.6-inch OLED display with ProMotion technology, enabling a 120Hz refresh rate. If implemented, it will mark the first time Apple extends this feature to non-Pro models, potentially setting a new standard for mid-range devices. The iPhone 17 Air is rumoured to feature a simplified design, highlighted by a single 48-megapixel rear camera—a shift from the dual-lens systems of current models. This streamlined setup is expected to save space and enhance the device's slim profile. On the front, it may include a 24-megapixel TrueDepth camera, delivering double the resolution of its predecessors.   In terms of performance, the iPhone 17 Air is anticipated to be powered by Apple’s A19 chipset, promising greater efficiency and processing power. Additional upgrades are expected to include 8GB of RAM and Apple’s new in-house modem, codenamed “Sinope.”Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Apple could copy Android phones by bringing vapour cooling chamber to iPhone 17Also read |  iPhone 17 Air launching in 2025? A19 chip, 120Hz refresh, slim design and everything we expectAlso read |  Apple is rumoured to release either iPhone SE 4 or iPhone 17 Air in 2025

Headline: Apple says iOS 18.3 will automatically turn on Apple IntelligenceWith iOS 18.3, iPadOS 18.3, and macOS 15.3, Apple Intelligence will be turned on by default. This means that the eligible devices will run on AI-powered features automatically without manually turning it on.
Content:
You no longer need a guide to tune into Apple Intelligence. Apple has recently confirmed that with the upcoming updates of iOS 18, the AI-powered features will be turned on automatically. Starting in iOS 18.3, iPadOS 18.3, and macOS 15.3, the users won't be required to switch the Apple Intelligence features manually, it will be a default configuration. According to the official developer blog, Apple Intelligence will be enabled automatically for users who are upgrading to macOS 15.3 or onboarding to the latest Mac. And it goes the same for eligible iPhones and iPads.  It states, "Users will have access to Apple Intelligence features after setting up their devices. To disable Apple Intelligence, users will need to navigate to the Apple Intelligence & Siri Settings pane and turn off the Apple Intelligence toggle. This will disable Apple Intelligence features on their device." iOS 18.3 launch date The reports indicate that Apple will release a stable version of iOS 18.3 later this month. Now that we are already in the second last week of January, the word is that iOS 18.3 will be launched on January 27 or 28. After iOS 18.3, the company will release the next update, iOS 18.4, in April. iOS 18.4 is expected to be a bigger update. iOS 18.3 and Apple Intelligence: What is coming  The iOS 18.3, iPadOS 18.3, and macOS 15.3 will bring Apple Intelligence to the eligible devices: iPhone 15 Pro models, iPhone 16 series, iPad Pro, iPad Air, iPad Mini, MacBook Air (M1 and later), MacBook Pro, iMac, Mac mini, Mac Studio, and Mac Pro. The upcoming update will bring a pack of new features. Let's look at the new features. 

The latest update introduces new Visual Intelligence features for iPhone 16 models, refines Notification Summaries on all Apple Intelligence-supported devices, and addresses several bugs related to Siri and Apple Music.   - The Visual Intelligence with Camera Control for iPhone 16 models will get a new feature. This feature will let users add events to their Calendar directly from posters or flyers. It will also let users easily identify plants and animals using the camera.   - Notification Summaries feature is also coming in for the eligible iPhones. With this, users will be able to manage notification summary settings directly from the Lock Screen.  The updated design for summarised notifications will include italicised text and a distinct glyph for better differentiation.  The Notification summaries for News & Entertainment apps are temporarily unavailable; users who opt in will regain access when the feature is restored.   Some features may not be available in all regions or on all Apple devices. Headline: Udupi man loses Rs 23.4 lakh after being added to WhatsApp groupA man from Udupi has become the latest victim of the growing online trading scam. The scammers managed to trick him into making large investments after adding him to a WhatsApp group.
Content: In yet another case of an online trading scam, a man from Udupi ended up losing Rs 23.4 lakh after being added to a WhatsApp group. The fake group promised the victim tips and tricks to help him earn good profits in online trading. However, as soon as he invested a large sum of money, the scammers refused to give back his profits or the invested amount. The case involves Baptist Maurice Lobo, who ended up losing money in this online scam. According to The Times of India, Lobo revealed in his complaint that one day a few individuals added him to a WhatsApp group named Aarayaa HSS. In this group, the alleged admins introduced themselves and informed him that the group offers tips and guidance on online trading. The group also had some other members who claimed to be earning good profits from their investments. Thinking it to be a good opportunity to make some easy profits, Lobo got convinced and transferred a total of Rs 21.4 lakh from his and his mother's bank accounts to several accounts shared by the scammers between December 2, 2024, and January 6, 2025. However, when he tried to withdraw his profits, the scammers refused and even cut off contact, leaving the victim to lose both his profits and the invested money altogether. Later, he registered a case at the CEN crime police station.What is an online trading scam? The above case is not the only case of online fraud where individual lost money after being added to a WhatsApp group. In fact, in the past few months, many individuals have fallen for similar investment scams. The method is often the same. Scammers create WhatsApp groups, name them to look like they’re part of some big organisation, and add individuals to these groups. Once people join, the scammers introduce themselves as experts and claim they can help group members earn high profits through online trading. To further convince their targets, the scammers ask them to download an app that they maliciously create. Initially, when individuals invest small amounts, the scammers show fake profits, encouraging them to invest larger sums. But as soon as the victims invest significant amounts, the scammers deny access to withdraw the money or demand additional payments under some pretext. In the end, they cut off all communication, leaving the victims financially drained. We have also explained the scam in details you can read here: First they share tips, then dupe people to steal their money: Online share market scam explainedHow to stay safe To stay safe from such scams, don’t fall for opportunities that sound too good to be true. Investments in the stock market are always subject to risks, and no one can guarantee huge profits, like 500 per cent. If someone claims they can, it’s likely a scam. Also, avoid downloading random apps shared by unknown people. These apps may look genuine but can be malicious and allow hackers to access your device. If you find yourself added to any suspicious investment groups on WhatsApp, block and report the group immediately.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also Read |  Apple's next device could be a wall-mounted device with home control, Siri and FaceTime supportAlso Read |  Apple likely to launch new iPad Air models with M3 chip in April 2025Also Read |  Samsung may launch Galaxy Slim on 22 Jan, but only in selected countries

Headline: Donald Trump says he is okay with Elon Musk buying TikTok: Will the app return to India?President Donald Trump made a big announcement that he is okay with his billionaire supporter Elon Musk or Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison buying TikTok. But, he is not asking these tech leaders to buy this social media platform completely and is suggesting that somebody can buy it and give half to the United States of America.
Content: At a press conference, President Donald Trump announced he is okay with his billionaire supporter Elon Musk or Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison buying TikTok. But, he is not asking these tech leaders to buy this social media platform completely and is suggesting that somebody can buy it and give half to the United States of America. "What I’m thinking about saying to somebody is, buy it, and give half to the United States of America. Half, and we’ll give you the permit. And they will have a great partner, the United States."  "Sounds like a good deal to me, Mr President," Ellison said. So far, Musk hasn't commented on this matter. Also, it is unclear how this joint venture between the Chinese TikTok app and the US government will work.  TikTok hasn't yet responded to the latest comment from Trump, but it recently denied reports of the platform considering a sale to Elon Musk or any other entity.  The latest comments by Trump came after the US Supreme Court upheld a law that bans TikTok in the country unless its China-based parent company, ByteDance, sells the app’s operations. With Trump’s suggestion now in the mix, one question that comes to mind is whether such a deal could influence TikTok’s return to other banned markets like India.Could this deal lead to TikTok’s return to India? While the prospect of Elon Musk buying TikTok is primarily focused on the US market, it has raised questions about whether the deal could make way for TikTok’s return to India, where the app has been banned.  India was one of the first major markets to ban TikTok, citing concerns over data privacy and national security. The ban, which was imposed in June 2020, saw TikTok removed from app stores and millions of users cut off from the platform.  For TikTok to return to India, several hurdles would need to be cleared. First and foremost, the Indian government would need to be convinced that the app no longer poses a risk to the country’s data privacy laws. With the possibility of Elon Musk or any other American entity owning a big stake in TikTok, there could be an argument that the app’s ties to the Chinese government are sufficiently weakened, potentially satisfying Indian authorities. However, there is no indication yet that the Indian government is reconsidering its stance on TikTok. India’s Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology has not made any statements regarding the app’s potential return, and the ban remains in place. Additionally, in the recent past, India has promoted domestic alternatives to TikTok, such as Chingari and Moj, which have tried to fill the void left by TikTok’s departure. The government’s "self-reliant" digital push makes it uncertain whether a foreign entity, even one partially owned by an American, could easily re-enter the Indian market. Moreover, while TikTok was immensely popular in India before the ban, re-entering the market would require the company to rebuild trust and assure the Indian government and public that user data would not be compromised. TikTok’s previous issues with data handling and its alleged links to the Chinese government continue to cast a shadow over any discussions about its return.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Google Pixel 8 available at nearly half its launch price: How to get the offerThe Google Pixel 8's 128GB variant is selling at a price under Rs 50,000. Here is how you can get the discount.
Content: The Google Pixel 8 is currently available on Flipkart at its lowest-ever price –– under Rs 50,000. This offer is available on the 128GB variant of the phone. As per the listing on the e-commerce website, there is a flat discount of Rs 26,000 available, which brings the price of the Pixel 8 down to Rs 49,999. However, if you use an HDFC Bank credit card and buy the smartphone on EMI transactions, you can get an additional Rs 3,000 off on the phone’s purchase. Which means, the phone’s price comes down to Rs 46,999 effectively.  Additionally, there are exchange offers available up to Rs 35,000 that can further bring down the price of the phone. For instance, at the time of writing the story, we checked the exchange price for a Pixel 7 which is in good condition. For that, you can get up to Rs 13,365 in exchange. This means, if you do end up getting that amount at the time of exchange, the price of the phone eventually comes down to around Rs 33,000. In case you have an old smartphone that you do not have a use for, we recommend you format and factory reset your device, save any and all the data you need from it, and then consider an exchange. It is a great way to save some extra money on a phone purchase.  Notably, in August 2024, Google also officially announced a price cut for the Pixel 8 series and the Pixel 7a. The Pixel 8, in particular, received a considerable price drop. Its base variant with 128GB, which was launched in India at Rs 75,999 had a price revision to Rs 71,999. The 256GB model of the phone was earlier priced at Rs 82,999 and its price was brought down to Rs 77,999 after the price cut.  However, with the currently ongoing offer on Flipkart, the pricing of the Pixel 8 is even lower than that of the Pixel 8a after the price cut in August.  And if you are wondering if the Pixel 8 is still a good choice with the Pixel 9 launched last year, and the Pixel 10 series due for October 2025, we think the phone is still worth considering. In our review of the Pixel 8, we found that the device not only “looks good”, it also has a “fast processor, [and an] amazing camera”. At the time of our review, the only thing we thought that could hold back a purchase of the phone was its steep pricing. However, with the recent price cut and the current discount, the phone will be absolutely worth the money. Headline: iOS 18.3 latest update brings new features for Visual Intelligence on iPhone 16iOS 18.3 latest beta update brings a mix of new features and improvements, including updates to Visual Intelligence on the iPhone 16 and changes to the Apple Intelligence notification summaries.
Content: Apple is expected to release the stable iOS 18.3 update to the public soon. Before that, the Release Candidate (RC) update is now available for developers and public beta testers. The update, which follows iOS 18.2, brings a mix of new features and improvements, including updates to Visual Intelligence on the iPhone 16 and changes to the Apple Intelligence notification summaries. One of the standout features of the iOS 18.3 RC beta release is to make Visual Intelligence better. Initially introduced with iOS 18.2 for the iPhone 16 and 16 Pro, Visual Intelligence allows users to long-press the Camera Control button to access an AI-powered camera mode, which works similar to how Google Lens does.  With iOS 18.3, Visual Intelligence is getting two new useful features: — Calendar Integration: When your iPhone detects dates on posters or flyers, you can instantly add them to your calendar with a simple action. — Plant and Animal Identification: Visual Intelligence can now identify plants and animals, making it a handy tool for nature enthusiasts. These features, which Apple has demonstrated before, are now becoming widely available. For example, being able to add events to your Calendar app straight from your camera is a practical addition, especially for people who often attend events or meetings. Similarly, the plant and animal identification feature could be a fun way to learn more about your surroundings. Currently, Visual Intelligence works by pulling information from platforms like ChatGPT and Google, but Apple’s focus on tying it into its native apps like Maps and Calendar shows a clear direction for this feature.  Beyond Visual Intelligence, iOS 18.3 also addresses some key concerns with Apple Intelligence notification summaries. Following criticism from outlets like the BBC over misinformation being spread through these summaries, Apple has taken a step back. In the iOS 18.3 RC release, notification summaries for the News & Entertainment category of apps have been temporarily disabled. Users will also notice that summaries now feature italicised text to help distinguish them from regular notifications. Additionally, you can now disable notification summaries for individual apps directly from the lock screen, offering more control over what you see. Apple has also made it clear that the notification summaries feature is still in beta and may have errors.  Alongside the Visual Intelligence upgrades and notification changes in iOS 18.3, the update also includes bug fixes, such as one for the Calculator app. The public release is expected later this month.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Netflix increases prices of its subscription plans, but you don't need to worry about it yetNetflix has increased the prices of all its plans in US and other countries to improve its platform. However, the prices haven't hiked for Indian users yes.
Content: Netflix has again announced an increase in prices across all its subscription plans in several countries, including the United States, Canada, Portugal, and Argentina. The new pricing was revealed through the company’s latest Q4 2024 earnings report. According to Netflix, the increased prices align with the company's efforts to maximise revenue while continuing to invest in its programming and platform improvements. In the United States, Netflix has increased the Standard plan with ads to $7.99 per month, up from $6.99. The price of the Standard plan, offering ad-free 1080p HD video, has also risen from $15.49 to $17.99 per month. Meanwhile, the Premium plan, the only option supporting 4K streaming, has been increased from $22.99 to $24.99. Similar price adjustments are expected for Netflix users in other countries, including Canada. Netflix has cited these new price revisions as part of its efforts to improve its platform. “As we continue to invest in programming and deliver more value for our members, we will occasionally ask our members to pay a little more so that we can reinvest to further improve Netflix. To that end, we are adjusting prices today across most plans in the US, Canada, Portugal, and Argentina (which was already factored into the 2025 guidance we provided in October 2024),” the company said in its report.  Notably, the increase in Netflix's prices comes just over a year after the company not only raised the cost of its Standard and Premium plans but also introduced a new ad-supported plan. With the new ad-supported plan, Netflix removed the Basic ad-free plan, requiring users to either pay more for an ad-free experience or opt for the ad-supported tier, in an effort to increase revenue through both subscriptions and ad revenue. However, the new price hike does not apply to Indian users. For now, Indian users can continue using Netflix with the currently available subscription plans. For context, in India, Netflix offers four plans – Mobile, Basic, Standard, and Premium. The Mobile plan is priced at Rs 149 per month and offers fair video quality with 480p resolution. However, the plan only supports one device, either a mobile or tablet, at a time within a household. The Basic plan is priced at Rs 199 in India, offering 720p resolution and support for TV, computer, mobile, and tablet devices. However, only one device can stream at a time within a household. The Standard plan is priced at Rs 499 and offers 1080p HD resolution. It supports all devices and allows two devices to stream simultaneously within a household. Lastly, the Premium plan is priced at Rs 649 per month, offering 4K resolution, spatial audio, and support for up to four streaming devices simultaneously within a household. At any time, content can be downloaded on up to seven devices.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also Read |  Udupi man loses Rs 23.4 lakh after being added to WhatsApp groupAlso Read |  Apple's next device could be a wall-mounted device with home control, Siri and FaceTime supportAlso Read |  Apple likely to launch new iPad Air models with M3 chip in April 2025

Headline: Truecaller finally adds live caller ID on iPhones: How to enable the featureFor years, Truecaller just did not make sense on iPhones because its key features, the live caller ID, never worked on iOS. But that has finally changed.
Content: Truecaller is a popular app among Android users. However, on iOS, the app has made very little sense. That is because the most critical feature that Truecaller offers, which is the live caller ID, was never available on iPhones. You could search for a number in the app later on, but you never got notified who was calling, in real time. That has now finally changed. Truecaller on Wednesday announced that its live caller ID feature is now available on iPhones. advertisementTruecaller finally works on iPhonesTruecaller CEO Alan Mamedi announced the arrival of the feature back in September 2024. He had said that he hopes that people will soon say:“Truecaller finally works on iPhones”. While it is definitely a welcome update to the Truecaller app, it is interesting to see if this would really boost the app’s adoption, considering Apple launched its own caller ID lookup feature that automatically suggests who could be calling. That said, Apple uses data from your messages and mails to offer a caller suggestion. However, Truecaller has a much larger database of phone numbers and IDs, so if you are using Truecaller, you would get a much more accurate caller ID suggestion.  Truecaller CEO Alan Mamedi announced the arrival of the feature back in September 2024. He had said that he hopes that people will soon say:“Truecaller finally works on iPhones”.  While it is definitely a welcome update to the Truecaller app, it is interesting to see if this would really boost the app’s adoption, considering Apple launched its own caller ID lookup feature that automatically suggests who could be calling. That said, Apple uses data from your messages and mails to offer a caller suggestion. However, Truecaller has a much larger database of phone numbers and IDs, so if you are using Truecaller, you would get a much more accurate caller ID suggestion.  Additionally, with the rollout of the feature, Truecaller says that iPhone users will also be able to take advantage of the feature that automatically blocks spam calls. Truecaller on iOS will now also allow users to search for previously identified calls, letting them go as far back as 2,000 previous numbers in the recent list on the Phone app.  Notably, the number search and caller ID features will be available for Truecaller Premium users. However, if you are a free user on iOS, you can still use the feature, but you will see ads while using the feature. Auto-blocking of spam is already available to all users globally. The new Caller ID feature will be rolled out starting January 22.How to enable caller ID on Truecaller iOS app? To enable the caller ID feature on Truecaller iOS app, you need to first ensure that your iPhone is running iOS 14.0 or later. Then, open iPhone Settings, head to Apps, then Phone, then Call Blocking & Identification. Here, you need to enable all Truecaller switches and open the Truecaller app again. And you are set. The rest of the setup happens automatically. Headline: Marshall Willen II review: Small but mighty The Marshall Willen II is the smallest and most affordable speaker from the company. And despite the size, the speakers are able to deliver the signature Marshall sound. So what we have is good sound and great price — but is it perfect? Well, almost.
Content:
I absolutely love the new Marshall Willen II. Yes, those are some big words to start off a review, but I have my reasons for saying so. This new Bluetooth speaker from Marshall is cute, compact, lightweight, and offers balanced sound while smoothly juggling between highs and mids, and hitting the treble just right. In fact, this is one of the best portable — like really portable — Bluetooth speakers you can buy right now. However, it costs Rs 12,499.    Now, if you are a Marshall fan, or aspire to own a Marshall speaker, you might even think it’s affordable –– considering the usual prices of Marshall products –– but if you look at alternatives in general, you might be able to get a more affordable option too. For instance, you can get a JBL Go 4 Ultra, which is around Rs 4,000 and just as compact –– may be even lighter than this. But here is the thing, if you can shell out the money, we would still recommend the Marshall Willen II, and here is why.   But before I get into the whys and whats of the speaker, let’s take a quick look at its specifications.    The Willen II features the classic Marshall design. It is dust- and waterproof with an IP67 rating, which means the device can handle accidental water splashes or even a dip in a pond. The Willen II also comes with a microphone, so you can take calls on the speaker. It has a square body. And like I said it’s quite portable. It is 10.05 cm thick, 4.34 cm tall, and weighs 0.36 kg. It has a flexible strap at the back which can be used to hold the device. Or you can detach it from one end and strap it to your belt or table or chair.   Small but tough    Design is one of the highlights of the Willen II –– and full marks for that. I reviewed the black variant. Its design is similar to traditional Marshall speakers — a leatherette finish with a grille on the front and the Marshall logo in matte gold. While you would usually see compact speakers made in a rectangular shape, the Willen II’s square built makes it more portable. In fact, I’ve been carrying the device in my pocket while traveling.  
 


 In spite of being lightweight, you don’t see Marshall compromising on the build quality of the speakers. It feels sturdy, and sports IP68 rating, which means good overall durability.    I like my black variant, but after using it for about 10 days, I feel the other cream colour variant could be a better choice. That is because the black finish attracts a lot of dust. While it is easy to clean the rest of the body of the speaker, the grille is a bit tricky.   
 


As for controls, there’s a Type-C port on its left. On top, you’ll find controls like the power button, Bluetooth pairing, microphone, and a battery indicator (which uses a red LED). When you see the device, you will notice there is no dedicated pause or volume button on it. The Willen II features a tiny joystick on the top corner of the grille. It lets you pause, play, control volume, or skip tracks forward.  While the little button adds a touch of style, it can be a bit tricky to use, as it’s partially embedded into the Willen II’s body. Pausing or playing music is simple, but toggling it to the side might be slightly tough — especially for those with longer nails or fatter fingers (no offence intended).  Other than that, the design of the Willen II is quite good. It matches Marshall’s signature experience and turns heads wherever you go. 
 


advertisement Sounds right   Talking about being a headturner, the speaker’s sound gets big credits for that. The Marshall Willen II offers balanced sound. I listened to a lot of hits, including Die With a Smile by Bruno Mars and a LOT of Coldplay songs — I had to make up for missing the Coldplay concert in some way. The speaker was also used at all the house parties at my place in the last 10 days. And during this time, I found that the speaker sounds just right, regardless of the genre of music you are listening to. It lacks a bit of bass though. I would have also liked to see more equaliser controls in the app. But the default sound output is pleasant.   
 


Volume is also decent, especially for casual listening. In a crowded room, however, you may find yourself wanting an option for higher volume.   advertisementBattery is another highlight. Every weekend since I got the device, I would charge it just once on a Friday and that sorted my entire weekend. Of course, I didn’t play continuously for 42 hours, but it ran for no less than 15 hours. It could have gone another one hour, I think, but I think 15 hours of playtime on a single charge is still pretty good. Charging speed of the Willen II is also quite fast, it gets powered up in around two hours.  
 


Marshall Willen II review: Should you buy it?   If you want to experience the Marshall signature sound without spending on the signature Marshall price tags, Willen II is a speaker to consider. And if you are in the market for something compact and portable, then you have really hit the jackpot with the Willen II.   The speakers offer a tiny build without compromising on sound. It is lightweight, easy to carry, and fits easily in a handbag or pockets. The sound is great, the battery life is long, and the app offers a bit of extra control.   advertisementHowever, if you are someone who likes bass-heavy music, then the Willen II might not be the right pick for you. The speakers may also not be the right choice for loud house parties with large crowds.   As for the price, it’s not cheap for sure but it also offers an experience that cheaper alternatives from brands like Boult or Boat do not. Headline: Oppo Find N5 aka OnePlus Open 2 will feature 50W fast wireless charging, company confirmsAlong with being touted as the slimmest foldable smartphone and also featuring an IPX9 rating for water resistance — the Oppo Find N5 aka OnePlus Open 2 is also confirmed to feature 50W fast wireless charging.
Content: Oppo’s upcoming foldable smartphone, the Find N5 aka the OnePlus Open 2, is expected to be the thinnest foldable smartphone ever made, even thinner than the current title holder of the thinnest foldable device — the Honor Magic V3. Earlier this week, Oppo even confirmed the device’s impressive IPX9 rating for water resistance — which will be a first for any foldable smartphone. Now, Zhou Yibao, Head of Oppo’s Find series, has announced that the Find N5 will support wireless charging — something its predecessor, the Find N3, lacked. According to Zhou Yibao, the wireless charging speed on the Oppo Find N5 will max out at 50W, a feature that puts it in direct competition with Huawei’s Mate X6 and Honor’s Magic V3, which also offer similar charging speeds. However, what sets the Find N5 apart is its design. Rumours suggest it could become the thinnest foldable phone in the world to feature such fast wireless charging. If true, it would break the current record held by the Honor Magic V3, which measures 9.4mm when folded and 4.4mm when unfolded. For context, Samsung’s Galaxy Z Fold 6 and Google’s Pixel 9 Pro Fold lag far behind in wireless charging speeds, offering only 15W and 7.5W respectively. This should give Oppo, and probably even OnePlus too, a significant edge, particularly in markets where Huawei and Honor’s foldables aren’t available. Yibao also shared that the Find N5 will support in-car wireless charging and reverse wireless charging, though the latter’s exact charging speed hasn’t been confirmed yet. Apart from wireless charging, the Oppo Find N5 will come with several standout features. The foldable smartphone will come with an IPX9 rating, which ensures protection against water and introduces an underwater photography mode. The phone will reportedly be powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset, paired with 16GB RAM. For those who prefer traditional charging methods, the phone is expected to support 80W fast wired charging. The OPPO Find N5 is set to launch in China next month, probably after the Spring Festival celebrations conclude. The foldable smartphone is expected to debut globally as the OnePlus Open 2. For reference, the OnePlus Open, which was a rebranded version of the Oppo Find N3, launched in India for Rs 1,39,999 (16GB RAM + 512GB storage) in October 2023. A 1TB storage version of the phone was also launched last year in August, priced at Rs 1,49,999.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S26 Ultra tipped to feature a massive periscope camera upgradeEven before the Galaxy S25 series went official, leaks around the Galaxy S26 series have started circulating. The latest rumour suggests Samsung is said to use a 200-megapixel periscope telephoto camera on the next-generation Galaxy S26 Ultra.
Content: Samsung is all set to unveil the Galaxy S25 series to the world at the Galaxy Unpacked event in San Jose, California, on January 22, 2025. However, even before the upcoming devices have become official, rumours around the next-generation Galaxy S26 series have started popping up. Reportedly, the South Korean tech giant is planning some big upgrades, including advanced camera features and the latest battery technology.  One of the most exciting details comes from a new leak on Weibo by tipster DigitalChatStation. According to the source, Samsung is said to use a 200-megapixel periscope telephoto camera with a 1/1.5-inch sensor. To put this into perspective, the Vivo X200 Pro already features a 200-megapixel periscope telephoto camera with a slightly larger 1/1.4-inch sensor. If Samsung moves forward with this idea, the Galaxy S26 Ultra — possibly rebranded as the S26 Note — could see a big upgrade in zoom capabilities compared to its predecessors. Currently, the Galaxy S24 Ultra uses a 50-megapixel periscope lens with 5x optical zoom and a 10-megapixel telephoto lens with 3x optical zoom. The upcoming Galaxy S25 Ultra is rumoured to feature a similar setup. DigitalChatStation also hinted that three out of five flagship smartphones launching this year might feature a 200-megapixel periscope telephoto camera, suggesting this could be a growing trend. Another major development is the rumoured use of silicon-carbon battery technology. Samsung is reportedly working on finally adopting silicon carbon batteries for the Galaxy S26 series. For those who don’t know, silicon carbon batteries offer higher energy density, allowing for larger capacities without increasing the device’s bulk. We have already started seeing this latest battery technology in many high-end flagship phones, such as the recently launched Vivo X200 series, OnePlus 13 and more. Even the recently launched Poco X7 Pro — a sub-Rs 30,000 smartphone — features a 6,550mAh silicon carbon battery under the hood.  Apart from the camera and battery upgrades, Samsung is also said to be exploring improvements in display technology. The Galaxy S26 Ultra might use Colour-filter-on-thin-film-encapsulation (CoE) technology, which could reduce screen thickness while enhancing light transmittance. This would likely contribute to a more immersive viewing experience along with having a relatively slimmer profile compared to current generation models. Interestingly, Samsung’s naming conventions might also see a shake-up. Rumours suggest that the Ultra model could be renamed as the Galaxy Note, while the Plus variant might become the Galaxy Pro. If this happens, the Galaxy S26 lineup could consist of the Galaxy S26, S26 Pro, and S26 Note.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Airtel revises 2 popular prepaid recharge plans, check out latest benefitsAirtel has revised two of its popular prepaid recharge plans at the start of 2025. The updates reportedly focus on providing Special Tariff Vouchers (STVs) with voice and SMS benefits, but data offerings have been scaled back.
Content: Airtel has revised two of its popular prepaid recharge plans at the start of 2025, a move which likely has been taken to align with a recent directive from the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI). The updates reportedly focus on providing Special Tariff Vouchers (STVs) with voice and SMS benefits, but data offerings have been scaled back. Here is everything you need to know about it. Airtel has a Rs 509 prepaid recharge plan, which is the company's old pack but the benefits have been refreshed. The plan is still valid for 84 days and it now targets users who mainly require voice calls with no cap and a lot of SMS benefits, with no mobile data benefits. It comes with unlimited voice calls and 900 SMS. Earlier, this plan also included 6GB of data, but the updated pack has removed it. Airtel users will still get additional perks like free access to the Airtel Xstream app, Apollo 24/7 Circle membership, and Hello Tunes. Those who also need some data can consider buying the Rs 569 Airtel prepaid plan as this one comes with 6GB of mobile data along with the same voice and SMS benefits. Now, the second Airtel prepaid recharge plan that has been revised is its Rs 1,999 annual pack. While it continues to provide unlimited voice calls and 3,000 free SMS, the 24GB of mobile data previously included has been removed. Users of this plan can still enjoy extra services such as the Airtel Xstream app, Apollo 24/7 Circle membership, and Hello Tunes. The changes are in response to TRAI’s mandate that requires operators to offer STVs meant for voice and SMS services. This means that the new Airtel plans, while offering strong voice and SMS benefits, now come with fewer data options, requiring customers to purchase separate data packs if needed. One can also simply consider buying other packs that offer unlimited benefits. Additionally, charges for SMS beyond the free limit are set at Rs 1 for local and Rs 1.5 for STD.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Android 16 first beta releasing in January? Here is everything we knowGoogle is reportedly planning for an early beta release of its upcoming Android 16 by January 2025. The new OS upgrade will introduce features like revamped notifications, adaptive refresh rate improvements, and enhanced security.
Content:
Google is planning to release the first beta of its new-gen OS update– Android 16, by the end of January 2025. The tech giant is reportedly pushing the annual beta testing for the OS update early to make the final release all set to roll in May 2025– around the time of developer’s conference. With the upcoming Android 16 Google promises to bring users a host of new features and improvements, including revamped notifications, better adaptive refresh rate support, and more. According to a report by the Android Authority, Google plans to release the first beta build of Android 16 in January, with subsequent beta updates rolling out between February and March. This timeline reportedly matches Google’s plan to push the stable release by May 2025– certainly before the launch of the new flagship Pixel 10 launch. According to the reports, Google is said to be following this timeline:
January 22, 2025: First beta release.
February 19, 2025: Second beta release.
March 12, 2025: Third beta release.
May 2025: Stable version launch, possibly coinciding with Google I/O 2025.
 The early cycle of beta releases is likely due to the launch of the Pixel 10 series, expected in August 2025. Notably, the latest Pixel 9, which was launched in August 2024 was shipped with the older OS Android 14 as Android 15 was delayed. However, this year, Google is planning to bring the new flagship pre-installed with the latest OS update. Right now, Android 16 is in early beta and available for developers to test upcoming features on supported Pixel devices.What’s new in Android 16? While not all features have been revealed, the early betas have confirmed and hinted at several exciting updates for Android 16. Upgraded lock screen notifications: One of the most anticipated updates in Android 16 is the introduction of a "Compact" notification view for the lock screen. This feature, discovered by Android expert Mishaal Rahman, allows users to collapse all notifications into a small pill below the clock, showing only app icons. Tapping the pill expands the notification list, giving users a cleaner and more organised lock screen. Embedded Photo picker: Android 16 is also set to improve the embedded photo picker, reportedly enabling better integration with cloud media providers. The new feature will allow users to search for images directly within the picker, making it easier to upload photos to apps. Health records integration: Building on the success of Health Connect, Android 16 is also reportedly introducing support for Electronic Health Records (EHRs) in the Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) standard. This feature will let users access and manage health data securely, though functionality remains limited for now. Improved adaptive refresh rate support: Google introduced Adaptive Refresh Rate (ARR), with Android 15. Now in the new OS update, the company is bringing improvements to this feature. Google is reportedly introducing new APIs to make it easier for developers to optimise apps for ARR, offering smoother visuals and improved power efficiency on supported devices. Security features: Just like every year, the new OS Android 16 also includes new security features. This year, improving the security, Google is strengthening Wi-Fi location services, using the 802.11az standard. This will enable more accurate and secure proximity-based applications, like unlocking devices or vehicles. Writing tools API: A new Writing Tools API is also included in Android 16, letting app developers disable AI writing tools in specific contexts, such as password fields or numerical inputs, ensuring better accuracy and security in user interactions.Android 16 early access for Pixel users Right now, Pixel device owners can try out Android 16 early through the beta program. Google will release a full list of supported devices closer to the official release date. However, interested users can enrol in the beta program can explore the new features and provide feedback to Google before the stable release.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 22, 2025Also Read |  Marshall Willen II review: Small but mightyAlso Read |  Netflix increases prices of its subscription plans, but you don't need worry about it yetAlso Read |  Udupi man loses Rs 23.4 lakh after being added to WhatsApp group

Headline: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 price drops by Rs 46,009 without conditionsCroma is offering a big discount offer of Rs 46,009 on the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5, making it an attractive deal for anyone eyeing a premium foldable phone. This is notable as the Galaxy Z Fold 5 is currently one of the top foldable devices available in India.
Content: Croma is offering a big discount offer of Rs 46,009 on the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5, making it an attractive deal for anyone eyeing a premium foldable phone. This is notable as the Galaxy Z Fold 5 is currently one of the top foldable devices available in India. It is known for its slim design, good performance, and convenient multitasking features. If you're looking to own a flagship foldable, this is probably the best time to get one, as discounts of this scale on Samsung's high-end models are quite rare.advertisementSamsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 gets big discount, deal explainedThe Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 is currently listed on Croma with a starting price tag of Rs 108,990 for the 256GB storage model. This is down from its original launch price of Rs 1,54,999. This reveals that the platform is giving a flat discount of Rs 46,009.Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5: Reasons to buy or skip this dealThe Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 is a good option for those who want both a flagship smartphone and a mini-tablet-like experience in one device. With the latest Rs 46,000 discount offer, the deal has become quite attractive for those who could not buy it last year after the launch as the device was a bit expensive.  The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 is currently listed on Croma with a starting price tag of Rs 108,990 for the 256GB storage model. This is down from its original launch price of Rs 1,54,999. This reveals that the platform is giving a flat discount of Rs 46,009.Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5: Reasons to buy or skip this deal The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 is a good option for those who want both a flagship smartphone and a mini-tablet-like experience in one device. With the latest Rs 46,000 discount offer, the deal has become quite attractive for those who could not buy it last year after the launch as the device was a bit expensive.  One common concern when buying a foldable phone is the fear of it breaking easily. However, the same risk exists with traditional smartphones if they are dropped from a certain height onto a hard surface. But, Samsung's Galaxy Z Fold 5 has a strong hinge and a durable design. Additionally, you will hardly notice creases on the inner display, which Samsung has improved with every generation. It is also not that bulky and you can easily use it as your daily driver. The device even has an IPX8 rating, which makes it resistant to water immersion up to 1.5 meters for 30 minutes. So, you don't have to worry about everyday spills or accidental splashes. Although, it doesn’t have dust resistance. It features a massive 7.6-inch AMOLED inner screen, which offers rich colours and refreshes at 120Hz for a smoother scrolling experience. One of the interesting parts is that the camera is incorporated under the inner display. You can just unfold the device to watch a movie or video on the bigger screen. You can also use the device in laptop or tent mode. You can switch to the outer 6.2-inch cover screen anytime if you want to use the phone as a regular smartphone.   When the device is partially folded in laptop mode, apps like the camera or video players automatically adapt their interface, with controls appearing on the lower half of the screen, while the content remains on the top. It’s a smart use of the folding design and makes the device feel more comfortable to use. The software is well-optimised for multitasking, allowing you to run up to three apps simultaneously on the inner display with quick app-switching and window-resizing options. The Edge Panel lets you quickly access apps and drag them onto the screen, making multitasking intuitive and fluid. App Continuity is another standout feature — if you’re using an app on the outer display and unfold the device, the app transitions to the larger screen without any issue. The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 5 uses a Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 chip. While this is 2 generation older flagship chipset, it is still a capable chipset and will offer users a fast performance. But, people who require raw power should maybe buy the Z Fold 6 model or consider buying the Galaxy S24 Ultra for better performance gains. Despite its slim profile, the Galaxy Z Fold 5 houses a 4,400mAh battery, which may seem small for such a large dual-display device, but Samsung has done an excellent job optimising battery efficiency. With the Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 processor and better power management in One UI, the phone can comfortably last through a day of average use, with close to 8-9 hours of screen time. The heavy users might need a top-up by the evening. Also, Samsung doesn't bundle a charger with its phone and this one has support for 25W wired charging, which takes about 30 minutes to fully charge the device.  Foldables often have to compromise on camera performance to fit all the folding mechanics, but Samsung hasn’t skimped here. The Galaxy Z Fold 5 sports a triple-camera setup on the rear with a 50-megapixel primary sensor, 12-megapixel ultra-wide, and 10-megapixel telephoto lens, which delivers excellent results. The main sensor is capable of capturing sharp, detailed images, even in challenging lighting conditions, with good dynamic range and colour accuracy. The 10-megapixel telephoto sensor offers 3x optical zoom, which is solid for a foldable, and the ultra-wide lens is good for capturing landscapes or group shots. You can expect to get good low-light shots as well with the Samsung phones with the output having decent details, good colours, enough sharpness and almost no noise. The 4-megapixel under-display camera on the inner screen is less impressive, but it serves its purpose for video calls or occasional selfies when using the large display. The outer 10-megapixel front camera on the cover display is more reliable for everyday selfies and video calls. All-in-all, it is a great deal for foldable phone lovers.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 series launched: Price, full specs, featuresThe Samsung Galaxy S25 series has finally launched in India. The latest Samsung Galaxy S25 series comes with a starting price of $799 (around Rs 69,000) in the US. The India prices of the new flagship phones are still under wraps, but you can check out the specs below.
Content:
The Samsung Galaxy S25 series has finally launched in India. The company has announced three models, a standard, Plus and Ultra. The Galaxy S25 Slim — which was heavily rumoured — hasn't been teased. This suggests that Samsung might be keeping it under wraps only to surprise you later. The latest Samsung Galaxy S25 series comes with a starting price of $799 (around Rs 69,000) in the US. The Galaxy S25+ will cost $999, whereas the Galaxy S25 Ultra is priced at $1,299. The India prices of the new flagship phones are still under wraps, but you can check out the specs below.advertisementSamsung Galaxy S25 Ultra: Full specsThe new Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra takes a big step forward with upgrades in design, performance, and functionality. Starting with its display, the phone features a larger 6.9-inch screen, up from 6.8 inches in previous models, with more rounded edges that move away from the sharper Galaxy Note design. Despite this, the Ultra is lighter, weighing just 218 grams, while still housing the same 5,000mAh battery that has powered Ultra models since the Galaxy S20 Ultra.One of the standout improvements is in the camera system. The 200MP primary sensor is now accompanied by a 50MP ultra-wide camera, replacing the 12MP sensor used in earlier models. There’s also a 50MP telephoto lens with 5x optical zoom and a secondary 10MP telephoto camera with 3x optical zoom. The 12MP front-facing camera remains unchanged but it is expected to offer better performance for selfies and video calls. The new Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra takes a big step forward with upgrades in design, performance, and functionality. Starting with its display, the phone features a larger 6.9-inch screen, up from 6.8 inches in previous models, with more rounded edges that move away from the sharper Galaxy Note design. Despite this, the Ultra is lighter, weighing just 218 grams, while still housing the same 5,000mAh battery that has powered Ultra models since the Galaxy S20 Ultra. One of the standout improvements is in the camera system. The 200MP primary sensor is now accompanied by a 50MP ultra-wide camera, replacing the 12MP sensor used in earlier models. There’s also a 50MP telephoto lens with 5x optical zoom and a secondary 10MP telephoto camera with 3x optical zoom. The 12MP front-facing camera remains unchanged but it is expected to offer better performance for selfies and video calls. The Galaxy S25 Ultra comes with 12GB of RAM across all storage options — 256GB, 512GB, and 1TB. This 12GB RAM configuration is consistent across the entire Galaxy S25 lineup, as Samsung has decided to eliminate the 16GB RAM variant this year. At the core of the device is the Snapdragon 8 Elite for Galaxy, a custom-tuned version of Qualcomm’s latest flagship chipset for 2025, featuring an advanced APU for improved efficiency and performance. Additionally, Samsung claims to have improved heat management by increasing the vapour chamber size by 40 percent on the S25 Ultra, with smaller but notable improvements of 15 per cent on the S25 and S25+.Samsung Galaxy S25, S25+: Specs The newly launched Samsung Galaxy S25 and Galaxy S25+ carry forward a bit of the hardware from their predecessors. The S25 features a compact 6.2-inch display, while the S25+ offers a larger 6.7-inch screen. Both devices come equipped with a 50MP primary camera, a 12MP ultra-wide lens, and a 10MP telephoto camera with 3x optical zoom. Battery capacities remain unchanged, with the S25 housing a 4,000mAh battery and the S25+ featuring a 4,900mAh cell. Charging speeds are also consistent, offering 25W wired charging for the S25 and 45W for the S25+. These devices run on Android 15 with Samsung's One UI 7 interface and promise extended software support, including 7 years of OS updates and security patches. The base model of the Galaxy S25 starts with 128GB of storage. Samsung is now offering 12GB RAM as the base model for the standard and Plus versions. Also, the Snapdragon 8 Elite powers the new devices.
 


New AI features The new phones are running on the latest One UI 7 custom skin based on Android 15, which the company says is built from the ground up with AI.  Samsung is pushing the boundaries of AI integration in One UI 7 on the Galaxy S25 with a suite of Gemini-powered features. At the heart of these updates is the introduction of "AI agents," which streamline how users interact with their phones. Gemini now allows for chaining multiple commands and app interactions to make complex tasks feel effortless. Users can also access Gemini directly by long-pressing the power button, ensuring quick and intuitive access to its capabilities. Furthermore, Samsung apps are being upgraded with Gemini extensions. On the AI front, Samsung is bringing several new features to its Galaxy lineup. "Generative Edit" in the photo editing tools has been upgraded to not only remove people from images but also their shadows. The "Now Brief" feature provides a personalised daily summary to keep users informed, while Samsung Gallery now supports searching for images using natural language, making it easier to find specific photos. To tie it all together, the on-device "Personal Data Engine" analyses user data securely, all while maintaining a focus on privacy, according to the company.  There is also a new AI Select tool that suggests relevant AI features based on screen activity—such as offering writing assistance to summarise, spell-check, or adjust text tone. On-device search now supports detailed queries, like finding a photo of a dog in a red coat near a cake. Samsung also added voice-triggered tasks, such as activating a blue light filter when you mention eye strain, eliminating the need to navigate menus. Another standout is Live Video, which provides step-by-step guidance by analysing activities, like giving baking instructions as you roll dough. The AI system now supports translations in 20 languages for calls and in-person interactions, expanding its utility.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 22, 2025

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge teased at Unpacked 2025, will come with new design and 2 rear camerasAt Unpacked 2025, Samsung on Wednesday night announced three new Galaxy phones and teased one unique device — the Galaxy S25 Edge. Earlier the device was rumoured to be called Galaxy S25 Slim.
Content:
Samsung has finally introduced its new flagship Galaxy S25 series. And just like every year, this year too we have 3 new Galaxy phones. These are the Galaxy S25 Ultra, the Galaxy S25+, and the vanilla S25. Now one device, if the rumours were anything to go by, was missing in this announcement. That is until the very end of the Unpacked 2025, the Samsung event where it launches its flagship phones. And this one was Galaxy S25 Slim, a name circulating in rumours for a while. But at the close of the event Samsung brought out a teaser of a new phone. This one is called the Galaxy S25 Edge.  In other words, the Galaxy S25 Slim exists. But it is now officially called the Galaxy S25 Edge.  What it will be, we do not know for sure for now. However, the teaser shown at the unpacked event shares the first look, showing a new Galaxy device with a flat design and two cameras at the rear. As for everything else, that’s for later.

 



Samsung teases the upcoming launch of the new Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge
 But of course, here too rumours come to rescue. And we have seen that so far rumours around the Galaxy S25 series have turned out to be mostly accurate.  Going by these reviews it is safe to say that the galaxy S25 Edge is likely to come with the Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset, plenty of RAM — say 12GB at least — and two rear cameras, one of which is expected to use the 200MP sensor that is also in the other flagship S25 phones, and another one is said to be a slimmed down periscope lens. It is also likely that the phone will have a 6.7-inch display, complete with top features like 120Hz refresh rate and extra high brightness.  But the main feature of the phone, which also gives the device its name, is the design of the phone. It is expected that the Galaxy S25 Edge is likely to be just 6.4mm slim.  Now, another rumour about the S25 Edge is that it is not going to be available anytime soon. While the other three S25 phones are going on sale from February 7, the S25 Edge is likely to be available for sale only from May and that too only in some countries. It is possible that in many countries, including in India, the phone might not even arrive.  Given that the S25 Edge is not launching along with the other S25 phones it seems like that the phone is an afterthought by Samsung, possible to counter the iPhone 17 Air that has also been in rumours for the last few months. It is almost certain that Apple is going to launch the iPhone 17 Air, a rather slim and petite iPhone later in September or October. Chances are that Samsung also wants to have a similarly slim-profile phone in its lineup.  As for the new Galaxy S25 series, the Galaxy S25 Ultra is leading the Samsung lineup with a larger 6.9-inch display, an upgraded camera setup featuring a 200-megapixel primary sensor and dual telephoto lenses, and the latest Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset with advanced thermal management. The Galaxy S25 and S25+, meanwhile, retain the familiar designs from their predecessors and offer respective 6.2-inch and 6.7-inch displays.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also Read |  Android 16 first beta releasing in January?
