Headline: OpenAI tells India court ChatGPT data removal will breach US legal obligationsIn the most high-profile and closely-tracked lawsuit on AI use in India, ANI sued OpenAI in Delhi in November, accusing it of using the news agency's published content without permission to train ChatGPT.
Content: OpenAI has told an Indian court that any order to remove training data powering its ChatGPT service would be inconsistent with its legal obligations in the United States, according to a recent filing seen by Reuters.  The Microsoft-backed AI firm also said that it was not within the jurisdiction of Indian courts to hear a copyright breach case brought by local news agency ANI as OpenAI had no presence in the country.  In the most high-profile and closely-tracked lawsuit on AI use in India, ANI sued OpenAI in Delhi in November, accusing it of using the news agency's published content without permission to train ChatGPT. OpenAI responded to the lawsuit, which is also seeking the deletion of ANI's data already stored by ChatGPT, in an 86-page filing at the Delhi High Court dated January 10, which has not previously been reported. OpenAI and other firms have faced a wave of similar lawsuits from prominent copyright owners over alleged misuse of their work to train AI models, including a case brought by the New York Times against OpenAI in the United States.  OpenAI has repeatedly denied the allegations, saying its AI systems make fair use of publicly available data. During a November hearing, OpenAI told the Delhi court it would not use ANI's content anymore but the news agency argued its published works were stored in ChatGPT's memory and should be deleted. In the January 10 submission, OpenAI said that it is currently defending litigation in the United States concerning the data on which its models have been trained, with laws there requiring it to preserve the data while hearings are pending.  OpenAI "is therefore under a legal obligation, under the laws of the United States to preserve, and not delete, the said training data", it said. OpenAI did not respond to a request for comment.  In its submission, OpenAI also said the relief being claimed by ANI was not subject to the processes of Indian courts and was beyond their jurisdiction. The company has "no office or permanent establishment in India ... the servers on which (ChatGPT) stores its training data are similarly situated outside of India".  ANI, in which Reuters holds a 26 per cent interest, in a statement said that it believes the Delhi court has jurisdiction to decide on the matter, and it would file a detailed response. A Reuters spokesperson did not respond immediately to a request for comment but the agency in November said it was not involved in ANI's business practices or operations. The New Delhi court is due to hear the case on January 28. OpenAI has been gearing up to transition from a non-profit enterprise into a for-profit business as it looks to capture even more funding to stay ahead in the costly AI race after raising $6.6 billion last year. In recent months, it has signed deals with Time magazine, the Financial Times, Business Insider-owner Axel Springer, France's Le Monde and Spain's Prisa Media to display content. ANI has also said it is concerned about unfair competition given OpenAI's commercial partnerships with other news organisations, and has told the court that in response to user prompts, ChatGPT reproduced verbatim or substantially similar extracts of ANI's works. In its rebuttal submission, OpenAI argues that ANI "has sought to use verbatim extracts of its own article as a prompt, in an attempt to manipulate ChatGPT".Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 series brings big updates to Galaxy AI: Here are 4 features you should know about The Samsung Galaxy S25 series has launched globally, bringing several AI-powered features. The series includes 3 phones so far; Galaxy S25, S25+ and S25 Ultra.
Content:
Samsung has finally released its next-gen flagship series -- the Samsung Galaxy S25 series. The company has launched 3 phones: The Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and the Galaxy S25 Ultra. But this is not it. The much anticipated slim variant of the series was also teased during the launch-- the Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge will feature a flat design and two rear cameras. Apart from this, all the other details are still under wraps for the Edge. At a starting price of Rs 80,999, the series comes with enhanced features over its predecessor. The Galaxy AI is one of the standout features. For instance, the series is the first one to come with Gemini as its default AI assistant, something which was only exclusive for Google phones. Let's delve deeper to find out more about these upgrades. advertisementSamsung Galaxy S25 series AI-featuresGemini AI assistant: This is not the first time that Google's Gemini has been integrated into any of the Samsung phones, but it is the first time that the Gemini is the default AI assistant of the series. It has already enabled users to perform several tasks across apps like YouTube, Google Maps, Gmail, and Spotify. But now, with the Samsung Galaxy S25 series, Gemini expands its capabilities to integrate with Samsung apps, including Samsung Calendar, Notes, Reminder, and Clock.  
 


Users can now use Gemini to handle multiple tasks in a single prompt. For instance, if you need high-protein lunch ideas, you can ask Gemini for recipes and save them directly to Samsung Notes or Google Keep.    Gemini AI assistant: This is not the first time that Google's Gemini has been integrated into any of the Samsung phones, but it is the first time that the Gemini is the default AI assistant of the series. It has already enabled users to perform several tasks across apps like YouTube, Google Maps, Gmail, and Spotify. But now, with the Samsung Galaxy S25 series, Gemini expands its capabilities to integrate with Samsung apps, including Samsung Calendar, Notes, Reminder, and Clock.  
 


 Users can now use Gemini to handle multiple tasks in a single prompt. For instance, if you need high-protein lunch ideas, you can ask Gemini for recipes and save them directly to Samsung Notes or Google Keep.    To make Gemini even more accessible on Galaxy S25 devices, simply long-press the side button to summon it for assistance or to interact with content on your screen. Additionally, for Advanced users, access to Deep Research in the Gemini mobile app will begin rolling out later this week, offering a powerful tool to save time on research, even while on the move.
 


 Gemini Live: Gemini Live now offers an even more dynamic conversational experience, enabling users to engage in natural, free-flowing chats while incorporating images, files, and YouTube videos into their conversations.  
 


 This enhanced version of Gemini Live is being rolled out to the Samsung Galaxy S24 and S25 series, as well as Pixel 9 devices. Furthermore, Google plans to introduce Project Astra features, including screen sharing and live video streaming, to the Gemini mobile app on Android and the Samsung Galaxy S25 in the coming months. Circle to Search: This Google AI-feature was first introduced in the Samsung Galaxy S24 series. And now with the new series in town, Samsung seeks to take it up a notch. The feature will now automatically identify phone numbers, email addresses, and URLs, making it easier for users to interact with them. Additionally, AI Overviews in search results have been enhanced to support a wider range of visual search queries. This increases the likelihood that using Circle to Search on an image of a location, artwork, or object will produce an AI Overview in the results.
 


 Briefs: A standout feature is the Brief tool, which provides personalised daily summaries. The morning brief includes the weather forecast, your schedule for the day, and an energy score if you're using a Samsung wearable. During your commute, it automatically initiates navigation and plays music when you get into your vehicle. In the evening, it offers a summary of your day, highlighting key activities and showcasing memorable moments through photo collages.
 


 The Samsung Galaxy S25 series is available for pre-order beginning January 23, 2025, through all major online and offline retailers. Customers can also pre-order directly on Samsung’s official India website. The devices are set to go on sale starting February 7, 2025. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 series is priced the same as Galaxy S24 –– well, almostSamsung has launched the new Galaxy S25 series and the India prices for the phones are now out. Here is how the S25 series is priced compared to last year's Galaxy S24.
Content:
At the annual Galaxy Unpacked event on Wednesday, that took place in San Francisco, Samsung announced the new Galaxy S25 series. The series includes the three usual suspects: the Galaxy S25, the Galaxy S25+, and the Galaxy S25 Ultra. In a wonderful surprise for Samsung fans, the company also announced the revival of the Edge series. Basically, the slimmest smartphone by Samsung, which we thought would be called the Galaxy S25 Slim, is actually called the Galaxy S25 Edge. Samsung only shared a brief sneak peek of the Galaxy S25 Edge, but we have all the details about the other three smartphones.  Over the Galaxy S24 series, the Galaxy S25 does not feature prominent hardware upgrades, but when you get to the pricing, you will notice something interesting.  The Samsung Galaxy S25 series is priced the same as last year’s Galaxy S24 series –– well, almost. While there is a slight increase in pricing for the Galaxy S25 Ultra, the Galaxy S25+ is priced exactly the same as the Galaxy S24+. Meanwhile, the standard variant has seen a minimal increase in price for the base variant, but there is a legitimate reason for that. Let’s dive deeper into the pricing.  The Samsung Galaxy S25’s base model is priced starting at Rs 80,999 this time, whereas in 2024, the Galaxy S24’s base model was priced at Rs 79,999. That’s a small difference of one thousand, but the big difference here is RAM. The Galaxy S24 offered only 8GB RAM, while the new S25 comes with 12GB RAM for both the 256 and 512GB storage models.  As for the Galaxy S25+, the RAM and storage specifications are exactly the same as those of the Galaxy S24+. The price of the 12GB RAM and 256GB storage model is also the same at Rs 99,999. However, there is a slight bump in price for the 12GB RAM and 512GB storage model of the Galaxy S25+, which is priced at Rs 1,11,999, while the Galaxy S24+’s same variant was priced at Rs 1,09,999 –– a difference of Rs 2,000.  There is a more visible difference in the prices of the Galaxy S25 Ultra though. The Galaxy S25 Ultra comes in three variants with all of them featuring 12GB RAM, and options for 256GB, 512GB and 1TB storage. The prices for these are Rs 1,29,999, Rs 1,41,999, and Rs 1,65,999 respectively. Compared to the Galaxy S24 Ultra, the prices for the 256GB and 512GB models of the S25 Ultra are pretty much the same, with a small difference of one or two thousand. The only significant bump in price you notice is with the 1TB variant, which is Rs 6,000 more expensive.  For context, the Galaxy S24 Ultra also featured 12GB RAM. Its 256GB storage model was priced at Rs 1,29,999, the 512GB model was priced at Rs 1,39,999, and the 1TB variant cost Rs 1,59,999 at the time of launch.  TL;DR: With the taxes and duties that smartphone manufacturers have to pay, it is always great to see when there isn’t a dramatic hike in their flagships from one year to the other. With the Galaxy S25 series, we think Samsung has done a pretty good job with the phones’ pricing.

Headline: Elon Musk slams Sam Altman as Trump backs OpenAI's Stargate ProjectWith US President Donald Trump backing Sam Altman's latest initiative, the Stargate Project, Elon Musk is lashing out. In a series of posts about the OpenAI CEO, Musk has called him a liar, claimed lack of funds in his new company, and more. Here is the whole drama between Elon Musk and Sam Altman.
Content:
Elon Musk is furious. He has again picked up a fight with Sam Altman, and the trigger this time is OpenAI’s Stargate Project. What makes things worse is that the AI project is backed by Musk’s new favourite, US President Donald Trump. Musk’s new tirade is laced with accusations and screenshots of old tweets. Things seem to be taking a personal turn as he (once again) publicly accuses Altman of playing a game with the agenda of making money, which is in contrast to the vision Musk and Altman once shared for an open-source, non-profit AI organisation.   There is more. In the middle of the feud is Musk’s complaint about Altman’s alleged $10 billion demand, which is equivalent to a 7 per cent share in the new Stargate Project. Musk says that this is after Altman testified to Congress that he will not be taking any compensation or pay from OpenAI. Trump is unhappy that Altman is now looking to make money by setting up a new AI company.
 


 Unsurprisingly, it is not as if Musk is completely impartial here. His own AI company called xAI is a direct competitor of OpenAI and is tangled in lawsuits with the company at the moment. Musk and his AI company have accused OpenAI of anticompetitive behaviour, and of discouraging investors from putting their money in its rival companies.  And it gets better: Just like OpenAI needs AI infrastructure –– that’s where the Stargate Project steps in –– to advance its AI systems, Musk’s xAI needs the same backing. xAI has reportedly spent around $12 billion on a single AI data centre. But Donald Trump’s support for the Stargate Project, which has a $500 billion investment plan, has added fuel to the fire.  Musk has accused Altman of being a "liar" for demanding $10 billion from his new company after testifying that he won't be taking compensations from OpenAI. He has also suggested in a post on X that Altman’s new initiative lacks sufficient funds. “They don’t actually have the money,” he wrote in a post replying to OpenAI’s announcement of the Stargate Project. “SoftBank has well under $10B secured. I have that on good authority,” Musk added. Altman’s new initiative is led by OpenAI and SoftBank, with the latter responsible for managing the financial aspect of things. Altman quickly responded to Musk’s claims. “Wrong, as you sure know,” wrote the OpenAI CEO as he denied Musk’s accusations. “Want to come visit the first site already underway? This is great for the country. I realise what is great for the country isn't always what's optimal for your companies, but in your new role I hope you'll mostly put [America] first”, Altman’s post on X read. 
 


Elon Musk is heading a newly formed US advisory commission called the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) that has been tasked with proposing ways to make federal agencies more efficient. The DOGE commission was first announced last year and as Trump was officially sworn in on Monday, it was made more official with an executive order signed by the new US president.Musk is now digging up old tweets by Altman, some of which reveal him writing about stopping Trump from being re-election as the US president.
 


Musk has also shared posts on X that accuse Altman of "funding Axios, which pushes against Trump and anti-American propaganda". 
 


advertisementIn response to accusations of being anti-Trump, Sam Altman also responded by saying that his perspective has really changed about the new US President. 
 


In a separate post, Altman also said that he thinks Musk is “not a nice person”. “I don’t think he's a nice person or treating us fairly but you have to respect the guy and he pushes all of us to be more ambitious,” his post read. 
 


The Elon Musk vs Sam Altman drama has been going on for years, and it doesn’t seem to be remotely close to ending any time soon –– primarily because what started as a debate over OpenAI’s original mission has now escalated into a super-publicised feud of egos and ambitions, and OpenAI’s new Stargate Project is the latest hot button. Headline: iPhone SE 4 launch timeline and chipset details leakedAlongside the iPhone SE 4, new details about the next-generation iPad 11, iPad Air, and MacBook Air models have also emerged, setting the stage for an exciting first quarter of 2025 for Apple enthusiasts.
Content: Apple’s long-rumoured iPhone SE 4 is expected to launch very soon. For the longest time, leaks around the device have dropped left, right and centre, giving us a good idea of its expected features, software, and possible launch timeline. Alongside the affordable iPhone SE, new details about the next-generation iPad 11, iPad Air, and MacBook Air models have also emerged, setting the stage for an exciting first quarter of 2025 for Apple enthusiasts. As per the latest rumours, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to ship with iOS 18.3 preinstalled, as will the upcoming iPads with iPadOS 18.3. A private social media account, known for its reliable Apple-related leaks, has shared build numbers for these software versions — iOS 18.3 (22D8062) for the iPhone SE 4, and iPadOS 18.3 (22D2060 and 22D2062) for the iPad 11 and iPad Air. While the exact launch date remains unclear, the information hints at an announcement before the iOS 18.4 and iPadOS 18.4 rollout, suggesting a March or April launch window. In terms of design, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to resemble the standard iPhone 14 or the upcoming iPhone 16, making it a major upgrade over its predecessor. Rumoured features include a 6.1-inch OLED display, Face ID, a single 48-megapixel rear camera, and the addition of a USB-C port — a welcome change that will bring it in line with the latest-generation iPhone models. Performance-wise, the iPhone SE 4 will reportedly house a newer A-series chip, possibly the A17 Pro, along with 8GB of RAM. This upgrade is big, as it positions the device to support Apple Intelligence features, like advanced machine learning and on-device AI tasks. It will also debut Apple’s first in-house 5G modem, potentially improving connectivity and reducing reliance on Qualcomm. Coming to the iPads — they are also shaping up to be promising upgrades. The iPad 11 is expected to feature the A17 Pro chip and 8GB of RAM, mirroring the iPhone SE 4 when it comes to hardware prowess. As for the iPad Air, there’s some debate about its processor. While earlier rumours hinted at the M3 chip, recent leaks suggest Apple might opt for the more powerful M4 chip, aligning it with the latest iPad Pro models. Meanwhile, the 13-inch and 15-inch MacBook Air models with the M4 chip are reportedly on track to launch earlier than the iPhone SE 4 and the new iPads. Mark Gurman has repeatedly emphasised that the upcoming MacBook Air is already in production, with a release as early as January or February 2025 looking increasingly likely.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra vs iPhone 16 Pro Max: India price and specs comparedThe Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra is the high-end flagship model of the recently launched series. Powered by a Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, the phone is tough competition for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.
Content: Samsung has recently launched its latest flagship series in India -- the Galaxy S25 series. At the starting price of Rs 80,999, the series includes three models; the Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+ and the Galaxy S25 Ultra. With Samsung unveiling its latest flagship lineup, comparing the Galaxy S25 series to the iPhone 16 series is inevitable, continuing the years-long rivalry. This article focuses on the high-end models, the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra and the iPhone 16 Pro Max, examining their pricing and specifications in detail.advertisementSamsung Galaxy S25 Ultra vs iPhone 16 Pro Max: India price The Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra series comes in three variants with prices starting at Rs 1,29,999, similar to its predecessor. The 256GB storage variant is priced at Rs 1,29,999, 512GB for Rs 1,49,999 and 1TB for Rs 1,65,999. Colour options include Titanium Silver Blue, Titanium Gray, Titanium White, and Titanium Black. Coming to the iPhone 16 Pro Max, the price starts at Rs 1,44,900. It comes in three storage variants: 256GB, 512GB and 1TB, the same as the recently released Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra. The 256GB was launched at Rs 1,44,900, 512GB at Rs 1,64,900, and 1TB at Rs 1,84,900.  The Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra series comes in three variants with prices starting at Rs 1,29,999, similar to its predecessor. The 256GB storage variant is priced at Rs 1,29,999, 512GB for Rs 1,49,999 and 1TB for Rs 1,65,999. Colour options include Titanium Silver Blue, Titanium Gray, Titanium White, and Titanium Black.  Coming to the iPhone 16 Pro Max, the price starts at Rs 1,44,900. It comes in three storage variants: 256GB, 512GB and 1TB, the same as the recently released Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra. The 256GB was launched at Rs 1,44,900, 512GB at Rs 1,64,900, and 1TB at Rs 1,84,900.  When comparing prices, Samsung's newest flagship is priced more affordably than the iPhone 16 Pro Max. The first two storage options, 256GB and 512GB, are Rs 14,901 less expensive, while the price gap for the 1TB variant rises to Rs 18,901. Notably, the iPhone 16 Pro Max comes with 8GB RAM, whereas the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra has 12GB RAM. Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra vs iPhone 16 Pro: Specs Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra: The Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra makes significant strides in design, performance, and functionality. Its display has been upgraded to a larger 6.9-inch screen, an increase from the previous 6.8 inches, and now features more rounded edges, moving away from the sharper Galaxy Note aesthetic. Despite the size increase, the Ultra is lighter, weighing just 218 grams, while still retaining the reliable 5,000mAh battery that has powered Ultra models since the Galaxy S20 Ultra.   A key highlight is the revamped camera system. The 200-megapixel primary sensor is now paired with a 50-megapixel ultra-wide camera, replacing the previous 12-megapixel sensor. Additionally, there’s a 50-megapixel telephoto lens with 5x optical zoom, along with a secondary 10-megapixel telephoto camera offering 3x optical zoom. The 12-megapixel front camera remains the same but is expected to deliver enhanced performance for selfies and video calls.   Under the hood, the Galaxy S25 Ultra is powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite for Galaxy, a custom-optimised version of Qualcomm’s latest flagship chipset for 2025, designed with an advanced APU for greater efficiency and performance. iPhone 16 Pro Max: The iPhone 16 Pro Max features a 6.9-inch display, marking the largest screen ever on an iPhone. It showcases Super Retina XDR technology with Always-On and ProMotion features for a smooth and immersive visual experience. Apple has introduced a sleek new gold colour option and a highly anticipated Camera Control button exclusive to the Pro models. This button is pressure-sensitive, responding differently based on how hard you press, and it also allows you to scroll for seamless zooming.   The iPhone 16 Pro Max boasts a lightweight titanium body paired with next-generation Ceramic Shield, which Apple claims is twice as durable as any other smartphone glass.   Under the hood, it is powered by the new 3nm A18 Pro chipset. Apple states that this chip features a 6-core GPU, offering 20 per cent faster performance compared to the A17 Pro. It also includes next-gen machine learning accelerators, enhanced USB 3 speeds, and ProRes video recording support, ensuring top-tier performance and efficiency. But, we ran the phone under real-life scenarios and here is our detailed review of the iPhone 16 Pro Max. The iPhone 16 Pro Max also comes with an upgraded triple-camera system. The primary 48-megapixel Fusion camera includes a second-generation quad-pixel sensor, enabling zero shutter lag for ProRAW and HEIF photos. The camera supports 4K120 video recording and introduces a 48-megapixel ultra-wide camera with autofocus. Additionally, a 12-megapixel telephoto lens with a 5x optical zoom and 120mm focal length enhances zoom capabilities. The Pro models also offer up to 10x optical zoom for even greater versatility.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 series launched in India: Price, full specs, featuresAlso read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 series launched: Price in India, pre-order deals, and moreAlso read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 series brings big updates to Galaxy AI: Here are 4 features you should know aboutMust Watch

Headline: YouTube announces new features for its premium users: Smart download for shorts, jump ahead and moreGoogle has announced new features for YouTube Premium subscribers, including experimental tools, a bundled subscription with Google One, and the expansion of popular features to more regions.
Content: Google has introduced a host of new features for YouTube Premium subscribers. These new tools include multiple experimental features such as high-quality audio, faster playback, a partnership with Google One, and expanding the availability of some existing features to more regions. According to the company, these new  updates are aimed at enhancing the user experience and making the YouTube Premium subscription a comprehensive entertainment solution. Let’s take a quick look at what’s new for YouTube Premium users. YouTube, in its official blog post, revealed that it is now making experimental tools more accessible to Premium users. With the new update, users can now try multiple features simultaneously via youtube.com/new, unlike earlier, when YouTube allowed only one feature to be tested at a time. The new features now available for paid users include: Faster playback speeds: One of the most notable updates is the introduction of precise playback speed controls on mobile devices. The feature allows users to fine-tune playback speeds up to 4x offering users better control over their viewing experience.  High-quality audio: For music lovers, YouTube has introduced high-quality 256kbps audio for music videos. This update will now offer users a richer, more immersive listening experience with enhanced clarity and depth. Picture-in-picture for YouTube Shorts on iOS: This feature will now allow users to multitask by watching Shorts while using other apps simultaneously. Smart downloads for YouTube Shorts on iOS: Premium users are also getting the ability to automatically download recommended Shorts for offline viewing. Jump ahead on YouTube web: Previously available only on mobile, this feature is now accessible on the web. It lets users skip directly to the most engaging parts of a video. With these updates, YouTube aims to offer users a more personalised and enhanced viewing experience on the platform.Exclusive bundle with Google One In the U.S., Google has introduced a bundled subscription option that combines YouTube Premium with a Google One Premium plan for its paid users. This bundle includes ad-free YouTube, 2 TB of cloud storage, and additional Google One perks at a relatively lower cost.Expanding availability of popular features YouTube has also announced the expansion of some fan-favorite tools to new platforms and regions: Ask Music: YouTube will soon expand this AI-powered feature, in the UK and Ireland. Once available this feature will allow users to create personalized radio stations based on prompts like “upbeat workout tracks” or “relaxing jazz.” Conversational AI on iOS: YouTube will soon roll out access to its conversational AI assistant for iOS. This tool will provide users with answers to video-related questions, recommends related content, and more—all without interrupting playback.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also Read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge teased at Unpacked 2025, will come with new design and 2 rear camerasAlso Read |  Android 16 first beta releasing in January? Headline: iPad 11 is likely to launch soon, but will it support Apple Intelligence?After being reported by Mark Gurman that the iPad 11 will be powered by the A17 Pro chip and feature Apple Intelligence features. A new rumour suggests the iPad 11 will instead be powered by an A16 chip and won't come with Apple Intelligence support.
Content: The iPad 11 is expected to be unveiled by March or April, but questions remain about whether Apple’s upcoming entry-level tablet will support its Apple Intelligence suite of features. While Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman had confidently predicted in his Power On Newsletter, that the iPad 11 will have the hardware necessary to support these advanced AI-driven features, a new leak casts some doubt on the matter. According to an anonymous account on X (formerly Twitter) known for accurate Apple leaks, the iPad 11 will be powered with a chip identified as T8120. This identifier matches the A16 chip found in devices like the iPhone 14 Pro and the iPhone 15 duo. The problem? The A16 chip doesn’t currently support Apple Intelligence — this is also why the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus didn’t support the features, as opposed to the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max, which are powered by the A17 Pro chip and support Apple Intelligence.  This is also the reason that Apple Intelligence features are limited to devices with at least the A17 Pro chip and 8GB RAM, such as the latest generation iPad Mini, iPad Pro, and M1-powered iPads. So, if this leak is about the iPad 11 featuring an A16 chip paired with 6GB RAM turn accurate, it would be a modest improvement over the iPad 10, which is powered by an A14 chip with 4GB RAM. However, this hardware configuration would not meet Apple’s current minimum requirements for Apple Intelligence. So, what gives? Mark Gurman has been clear about the fact that the iPad 11 will have the A17 Pro chip and 8GB RAM, setting it up to join the Apple Intelligence ecosystem. He suggests that Apple’s upcoming entry-level tablet will bring significant performance improvements but no major design changes compared to the iPad 10. Gurman also expects Apple to release an updated Magic Keyboard accessory for the iPad 11 alongside the launch. Both sources may be correct, with Apple offering multiple configurations of the iPad 11 at different price points. For instance, a base model with the A16 chip could target budget-conscious buyers, while a higher-end version with the A17 Pro chip might cater to those who wish to have Apple Intelligence features on their devices. The iPad 10 launched in October 2022 at $449 (Rs 44,900 in India) but saw a price cut to $349 (Rs 34,900 in India) in mid-2024. If the iPad 11 starts at the same price point, it could make sense for Apple to introduce a range of options to appeal to more buyers. Of course, Apple has yet to confirm any details, so speculation continues to swirl. Either way, the iPad 11 — with or without Apple Intelligence — should offer improved performance over its predecessor.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Govt asks Google, Apple to pre-install state-owned apps: Report With this move, the Indian government aims to enhance the delivery of its public welfare services through the use of technology.
Content: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) has reached out to Google, Apple and other OEMs to open up a state-backed app store. According to the latest report, published by Bloomberg, the ministry has contacted smartphone companies to work out its idea -- creating government-app suite. The report states that the officials reached out to Apple and Google executives last month, requesting them to grant Indian users direct access to the government’s range of apps. With this move, the ministry is focused on increasing the reach of its public welfare services using technology. It also wants the state-supported app suite to come pre-installed on devices before they hit the market and to be downloadable from third-party sources without triggering warnings. Officials requested the tech companies to include the state-backed GOV.in app store in their marketplaces, such as Apple’s App Store and the Google Play Store, according to reported sources who spoke anonymously as the discussions have not been made public.  That said, both Google and Apple are unlikely to agree to the requests. The report said, "Google, whose Android operating system accounts for more than 90% of the country’s roughly 700 million smartphones, is pushing back on the initiative, the people said, adding that Apple is also unlikely to agree. In the meeting, government officials discussed the possibility of a policy mandate or using legal measures to get Apple and Google to comply." Currently, the government's apps are accessible individually through Apple and Google digital stores in India. However, officials believe that bundling these apps into a GOV.in app suite within the stores could significantly increase their usage. Notably, this is not an aloof idea. Apple has done in for Russia in 2021. It offered an option for users to install government-suggested applications, complying with local regulations.  Likewise, India also wants to make a separate app-suit for its citizens. The nation has frequently taken a leading role in implementing stringent regulations on global tech companies. For instance, the 2020 ban on the video app TikTok and a legal demand for Meta to grant access to encrypted WhatsApp messages under certain conditions-- a move the US social media giant has challenged in court. New Delhi's tech policies often set a precedent for other nations, posing significant challenges for major technology firms. Looking at the rise in smartphone usage and vulnerabilities, a strict approach becomes important. If Apple and Google comply with the request, it could improve the cybercrime statistics in the country. Apple and Google, which typically retain 30 per cent of app revenue, actively manage developers' contributions to their platforms, ensuring reduced exposure to viruses, cyber threats, and faulty software. These companies maintain tight control over their app stores, a key factor enabling them to wield significant influence over smartphones worldwide.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Tune InAlso read |  ChatGPT data removal in India will breach US legal obligations, OpenAI tells Delhi High CourtAlso read |  Donald Trump says he is okay with Elon Musk buying TikTok: Will the app return to India?Also read |  OpenAI may launch its AI super agent called Operator as early as this weekMust Watch

Headline: Is your Aadhaar safe? Here is how you can check who is using your Aadhaar numberAadhaar number tracking: UIDAI offers a dedicated tool that allows users to check their Aadhaar history and ensure their Aadhaar is not being misused.
Content: Our 12-digit Aadhaar number has become a very important ID document. Whether travelling, securing admission, or opening a new bank account, we are required to share our Aadhaar details to verify our identity. In fact, Aadhaar has made it easier for us to access government services and financial institutions. However, with its increased use, Aadhaar has also become a common target for scammers seeking to exploit it for financial fraud or illegal activities. Therefore, it is important to keep your Aadhaar safe. But how can you check if your Aadhaar is being misused? To help Aadhaar holders monitor activities linked to their Aadhaar, the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI)—the governing body responsible for Aadhaar—has an online tool called the “Authentication History” feature on the myAadhaar portal. This tool allows Aadhaar holders to track and secure their Aadhaar-related activities.  Here’s a step-by-step guide to check how your Aadhaar is being used and how to secure it if you suspect misuse. To check your Aadhaar history: – Visit the myAadhaar portal: Go to the official myAadhaar website. – Login with OTP: Enter your Aadhaar number and the captcha code displayed. Click on “Login With OTP” and use the one-time password sent to your registered mobile number to access your account. – Access your authentication history: Select the “Authentication History” option and choose a date range to review Aadhaar usage during that period. – Review the details: Now carefully check the listed transactions. If you notice any unfamiliar or suspicious activity, report it immediately. Report unauthorised activity If you identify any unauthorised activity linked to your Aadhaar number: -- Call UIDAI’s toll-free helpline at 1947. -- Email your concerns to help@uidai.gov.in. Lock Aadhaar biometrics  Additionally, UIDAI also allows users to prevent Aadhaar misuse by locking their biometrics. This feature ensures that even if someone gains access to your Aadhaar number, they cannot use your biometric information without your consent. To lock your Aadhaar biometrics: Visit the UIDAI website: Now navigate to the “Lock/Unlock Biometrics” section. Enter the necessary details: Provide your Virtual ID (VID), name, PIN code, and the captcha code displayed. Authenticate with OTP: Click “Send OTP” and use the code sent to your registered mobile number to proceed. Secure your biometrics: Complete the process to lock your Aadhaar biometric. Aadhaar Card Update: Easy steps to change mobile number It is advisable to regularly check your Aadhaar activity to ensure your details are not being misused. UIDAI also encourages Aadhaar holders to keep their details updated, including phone number, address, and even biometric details such as fingerprints. This is particularly important if you haven’t updated them in the past 10 years, have experienced an accident that affected your biometrics, or if the Aadhaar holder is a child who has turned 15.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also Read |  YouTube announces new features for its premium users: Smart download for shorts, jump ahead and moreAlso Read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge teased at Unpacked 2025, will come with new design and 2 rear camerasAlso Read |  Android 16 first beta releasing in January? Here is everything we know

Headline: OpenAI may launch its AI super agent called Operator as early as this weekOpenAI is rumoured to be working on an agentic AI called Operator. While it was expected to launch by the end of this month, new reports suggest it may launch as early as this week.
Content:
OpenAI has long been rumoured to be working on either a new AI system or the next-generation of ChatGPT. The biggest rumour was around the AI company working on artificial general intelligence (AGI). Several reports even suggested that this year OpenAI will roll out AGI. However, very recently OpenAI CEO Sam Altman busted that rumour saying the company has not even started work on AGI, forget launching it. That said, Altman may have denied reports on launching an AGI system, but has been frequently talking about AI agents. He even wrote in a post earlier this week, that AI agents will become a part of the workforce in 2025.  While OpenAI has not yet spoken about a launch, there are many reports that claim that the company is preparing to launch its AI agent by the end of this month, with several of them suggesting January 30 as the date of launch. But now, a new report suggests it could launch as early as this week, according to a report by The Information.  Rumoured to be called the Operator, the AI super agent is believed to have “PhD-level intelligence”. The AI agent is believed to be able to handle complex tasks like booking a table at a restaurant on your behalf, or booking a flight ticket for you, or any other talks that require multiple steps and actions. 
The reports about the launch of OpenAI’s agentic AI also seem like it is because of a recent blog post about the company’s CEO where he wrote about humanity stepping into the “Intelligence age”. In another post he also spoke about “AI agents joining the workforce” and “changing the output of companies” in 2025. Separately, earlier this week, Altman also popped the bubble of AI-enthusiasts about AGI launching this year. He dismissed the conversation around AGI as just Twitter hype, and said that the company is working on something cool, but people need to reduce their expectations of it by 100 times. “Twitter hype is out of control again. We are not gonna deploy AGI next month, nor have we built it. We have some very cool stuff for you but pls chill and cut your expectations 100x!” Altman wrote in a post. The rumour about the launch of the AI agent system comes on the heels of OpenAI's announcement about a new AI company called The Stargate Project, which is aimed at building AI infrastructure for OpenAI in the United States. The initiative is led by OpenAI and SoftBank. OpenAI has announced an ambitious investment of $500 billion in the project in the next four years, with the deployment of $100 billion immediately.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also read |  OpenAI announces new company called Stargate Project, will invest $500 billion to develop AI data centresAlso read |  â Elon Musk vs Sam Altman: As Trump backs OpenAI's Stargate Project, Musk lashes out and calls him a liar

Headline: Google is making Circle to Search feature smarter, new update coming first to Galaxy S25 seriesGoogle has announced new features for its Circle To search. The updates will first arrive with the new Samsung Galaxy S25 series and later for other the eligible Android phones.
Content: Google is giving more power to its Circle to Search. The feature allows users to quickly find information by circling, scribbling, or tapping on anything they see on their Android screen. It was initially launched last year with the Samsung Galaxy S24 series. Now, as Samsung has unveiled its new generation of flagships – the Galaxy S25 series – Google has announced new improvements for the Circle to Search feature, which will make the new Galaxy phones smarter. During the Galaxy Unpacked event, Samsung revealed that it had doubled down on its collaboration with Google. Following this partnership, Google’s Gemini AI will be the default smart assistant on all three new Galaxy S25 devices – Galaxy S25, Galaxy S25+, and Galaxy S25 Ultra. But that’s not all. Bringing more AI powers to Galaxy devices, Google has announced new upgrades to the Circle to Search feature, including AI Overviews and one-tap interactions.AI overviews for visual searches The most notable addition to Circle to Search is the integration of AI Overviews. Previously, the feature would generate a list of Google search results based on the selected content. The new update will now provide users AI-generated summaries of the circles subject for visual searches. These AI summaries, according to Google, will deliver more context and deeper insights without requiring users to leave the app and search on the web. For instance, circling a photo of any dish on a plate will provide a concise overview of the dish and even its origin or related details. With this update, Google aims to offer users a quicker and easier way to use the Circle to Search features and understand anything at a glance.One-tap actions Another upgrade to the Circle to Search feature is the addition of one-tap actions for recognised phone numbers, email addresses, and URLs on the subject of the visual search . With this update, users will be able to directly call, email, or visit a website without any extra steps.First for the Galaxy S25 series  Just like last year, Google is first rolling out these new upgrades for Circle to Search with the Galaxy S25 series. However, the feature will not be exclusive to Galaxy phones. With the launch of Pixel phones later in the year, the feature will arrive in Google's own flagship devices. In fact, Google plans to roll out the enhanced Circle to Search experience across all Android devices that support the feature. Initially, these updates will be available in English, with potential expansion to other languages in the future.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also Read |  Is your Aadhaar safe? Here is how you can check who is using your Aadhaar numberAlso Read |  YouTube announces new features for its premium users: Smart download for shorts, jump ahead and moreAlso Read |  Samsung Galaxy S25 Edge teased at Unpacked 2025, will come with new design and 2 rear cameras

Headline: Samsung shows off its first VR headset at Galaxy Unpacked eventSamsung's VR headset, codenamed Project Moohan, is developed in collaboration with Google, and marks the company's first foray into the realm of Extended Reality (XR).
Content: After leaks and rumours, Samsung finally gave the world its first look at the company’s upcoming VR headset, codenamed Project Moohan. The device, developed in collaboration with Google, marks Samsung's first foray into the realm of Extended Reality (XR) and was showcased at the Galaxy Unpacked event in San Jose, California. With the headset expected to launch in 2025, the South Korean tech giant is aiming to make its presence felt in VR space. Project Moohan will be powered by a Qualcomm chipset and run on Android XR, a new operating system developed by Google specifically for XR devices. This collaboration ensures a seamless experience, bringing popular Google features and services to the headset. One such feature is Gemini, Google’s AI assistant, which will give users access to device controls and real-time information based on what they’re viewing. Google Maps, for example, is expected to get a futuristic upgrade when experienced in XR, kind of similar to what Apple users experience on the Vision Pro. Samsung’s VR headset will offer a mixed-reality experience, allowing users to remain present in the real world while overlaying virtual elements. Like other XR devices, it will also provide the option to fully immerse oneself in virtual reality. Samsung has been working on creating a headset that is lightweight and ergonomically designed for maximum comfort, though details about its weight and design are still under wraps. Samsung’s announcement comes as competition in the XR space heats up. While the Apple Vision Pro has already set benchmarks for mixed-reality headsets, it also left room for improvement in areas like pricing and user comfort. Samsung appears to be positioning itself as a more accessible option, learning from Apple’s early feedback. Despite similarities in functionality with devices like the Vision Pro, Samsung's headset aims to carve out its own identity by leveraging Android XR and Google’s ecosystem of apps. This partnership could prove to be a key differentiator, offering a familiar and versatile experience to Android users. Details about Project Moohan are still sparse, as Samsung is likely fine-tuning the design and finalising hardware specifications. Some industry insiders speculate that the company is waiting to see how competitors, including Apple, go forward with their products. Reports of an Apple Vision Pro 2 in development might influence Samsung's strategy. With the Samsung VR headset expected to hit the market in 2025, the focus will be on balancing performance, comfort, and cost. Extended reality is still finding its place in the mainstream, and devices that can provide a comfortable and affordable experience are likely to resonate with users.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 23, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: ChatGPT down: Both web and app versions not opening for many usersOpenAI's ChatGPT is currently experiencing another outage. Users are reporting difficulties accessing the chatbot through both the website and the app.
Content:
ChatGPT, the popular AI chatbot from OpenAI, is currently experiencing an outage. Both the web version and the app are showing problems, displaying a 'Bad Gateway Error.' Many users on social media, including X (formerly Twitter), are also flagging the issue, noting that the AI chatbot has been experiencing access problems since evening. According to Downdetector, the issue with the chatbot started around 5 PM IST and is still ongoing. On Downdetector, more than 3,000 users have submitted reports of the ChatGPT outage since evening. Users are reporting that the AI platform is not opening, and they are receiving a "bad gateway" error from the web server. On the app too, for many users, the app is not opening or has logged users out.  

 



ChatGPT web prompting bad gateway error.
 Notably, around 4:00 PM earlier, OpenAI reported an incident of experiencing elevated error rates in the API on its official website. In response, the company stated that it was working on the issue. By 4:43 PM, they reported that the issues had been resolved. "This issue has now been resolved. Between 3:33 AM and 4:23 AM PST, customers experienced elevated error rates on ChatGPT and the API."

 



OpenAI raised incident of Elevated Error Rate for ChatGPT and API on its official website
 It is being speculated that OpenAI is currently gearing up to launch ChatGPT's Operator this week, likely on Thursday. And this outage could be due to ongoing developments. According to the Information, OpenAI has been planning ChatGPT Operator, which will be an AI agent that will automate users' tasks and which users can access via a web browser. From making reservations to travel bookings, this new AI operator is expected to change how users use the AI platform and make ChatGPT more than just a chatbot answering queries. According to the report, the rumoured AI operator will help users automate their work in different categories of tasks, such as dining and events, delivery, shopping, and travel, as well as suggest prompts within each category. "When users enter a prompt, a miniature screen opens up in the chatbot that displays a browser and the actions the Operator agent is taking. The agent will also ask follow-up questions, such as the time and number of people for a restaurant reservation.
Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Jan 23, 2025

Headline: Mukesh Ambani buys Nvidia AI chips, plans to build largest data centre in India: ReportMukesh Ambani plans to build a massive data centre in Jamnagar, Gujarat, potentially the world's largest. Reliance aims to power it with renewable energy and lower AI computing costs for India.
Content: Mukesh Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries, is reportedly planning to build what could become the world’s largest data centre in Jamnagar, Gujarat, India. The facility, expected to boast a total capacity of three gigawatts, would be a huge move in India’s tech landscape, easily outpacing current global benchmarks by a big margin. For comparison, the largest operational data centres today, mostly located in the United States, are under one gigawatt. To support this ambitious move, Reliance is procuring advanced AI semiconductors from Nvidia Corporation. These high-performance chips are essential for the complex computations required by AI-driven tools, such as ChatGPT and other generative AI platforms. The timing of Mukesh Ambani’s move is no coincidence. Globally, tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon, and Google have been spending billions of dollars on expanding data centre capacities to keep up with the high demand for AI services. Earlier this week, a consortium including OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle announced plans to invest up to $500 billion in AI infrastructure under a project called Stargate. If this initiative goes ahead as planned, Ambani’s Jamnagar facility will not only surpass existing data centre capacities but also give India a competitive edge in the growing AI market. As of now, India’s total data centre capacity — just like the USA — is under one gigawatt. Tripling this capacity in one project would be a major milestone for the country, potentially accelerating its AI development. While the scale of the project is unprecedented, so is its estimated cost. Building such a massive facility could require an investment of $20 to $30 billion, according to industry estimates. Although Reliance Industries has about $26 billion in cash reserves, funding such a project would still be a challenge. The company has not commented on the reports yet. Ambani’s strategy appears similar to his approach in the telecom sector, where Reliance Jio disrupted the market by offering services at affordable prices. This time, the aim is to lower the cost of AI inferencing — the computational process behind running AI models — which can be prohibitively expensive for startups and established firms alike. Jamnagar, already the site of Reliance’s oil refining and petrochemical operations, will now play a central role in the company’s push for renewable energy and AI. The data centre is expected to be powered largely by green energy, with Reliance building solar, wind, and green hydrogen projects nearby. However, experts point out that maintaining a continuous energy supply for such a massive facility may still require fossil fuels or large battery storage systems. Ambani has made it clear that his ultimate goal is to make AI accessible to everyone in India. “We want to offer the lowest AI inferencing costs in the world, making AI affordable and available to all,” he said last year.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 24, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: OpenAI launches Operator, its first AI agent that performs tasks on webOpenAI's Operator is currently a research preview and is available only to ChatGPT Pro users in the US.
Content:
OpenAI has released its new AI agent — Operator— that can go to the web to perform tasks for the user. The company explains, “using its own browser, it can look at a webpage and interact with it by typing, clicking, and scrolling.” Interestingly, this is OpenAI’s first AI agent that can independently perform tasks. In this case, it essentially works as a middlemen, which is capable of completing tasks while interacting with the web. Currently, OpenAI has released a research preview, which means it has limitations and is open to feedback. This version is available in US for ChatGPT Pro users for now. 
 


advertisementOperator and its operations The Operator can be tasked with a wide range of repetitive browser activities, such as completing forms, ordering groceries, or even creating memes. By leveraging the same interfaces and tools that people use every day, AI expands its practical applications, helping individuals save time on routine tasks while creating new opportunities for businesses to engage with customers. OpenAI plans to expand it to Plus, Team, and Enterprise users and integrate these capabilities into ChatGPT in the future.
 


 The Operator can be tasked with a wide range of repetitive browser activities, such as completing forms, ordering groceries, or even creating memes. By leveraging the same interfaces and tools that people use every day, AI expands its practical applications, helping individuals save time on routine tasks while creating new opportunities for businesses to engage with customers.  OpenAI plans to expand it to Plus, Team, and Enterprise users and integrate these capabilities into ChatGPT in the future.
 


 In the blog, OpenAI states, “Operator is powered by a new model called Computer-Using Agent (CUA). Combining GPT-4o's vision capabilities with advanced reasoning through reinforcement learning, CUA is trained to interact with graphical user interfaces (GUIs)—the buttons, menus, and text fields people see on a screen.“  The operator can "see" the browser through screenshots and "interact" with it using standard mouse and keyboard actions, allowing it to perform tasks on the web without the need for custom API integrations. But is it better when it comes to hallucinations? OpenAI explains that if the Operator faces challenges or errors, it can use its reasoning abilities to correct itself. If it reaches an impasse and requires help, it seamlessly hands control back to the user, ensuring a fluid and cooperative experience. 
 


 Similar to using multiple tabs on a browser, users can have Operator run multiple tasks simultaneously by creating new conversations. o3-mini to come to free users  Just as OpenAI introduced Operator, its first AI agent, CEO Sam Altman took to X (formerly Twitter), saying that the company has decided to introduce o3-mini in the free tier.
 


 The o3-mini marks a significant advancement over its predecessor, the o1-mini, by integrating enhanced reasoning capabilities that enable step-by-step logical analysis. This AI model is yet to see the day of light. According to Altman, it could be launched within 2-weeks. Headline: Trump dismisses Elon Musk's complaint about Altman's Stargate ProjectDonald Trump says Elon Musk hates one of the people who are part of the Stargate Project deal.
Content: Elon Musk and Sam Altman on Thursday had an ugly back and forth on X, which was largely centred around Sam Altman’s new company called the Stargate Project. Musk accused the company of having no money, and in a separate post he also called Altman a liar. Altman also fired back at his posts. Now, commenting on the online fight between the two, Trump has dismissed Musk’s complaints saying “he hates one of the people in the deal”.  “I’ve spoken to Elon, but — spoken to all of them, actually. The people in the deal are very, very smart people – but Elon, one of the people he happens to hate. But I have certain hatreds of people too,” Trump said at the White House, according to a report by CNN Business.  Trump’s comment about Musk hating someone was a clear suggestion that he was talking about Altman. Musk and Altman have a longstanding feud going on, which is largely based on the SpaceX CEO’s argument that OpenAI –– a company that he set up along with Altman –– has moved away from its original mission. OpenAI, he says, was supposed to be open-source and non-profit. However, he has accused Altman of now being driven by a money-making agenda, forgetting the original purpose behind setting up the company.  One of the tweets that Musk posted about Altman on Thursday was again about the money he would make through the Stargate project. Musk claims that in spite of testifying to the congress that he would not take any compensation from OpenAI, now with the setup of the new AI Stargate Project, Altman is seeking 7 per cent of the company, which would apparently be equal to $10 billion.  Musk also tweeted saying that SoftBank and OpenAI, the two companies that will be leading the Stargate Project initiative, “don’t actually have the money”. “SoftBank has well under $10 billion secured. I have that on good authority,” Musk said in a tweet.  To this, Trump responded saying: “I don’t know if they do, but you know, they’re putting up the money –– the government’s not putting up anything, they’re putting up money. They’re very rich people, so I hope they do.” During the Trump inauguration, OpenAI and Softbank announced the new AI company, the Stargate Project. The initiative– which will have an ambitious investment of $500 billion– is backed by the US President. The company is aimed at building AI infrastructure for OpenAI in the United States.  Besides the online fight on Thursday, Elon Musk and Sam Altman are also tangled in lawsuits, which also go back to Musk’s accusation that OpenAI has moved away from its original purpose. Headline: Retired bank manager from Pune loses Rs 2.22 crore after buying multiple insurance policiesIn a new case of cyber fraud, a retired bank manager from Pune lost Rs 2.22 crores over several months. The victim was duped by scammers posing as government officials who had offered her insurance policies with promised high returns.
Content:
A new case of cyber fraud has been reported from Pune, where a 62-year-old retired bank manager lost Rs 2.22 crore. The scam, which spanned several months, involved scammers impersonating government officials and making the victim buy multiple policies with the promise of high maturity benefits. According to the police complaint, as reported by the Indian Express, the fraud began at the end of 2023 and continued until recently. During this time, the victim received several calls from individuals posing as government officials, including those from reputed agencies like the Ministry of Finance, the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI), and the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI). The scammers claimed to represent these organizations and offered the victim several insurance policies with guaranteed high maturity benefits. To further establish their credibility, the scammers even misused the names of prominent personalities such as Deendayal Upadhyaya, along with fictitious titles of finance experts and government officials. The calls were so convincing that the victim ended up believing them. Over time, the victim was coaxed into purchasing various insurance policies and was asked to pay multiple charges, including GST, Income Tax, TDS, transaction fees, verification charges, and NOC charges. According to the report, the criminals operated under at least 19 different identities to maintain their deception. Each time the victim followed the instructions to send money for policies, the scammers asked her to transfer additional funds under the pretext of processing or recovery fees. As the scam progressed, the victim even started receiving calls from purported officials who claimed her previous payments had been diverted to fraudulent accounts. To recover those funds, she was instructed to make further payments, causing her to lose even more money. During the scam period, the victim lost her savings while being threatened and manipulated by the scammers. While the case is under investigation, individuals are urged not to fall for such calls or offers that sound too good to be true. Note that cyber frauds involving insurance and financial benefits are becoming increasingly common in the country. To protect yourself, it’s crucial to follow these safety measures: If you receive calls from unknown persons asking about investments, always cross-check the identity of the callers claiming to represent government agencies or financial institutions. Use official contact details available on their websites. Never share personal or financial details, including bank account numbers, OTPs, or policy numbers, over the phone or with someone you barely know. Be skeptical of unrealistic offers. Investments that guarantee high returns or benefits should raise red flags. Be cautious about requests for payments such as GST, TDS, or other fees. If you need to send money, always first confirm the legitimacy of such demands with the concerned organization.

Headline: Trump issues executive order to create internal group to push crypto growthAs part of the executive order, the creation of central bank digital currencies in the US has also been banned, which could compete with existing cryptocurrencies.
Content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday ordered the creation of a cryptocurrency working group tasked with proposing new digital asset regulations and exploring the creation of a national cryptocurrency stockpile, making good on his promise to quickly overhaul US crypto policy. The much-anticipated action also ordered that banking services for crypto companies be protected, alluding to industry claims that US regulators have directed lenders to cut crypto companies off from banking services - something regulators deny. The order also banned the creation of central bank digital currencies in the US which could compete with existing cryptocurrencies. In another key action pushed for by the crypto industry, the US Securities and Exchange Commission late on Thursday rescinded accounting guidance that had made it very expensive for some listed companies to safeguard crypto assets on behalf of third parties. The crypto industry said that guidance had stymied digital asset adoption. On the campaign trail, Trump courted crypto cash by pledging to be a "crypto president" and promote the adoption of digital assets. That is in stark contrast to former President Joe Biden's regulators which, in a bid to protect Americans from fraud and money laundering, cracked down on the industry, suing exchanges Coinbase, Binance and dozens more, alleging they were flouting US laws. The companies deny the allegations. Thursday's order was cheered by the crypto industry, which had been pushing for the new administration to send a strong signal of support in Trump's first few days in office. "Today’s crypto executive order marks a sea change in US digital asset policy," said Nathan McCauley, CEO and co-founder of crypto company Anchorage Digital. "By taking a whole-of-government approach to crypto, the Administration is making a significant first step toward writing clear, consistent rules of the road." If implemented by the relevant regulators, Trump's order has the potential to push cryptocurrencies into the mainstream, regulatory and crypto experts said. It follows Tuesday's SEC announcement that it was creating a taskforce to overhaul crypto policy. Bitcoin hit a fresh record high of $109,071 on Monday amid investor excitement over the new crypto-friendly administration, although it was down to about $103,000 as of late Thursday afternoon. "Just days into his administration, President Trump is delivering on his promises... to keep the United States a leader in digital assets innovation," Senator Tim Scott, the Republican chair of the Senate Banking Committee, said in a statement. The industry has for years argued existing US regulations are inappropriate for cryptocurrencies and have called for Congress and regulators to write new ones clarifying when a crypto token is a security, commodity or falls into another category. The working group, which will include the Treasury secretary, chairs of the SEC and Commodity Futures Trading Commission, along with other agency heads, is tasked with developing a regulatory framework for digital assets, according to the order. That includes stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency typically pegged to the US dollar. The group is also set to "evaluate the potential creation and maintenance of a national digital asset stockpile... potentially derived from cryptocurrencies lawfully seized by the Federal Government through its law enforcement efforts." The order did not provide further details on how such a stockpile would be set up and analysts and legal experts are divided on whether an act of Congress will be necessary. Some have argued the reserve could be created via the US Treasury's Exchange Stabilisation Fund, which can be used to purchase or sell foreign currencies, and to also hold bitcoin. In December, Trump named venture capitalist and former PayPal, opens new tab executive David Sacks as the crypto and artificial intelligence czar. He will chair the group, the order said.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Jan 24, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: iPhones with pre-installed TikTok selling for thousands of dollars in USASome iPhone owners are cashing in, listing phones with TikTok installed for thousands on eBay, as the app remains unavailable in US app stores.
Content: Some iPhone users are cashing in on an unusual opportunity created by TikTok’s brief absence from the Apple and Google app stores in the United States, according to a report by USA Today. As the popular social media app remains unavailable for new downloads, iPhones with TikTok already installed are popping up on eBay, with some sellers demanding mind-boggling prices of up to $25,000 (roughly Rs 21.6 lakh). The situation stems from a temporary ban that saw TikTok removed from the Apple and Google app stores in the U.S. Although the app has recently become accessible again for millions of users who already had it downloaded, others who deleted it or never installed it are still unable to find it in the stores. This has created a market for phones with the TikTok app pre-installed. Listings for these devices on eBay reveal a wide range of prices. While some sellers are asking for hundreds of dollars, others are going to extremes. For instance, an iPhone 15 Pro Max with TikTok installed was recently listed for $10,000 (roughly Rs 8.62 lakh) by a seller in Florida. Another user in North Carolina listed an iPhone 16 Pro Max for a staggering $25,000 (roughly Rs 21.6 lakh). In one case, an iPhone 15 Pro with TikTok and ByteDance’s video-editing app CapCut installed was listed for a staggering $4.5 million (roughly Rs 38.81 crores). Despite these crazy high price tags, it’s unclear whether such phones are actually selling. Many listings have drawn attention, with some receiving thousands of views, but most devices don’t appear to have active bids. The phones that do have offers tend to be older models priced much more modestly, between $100 and $200 (roughly between Rs 8,600 to Rs 17,200). The demand for these TikTok-equipped phones comes as users wait for the app’s official return to the app stores. President Donald Trump’s recent executive order delaying the enforcement of the TikTok ban has given some hope. However, there is still no timeline for when the app might be reinstated. Trump has suggested the possibility of a joint venture where the U.S. would own 50 per cent of the app or even a potential sale to high-profile figures such as Tesla’s Elon Musk or Oracle’s Larry Ellison. General Atlantic CEO Bill Ford, a major investor in TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance, expressed optimism that a deal could be reached soon. Speaking at an event in Davos, Switzerland, Ford suggested that discussions involving both the Chinese and U.S. governments are moving forward and could yield results by the end of the week.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 24, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Android 16 first public will roll out today, set to bring live updates to your phone's lockscreenAndroid 16's first public beta is rolling out with dynamic notifications, better support for foldables, and app resizability. A full release is expected in Q2.
Content: Google is rolling out the first public beta of Android 16 today, giving early testers a chance to see what the next version of the company’s operating system has in store. This release comes with some big updates, including dynamic notifications for live activities and a push to ensure apps work better on larger screens like foldables and tablets. One of the standout features in Android 16 is called Live Updates, which are real-time notifications designed to help users keep track of ongoing activities like ride-sharing, food deliveries, and navigation. Think of it as Android’s answer to Apple’s Live Activities, introduced in 2022. However, Google’s version is more focused. Unlike Apple’s approach — which supports everything from sports scores to shopping updates — Android’s Live Updates currently only work with progress trackers for specific apps. Interestingly, Samsung showcased a similar feature during the launch of its Galaxy S25 phones during Galaxy Unpacked. Named the Now Bar, Samsung’s take on live notifications appears as a floating bar at the bottom of the lock screen and supports various app types, including sports updates. In contrast, Android 16’s Live Updates are pinned to the top of the standard notification stack, staying true to Android’s simpler design. The Android 16 public beta also brings a change aimed at improving how apps work across devices with different screen sizes. Developers will now have to make their apps resizable, ensuring they run seamlessly on tablets and foldable phones. This means apps will open in full-screen on larger displays and allow users to multitask more easily. For now, developers can opt out of this requirement, but by the time Android 17 arrives in 2026, resizable apps will be mandatory. Games, however, are exempt from this rule. Aside from these changes, Android 16 is adding other features, such as support for the Advanced Professional Video (APV) codec, improved vertical text rendering, and scene detection in camera apps to enable night mode automatically. These features build on improvements introduced in earlier developer betas, such as richer haptic controls, a more refined photo picker menu, and the Health Connect app for sharing medical data across apps securely. Another interesting development is Google’s work on its Gemini AI assistant. Gemini now supports multi-app prompts, though compatibility is currently limited to Google’s apps, a few from Samsung, and third-party platforms like Spotify and WhatsApp. Google promises broader support soon. The Android 16 public beta is available starting today for Pixel 6 and newer devices, as well as the Pixel Tablet. If you’re not ready to dive into beta software, you won’t have to wait long. Google plans to release the stable version of Android 16 by Q2 this year, much earlier than its usual late-summer launch schedule.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 24, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  Best flagship mobile phones in January 2025: OnePlus 13, Vivo X200 Pro and more

Headline: Nobody will use current genAI, LLMs in the next 5 years: Meta chief AI scientist Meta's chief AI scientist predicts that in the next three to five years, we will enter the decade of robotics.
Content:
Speaking at a session at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Meta chief AI scientist, Yann Le Cunn, has predicted “a new paradigm shift of AI architectures”. He says that the AI we know right now, which is generative AI and large language models (LLMs), are not capable of much. They get the basics done but still fall short. And in the next five years, “nobody in their right mind would use them anymore”, he said. “I think the shelf life of the current [AI] paradigm is fairly short, probably three to five years,” LeCun added.  “We’re going to see the emergence of a new paradigm for AI architectures, which may not have the limitations of current AI systems,” he predicts.
The Meta chief AI scientist also believes that in the next few years we could be living in the “decade of robotics” where we will see a whole new application of the technology that will combine robots and AI.  LeCun also explains why he thinks the current AI models aren't capable of doing much. He gives four reasons for that. One, he says, the current models lack the awareness and understanding of the physical world. Two, there is a limitation to how much it remembers at once and does not have a continuous memory. Three, it lacks the power of reasoning. And four, it is unable to perform complex planning tasks.  “So there’s going to be another revolution of AI over the next few years. We may have to change the name of it, because it’s probably not going to be generative in the sense that we understand it today,” LeCun says.  LeCun points out that the “AI revolution” could be some 10 years away, but with the way AI is progressing right now, the big change could be closer. “LLMs are good at manipulating language, but not at thinking,” LeCun said.  While “Debating Technology” at Davos, LeCun may have also revealed what Meta’s AI labs are working on right now. “So that’s what we’re working on — having systems build mental models of the world. If the plan that we’re working on succeeds, with the timetable that we hope, within three to five years we’ll have systems that are a completely different paradigm,” he said. “They may have some level of common sense. They may be able to learn how the world works from observing the world and maybe interacting with it.” Interestingly, as the Meta AI chief scientist spoke about the current AI and LLM models’ lack of performing complex tasks, OpenAI and Perplexity on Friday, unveiled new agentic AI, which they claim excel at performing complex, multi-step tasks. For instance, OpenAI’s AI agent called Operator –– which is unfortunately available only in the US right now –– is capable of ordering groceries for you if you give it a shopping list, or it can book flight tickets for you if you share your itinerary with it. It can also create memes for you. Basically, anything you do on the web, the agentic AI can do on your behalf.
