Headline: Samsung is likely to launch four affordable smartphones in India soonSamsung is planning to expand its 5G smartphone lineup in India with the upcoming launch of four new models — the Galaxy A06, Galaxy F06, Galaxy F16, and Galaxy M16.
Content: Samsung is planning to expand its 5G smartphone lineup in India with the launch of four new models — the Galaxy A06, Galaxy F06, Galaxy F16, and Galaxy M16. The support pages for these devices have recently gone live on Samsung’s official India website, hinting that their release is just around the corner. While the company has not yet made an official announcement, the appearance of these pages, along with multiple certifications and benchmark listings, strongly suggests that the launch is imminent. The model numbers for these devices have been confirmed as SM-A066B/DS (Galaxy A06), SM-E066B/DS (Galaxy F06), SM-E166P/DS (Galaxy F16), and SM-M166P/DS (Galaxy M16). These model numbers were previously spotted on the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) website, further hinting at the possibility of an Indian launch. Additionally, the Galaxy A06 and Galaxy F06 were seen on the Bluetooth SIG database, confirming their support for 2G, 3G, 4G LTE, and 5G connectivity, as well as Bluetooth and WLAN capabilities. The Galaxy A06 is expected to be a major addition to Samsung’s budget A0x series, marking the first time a 5G-enabled device will be introduced in this lineup. Recent Geekbench listings revealed that the phone could come with Android 15 out of the box, paired with 4GB RAM and a MediaTek Dimensity 6300 chipset. On Geekbench 6, the device scored 731 in single-core performance and 1,816 in multi-core performance. There are also rumours that the Galaxy F06 might share similar hardware specifications, positioning it as a slightly more premium alternative to the Galaxy A06. As for the Galaxy F16 and Galaxy M16, these devices are speculated to be rebranded versions of the Galaxy A16, which was launched in India last year, in October. If this turns out to be true, both phones could feature a 6.7-inch FHD+ display, a MediaTek Dimensity 6300 chipset, 8GB RAM, and a triple-camera setup with a 50-megapixel primary rear snapper. Other expected features include a 13-megapixel front-facing camera, a 5,000mAh battery, and support for dual-band Wi-Fi (2.4GHz and 5GHz). Interestingly, a 4G variant of the Galaxy A06 was launched in India in September 2024, featuring a MediaTek Helio G85 chipset, a 5,000mAh battery with 25W charging, and a 50-megapixel dual-rear camera system.  While pricing and exact launch dates remain under wraps, the growing evidence suggests that the wait for these aforementioned affordable devices won’t be long.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 28, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?

Headline: DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works, is it better than ChatGPT? Everything to knowDeepSeek AI has quickly become a major contender in the world of Artificial Intelligence (AI), giving tough competition to platforms like ChatGPT. But, what exactly is DeepSeek AI, how does it work, when was it founded, how can you access DeepSeek R1, and is it better than ChatGPT? We try to answer all these questions in this article.
Content: DeepSeek AI has quickly become a major contender in the world of Artificial Intelligence (AI), giving tough competition to established platforms like ChatGPT. This Chinese startup recently gained attention with the release of its R1 model, which delivers performance similar to ChatGPT, but with the key advantage of being completely free to use. As a result, the DeepSeek app has shot to the top of the charts on the iPhone App Store, showing its growing popularity. But, what exactly is DeepSeek AI, how does it work, when was it founded, how can you access DeepSeek R1, and is it better than ChatGPT? We try to answer all these questions in this article.advertisementWhat is DeepSeek AI, who founded it and how does it work?DeepSeek AI was founded by Liang Wenfeng in May 2023, but it gained the limelight in early 2025 - all thanks to its latest developed large language models (LLMs) - DeepSeek-V3 and DeepSeek-R1. They are designed to be both efficient and cost-effective. To be precise, DeepSeek-V3 is a general-purpose model, while DeepSeek-R1 focuses on tasks requiring reasoning and deeper thinking. Both the models have delivered impressive benchmarks and use fewer resources compared to their rivals. DeepSeek AI was founded by Liang Wenfeng in May 2023, but it gained the limelight in early 2025 - all thanks to its latest developed large language models (LLMs) - DeepSeek-V3 and DeepSeek-R1. They are designed to be both efficient and cost-effective.  To be precise, DeepSeek-V3 is a general-purpose model, while DeepSeek-R1 focuses on tasks requiring reasoning and deeper thinking. Both the models have delivered impressive benchmarks and use fewer resources compared to their rivals. What sets DeepSeek apart from its competitors is the use of a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture. This unique design ensures that only a small portion of the model’s parameters are active at any given time, reducing the amount of computing power required to process queries. Additionally, the AI models improve themselves through a trial-and-error learning process, which mimics human learning. This approach has helped DeepSeek gain a reputation for rapid advancement.How to use DeepSeek R1 AI model? Using DeepSeek is easy and accessible through both its website and mobile apps. People who are not aware, when they start using DeepSeek, the platform is by deault set to DeepSeek-V3 version. In the prompt box, people will also see a DeepThink R1 option, which one can select to start using the company's DeepSeek R1 AI version. It offers advanced reasoning capabilities. The R1 model excels in handling complex questions, particularly those requiring careful thought or mathematical reasoning. While the answers take a few seconds to process, they offer a more thoughtful, step-by-step explanation for the queries.DeepSeek AI vs ChatGPT: Which one is better? What are the key differences? While DeepSeek AI performs impressively in delivering accurate answers, it lacks some of the advanced features that ChatGPT offers. ChatGPT allows users to generate AI images, interact with various tools like Canvas, and even provides a multimodal interface for tasks like image analysis. Additionally, ChatGPT offers voice interaction for users who prefer speaking to the chatbot, while DeepSeek is limited to text-based interactions. In terms of performance, DeepSeek-V3 and R1 compete greatly with ChatGPT models, particularly in answering questions and generating code. You can expect similar and accurate answers with both AI chatbots. In addition to this, both of them have support for search the web feature, so that you can get the latest and accurate info via them.  However, users looking for extra features like customised GPTs (Insta Guru" and "DesignerGPT) or multimedia capabilities will find ChatGPT more useful. For your reference, GPTs are a way for anyone to create a more personalised version of ChatGPT to be more helpful in their daily life, at specific tasks. That being said, DeepSeek’s biggest advantage is that its chatbot is free to use without any limitations and that its APIs are much cheaper. ChatGPT, on the other hand, has paid options for more advanced features. This makes DeepSeek a great option for users who just want a straightforward AI experience without any costs.  People who want to use DeepSeek for more advanced tasks and use APIs with this platform for coding tasks in the backend, then one will have to pay. However, the cost is still quite low compared to OpenAI's ChatGPT. For DeepSeek, one will have to spend $0.55 per mission input tokens and $2.19 per million output tokens. This is way lower than OpenAI's API, costing $15 and $60.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 28, 2025

Headline: Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok, says US President TrumpAmid the chaos over TikTok ownership, US President Donald Trump confirmed that Microsoft is consulting to acquire the Chinese social media platform.
Content: US President Donald Trump told reporters on Monday that Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok and that he would like to see a bidding war over the app. Microsoft declined to comment. TikTok and ByteDance did not immediately respond to Reuters' requests for a comment outside regular business hours. TikTok, which has about 170 million American users, was briefly taken offline just before a law requiring its Chinese owner ByteDance to either sell it on national security grounds or face a ban took effect on January 19. Trump, after taking office on January 20, signed an executive order seeking to delay by 75 days the enforcement of the law. Trump said last week that he was in talks with multiple people over buying TikTok and would likely have a decision on the popular app's future in 30 days. The US president has previously said that he was open to billionaire Elon Musk buying the social media app if the Tesla CEO wanted to do so. Musk, however, has not publicly commented on Trump's offer. More recently, AI startup Perplexity AI on Sunday made a proposal to merge with TikTok, with the US government getting up to half of the new company in the future, a source told Reuters on Sunday. The reported talks mark the second time that Microsoft has been in the frame to acquire TikTok. During his first term, Trump ordered TikTok to separate its US version from ByteDance citing national security concerns. Microsoft emerged as a top bidder in 2020, but the talks soon collapsed, and Trump's divestment push ended a few months later when he left office. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella called that deal the "strangest thing I've ever worked on." The US government had a "particular set of requirements and then it just disappeared," he said in 2021.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 28, 2025Tune InAlso read |  Meta offering Rs 43 lakh per month to TikTok creators for creating content on InstagramAlso read |  New bid for TikTok from Perplexity AI could give US government 50% stakeAlso read |  Perplexity AI proposes US stake in TikTok merger: ReportMust Watch

Headline: iPhone SE 4 is said to feature a notch like iPhone 14 and not the Dynamic IslandiPhone SE 4 is rumoured to feature a notch instead of the Dynamic Island, aligning it closer to the iPhone 14 design. Expected to launch in spring, the phone is expected to feature a 6.1-inch OLED display, a single rear camera and an A17 Pro chip under the hood paired with 8GB RAM.
Content: Apple’s next iPhone, the iPhone SE 4, was looking to be a big update, but not in the way some leaks initially suggested. According to Ross Young, the device will feature a notch, similar to the one found on the iPhone 14, rather than the Dynamic Island that has become a go-to design inclusion in Apple’s more recent premium models. This contradicts earlier leaks, including one from Evan Blass, which showed the SE 4 with a Dynamic Island. The confusion doesn’t end there. Earlier this month, leaker Evan Blass shared images of what was claimed to be the iPhone SE 4’s design, showcasing a device with a Dynamic Island. Adding to the mix, a leak from February 2024, via Majin Bu on X (formerly Twitter), also suggested the Dynamic Island would make its way to SE 4. However, most other reports and rumours point towards Apple sticking with the older notch design, especially since the SE 4 is said to be modelled after the iPhone 14. If the iPhone SE 4 does end up getting the notch design, it would at least make sense from a cost perspective. The iPhone 14’s body and components are likely more affordable to replicate, keeping the SE 4’s price tag competitive. Alleged screen protectors for the SE 4 also seem to support the notch design, further hinting that these speculations are indeed true. Apart from this, one of the biggest changes coming with the iPhone SE 4 is the removal of TouchID. Apple is reportedly planning to remove the fingerprint sensor in its iPhone lineup, making FaceID the standard across all models.  In terms of specs, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to feature a 6.1-inch OLED display, a single rear camera, and 8GB RAM. Under the hood, it’s rumoured to be powered by the A17 Pro chip, which should make it capable of supporting Apple Intelligence, given the iPhone 15 Pro supports the company’s latest AI-driven features, and it is also powered by the A17 Pro chip. While some leaks have suggested a vertical rear camera bump similar to the rumoured iPhone 16 design, this remains unconfirmed. As for the launch, current rumours point to a spring release, likely between March and April. With the iPhone SE 4, Apple seems to be aiming to offer a more modern design and features at an accessible price point, though it remains to be seen how much of the premium iPhone experience will trickle down to this budget model. Globally, the phone is tipped to be priced under $500 (roughly 43,300). An earlier rumour placed its price between $499 (roughly Rs 43,200) and $549 (roughly Rs 47,500). This is a noticeable jump from the launch price of the iPhone SE 3, which debuted at $429 or Rs 43,900 in India. However, after just a few months, the Indian price of the SE 3 rose to Rs 49,900. So, the biggest question is — with its upgraded features, can the iPhone SE 4 remain under the Rs 50,000 price point in India? We’ll have to wait and see.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?

Headline: Elon Musk's X will launch its first digital wallet this yearX has joined hands with Visa to handle payment services on X Money, scheduled to arrive later this year.
Content:
Elon Musk owned social media platform, X (formerly Twitter) will soon introduce financial services on its app. X has recently announced its partnership with Visa, signalling its first digital wallet. The company will use Visa Direct, Visa's real-time money transfer solution, to fund X Money’s wallet, link to a debit card for payments to other users, and enable seamless transfers back to your bank account. In a post, X CEO Linda Yaccarino stated that X Money is scheduled to launch later this year. This X-Visa partnership will allow secure and instant funding to users’ X Wallet via Visa Direct, she added. It will also connect debit cards, allowing person-to-person payments. 
 


 X Money will also give users an option to instantly transfer funds to your bank account. Yaccarino claims that this is the "first of many big announcements about X Money this year”.  The thought of adding financial services to X was communicated right after Musk took over. With this partnership, it looks like the services will arrive in the US first and then expand to the rest of the world. But as per previous reports, this service will be available to selected states first.  App researchers have repeatedly discovered code related to X Money, highlighting features such as the ability to load funds into a wallet on the platform and make payments to other users. The X Money service is set to launch in the first quarter, with additional partnerships in the works. According to the CNBC report, one of the initial use cases for X Money will be to enable creators on the platform to receive payments and store funds independently.  X Payments LLC is licensed in 41 states and registered with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN), according to its website. In the recent affair, Musk has been reportedly sending emails to its X employees, signalling that the platform is struggling financially. According to a report by Wall Street Journal, he admitted that X is “barely breaking even,” citing stagnant user growth and underwhelming revenue.  He added, “Our user growth is stagnant, revenue is unimpressive, and we’re barely breaking even.”  Musk acquired the social media platform, previously called Twitter, in a $44 billion deal in late 2022. Since then, he has implemented several changes, such as eliminating the free verification program, launching a paid membership option, and rebranding the company as X.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Tune InTrending Reel

Headline: OpenAI introduces ChatGPT Gov for US government: How does it workOpenAI has recently launched ChatGPT Gov for US government agencies to boost the adoption of artificial intelligence.
Content: OpenAI's ChatGPT Gov is a new tailored version of ChatGPT designed to provide US government agencies with an additional way to access OpenAI’s frontier models. In the blog post, the company said that by making ChatGPT available to the US government, OpenAI aims to ensure "AI serves the national interest and the public good, aligned with democratic values, while empowering policymakers to responsibly integrate these capabilities to deliver better services to the American people."  OpenAI said the agencies can deploy ChatGPT Gov in their own Microsoft Azure commercial cloud, and will have access to many of the features and capabilities of ChatGPT Enterprise, including custom GPTs. The blog stated that ChatGPT Gov will help agencies control their own security, privacy, and compliance needs, including strict cybersecurity standards like IL5, CJIS, ITAR, and FedRAMP High. This setup can also speed up internal approval for using OpenAI’s tools with sensitive, non-public data.  Kevin Weil, OpenAI CPO, posted on X (formerly Twitter) that the ChatGPT Gov delivers "enormous potential tools to support the public sector in tackling complex challenges, from improving public health and infrastructure to strengthening national security." OpenAI's ChatGPT Gov has similar features as ChatGPT Enterprise In the blog post, the company listed a few features, claiming that the features overlap with ChatGPT Enterprise. But these features come with enhanced security. As per the company, it allows government officials to save and share conversations within a secure workspace, as well as upload text and image files. Powered by the GPT-4o flagship model, it also enables employees to create and share custom GPTs within their workspace. This launch follows widespread adoption of OpenAI's AI technology across various government levels. More than 90,000 government employees have used ChatGPT, generating over 18 million prompts for tasks like document translation, drafting policy memos, code development, and application creation, according to the company. OpenAI is also pursuing FedRAMP accreditation for ChatGPT Enterprise, the foundation of ChatGPT Gov, to ensure compliance with government security standards. The launch follows a post by CEO Sam Altman on X, where he announced plans to accelerate certain releases. This was his first public comment after the low-cost Chinese AI startup DeepSeek disrupted AI-related stocks on Monday. Altman referred to DeepSeek as a "new competitor" after its free AI assistant surpassed ChatGPT in downloads on Apple's App Store. The model's rapid rise has prompted US tech investors to take a closer look at the billions of dollars committed to expanding AI operations.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Elon Musk's X will launch its first digital wallet this yearAlso read |  DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works and is it better than ChatGPT? Everything to knowAlso read |  OpenAI CEO Sam Altman calls rival DeepSeek impressive, promises to deliver AGI soon

Headline: iPhone 17 tipped to receive big design overhaul, but it could miss out on this featureRumours about the iPhone 17 series suggest a major redesign of the rear camera module, potentially impacting spatial video capabilities. Could Apple's new design come at the cost of a key feature?
Content: Apple’s iPhone 17 series is rumoured to bring one of the most impactful design changes in years, particularly to its rear camera module. Reports suggest that the Pro models might get rid of the iconic triangular lens arrangement in favour of a sleek horizontal bar-style setup, similar to what we get on Google’s Pixel 9. While this could give the iPhone a much-needed design change, it might come with a major trade-off — the potential loss of spatial video. Spatial video, introduced with the iPhone 15 Pro, is a feature that allows users to capture immersive, three-dimensional content for Apple’s Vision Pro headset. It works by using vertically aligned lenses to mimic the distance between human eyes, creating depth and perspective in videos. This alignment is crucial for the feature to function properly. However, if Apple shifts to a horizontal camera layout, as rumoured, spatial video capture in landscape mode could become impossible. This raises questions about Apple’s priorities. Spatial video has been a standout feature in recent iPhone models, heavily marketed as part of the Vision Pro ecosystem. Losing it on the Pro models, which are typically the most advanced in the lineup, would be a surprising move. Even more intriguing is the possibility that the standard iPhone 17 models might retain the vertical lens alignment, keeping spatial video functionality intact. If true, this would mark a big shift in Apple’s strategy, as advanced features have historically been reserved for the Pro models. On the other hand, if the horizontal design is adopted across the entire iPhone 17 series, including the rumoured iPhone 17 Air, spatial video could disappear altogether. The Air model, said to feature a single rear camera, would be essentially incompatible with the feature. This has left many wondering whether Apple is willing to sacrifice a key selling point for the sake of a design overhaul. However, there’s a chance Apple might have a workaround. Advances in computational photography, such as Gaussian splatting, could allow the company to retain spatial video functionality without relying on traditional lens arrangements. This technology, which creates 3D models from multiple camera angles, might offer a solution to the hardware limitations posed by a horizontal camera design. Having said that, it is still very early to talk about the iPhone 17 series. Until then, the rumours remain just that — rumours.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?

Headline: Nothing Phone 3a specs leaked, said to feature 6.8-inch display and 50MP telephoto cameraNothing is gearing up to launch its Phone 3 series, including the Phone 3a, on March 4. The phone is rumoured to feature a Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chip, a 6.8-inch OLED display, and a 50-megapixel telephoto camera.
Content:
Nothing, a brand synonymous with making phones with unique designs and Glyph lighting, is preparing to unveil its next smartphone, the Nothing Phone 3a, on March 4. According to a tweet by Gadget Bits on X (formerly Twitter), this upcoming mid-range device is expected to bring some notable upgrades over its predecessor, including a larger display, a new Qualcomm chipset, and an improved camera setup. While the company has remained tight-lipped about the specifics, leaks and certifications have given us a clearer picture of what to expect.

Source: Gadget Bits/ X (formerly Twitter)
 The Nothing Phone 3a is rumoured to feature a 6.8-inch OLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate, making it the biggest screen on any Nothing phone so far. The device will reportedly be powered by the Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chipset, a shift from the MediaTek Dimensity processor used in the Phone 2a. The phone will also run on Nothing OS 3.1, based on Android 15. One of the most exciting upgrades is the camera system. The Phone 3a is said to include a 50-megapixel primary rear camera paired with a 50-megapixel telephoto camera with 2x optical zoom, marking the first time Nothing has included a telephoto lens in its smartphones. However, this addition comes at the cost of the ultra-wide camera, which is expected to drop to 8-megapixel. On the front, a 32-megapixel selfie camera will sit in a hole-punch cutout, similar to previous models. In terms of battery life, nothing major is expected here, at least, if the leaks are to be believed. The Nothing Phone 3a will reportedly pack a 5,000mAh battery with support for 45W wired charging, matching the battery specs of the Phone 2a. Other expected features include NFC support and the company’s signature Glyph lighting. Interestingly, rumours suggest that Nothing might also launch a more premium variant, the Phone 3a Plus, alongside the standard model. The Plus variant could feature a periscope telephoto camera, offering a longer focal length than the 2x zoom on the Phone 3a. This would make it a more appealing option for photography enthusiasts. Both models have been spotted in certification databases, with model numbers A059 and A059P, respectively. Earlier reports suggested that Nothing might launch the Phone 3 series, including the flagship Phone 3, alongside the Phone 3a and 3a Plus on March 5. However, according to Yogesh Brar on X, it seems the Nothing Phone 3 may not debut on that date after all. Instead, the event is expected to feature the launch of three devices, but those eagerly awaiting the Phone 3 might have to wait a bit longer. If the Nothing Phone 3 doesn’t arrive on March 5, the question arises — what could the third device be, alongside the Phone 3a and 3a Plus? For now, it’s anyone’s guess, and only time will tell. We recommend taking this information with a healthy grain of salt until official details are confirmed.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?

Headline: Microsoft investigating if DeepSeek-linked group improperly obtained OpenAI dataMicrosoft and OpenAI are probing if data output from the ChatGPT maker's technology was obtained in an unauthorised manner by a group linked to Chinese artificial intelligence (AI) startup DeepSeek, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday.
Content: Microsoft and OpenAI are probing if data output from the ChatGPT maker's technology was obtained in an unauthorised manner by a group linked to Chinese artificial intelligence (AI) startup DeepSeek, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday. Microsoft's security researchers observed that, in the fall, individuals they believed to be connected to DeepSeek exfiltrating a large amount of data using the OpenAI's application programming interface (API), the report said. OpenAI's API is the main way that software developers and business customers buy OpenAI's services. Microsoft, the largest investor for OpenAI, notified the company of suspicious activity, according to the Bloomberg report. Low-cost Chinese AI startup DeepSeek, an alternative to US rivals, sparked a tech stock selloff on Monday as its free AI assistant overtook OpenAI's ChatGPT on Apple's App Store in the United States. David Sacks, the White House's AI and crypto czar, told, opens new tab Fox News in an interview earlier on Tuesday that it was "possible" that DeepSeek stole intellectual property from the United States. "There's substantial evidence that what DeepSeek did here is they distilled the knowledge out of OpenAI's models," Sacks said. Asked for comment on the Bloomberg report, an OpenAI spokesperson echoed Sacks in a statement that noted China-based companies and others were constantly attempting to replicate the models of leading US AI companies, without specifically naming DeepSeek or any other company. "We engage in counter-measures to protect our IP, including a careful process for which frontier capabilities to include in released models, and believe as we go forward that it is critically important that we are working closely with the US government to best protect the most capable models from efforts by adversaries and competitors to take US technology." Microsoft declined to comment, while DeepSeek could not be immediately reached for a comment.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 29, 2025

Headline: iPhone SE 4 leaks again in new images next to iPhone 16The latest leaked images of the iPhone SE 4 have surfaced, this time alongside the iPhone 16 in pink. As long-rumoured, the SE 4 retains the single rear camera setup from its predecessors. However, the camera module itself appears larger this time around.
Content:
The iPhone SE 4 has been making quite the headlines lately, thanks to a series of leaks and rumours. Recently, new images and a hands-on video have surfaced online, giving us a closer look at what Apple’s next budget-friendly iPhone might offer. According to tipster Majin Bu on X (formerly Twitter), the leaked images show the device in black and white, with a design that seems to blend elements from recent iPhones while keeping some familiar touches from the SE lineup. A separate post also shows the iPhone SE 4 posing next to the iPhone 16. 

Source: Majin Bu/ X (formerly Twitter)
 According to the leaks, the alleged iPhone SE 4 appears to have a boxy frame with rounded edges, similar to the iPhone 14 and retains the power button on the right side. However, one of the biggest talking points is the rear camera setup. Unlike the dual-camera system seen on the iPhone 16, the SE 4 seems to stick with a single large sensor, accompanied by an LED flash. This keeps it in line with its predecessor, the iPhone SE 3, but with a noticeably larger camera module. The front design remains a bit of a mystery. While the leaked video doesn’t show the screen turned on, Majin Bu suggests that the final version will feature a notch, much like the iPhone 14. However, recent rumours have also hinted at the possibility of a Dynamic Island, which has become a signature feature on newer iPhone models. In fact, in a recent tweet, Ross Young claims that the iPhone SE 4 will feature a notch instead of the Dynamic Island. Amid the confusion, it’s unclear which direction Apple will take, but the notch seems more likely for a budget device. Another interesting detail is the inclusion of an action button, replacing the traditional mute switch. This change aligns the SE 4 with Apple’s current iPhone models, giving it a more modern feel. The phone is also expected to ditch the Lightning port in favour of USB-C. Under the hood, the iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to be powered by the A17 Pro chip, the same processor that’s also in the iPhone 15 Pro, along with 8GB RAM. The display is likely to be a 6.1-inch OLED panel with a 60Hz refresh rate, offering a big upgrade over the LCD screens used in previous SE models. The camera setup is expected to include a 48-megapixel primary rear camera and a 24-megapixel front-facing camera. As for the launch, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to hit the global market, including India, between March and April, later this year. Pricing is rumoured to start at $499 (roughly Rs 43,200). This is a noticeable jump from the launch price of the iPhone SE 3, which debuted at $429 or Rs 43,900 in India. However, after just a few months, the Indian price of the SE 3 rose to Rs 49,900. So, the biggest question is — with its upgraded features, can the iPhone SE 4 remain under the Rs 50,000 price point in India? We’ll have to wait and see.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  OnePlus 13 effectively available for Rs 64,999: Who should buy it?Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?

Headline: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7, Flip 7 prices leak: How much will they cost in India?Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Flip 7 are rumoured to hit the market in July or August. While the details are under wrap for now, the recent leak suggests the price tag of the phones.
Content: After launching the Samsung Galaxy S25 series, the company is anticipated to launch its next-gen foldable devices soon. For years, Samsung has been following a timeline that unveils the foldables in July, and 2025 seems no different. Aligning with this speculation, previous rumours also suggested that the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Flip 7 are expected to hit the market in late July or early August. While there is no official information yet, a recent leak suggests the pricing of the upcoming foldables. advertisementSamsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Flip 7 prices leakedAccording to the leak, the upcoming folds will be priced similar to its predecessor, the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 6 and Z Flip 6. Tipster @PandaFlashPro posted on Twitter, stating that in most of the markets, the Galaxy Z Flip 7 and Galaxy Z Fold 7 will be launched at the same prices as last year. This means that the Galaxy Z Fold 7 could start at Rs 1,64,999, and the Galaxy Z Flip 6 at Rs 1,09,999 in India, since these were the respective prices of the predecessors.   According to the leak, the upcoming folds will be priced similar to its predecessor, the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 6 and Z Flip 6. Tipster @PandaFlashPro posted on Twitter, stating that in most of the markets, the Galaxy Z Flip 7 and Galaxy Z Fold 7 will be launched at the same prices as last year. This means that the Galaxy Z Fold 7 could start at Rs 1,64,999, and the Galaxy Z Flip 6 at Rs 1,09,999 in India, since these were the respective prices of the predecessors.    If this holds to be true, the upcoming foldables will not see a price increase. That said, rumours also suggest that Samsung will reveal a budget-friendly choice, to make up for the decreased price expectations. Samsung Galaxy Flip 7 might arrive with a younger sibling this year -- Galaxy Z Flip 7 FE, which would be a more affordable alternative to the flagship. Samsung Galaxy Z Flip 7 and Fold 7: What to expect  The Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7 are expected to introduce notable upgrades, including Samsung's Exynos 2500 chipset. Display sizes are rumoured to increase, with the Galaxy Z Fold 7 featuring an 8-inch internal screen and a 6.5-inch cover display, matching the Galaxy Z Fold 6 SE. The Galaxy Z Flip 7 may boast a 6.85-inch main display, up from the Flip 6’s 6.7 inches, and a larger 4-inch cover screen compared to its predecessor's 3.4 inches. Both foldables are also expected to be 10 per cent thinner, offering a more refined and compact design. But there is more... Samsung to launch 4 foldables this year  As we discuss Samsung's plans for its next-gen foldables, the rumour has it that it will release 2 more devices other than usual. The Galaxy Z Flip 7 FE and a triple foldable are also expected to hit the market, along with the Galaxy Z Flip 7 and Fold 7.  Galaxy Z Flip 7 FE: After Motorola and Infinix launched their flip phones for under Rs 50,000, Samsung is reportedly planning to expand its foldable tech into an affordable range. To maintain a low-cost, the FE model is reportedly powered by the Exynos 2400e, which also powers the Galaxy S24 FE.  Triple-foldable phone: Samsung has been developing a triple-fold smartphone for quite some time. In 2022, the company revealed a prototype of the device, but it has yet to be released. However, recent leaks suggest that 2025 might finally be the year for its debut, with a potential launch as early as September. Notably, this timeline coincides with the anticipated release of the Galaxy Z Flip 7.   While details about the tri-fold device remain limited, one intriguing theory indicates it could feature a massive 12.4-inch display when fully unfolded. This impressive screen size could position the device as a versatile hybrid, serving as both a smartphone and a tablet, and surpassing the 10.2-inch display of Huawei’s Mate X3. Additionally, a partially unfolded mode with a screen size of around 10.5 inches could offer a premium viewing experience, further boosting its appeal.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  Samsung is likely to launch four affordable smartphones in India soonAlso read |  Nothing Phone 3a specs leaked, said to feature 6.8-inch display and 50MP telephoto cameraAlso read |  iPhone 17 tipped to receive big design overhaul, but it could miss out on this featureMust Watch

Headline: 5 habits of Bill Gates that can improve your productivity and achieve successBill Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft and a well-known philanthropist, is often admired for more than just his contributions to technology. While success is unique to each individual, Gates' routines can serve as valuable lessons for improving productivity and achieving goals. Here are five key habits of Gates that you should know about.
Content: Bill Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft and a well-known philanthropist, is often admired for more than just his contributions to technology. His disciplined habits and approach to life have played a big role in shaping his journey to success. While success is unique to each individual, Gates' routines can serve as valuable lessons for improving productivity and achieving goals. Here are five key habits of Bill Gates that can inspire and guide you.advertisementAvid ReaderOne of Bill Gates’ defining habits is his love for reading. He reads around 50 books each year, using them as a source of continuous learning and growth. Gates often shares his book recommendations on his blog, showcasing the importance of expanding one's knowledge across different fields. Whether it’s business, science, or personal development, reading regularly helps broaden perspectives and improves problem-solving abilities. This habit reminds us that investing time in learning is crucial for staying ahead in any field.Clear goals and hard workGates always had a clear vision for Microsoft, and his dedication to achieving that vision was constant. He consistently worked hard to bring his ideas to life, which ultimately led Microsoft to become one of the most influential tech companies in the world. Gates' approach shows us that setting clear goals and putting in consistent effort are critical steps toward success. Without a strong work ethic and focus, it’s challenging to turn dreams into reality.Learning from mistakesadvertisement One of Bill Gates’ defining habits is his love for reading. He reads around 50 books each year, using them as a source of continuous learning and growth. Gates often shares his book recommendations on his blog, showcasing the importance of expanding one's knowledge across different fields. Whether it’s business, science, or personal development, reading regularly helps broaden perspectives and improves problem-solving abilities. This habit reminds us that investing time in learning is crucial for staying ahead in any field.Clear goals and hard work Gates always had a clear vision for Microsoft, and his dedication to achieving that vision was constant. He consistently worked hard to bring his ideas to life, which ultimately led Microsoft to become one of the most influential tech companies in the world. Gates' approach shows us that setting clear goals and putting in consistent effort are critical steps toward success. Without a strong work ethic and focus, it’s challenging to turn dreams into reality.Learning from mistakes Unlike many who shy away from failure, Bill Gates believes in learning from mistakes. Throughout his career, Gates has openly acknowledged his missteps, viewing them as valuable learning experiences. This mindset teaches us the importance of resilience — mistakes aren’t the end of the road, but opportunities for growth. By accepting errors and adapting, one can continuously improve and refine their strategies, both in work and life.Success beyond personal gain Beyond his success in business, Gates is known for his deep connection to philanthropy. Through the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, he has supported many causes, focusing on global health and development. Gates’ dedication to giving back serves as a reminder that true success isn’t just about personal wealth, but also about making a positive impact on the world. This habit of philanthropy highlights the importance of using resources to uplift others and create meaningful change.Focus on what truly matters Despite his billionaire status, Bill Gates leads a life of simplicity. Whether it’s his modest choice of clothing or his approach to spending, Gates chooses substance over materialism. He believes that success doesn’t come from luxury but from focusing on important aspects of life, such as knowledge, relationships, and giving back. This habit of simple living with high thinking gives the idea that true fulfilment comes from pursuing one’s passion and contributing to society, rather than from material possessions. By adopting these habits from Bill Gates, individuals can not only improve their productivity but also lead a more purpose-driven life. Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 29, 2025

Headline: Just days after DeepSeek AI craze, China's humanoid robots dance and dazzle in a viral videoJust days after the DeepSeek AI trend swept across tech circles, 16 robots from Unitree Robotics took centre stage, dancing alongside human performers in a display that quickly went viral and caught the attention of social media users on X and Reddit.
Content:
In an impressive showcase of technology and culture, China’s humanoid robots stunned audiences at this year’s Spring Festival Gala. Just days after the DeepSeek AI trend swept across tech circles, 16 robots from Unitree Robotics took centre stage, dancing alongside human performers in a display that quickly went viral and caught the attention of social media users on X and Reddit. The robots were made to perform a traditional Yangko dance — a folk art from northeast China. Users on social media are impressed by the performance of these robots because they move in perfect sync with the human performers. They even manipulated handkerchiefs with their mechanical arms, twirling and tossing them into the air with a precision that left audiences in awe.Social media users make fun of Elon Musk's Optimus robot Social media was quick to react to the performance, with platforms like Reddit and X (formerly Twitter) flooded with comments from impressed viewers. Many expressed amazement at how smoothly the robots danced, with some users calling it a "fascinating" display of AI capabilities. One Reddit user commented, "The way those robots spin those handkerchiefs is seriously impressive," while another added, "I think it’s cool how they’re blending technology with culture. This is the future." Comparisons are also being drawn between China’s humanoid robots and other robotics projects around the world, particularly Elon Musk’s Optimus robot. Some users noted that while Optimus is still in development and struggles with basic movements, China’s robots were already performing complex dance routines with ease. One X user humorously commented, "While Musk’s robot is still learning to walk, China’s robots are already dancing like pros."What tech these Chinese humanoid robots are using? Unitree Robotics, the Chinese company behind these humanoid robots, revealed that the robots used in the performance are part of their "Fuxi" series. According to the company, these robots are equipped with 360-degree of panoramic depth perception technology, which allows them to navigate their surroundings with precision. It allows them to perform complex movements like the waist-twisting and leg-kicking steps typical of the Yangko dance. This technology, combined with high-precision 3D laser SLAM (simultaneous localisation and mapping) positioning, enables the robots to perform on complex stages like the one at the Spring Festival Gala without missing a beat. Check out the robot dancing video below
 
Why is this a big deal? It is a big deal because China is giving tough competition to America in this AI race and the country is able to offer great AI products without making much of noise. As mentioned above, the new robots are designed with AI-driven motion control technology that allows them to mimic human movements and the accuracy is remarkable, something which can be seen in the viral video.  What set the performance apart was not just the robots' ability to replicate human dance moves, but their capacity to adjust in real-time to the music. Using advanced AI algorithms, the robots were able to "understand" the music, adapting their movements based on its rhythm and tempo. This ability to react to external stimuli is one of the key features of Unitree’s AI-driven robots, allowing them to function in dynamic environments like a live stage performance.China's growing presence in AI is likely a threat to the US market The viral success of the robot dance comes just days after another major AI breakthrough from China: the release of DeepSeek AI. It is an advanced large language model that has been gaining attention as a strong competitor to platforms like ChatGPT, which is free of cost with performance on point and it even uses fewer resources compared to its rivals.  Together, these two events shows China’s growing presence in the global AI and robotics space. Donald Trump has also issued a warning against the growing presence of Chinese AI tech with a statement that the success of DeepSeek AI should be a wake up call for the US tech industry. Well, so far, America has been dominating the AI space with companies like OpenAI and Google. With the debut of DeepSeek AI, Trump is seemingly worried about his country's future position in the AI tech space.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 29, 2025

Headline: iOS 18.3 introduces Starlink connectivity: What is it and how does it workApple has recently rolled out the iOS 18.3 update globally. Apart from other Apple Intelligence features and improvements, it has also introduced Starlink connectivity.
Content: Apple iOS 18.3 is finally here with a bunch of new features and bug fixes. Apart from the mainstream features, the company has also introduced Starlink connectivity, a new satellite connection. After introducing satellite connectivity features in 2022, iOS 18.3 has further improved the functionality. According to the Bloomberg report, Apple was secretly working with Space X and T-mobiles, to bring Starlink satellite connectivity to the iPhone.  The report added that T-Mobile has begun testing an early version of the Starlink service with a limited number of iPhones. This development coincides with the release of iOS 18.3, although Apple did not highlight this change in the update’s release notes.How does it work?  Now that Starlink is on board with Apple, it will allow users to send text messages even when there is no cellular network. But how is it different? The company explains, when a T-Mobile iPhone has no cellular signal, devices in the Starlink program will try to connect to SpaceX satellites. Users can also enable texting through the satellite menu for Globalstar or contact emergency services via Apple.  Currently, Starlink only supports texting, but SpaceX and T-Mobile plan to add data and voice services later. The program is available only in the US for now, unlike Apple’s Globalstar service, which works in multiple countries. SpaceX also aims to expand Starlink to other carriers worldwide. The Bloomberg report also highlighted another key difference. It states that Apple's current feature requires users to manually point their iPhone toward the sky to connect with a satellite. In contrast, the Starlink option is designed to work automatically, even when the phone is in the user's pocket. iOS 18.3 update: What is new Other than the Starlink connectivity, Apple has also improved certain existing features and introduced a few new ones.  Return of Calculator Repeated Operations: iOS 18.3 reinstates the repeated operations feature in the Calculator app, a popular functionality from iOS 17 that was removed in iOS 18. Its return has been welcomed by users who rely on it for quick and efficient calculations. New Features for iPhone 16 Series: The update introduces enhanced camera controls for iPhone 16 users, allowing Auto Exposure and Auto Focus Lock with a simple press and hold on the Camera Control button. The new Visual Intelligence feature also lets users scan posters with date and location details to create calendar events seamlessly and identify plants and animals in real-time—perfect for nature enthusiasts. Improved Notification Summaries: Notification summaries in iOS 18.3 now appear in italicised text, making them easier to differentiate from standard notifications. Genmoji Accessibility and Security Enhancements: Creating and using Genmoji is now more straightforward in Messages and other supported apps. On the security side, the update fixes 20 bugs and introduces safeguards to prevent unauthorised access to sensitive audio and visual data on iPhones.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Jan 29, 2025Also read |  iPhone SE 4 leaks again in new images next to iPhone 16Also read |  iPhone 17 tipped to receive big design overhaul, but it could miss out on this featureAlso read |  iOS 18.3 stable update now rolling out to compatible iPhones

Headline: Canon R5 Mark II review: One camera to do it all Cameras, once considered essential, have evolved into specialised tools. But in 2025 if you need one, irrespective of your requirement, chances are that you won't find a camera better than the Canon R5 Mark II. It is expensive but it also does everything.
Content:
Over here at India Today Tech we rarely review DSLR cameras nowadays. Reason for that is simple: as smartphones have improved at clicking photos in the last 7-8 years, the nature of big and hulking DSLR cameras has changed. Earlier cameras used to be a general-purpose tool. They would be required whenever we wanted to click photos. Now, most people use a phone for that. Cameras, essentially, have become specialised tools. So, why am I reviewing the Canon R5 Mark II today? Because it is an incredible machine, and while I am certain that a lot of people who use DSLRs already know about it well enough, it is a kind of gadget that is worth the attention from anyone thinking of upping their game and getting into serious photography, the kind of photography that is done not as a family service during a weekend outing, but as a hobby and for joy.  And talking of joy, here is my one-line review of the Canon R5 Mark II: It has been a blast to click photos with it over the last 10 days. The experience has been so good that it reminded me of days from a few years ago when I always had a DSLR camera in my bag.  Now, before I talk about my experience with it, first a quick primer on the R5 Mark II, largely for people who don’t track cameras. The Canon R5 Mark II is the first update to the popular R5. And as an update, it shares a number of similarities with the R5, as well as a few key enhancements. Over the last few years, there has been a flurry of improvements in the camera market. The mirror is now gone from DSLRs. The sensors have much higher resolutions and their read-out speeds have gone up significantly. The electronic viewfinders have become much much better. And most importantly — this is a trend that Canon kickstarted — the autofocus has acquired some new AI-driven tricks.Excellent sensor and hardware The Canon R5 Mark II, in a way, is a machine that brings to prosumers, professionals and hobbyists the best of this camera progress in a price that is high but palatable. It is built around a 45-megapixel sensor, which means it is versatile. Shooting landscape, portraits and architecture? Its sensor has enough pixels to give you a truckload of details. Shooting action such as your friends during a cricket match or a running wildebeest during a safari in Kenya? The sensor resolves enough details to let you do some aggressive cropping. Want to do some low-light shooting? The Canon R5 II sensor has enough dynamic range to make even extremely high ISO photography — say 12800 — usable. 
 


 The high-resolution sensor also means that the R5 Mark II can be a perfect tool for amateur or semi-professional videography. It can shoot video footage in up to 8K and 30FPS, with higher speeds of 120FPS and 60FPS available with 4K resolution. Even if you are going to only use 4K or 1080P footage for your content, the higher resolution gives you the ability to do more creative cropping. In other words, you can easily make the R5 Mark II work as your primary camera for YouTube content. This sensor is paired with the rest of the hardware that too is top of the line. The body of the R5 II is built well and is weather-sealed, offering a decent amount of protection against moisture and dust. Yet, it is also relatively light. It weighs just a little over 700 grams, which makes it handier and easier to use even for hours when paired with a relatively short and light lens. For example, I used the R5 Mark II with the RF 24-105 F4 lens, which is available as a kit option with the camera. The combination was perfect for day-to-day shooting. One more thing that helps as you use the R5 Mark II is its mature controls and grip. Unlike what I have seen with cameras from some other brands, the Canon grip and control system is well-tuned, making the camera feel like an extension of your arm. Inside the camera, there is the Digic X chipset accompanied by a separate accelerator chip. Apart from the sensor, it is this chipset that is largely responsible for the speed of the camera. And the R5 Mark II is extremely fast. Because of its electronic shutter, it can shoot at a speed of up to 30FPS. Although if you are a purist and choose to use a mechanical shutter — there is virtually no need though — the R5 Mark II still manages up to 12 frames per second, which is going to be more than enough for almost any kind of shooting a prosumer or hobbyist may want to do.  Rest of the hardware is exactly what you would expect in an expensive high-end camera. There are two card slots — one CFexpress and another a regular UHS-II. USB C with 3.2 is there and so is the full-size HDMI port. Using the accompanying app, the camera can be connected to a phone. The electronic viewfinder uses an extremely bright OLED with 5.76 million pixels, and the 3.2-inch LCD screen is vari-angle, something that is essential for video work. advertisementUsing the Canon R5 Mark II
 


As good as the hardware, the proof of the pudding is in eating. But before I share my experience with the Canon R5 Mark II, some notes: — I have used the camera mostly for shooting images, so my experience is primarily about that. But it is a capable camera for video shooting and content creation as well. For example, check this FIIBER by India Today video: the anchor links in it were shot with the R5 Mark II. Notice how sticky the auto-focus is in the videos, always sticking to the eyes of the anchor. — I used the R5 Mark II only with the RF 24-105 F4 lens.— I am not a professional photographer, so this is not a review from their point of view. They probably already know everything that is to know about the R5 Mark II. — The image samples used in this review have been edited as per taste. The technical ability of the R5 Mark II is not in doubt. Actually, there is no modern camera released after 2000 that is bad at image quality. So, this review is not about what image quality R5 Mark II can offer. It is about what a user can do with it, and that depends more on its auto-focus system, ergonomics, speed etc. I have also reduced the resolution of the image samples here to around 1200P width to keep this page mobile-friendly.advertisement— I didn’t shoot RAW. I know purists will scoff at it. But most people don’t shoot RAW, and I wanted to try the camera from the perspective of somewhat more regular users. Also, the image sensors have become so good that the differences aren’t that big between photos shot in RAW and then developed and photos that were simply shot as JPEG and then lightly edited. Now, let’s talk about the R5 Mark II in use. As expected, the camera excels at image quality. Whether in good light or in low, the image fidelity in photos clicked with the R5 Mark II is off the charts. All of this is expected, of course. But what surprised me in a pleasant way is the kind of colours this camera renders. I am more used to Nikon colours and in the past always found the Canon colours to be slightly warmer and lighter to my taste. The Canon R5 Mark II, however, gets it just right. More significantly, not only does it render colours brilliantly in good light but also in low light. For example, in the image samples, look at the photo of the woman near the lamp post: her red shawl is pleasantly vivid despite poor lighting in the scene. 

 



The Canon R5 Mark II is fast enough to shoot moving subjects like this woman on a bicycle.
One of the top reasons why you may want to get a super expensive DSLR camera even if you are not a professional shooter is the speed that these cameras offer. Despite advances in smartphones, or great image sensors in smaller cameras, if you want to shoot speed and action — think wildlife running and birds flying, children playing a competitive game, surfers and bikers — you need a proper full-size camera. The R5 Mark II is one such camera. While I did not get a chance to go birding with it, I did try the camera on kids playing in a housing society, as well as on people going on about their life on bikes and cycles. 

 



The 45-megapixel sensor in the R5 Mark II captures a tremendous amount of details.
The autofocus in the R5 Mark II is top-notch, driven by AI that uses subject recognition. There are several options to choose from and several settings to turn on or turn off. But irrespective of how you tune it, one key feature of the R5 Mark II is that it is always looking for and tracking eyes in a frame. You are shooting your pet dog, the camera locks on its eyes. You are shooting a pigeon cooing and strutting in your balcony, the camera finds its eye and sticks to it. You are shooting someone coming towards you speedily on a cycle? You get it, the camera finds the eyes of the person and locks its focus. The focus system in the R5 Mark II is fast, precise and incredibly sticky. It is a focus system designed to deliver sharp photos whether you are shooting the bride and groom at a wedding or seagulls on your holiday.

 



The R5 Mark II renders deep and rich colours in photos clicked with it.
The good focus, combined with fast shooting speed, meant that I could click photos of moving subjects easily and with almost no effort on my part. It was so easy that it felt like cheating. Another bit that I absolutely love about the R5 Mark II is how much leeway it has for cropping images. I was shooting with a 105mm lens, which means with hardly any reach. Yet, after clicking photos I could easily crop them aggressively. The sensor is so good that if the photo has been clicked in daylight it wouldn’t be a hassle even if you end up cropping almost 70-80 per cent of the photo to get closer to the subject. A good image sensor also means good performance in low light, even with high ISO. During my night-time walks with the camera I often used ISO as high as 25600 and 12800. At 12800, the images do get noisy but not so much that a run through Lightroom won’t fix them. Under dire circumstances, most shooters will find even 25600 ISO usable. Click on any photo below to access all the camera samplesThe speed is also evident in the way the electronic viewfinder works. As noted earlier, it uses OLED and it gets extremely bright. Compared to optical viewfinders, I find that the disadvantages of electronic viewfinders are now all gone. The visual acuity is superb and speed means there is no longer a viewfinder blackout, at least not in the R5 Mark II, even when you are shooting at a high frame rate. The LCD screen, meanwhile, I believe could have been better. It supports touch, which is always a good feature because it makes dealing with the unwieldy and over-complicated menu system in cameras easier. But I find that the LCD screen could have been sharper and brighter.Who should get the Canon R5 Mark IIAs I noted earlier, the R5 Mark II is a camera meant for anyone who wants to do photography either for work — hello, wedding photographers — or for joy. Otherwise, you can simply use a high-end smartphone. If you are looking to do more, if you want a camera that will let you click action and speed, which will give you images that are full of details, micro-contrast and high-dynamic range, you need a camera like the Canon R5 Mark II. It’s perfect at what it does. In fact, it is more than perfect given its versatility. From wildlife shooters to wedding photographers, everyone will appreciate it. It is also a camera that will even please content creators because of its ability to offer sticky auto-focus and high-resolution footage.One issue, however, is its cost. The versatility of the R5 Mark II comes at a price. At a price of Rs 405,995 to be precise for the camera body. Lenses, depending on what you get, will cost more. This is MRP and the market price would be lower. Yet, it is some serious dough to put on a camera if you are not a professional. Then there is another consideration: the availability of lenses. As much as I loved using the R5 Mark II, I do see that Canon has a few gaps in its RF lens lineup. In consumer-grade (and hence relatively cheaper), Sony and Nikon have a better super telephoto. Sony and Nikon also have cheaper, but optically superb, primes compared to Canon that has more exotic but pricier ones. Having said all this, I do find the R5 Mark II a gem of a camera. It is, arguably, the most versatile camera in the market. And while it is priced higher than its competition — Nikon Z8 and Sony 7R Mark 5 — it offers enough to justify its price to those who need its versatility.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 29, 2025

Headline: Elon Musk makes fun of DeepSeek AI as he is not satisfied with OpenAI's strong competitorElon Musk has expressed scepticism about the success of DeepSeek. His comments on X (formerly Twitter) show he is not entirely convinced by its claims or hype. He has also made fun of DeepSeek AI in one of his social media posts.
Content:
Elon Musk has expressed scepticism about the success of DeepSeek, a Chinese AI company that has been making waves in the tech world. As it gains attention for its AI advancements, Musk’s comments on X (formerly Twitter) show he is not entirely convinced by its claims or hype. He has also made fun of DeepSeek AI in one of his social media posts. DeepSeek's AI chatbot has been hailed as a big innovation, with many comparing its abilities to leading American AI models like OpenAI’s ChatGPT. What is notable, however, is that DeepSeek reportedly achieved these results with a much smaller investment. This has led to a lot of excitement in the AI community, with many seeing it as a strong competitor to the established players. The company’s rise to popularity has also triggered a noticeable shift in the market, as Nvidia, a key supplier of GPUs for AI, saw its market cap drop by a big margin after DeepSeek’s latest AI product was announced. Despite the buzz, Elon Musk has not been impressed. When Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff praised DeepSeek’s accomplishments and suggested that data and metadata are the real value of AI, Musk responded with a dismissive "Lmao, no." This short but sharp reply highlighted Musk’s doubt over the value of DeepSeek's AI model.
 advertisement


 Musk didn’t stop there. He also shared his views on DeepSeek’s hardware capabilities, particularly its use of GPUs. While DeepSeek claims to use around 10,000 A100 Nvidia GPUs, Musk and Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang speculated that the company might be hiding its true hardware capacity due to US export controls. Wang suggested that DeepSeek likely has access to around 50,000 Nvidia Hopper GPUs, which would make their AI system far more powerful than publicly disclosed. Musk responded to Wang’s claim with a simple "Obviously," further indicating his belief that the company is not being transparent.
 


 In addition to his critical comments on DeepSeek’s AI technology, Musk also took the opportunity to poke fun at the company’s Chinese origins. When a user joked that DeepSeek’s AI, called R1, was "leaked from a lab in China," Musk replied with a laughing emoji, referencing past controversies about China’s role in global technological developments.
 


 While DeepSeek continues to gain attention and recognition, Musk’s responses suggest he is not convinced that the company’s AI poses a serious challenge to the dominance of US tech giants like OpenAI. His scepticism also suggests that their is now a growing rivalry between AI companies from the US and China.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Jan 29, 2025
