Headline: New WhatsApp feature may soon let you schedule events in private chatsWhatsApp new feature: WhatsApp's event scheduling feature — that allows users to create events — which was only available in group chats, will soon be available for private chats.
Content: WhatsApp is set to make scheduling events even more convenient by extending the feature to private chats. Previously, this tool was only available in group chats, allowing users to create events, set reminders, and coordinate appointments directly within the app. Now, with the feature rolling out to one-on-one conversations, users will have more flexibility to manage their schedules without switching to a dedicated calendar app. According to WABetaInfo, the latest beta version (25.2.10.73) of WhatsApp for iOS, has already enabled this functionality, letting users add locations or links to audio and video calls while planning events. This move by WhatsApp comes at a time when Apple is reportedly experimenting with its own event management tool. Codenamed Invites, the app is designed to help users organise meetings and in-person gatherings. While Apple’s Calendar app already supports event creation, the new app is expected to offer additional features, such as a more interactive interface and deeper integration with iCloud. According to 9to5Mac, references to the app were first spotted in the iOS 18.2 beta, and although the code was temporarily removed, it has reappeared in the iOS 18.3 beta 2, suggesting Apple is still actively developing the idea. The Invites app is said to integrate with a new iOS 18 daemon called GroupKit, which manages database models for groups of people. This integration could allow users to see a list of invitees and track who has confirmed their attendance. However, it’s unclear whether the app will be standalone or integrated into existing services like iMessage. Apple has remained tight-lipped about the project, and there’s a chance it might not make it to the final release, as the company often tests ideas that don’t always see the light of day. Meanwhile, WhatsApp is also exploring other updates, such as allowing users to open View Once media on linked devices. Currently, this feature, which lets users send photos or videos that disappear after being viewed, only works on the primary device where WhatsApp is registered. Expanding this functionality would make a lot of sense, especially for users who have WhatsApp installed on multiple devices. As of now, there’s no official word on when WhatsApp’s event scheduling feature or Apple’s Invites app will be available to the public. WhatsApp’s beta version is currently accessible to select iOS users via TestFlight, while Apple’s plans for the Invites app remain speculative.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Best mobile phone under Rs 60,000 in January 2025: Realme GT 7 Pro, iQOO 13 and more

Headline: iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Here is how Apple may replace the Plus variant for slimmer iPhoneApple is rumored to be replacing its iPhone 16 Plus with a new iPhone 17 Air in its 2025 lineup. Here is everything we expect from the new iPhone and how it will offer a different experience from the current iPhone Plus variant.
Content:
The 2025 iPhone lineup is expected to get a new surprise edition: a new variant of the iPhone, most likely called the iPhone 17 Air. According to industry rumours, this new iPhone will be the slimmest Apple device and will offer users the same premium iPhone experience but with a slimmer and lightweight form factor—similar to what Apple offers with its other Air variants in the iPad and MacBook lineups. However, this new edition will not be the fifth iPhone but is instead likely to replace the existing iPhone 16 Plus. Apple is reportedly not reaching the expected sales figures for its Plus variant, even with the iPhone 16 Plus, and hence, in 2025, it is expected to replace the variant altogether with the new iPhone 17 Air. According to reports by analysts like Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman, this move of replacing the iPhone 16 Plus with the new iPhone 17 Air is likely to help Apple attract more customers with a sleeker design and refined features.  While Apple has neither confirmed nor hinted at this new variant, rumours and speculation are already fuelling anticipation. Let's take a detailed look at what the new iPhone 17 Air may offer and how it could provide a different experience compared to the iPhone 16 Plus.iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Design The most significant change between the current iPhone 16 Plus and its anticipated replacement, the iPhone 17 Air, lies in the design. The iPhone 17 Air is rumored to be Apple’s thinnest iPhone ever, with reports suggesting a thickness of just 5.5mm at its slimmest point. If this holds true, the design will mark a dramatic reduction compared to the iPhone 16 Plus, which measures 7.8mm thick. While being slimmer, the iPhone 17 Air is said not to compete with the Pro models as previously anticipated. The new iPhone 17 Air is also expected to feature an aluminum chassis, ditching the titanium used in the Pro models. In comparison, the iPhone 16 Plus has a larger, more traditional build—it's bigger than the standard iPhone 16 model. Notably, design is one of the selling points of the iPhone 16 Plus, as it offers the iPhone Pro Max size but with standard specifications for users wanting a bigger display. However, it seems like this strategy isn’t working for Apple, and hence the company may shift to offering a sleeker and more lightweight iPhone.iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Display On the front, the iPhone 17 Air is expected to feature a 6.55-inch display, slightly smaller than the iPhone 16 Plus’s 6.7-inch Super Retina XDR screen. Despite the size reduction, the Air will likely boast Apple’s latest and upgraded display technology. In fact, with the iPhone 17 series, Apple is rumoured to expand ProMotion technology across the entire lineup, enabling a 120Hz refresh rate for smoother scrolling and improved video playback. Additionally, an always-on display feature could make its way to the Air. The iPhone 16 Plus, on the other hand, currently offers only a standard 60Hz refresh rate.iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Camera Cameras will also get a big update with the new iPhone 17 series, including the anticipated iPhone 17 Air. Unlike the iPhone 16 Plus, which houses a dual-camera setup – 48 megapixel + 12 megapixel– , the Air may feature an upgraded rear camera. However, reports suggest that to achieve a sleeker design, the iPhone 17 Air might only feature a single camera, unlike the dual-camera setup of the iPhone 16 Plus. Despite having only one camera, Apple is expected to optimise it with advanced software enhancements to ensure high-quality photography. Additionally, the front camera is set for a major upgrade across the iPhone 17 lineup, with a new 24-megapixel sensor replacing the 12-megapixel shooter on the iPhone 16 Plus. This upgrade will offer users sharper selfies and improved video call quality.iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Performance Under the hood, the iPhone 17 Air will reportedly be powered by Apple’s next-generation A19 chip, built on an advanced 3nm process. This chipset will offer better performance and energy efficiency compared to the current A18 chip found in the iPhone 16 Plus. The Air is also expected to feature 8GB of RAM, matching the iPhone 16 series but offering improved multitasking and smoother operation, especially with Apple Intelligence features.advertisementiPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: ConnectivityTo achieve a slimmer profile, Apple is rumoured to eliminate the physical SIM card slot entirely, relying solely on eSIM technology worldwide. This contrasts with the iPhone 16 Plus, which still offers a SIM card slot in many markets outside the U.S.Moreover, the Air may be amongst the first iPhones to feature Apple’s in-house 5G modem and Wi-Fi 7 support, promising faster connectivity and better power efficiency. Notably, the iPhone SE 4, which is rumoured to arrive next month, is likely to debut first with Apple’s in-house modem.iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Battery lifeApart from the larger design and display, the iPhone 16 Plus also offers a bigger battery than the standard iPhone. However, the battery might take a hit in the iPhone 17 Air. That said, Apple could offset this potential battery downgrade with improved energy efficiency from the A19 chip and display optimisations. Durability-wise, the Air will likely feature a new anti-reflective coating on its display, making it more scratch-resistant than the Ceramic Shield on current models.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also Read |  Salesforce set to cut 1000 roles, impacted employees may have option to reapply internallyAlso Read |  iPhone SE4 expected to arrive next month? Headline: AGI could arrive much earlier than predicted, says SoftBank CEO Masayoshi SonSoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son had predicted a few months ago that artificial general intelligence will arrive in 2-3 years. However, he now thinks that AGI could arrive much earlier.
Content: The anticipation of the arrival of artificial general intelligence (AGI) has been growing steadily. While OpenAI CEO Sam Altman recently said that AGI is just Twitter hype, his business partner, SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son, has said that AGI will arrive much sooner than he predicted. Son says that as opposed to his earlier prediction, that AGI will become reality in the next two to three years, he now thinks that the tech may arrive “much earlier”, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. Meanwhile, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, in a recent post on X, said that AGI is just Twitter hype as of this point in time. While there was a lot of chatter about AGI being deployed by OpenAI as soon as next month, Altman denied the claims, and said that the company has not even yet built AGI.  For the uninitiated, AGI can be understood as the next step to AI, where the tech system is not just performing a task like a human would do, but is also capable of thinking, learning, and adapting like humans. As opposed to AI that we understand right now, AGI is believed to have a wider horizon. It will not be limited to a particular skill, it will have flexible thinking abilities similar to that of a human mind.  Basically, AGI right now seems like the highest goal AI research companies can achieve, that is, building a machine or an AI system that is able to understand, comprehend and react to a variety of problems just like a human would.  The SoftBank CEO said this as he announced a new AI system called Cristal Intelligence in Japan, which the company has released in collaboration with OpenAI. The joint venture, called SB OpenAI Japan, is owned 50-50 by both companies and involves an investment of $3 billion in the project, which is aimed at changing the way businesses work with the help of AI agents.  SoftBank has said that with Cristal Intelligence, AI agents will “automate everyday tasks”. The company also says that it will use the new AI system at its own Arm and SoftBank Corp to “drive innovation and boost productivity across the company.” The company’s press release claims that the AI agent will allow it to “automate over 100 million workflows”.  This is the second partnership that SoftBank and OpenAI announced this month. The first was Project Stargate, which is a new AI company that involves a massive investment of $500 billion over the next four years. An initial $100 billion has already been deployed in the project. At the time of announcing Project Stargate, Sam Altman had announced that the company is aimed to help develop data centres for OpenAI in the United States. Headline: Samsung Galaxy S26 Ultra tipped to get under-display selfie cameraThe dust hasn't even settled on the recently launched Galaxy S25 series, and we have already started hearing rumours about Samsung's next-generation Ultra flagship.
Content:
Samsung recently launched the Galaxy S25 series, but rumours about the next-generation flagship, the Galaxy S26 Ultra, are already making the rounds. According to a tipster on X (formerly Twitter), early prototypes of the Galaxy S26 Ultra are missing a visible selfie camera cutout on the display. This suggests that Samsung might be planning to introduce an under-display camera for its next flagship smartphone.

Source: @kro_roe/ X (formerly Twitter)
 If the rumour about the under-display selfie camera is true, this would be a big shift in Samsung’s design approach for its slab phones. The company has already experimented with under-display cameras in its foldable Galaxy Z Fold lineup, but the technology has often been criticised for compromising photo quality. For the Galaxy S26 Ultra, Samsung will need to improve the camera’s performance to avoid disappointing users, especially those who prioritise selfies and video calls. However, it’s important to note that these are very early prototypes, and a lot can change before the phone’s official launch. While the rumour is interesting, it’s worth taking it with a pinch of salt for now. If Samsung does move forward with this design, it would join brands like Nubia, which have already released smartphones with under-display cameras outside the Indian market. In addition to the potential under-display camera, previous rumours suggested that the S26 Ultra might actually be rebranded as the Galaxy S26 Note, reviving the beloved Note series name. The device is also expected to feature a brighter and more power-efficient display compared to its predecessor, along with a 200-megapixel periscope telephoto camera.  Meanwhile, the recently launched Galaxy S25 Ultra is already up for pre-orders in India and worldwide. Priced starting at Rs 1,29,999 for the 256GB storage variant, the Galaxy S25 Ultra is the top-of-the-line model in the S25 series. It features a 6.9-inch AMOLED display, a titanium build, and Corning’s Gorilla Armor 2, which is touted as the most scratch-resistant glass yet. The phone is also slimmer and lighter than last year’s S24 Ultra. One of the standout features of the Galaxy S25 Ultra is its built-in S Pen. However, for what it’s worth, Bluetooth connectivity for the S Pen is no longer there, as Samsung believes that only a small percentage of its users actually use the air gestures and wireless features. Apart from this, the Galaxy S25 Ultra features an impressive camera setup. There’s a 200-megapixel primary sensor, a brand new 50-megapixel ultra-wide lens, a 10-megapixel telephoto lens with 3X optical zoom, and a 50-megapixel periscope telephoto lens with 5X optical zoom. There’s a 5,000mAh battery under the hood, and the phone comes with 12GB RAM and storage options of up to 1TB.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Best mobile phone under Rs 60,000 in January 2025: Realme GT 7 Pro, iQOO 13 and more

Its 120Hz LCD display offers smoother scrolling and gaming, while the 108-megapixel primary camera delivers sharp, detailed photos in good lighting. The 5,000mAh battery remains unchanged, but charging speeds have been bumped up to 33W, with the charger included in the box. Running on HyperOS based on Android 14, the interface is faster and more intuitive than MIUI. With a strong mix of features, the Redmi 13 5G remains a top contender in the budget segment.Motorola G64 5G Last but certainly not least, the Motorola G64 5G is perfect for those who prefer a clean, bloatware-free experience. It’s powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 7025, handling daily tasks and light gaming smoothly. The 6,000mAh battery easily lasts more than a day, making it ideal for heavy users. The 50-megapixel main camera with OIS captures stable, sharp images in good lighting. Running on stock Android 14, the software is simple and smooth. Available in two variants, the higher model — 12GB + 256GB — slightly exceeds Rs 15,000 but is worth it for extra RAM and storage.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also read |  DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works and is it better than ChatGPT? Headline: Samsung triple-fold smartphone tipped to be named as Galaxy G FoldSamsung is expected to step down to the triple-fold game this year. Before any official notification can come, leaks and tips have a lot to say about the upcoming Samsung Galaxy G-Fold.
Content: Samsung is rumoured to release its first triple-fold smartphone this year, along with its next-gen foldable series. Previously, leaks have been pointing at the upcoming features and specs without even bothering about the name. But now, a recent leak has suggested that the company might name it the Samsung Galaxy G Fold. Introducing the idea, back in 2023, the company called it a multi-fold phone, but there was no name until now. According to Lanzuk on Naver, Samsung's upcoming tri-fold smartphone will not be included in the Galaxy Z series but will instead debut as the "Galaxy G Fold."    The rationale behind this naming decision remains uncertain, particularly since the "Z" branding in Samsung's foldable lineup already seems well-suited for a tri-fold device.  Additionally, the tipster shared that the triple-screen fold is scheduled to be introduced this year but will be available to buy in January 2026. Moreover, unlike the Huawei Mate XT, the Samsung's tri-fold can fold from both sides and will supposedly have a display that measures 9.96-inches when fully unfolded, being 6.54-inches tall. While the Huawei Mate XT and Galaxy G Fold  could share a similar weight, Samsung triple-fold is expected to be thicker.  Earlier reports have also suggested that Samsung’s tri-fold smartphone will feature a G-shaped folding design, where the outer screens fold inward. This contrasts with Huawei’s Mate XT, which utilises an S- or Z-shaped mechanism that folds both inward and outward. The report indicates that Samsung’s design could offer greater durability, making the device more resilient in the long run.Samsung Galaxy G Fold: What to expect Details about Samsung’s tri-fold smartphone remain scarce, but an intriguing theory suggests it could boast a massive 12.4-inch display when fully unfolded. This would position it as a versatile alternative to both smartphones and tablets, even surpassing Huawei’s 10.2-inch Mate XT. Additionally, the device may support a partially unfolded mode, offering a 10.5-inch display for a more immersive viewing experience.   Another notable rumour hints at the absence of under-display camera technology. While this could lead to improved front-facing camera quality, it would require a hole-punch cutout on the main screen, slightly affecting the device’s sleek design. However, this trade-off may be worthwhile for better camera performance. It looks like Samsung has major plans for foldable phones this year. After the Galaxy Unpacked event (scheduled for January 22), which will unveil the Galaxy S25 series, the company will turn its focus on Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7. This year, the company has two more foldables: Galaxy Z Flip 7 FE and a triple-fold phone. While there is a lot of variety in 2025, production is still expected to be low.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also read |  Realme GT 7 tipped to launch soon with Snapdragon 8 Elite chipAlso read |  Samsung Galaxy S26 Ultra tipped to get under-display selfie cameraAlso read |  Nothing Phone 3a could feature iPhone-like camera button, fresh teaser suggests

Headline: iQOO Neo 10R India launch confirmed: Expected price, specs and moreiQOO has confirmed the launch date for the iQOO Neo 10R. Ahead of the launch, the company has also confirmed some details about the device. Here is everything we know, and all that we expect from it so far.
Content:
iQOO has confirmed the launch of its new budget gaming device, the iQOO Neo 10R. The company’s CEO Nipun Marya, in a post on X, said it will launch on March 11. iQOO has also revealed that the smartphone will be powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8s Gen 3 chipset, LPDDR5X RAM and UFS 4.0 storage. For perspective, some other phones that launched with that chipset in India in the last few months are the Realme GT 6, Poco F6, Honor 200 Pro, among others. iQOO has also announced that the Neo 10R will be available in an India-exclusive colour variant called the Raging Blue. Teasers shared by the company also reveal what the Raging Blue variant would look like. It carries the classic Neo series design language with a thin grey strip on the left side of the back panel, and the rest of the panel features a shade of blue. The transition between the two colours uses tiny pixel graphics –– which look quite nice, in the pictures, at least. 
 


 Teasers also show that the iQOO Neo 10R will feature the popular squoval camera module at the back. The official image shows that the phone will feature a dual camera setup with support for optical image stabilisation (OIS). There is a tiny LED flash that sits outside the camera island –– on its right. While iQOO has yet to confirm the specifications of the camera, leaks suggest that it could feature a combination for a 50-megapixel primary sensor and an 8-megapixel wide-angle sensor.  Additionally, it is also already confirmed that the iQOO Neo 10R will be available for purchase via Amazon India and iQOO’s official website. 
Besides that, leaks also suggest that the iQOO Neo 10R could sport a 1.5K OLED display with a refresh rate up to 144Hz. Fuelling the phone is expected to be a 6,400mAh battery, with support for 80W wired fast charging. Leaks also hint that the phone will come with up to 12GB RAM and 256GB storage.  As for pricing, while other Snapdragon 8s Gen 3 smartphones in the market are currently priced slightly higher, there are speculations that the iQOO Neo 10R will be priced under Rs 30,000.  The launch of the iQOO Neo 10R will most likely take place via online channels. Which means, that the phone's launch will take place iQOO's social media channels like the X, Facebook, and YouTube accounts. More information and other details about the Neo 10R should start trickling in soon. Headline: Vivo V50 to debut this month and here are 5 things we already knowVivo V50 is expected to arrive in India later this month. Now, the company has revealed a few details around the phone before it hits the market. Let's delve deeper into the details.
Content:
Vivo is all set to release its next-gen smartphone this month -- the Vivo V50. Before announcing the launch details, the company revealed a handful of specs and features of the Vivo V50. For instance, Vivo has unveiled the full design, durability and camera specs. Teasing the design, the company claims that the upcoming V50 will be the segment's slimmest smartphone, packing a 6000mAh battery. Moreover, the device is also confirmed to come in three-colour options. Let's dive deep into the details of the upcoming Vivo V50. advertisementVivo V50: 5 things we already knowDesign: The Vivo V50 carries forward the same design as its predecessor, V40. It features a dual camera system housed on a pendulum-shaped panel. It is also confirmed to come in three colour options: Rose Red, Starry Night and Titanium Grey. The rear panel for each colour variant is different. For example, the Rose Red and Titanium Grey share the same texture, but the Starry Night has a shimmery back panel (resembling a starry night).  Design: The Vivo V50 carries forward the same design as its predecessor, V40. It features a dual camera system housed on a pendulum-shaped panel. It is also confirmed to come in three colour options: Rose Red, Starry Night and Titanium Grey. The rear panel for each colour variant is different. For example, the Rose Red and Titanium Grey share the same texture, but the Starry Night has a shimmery back panel (resembling a starry night).   According to the company, this phone is the slimmest device in the segment, packing a 6,000mAh battery, thanks to the 0.739cm (Titanium Gray), 0.757cm (Rose Red), and 0.767cm (Starry Night Blue) thickness.  Display: The Vivo V50 is confirmed to sport a quad-curve display, the first time in the V-series. Vivo has also shared that the display will host minimal bezels to enhance the viewing experience. Other than this, the company has not confirmed any details related to the display specs. However, the rumour has it that it might feature a 6.67-inch 1.5K AMOLED screen. 
 advertisement


Camera: The Vivo V50 is set to feature Zeiss-branded cameras on both the front and rear, promising a premium photography experience. Its rear setup includes a 50-megapixel OIS-enabled main sensor alongside a 50-megapixel ultra-wide-angle lens, both capable of 4K video recording. For selfies, the device sports a high-resolution 50-megapixel front camera. The V50 enhances portrait photography with a multifocus mode, allowing users to shoot at 23mm, 35mm, and 50mm focal lengths, along with seven Zeiss-style bokeh effects for artistic depth. Camera: The Vivo V50 is set to feature Zeiss-branded cameras on both the front and rear, promising a premium photography experience. Its rear setup includes a 50-megapixel OIS-enabled main sensor alongside a 50-megapixel ultra-wide-angle lens, both capable of 4K video recording. For selfies, the device sports a high-resolution 50-megapixel front camera. The V50 enhances portrait photography with a multifocus mode, allowing users to shoot at 23mm, 35mm, and 50mm focal lengths, along with seven Zeiss-style bokeh effects for artistic depth. Additionally, it introduces a Colour-Adaptive Border, which intelligently extracts hues from wedding photos to create complementary borders. Retaining the Aura Light flash, the device also features AI Studio Light Portrait 2.0, ensuring soft yet vibrant lighting for professional-quality shots.
 


 Battery: The Vivo V50 is powered by a 6000mAh battery.  Software: Vivo claims that the V50 will deliver smooth performance for up to five years, ensuring long-term reliability. The smartphone is set to feature advanced AI-powered functionalities, including Gemini, Circle to Search, AI transcription, and live call translation, enhancing user convenience. Out of the box, it will run on Funtouch OS 15, offering a refined and feature-rich software experience.Vivo V50: India launch date and price (expected) The Vivo V50 is rumoured to launch later this year, most likely February 20. Now coming to the price, a recent leak suggests that the Vivo V50 will launch with a starting price of Rs 37,999. Even if this is not the exact detail, it is most likely that the phone will cost below Rs 40k. For reference, the Vivo V40 debuted in India at Rs 34,999, indicating a possible Rs 3,000 price increase. However, since there is no official confirmation yet, users should take this information with caution. Headline: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman once again hints that he wants to make an AI deviceSam Altman has reiterated his ambitions of making an AI device in collaboration with Jony Ive, the man credited to designing some of Apple's best devices including the 1998 iMac, the iPhone, and even the Apple Park campus.
Content: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has once again shared his plans to develop an AI-first device in collaboration with Jony Ive, the man who is credited to designing some of Apple’s most iconic products, including the 1998 iMac, the iPhone, and even the Apple Park campus. The latest report about OpenAI’s AI hardware comes via a report from Nikkei Asia, according to which, Altman said "we hope to do it [develop AI hardware] in partnership" with Jony Ive. Reportedly, he said that during his visit to Japan to meet Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba.  Here is some context: In December 2023, a report went viral that claimed that Jony Ive and his new design company called LoveFrom were working on an AI-first device”. This device was backed by OpenAI and CEO Sam Altman. A few weeks after this report came out, there were reports that a bunch of Apple executives were leaving the company, and many of them, including Tang Tan, who was heading the iPhone and Apple Watch design team, were heading to LoveFrom.  The news stirred quite a storm. There were a flurry of reports claiming that Ive, Altman and Tan are getting together to work on this purported AI hardware. And if you join the dots a bit, it even makes sense. Jony Ive has decades of experience in design, and specifically the iPhone, a device that changed the way we knew phones back in 2007. Tang Tan has his expertise in making the device look and work in a particular way. And Sam Altman, who is the face of AI, will likely add all the AI-smarts to the hardware.  As for what the AI device will be. For now, reports keep fluctuating between an AI smartphone, AI device, or simply AI hardware. There haven't been many official reports around it in a long time, so for now what we understand is that it could be an AI device –– think on the lines of the Humane AI pin or the Rabbit R1. It’s possible that this device may not even look like a smartphone, but looking at the trend and the way these AI companies want us to interact with AI tools and systems, it is quite likely that this “AI device” will still function like a phone. I imagine the device to be what comes after the smartphone. I believed instead of being a phone with a built-in personal assistant, this would be a personal assistant that functions as your primary device, and communication would just be one of the many features on it. Whatever form this “AI device” may take, one thing is for certain, that it will be centered around voice interaction –– the push for the Advanced voice mode on ChatGPT, and Sam Altman's big investment in the Humane AI pin are a big hint at that.
