Headline: Indian Railways launches SwaRail app: All you need to knowIndian Railways is currently testing a new SwaRail app. This app will offer users several train-related services, including ticket booking, PNR status, food ordering, and more, under one unified platform.
Content: If you are someone who frequently travels by train, you might be juggling multiple apps by Indian Railways for different services. However, your struggles will soon be fixed and you may need to delete these apps. The Ministry of Railways has recently introduced a new Super App called 'SwaRail.' This app, developed by the Centre for Railway Information Systems (CRIS), offers a range of services—from booking tickets and checking PNR status to ordering food—all under one roof. Until now, Indian Railways passengers had to download and access different apps for different purposes—such as IRCTC Rail Connect for reserved tickets, UTS Mobile for unreserved tickets, and other apps for train inquiries, parcel bookings, and complaint management. However, with the new Super App SwaRail, Indian Railways has integrated all these services into one unified platform. It aims to help Indian railway travelers manage all their travel queries and services through just a single app with a simple interface.Currently under beta testing  Right now, the app is available for beta testers on both Android and iOS. Users can join the beta testing, although the beta testing limit on Android is currently full. However, according to Indian Railways, the app will soon be available for download once the beta testing is completed. But how does the app work? What does it offer? And how can you use it? Let’s take a detailed look at everything you need to know about Indian Railways’ new SwaRail app.How to use the SwaRail app Currently, the SwaRail app is in beta testing, but it will be available to the public soon. Once it’s public, you will be able to download it from the Google Play Store or Apple’s App Store. After downloading, you can either register as a new user or log in with your existing Rail Connect or UTS Mobile credentials. This will also sync all your past travel details into the app. Following a few simple login steps—including setting up an MPIN and other security options—the app will open to the homepage. On the homepage, you will find various services in a simplified UI, including: Reserved tickets: Book reserved tickets easily, just like in the IRCTC Rail Connect app. Unreserved tickets: Check and book unreserved tickets. Platform tickets: Book platform tickets when dropping off your relatives or friends. Parcel and Freight enquiries: Make inquiries related to parcel and freight services within the same app. Train and PNR Status enquiries: Get real-time updates on train schedules, running status, and PNR information. Food orders on trains: Order food during your journey for a more comfortable travel experience. Rail Madad for complaint management: Register complaints and track grievance redressal through the integrated Rail Madad platform. All in all, by merging various services, the SwaRail app eliminates the hassle of juggling multiple applications. Whether you need to book tickets, check train schedules, or file complaints—everything is accessible from one dashboard.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also Read |  iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Here is how Apple may replace the Plus variant for slimmer iPhoneAlso Read |  Salesforce set to cut 1000 roles, impacted employees may have option to reapply internallyAlso Read |  iPhone SE4 expected to arrive next month? Here is everything we know so far

Headline: Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?The Poco X7 and X7 Pro offer compelling choices for different users. The X7 Pro stands out with its top-tier performance, stunning flat display, and massive battery, making it ideal for gamers and power users. Meanwhile, the standard X7 impresses with its curved screen, solid performance, and attractive price, catering to casual users. Both phones deliver excellent value, but the X7 Pro's premium features make it a better choice for those willing to stretch their budget.
Content:
I’ve spent some time testing the Poco X7 series — the X7 and X7 Pro — and here’s my take. A quick disclaimer: the Poco X7 Pro is — without a shadow of a doubt — the better phone of the two, a sentiment I shared in my first impressions of these devices. However, this isn’t solely due to its higher price tag. The standard Poco X7 is a solid smartphone in its own right and should appeal to many within its price range. That said, the real star here — much like last year’s X6 Pro — is the Poco X7 Pro. It delivers exceptional raw performance at such an attractive price point that it could even give premium phones a good run for their money.  So, what makes the Poco X7 Pro so special? And who should consider the standard Poco X7? Let’s dive into all the details in this full review of both smartphones.Poco X7: Quick look at the specs — Display: 6.67-inch 1.5K, 120Hz refresh rate, curved AMOLED, Gorilla Glass Victus 2, in-display fingerprint sensor, 3,000 nits peak brightness — Chipset: MediaTek Dimensity 7300 Ultra, 4nm fabrication process — RAM and storage: 8GB + 128GB (Rs 21,999), 8GB + 256GB (Rs 23,999) — Battery: 5,500mAh — Charging: 45W, charger included in the box — Software: HyperOS based on Android 14, 3 years of OS updates plus 4 years of security patches — Camera: 50-megapixel Sony LYTIA LYT-600 primary rear camera, 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera, 2-megapixel macro sensor, 20-megapixel front camera — Miscellaneous: IP68/ IP69 rating, IR blaster, dual-stereo speakers, USB type-C port (2.0)Poco X7 Pro: Quick look at the specs — Display: 6.78-inch 1.5K, 120Hz refresh rate, flat AMOLED, Gorilla Glass 7i protection, in-display fingerprint sensor, 3,200 nits peak brightness — Chipset: MediaTek Dimensity 8400 Ultra, 4nm fabrication process — RAM and storage: 8GB + 256GB (Rs 27,999), 12GB + 256GB (Rs 29,999) — Battery: 6,550mAh — Charging: 90W, charger included in the box — Software: HyperOS based on Android 14, 3 years of OS updates plus 4 years of security patches — Camera: 50-megapixel Sony LYTIA LYT-600 primary rear camera, 2-megapixel macro sensor, 20-megapixel front camera — Miscellaneous: IP68/ IP69 rating, IR blaster, dual-stereo speakers, USB type-C port (2.0)A polarising look you can’t ignore At first glance, you might mistake the Poco X7 for the pricier model of the two. However, in reality, it’s the Poco X7 Pro that comes with the higher price tag — more on that in a moment. Both phones are available in striking green colourways, with the Poco X7 also offered in grey, while the X7 Pro comes in a stealthy black option. That said, the bold yellow colour variant for both the X7 and X7 Pro is what truly grabs attention. With a two-tone finish and prominent Poco branding, these devices are impossible to ignore. This is precisely why I call their design polarising — you might either love it or not, but there’s no denying its bold statement.  Personally, I’m a fan of the look and feel of these phones. For mid-range models, they exude a premium vibe with their dense plastic frames and vegan leather finishes on the back. Interestingly, despite being part of the same series, the Poco X7 and X7 Pro look completely different. The Poco X7 stands out with its curvy look and quadruple lens cutout (three functional), while the X7 Pro opts for a sleek boxy aesthetic and features dual rear cameras. Both devices score high on ergonomics. They are comfortable to hold, with well-placed buttons that are easy to reach. The optical fingerprint sensors on both phones are quick and reliable. Even with their large batteries — especially the X7 Pro, which packs a massive 6,550mAh battery — they manage to stay relatively light and slim.  Now, let’s revisit the price and display choices. Here’s the twist — the more affordable Poco X7 sports a curved display, while the pricier X7 Pro features a flat panel. This is unusual since curved displays are typically reserved for premium phones, giving the X7 a distinct edge in terms of aesthetics. While I personally prefer flat displays, the X7’s curve lends it a premium look and feel. Plus, it’s protected by Gorilla Glass Victus 2, which Poco claims offers better drop resistance — a critical feature for curved panels. On the other hand, the X7 Pro uses Gorilla Glass 7i. Though slightly less rugged, it suits the flat design and helps manage production costs. When it comes to design, both phones deliver in their unique ways. But once you look past the aesthetics, the X7 Pro begins to reveal its true advantages over the standard X7.Gorgeous displays but with a few differences When it comes to the display, Poco has done a very good job with both the X7 and X7 Pro, but some key differences set them apart. Let’s start with the basics.  The Poco X7 comes with a 6.67-inch curved AMOLED display with a resolution of 1,220x2,712 (1.5K) pixels. This panel offers a 120Hz refresh rate. It’s HDR10 certified, supports Dolby Vision, and covers the full DCI-P3 colour gamut, ensuring vibrant colours and excellent image quality. If you’re someone who spends a lot of time watching videos or scrolling through photos, this display won’t disappoint. In fact, at this price point, it’s one of the best screens you can get. Plus, it’s a curved screen, so, it looks and feels all the way more premium than its peers. On the other hand, the Poco X7 Pro steps things up with a slightly larger 6.73-inch flat AMOLED display. It also has a 1.5K resolution while offering an impressive peak brightness of 3,200 nits. Of course, the phone’s display — or, for that matter, X7’s display as well — does become a bit reflective under the harsh sun, but, rest assured, I didn’t face any major problems regarding legibility even on the brightest of days. Like the X7, it supports HDR10+ and Dolby Vision, so compatible content on platforms like Netflix and YouTube looks sharp and detailed.  Audio is another part of the multimedia experience, and the stereo speakers on both phones complement the displays well. They deliver loud and clear sound, even at high volumes, which is solid for binge-watching or gaming without headphones.
 


 Now, the main choice lies between curved and flat displays, which is often subjective. For me, the flat panel on the Poco X7 Pro wins. It’s not about the phone’s price tag — I just find flat displays more practical. They’re easier to use, especially when it comes to avoiding accidental touches, especially while gaming. Granted, the curved edges on the X7 look premium, no doubt, but they can feel fragile and might not be everyone’s cup of tea. Overall, the displays on both the X7 and X7 Pro are excellent, each catering to slightly different preferences. If you want something that feels premium and modern, the curved screen on the X7 will impress. But if you’re like me and prefer practicality and usability over aesthetics, the flat panel on the X7 Pro is hard to beat. Again, it’s not just a better display because the phone costs more — it’s better because it’s simply more versatile and easier to live with.Performance: X7 Pro takes the lead, but X7 can also hold its own When it comes to performance, the Poco X7 Pro clearly takes the lead, and again, it’s not just because it’s the more expensive model. Packed with a 4nm MediaTek Dimensity 8400 Ultra processor, Mali-G720 MC6 GPU, and up to 12GB LPDDR5X RAM, this phone is a powerhouse. I mean, beyond the raw hardware, this phone is truly great for its price when it comes to performance. Whether you’re juggling between apps, gaming, video-calling or recording 4K videos, the X7 Pro handles everything smoothly without breaking a sweat. The addition of a massive cooling system, a 3D IceLoop system, and Liquid Cool Technology 4.0 ensures the device stays cool even during heavy usage. Marketing jargon aside, just know that the X7 Pro is a great choice for gamers and power users who demand top-tier performance without lag.  On the other hand, the Poco X7, while not as powerful, still holds its own for everyday tasks. It’s powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 7300 Ultra chipset paired with 8GB LPDDR4X RAM, which is good enough for streaming, browsing, and social media. However, it struggles a bit with demanding games like COD: Mobile and BGMI, showing occasional frame drops and slight touch response delays. That said, it manages heat well during gaming, staying cooler than many competitors in its range. For casual users, the X7 is a decent pick, but gamers, you know which phone you have to choose.  As for software, both phones run on Xiaomi’s HyperOS, but the X7 Pro comes with Android 15, while the X7 boots Android 14. The X7 Pro is promised three years of Android updates (up to Android 18), while the X7 gets three years of updates starting from Android 14, which feels a bit limiting, considering both phones are new then why does the standard ship with older software out-of-the-box? Otherwise, both devices come with pre-loaded apps, but thankfully, you can uninstall most of them to free up space.Sleek phones with big batteries Now, let’s talk about battery life. Obviously, the Poco X7 Pro shines here with its massive 6,550mAh Silicon carbon battery. I have been talking about this in many of my articles and videos, but still, for the unaware — this new battery tech can store more power on a single charge and last longer than traditional Li-ion batteries. With normal usage, the X7 Pro easily lasts a day and a half, and even heavy binge-watching won’t drain it before bedtime. The 90W fast charger (included in the box) juices up the phone from 0 to 50 per cent in just 30 minutes and fully charges it in a little over an hour.  The Poco X7, while not as impressive, still offers solid battery performance. Its 5,500mAh battery lasts a full day with moderate use. The 45W (charger included in the box) fast charging is decent. It takes about 50 minutes to go from 20 per cent to 100 per cent, but it’s a step-down from the 67W charging seen in the Poco X6.Cameras: On par with the competition  The Poco X7 Pro and X7 share a similar camera setup on paper, but their performance shows noticeable differences. Both phones feature a 50-megapixel Sony LYT 600 primary sensor with OIS and an 8-megapixel ultra-wide lens, along with a 20-megapixel front camera for selfies. However, the X7 Pro’s camera tuning and capabilities give it a slight edge in certain areas. For what it’s worth, the X7 also gets a third 2-megapixel macro sensor at the rear.   Starting with daylight photography, both phones capture detailed and sharp images with decent colour accuracy. The X7 Pro, however, tends to boost colours a bit more, which can make photos look vibrant but sometimes unnatural. For instance, skies may appear more saturated than they actually are. On the other hand, the X7 does a better job with colour correction, without going overboard. HDR performance is also pretty decent on both phones, but the X7 Pro pulls ahead slightly in dynamic range and finer details. When it comes to portraits, the X7 Pro offers better edge detection in photos, thus capturing clean, well-defined subjects. However, it tends to smoothen facial details, giving selfies and portraits an artificial look. The X7, while not as strong in edge detection, delivers more natural skin tones and better colour accuracy in portraits. Both phones struggle with bokeh quality, but the X7 Pro’s colour tone can be more appealing to some users. In low-light conditions, the X7 Pro performs better, thanks to its superior HDR retention and ability to capture more details without over-smoothing. Its night mode produces balanced images with well-managed exposure, though colours can still appear slightly off. The X7, while decent in low light, tends to produce softer images with noticeable noise, even with night mode enabled. The X7 Pro’s low-light shots are sharper and more detailed. Selfies on both phones are a mixed bag. The X7 Pro smoothens facial details, which can make selfies look artificial, while the X7 maintains some level of detail but brightens skin tones unnaturally. In daylight, both phones take good-looking selfies. However, in low light, the X7 Pro’s selfies are slightly better, with less noise and better clarity. Click on any photo below to access camera samples of both the Poco X7 and X7 Pro.  Overall, the Poco X7 Pro’s camera is a step ahead, especially in low light and portrait edge detection. However, the X7 holds its own with more natural colours and better skin tones in portraits. If you’re looking for a phone with a camera that performs well in most scenarios, the X7 Pro is the better choice. But if you prefer a more balanced and natural look, the X7 is a solid option, especially for its price.Poco X7 series: Final verdict After spending a good amount of time with both the Poco X7 and X7 Pro, here’s the deal: if you’re looking for a phone that punches way above its weight, the Poco X7 Pro is the one to go for. It’s not just a slight upgrade over the X7 — it’s a proper powerhouse. From its top-tier performance and gorgeous flat display to that massive 6,550mAh battery and 90W charging, it’s a phone that feels like it should cost way more than it does. Gamers, power users, or anyone who wants a premium experience without breaking the bank? This is your phone.
 


 That said, the Poco X7 is no slouch either. It’s a solid mid-range smartphone in its own right. It has a beautiful curved display, decent performance, and a camera that holds its own in good lighting. If you’re a casual user who streams, scrolls, and occasionally uses the camera, the X7 will serve you well. Plus, it’s lighter on the wallet, which is always a win. But let’s be real — if you can stretch your budget a bit, the X7 Pro is worth the extra cash. It’s just that much better. So, who should buy what? If you’re on a tight budget and don’t need the extra oomph in performance, the Poco X7 is a great pick. But if you want the best bang for your buck and don’t mind spending a little more, the X7 Pro is the clear winner. It’s not just the better phone in this series — it’s one of the best value-for-money phones out there right now. Period.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 4, 2025Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?Also read |  DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works and is it better than ChatGPT? Everything to knowAlso read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?

Headline: Google is suddenly fine with using AI for weapons and surveillanceGoogle has quietly updated its AI guidelines dropping its pledge to not use the tech for weapons or surveillance.
Content:
Google has suddenly revised its ethical guidelines for artificial intelligence (AI), removing the explicit ban on using the technology for weapons and surveillance. The update came on Tuesday via a blogpost shared by the company on the 2024 report on “Responsible AI”. This was first spotted by The Washington Post via the archived versions of the guidelines. The change in policy marks a critical shift from Google’s previous pledge to limit AI applications that could cause harm. The company had earlier committed that it will not use AI for applications that are “likely to cause overall harm”.  Google’s AI principles, which were first published in 2018, pledged against using the technology in four areas: 
-weapons
-surveillance
-applications likely to cause overall harm,
-uses violating international law and human rights.  However, with the update to the AI guidelines, these restrictions have quietly been eliminated.  Meanwhile, Google’s head of AI, Demis Hassabis, and James Manyika, SVP for technology and society, wrote in the blogpost: “We are investing more than ever in both AI research and products that benefit people and society, and in AI safety and efforts to identify and address potential risks”. “There’s a global competition for AI leadership within an increasingly complex geopolitical environment. We believe democracies should lead in AI development, guided by core values like freedom, equality, and respect for human rights,” the post further reads –– which also sounds like Google trying to convince the reader that lifting the ban on using AI for weapons and surveillance has only been done with the greater good in mind.  When Google first announced its AI principles in 2018, it was after a huge protest by Google employees against a then-ongoing Project Maven. It was a Pentagon contract that needed to use AI for drone surveillance. However, Google employees were opposed to using the tech they built for surveillance, so after pressure from the workers, Google was forced to withdraw from the project. Now, the change in policy, however, shows a renewed willingness to use AI for surveillance, once again.  Google isn’t the only company that is working with AI and is open to providing its tech to the local government. Companies like OpenAI and Anthropic are also deeply involved with the US defence authorities. This change also makes the increased collaboration between tech companies and national security agencies quite evident.  Just last week, after the US President Donald Trump said that he wanted to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America, Google quietly agreed without any protest, and said that it has a policy to do so. As long as the change in name is reflected in official records in the US, it can make that change for Google Maps users in the US.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also read |  Donald Trump wants Gulf of Mexico to be renamed to Gulf of America, Google quickly agrees to make the changeAlso read |  Donald Trump signs order to create sovereign wealth fund, says it could help facilitate TikTok US saleAlso read |  OpenAI CEO Sam Altman once again hints that he wants to make an AI device

Headline: China targets Google, Nvidia and Intel as trade tensions escalateChina also announced 10 per cent tariffs on imports of US farm equipment that could impact firms.
Content: China announced a wide range of measures on Tuesday targeting US businesses including Google, farm equipment makers and the owner of fashion brand Calvin Klein, minutes after new US tariffs on Chinese goods took effect.  Beijing also slapped tariffs on US products such as coal, oil and some autos in a rapid response to the new duties on Chinese goods imposed by US President Donald Trump, escalating trade tensions between the world's two biggest economies. China's State Administration for Market Regulation said Google was suspected of violating the country's anti-monopoly law and an investigation was initiated in accordance with the law. It did not provide further details on the investigation or on what it alleged Google had done to breach the law. Google products such as its search engine are blocked in China and its revenue from there is about 1 per cent of global sales. It still works with Chinese partners such as advertisers. In 2017, Google announced the launch of a small artificial intelligence centre in China. But the project was disbanded two years later and the firm does not conduct AI research in China, according to a blog posting.  Separately, China's Commerce Ministry said it had put PVH Corp, the holding company for brands including Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, and US biotechnology firm Illumina ILMN.O on its "unreliable entity" list. It said the two companies took what it called "discriminatory measures against Chinese enterprises" and "damaged" the legitimate rights and interests of Chinese companies. Companies added to the blacklist can be subject to fines and a broad range of other sanctions, including a freeze on trade and revocation of work permits for foreign staff. While Google declined to comment, PVH said it was "surprised and deeply disappointed" by the ministry's decision, saying that the company maintains "strict compliance with all relevant laws and regulations and operates in line with established industry standards and practices." PVH added it would continue engagement with relevant authorities and look forward to a positive resolution.  Illumina did not respond to a request for comment. Shares of both PVH and Illumina were down nearly 4 per cent each in premarket US trading, while Google-parent Alphabet rose 1 per cent.  PVH had already been under scrutiny from Chinese regulators over "improper" conduct related to the Xinjiang region. "These moves are warnings that China intends to harm US interests if need be, but still give China the option to back down," Capital Economics said in a note. "The tariffs could be postponed or cancelled before they come into effect... The probe against Google could conclude without any penalties."Tesla and Farm Equipment firms  China also announced 10 per cent tariffs on imports of US farm equipment that could impact firms such as Caterpillar, Deere & Co DE.Nand AGCO AGCO.N, as well as a small number of trucks and big-engine sedans shipped to China from the United States. That could apply to Elon Musk's Cybertruck, a niche offering Tesla has been promoting in China, as it awaits regulatory clearance to begin sales. China's Ministry of Industry and Information technology designated the Cybertruck as a "passenger car" in a posting in December that was quickly deleted. If the Cybertruck was designated as an electric truck, Tesla would face a 10 per cent tariff on any future imports from its factory in Texas. Tesla had no immediate comment.  The new tariffs on US products will start on February 10, the ministry said. The announcements made on Tuesday ramped up trade restrictions between Beijing and Washington that had been largely limited to the tech sector under the administration of former US President Joe Biden, which sought to restrict China's access to high-end semiconductors.  China said in December it had launched an investigation into Nvidia NVDA.O over a suspected violation of the country's anti-monopoly law, a probe widely seen as a retaliatory shot against Washington's latest curbs on the Chinese chip sector. Intel's INTC.O products sold in China were also called for a security review late last year by an influential Chinese industry group.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: iPhone SE 4 may witness a price hike, new leak suggestsAccording to the latest leak, the iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to be priced a little higher than its predecessor, iPhone SE 3.
Content: Apple is planning to release its next-gen iPhone SE this year, after 2 years. In 2025, the company is expected to bring several improvements over its predecessor, the iPhone SE 3 (launched in 2022). For instance, the upcoming phone is rumoured to come with a big display and design change. While the design will continue to feature a single camera shooter, the display may come as 6.06- inch. This is not the only change we may encounter. According to the latest leak, Bloomberg’s Mark Zuckerberg has shared that the iPhone SE 4 may witness a price hike. advertisementiPhone SE 4: Price leak The iPhone SE 4 is expected to see a price increase compared to its 2022 predecessor, which was priced at $429 (approximately Rs 37,000). According to Mark Gurman, the price could rise to around $500 (over Rs 43,000), though this may vary depending on manufacturing location and applicable taxes.This aligns with earlier leaks, adding credibility to the speculation. A report from Korean outlet Naver, citing an unnamed Japanese carrier, suggests the iPhone SE 4 will likely be priced at $500 (around Rs 42,700) or lower, consistent with previous rumours about a $499 price point. The iPhone SE 4 is expected to see a price increase compared to its 2022 predecessor, which was priced at $429 (approximately Rs 37,000). According to Mark Gurman, the price could rise to around $500 (over Rs 43,000), though this may vary depending on manufacturing location and applicable taxes. This aligns with earlier leaks, adding credibility to the speculation. A report from Korean outlet Naver, citing an unnamed Japanese carrier, suggests the iPhone SE 4 will likely be priced at $500 (around Rs 42,700) or lower, consistent with previous rumours about a $499 price point. For reference, the iPhone SE 3 was launched in India in 2022 at a starting price of Rs 43,900, while its US price was $429 (approximately Rs 36,700). If Apple follows the same pricing strategy for the iPhone SE 4 (or iPhone 16e), the Indian price could increase to around Rs 49,900.iPhone SE 4: What to expect  The iPhone SE 4, also rumoured to be called the iPhone 16e, is set to bring significant upgrades, marking a departure from its predecessors. Moving away from the iPhone 8-inspired design, the new model is expected to adopt a look similar to the iPhone 14, offering a more modern and immersive experience. The device will feature a 6.06-inch OLED display, replacing the 4.7-inch LCD, delivering superior visual quality akin to Apple’s high-end models. A major design change includes the transition from the Touch ID home button to Face ID, resulting in slimmer bezels and a more contemporary appearance. The iPhone 16e will reportedly share the same screen size and edge-to-edge design as the standard iPhone 16, creating a cohesive aesthetic across Apple’s lineup. Performance-wise, the iPhone 16e is rumoured to be powered by Apple’s A18 chipset, paired with an upgraded 8GB of RAM (up from 4GB). This boost in hardware will improve multitasking and handle resource-intensive applications, including Apple’s latest advancements in AI and machine learning. With 128GB of storage as standard, the device promises an enhanced user experience while remaining affordable. In terms of photography, the iPhone 16e is expected to feature a 48-megapixel rear camera, a significant upgrade for Apple’s budget-friendly lineup. The advanced "Fusion" lens will enable high-quality standard shots and 2x zoom without sacrificing detail, delivering sharper and more versatile photos for users upgrading from older SE models. As a powerful yet cost-effective option, the iPhone SE 4/16e is positioned to offer premium features in a compact, budget-friendly package, bridging the gap between entry-level and flagship Apple devices.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Z Flip 7 rumoured to get major upgradesThe Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7 are rumoured to get major upgrades in the camera and performance departments. Here's what to expect from the company's next-generation foldables.
Content:
The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7 are expected to launch this summer — probably in August — and leaks are already revealing some key details. Both foldables are said to have made big improvements over their predecessors, including upgrades to the camera and the performance. According to Anthony on X (formerly Twitter), one of the main updates seems to be in the heat management department. Both devices — Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Galaxy Z Flip 7 — are reportedly getting larger vapour chamber cooling systems to help with heat dissipation. In addition, a smoother and more durable hinge is also in the works, which could help prevent the wear and tear that older models might experience over time. 

 



Source: Anthony/ X (formerly Twitter)
 For those who are particularly picky about their displays, the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 seems to have a notable improvement in the crease department. While it’s unlikely to completely disappear, sources suggest the foldable's display crease will become much smaller, resulting in a more seamless viewing experience. Meanwhile, the Flip 7 will retain its 2,600 nits peak brightness, the same as the Galaxy Z Flip 6. Another area where the devices will see upgrades is in the sound department. The Galaxy Z Fold 7 is expected to get new speakers. However, there is no mention yet of similar improvements to the Flip 7’s speakers, so it remains to be seen if that will be the case. The camera system of the Galaxy Z Fold 7 is also said to get a massive upgrade. According to rumours, the Galaxy Z Fold 7 will feature a 200-megapixel main camera, which is in line with what we have come to see on Galaxy Ultra models. It seems that Samsung is taking notes from its previous Galaxy Z Fold Special Edition (sold in select Asian regions) model, which had a larger display and a higher resolution camera. However, the Galaxy Z Fold 7 is still expected to have 12GB RAM, instead of the Special Edition’s 16GB. In terms of performance, the Galaxy Z Flip 7 will likely feature Samsung’s Exynos 2500 chip, while the Galaxy Z Fold 7 will be powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset. This is in line with what we've seen in previous leaks, which suggest that the Fold 7 will feature faster processing power and improved overall performance compared to its predecessor. Both foldables are expected to launch with One UI 7.1, though there’s some uncertainty about whether this will be based on Android 15 or Android 16. This is due to the early release of Android 16, which could come out before the devices officially arrive. Pricing is expected to stay the same as their predecessors.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works and is it better than ChatGPT? Everything to knowAlso read |  Best mobile phone under Rs 15,000 in February 2025: CMF Phone 1, Poco M7 Pro 5G and more

Headline: ChatGPT on WhatsApp can now see your images and listen to your voice messagesOpenAI adds support for text and audio inputs to its ChatGPT chatbot on WhatsApp. The update now allows users to interact with the chatbot using text, images, and audio messages. The feature is available globally.
Content: ChatGPT on WhatsApp has received a new update. It can now analyse images and listen to your voice messages. OpenAI launched the ChatGPT’s chatbot number for Meta’s instant messaging app in December 2024. During the launch, this chatbot allowed users to access ChatGPT and ask queries using text only. However, the chatbot on WhatsApp can now answer users’ queries made through images and voice messages or audio files. The new update for the ChatGPT chatbot on WhatsApp is available globally and was first spotted by Android Authority. According to the report, the update allows the AI chatbot on WhatsApp to read images and audio files shared by users and respond based on the queries. However, the chatbot will only reply in text messages.How to use ChatGPT on WhatsApp To use ChatGPT on WhatsApp and interact with the AI chatbot using text, images, or audio files, follow these steps: – Save the official ChatGPT chatbot number +1-800-242-8478 on your phone. –After saving the number, relaunch your WhatsApp app. – Go to your contacts and search for the saved ChatGPT number on WhatsApp. – Open the chat and start your conversation. – You can chat with the ChatGPT chatbot via text, share an image to ask questions about it, or even send voice messages. Interestingly, we even tried speaking in Hindi and asked ChatGPT to transcribe the voice message. It responded accurately in Hindi. For images, it analyzed the details and suggested more related information when prompted. For example, we asked it to detect what was in a picture, and it scanned the image and provided detailed information about the subject.  However, since the update is in its initial stages, the chatbot feels somewhat laggy. For instance, when we switched conversations, it replied to the new query but then automatically shared more details from the previous conversation. It seems like it struggles to differentiate between new and old conversations. That said, the chatbot is still simple to use, quickly scans content, and responds accurately to queries made via text, images or voice messages.  Meanwhile, the text and voice update is not the only improvement OpenAI is planning for its ChatGPT chatbot on WhatsApp. According to Android Authority, OpenAI is planning to soon allow WhatsApp users to sign into their dedicated ChatGPT accounts through WhatsApp. If true, this will make it easier for users to continue conversations and sync data from the ChatGPT app. However, it’s unclear if additional features will be introduced with this update. In other news, OpenAI recently added the ‘Deep Research’ mode to ChatGPT. This new feature allows users to initiate multi-step research on the web for more complex tasks. “Whether it's a comprehensive competitive analysis or a personalized report on the best commuter bike that meets your specific requirements, you can attach images, files, or spreadsheets to add context to your question,” says OpenAI. Notably, Deep Research is the second AI agent introduced by OpenAI following the earlier launch of Operator AI, which can go on the web and perform browser-related tasks without human intervention. According to OpenAI, the new AI agent works “using its own browser, it can look at a webpage and interact with it by typing, clicking, and scrolling.”Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also Read |  Indian Railways launches SwaRail app: What it is, how to use and everything you need to knowAlso Read |  iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Here is how Apple may replace the Plus variant for slimmer iPhoneAlso Read |  Salesforce set to cut 1000 roles, impacted employees may have option to reapply internally

Headline: Zomato CEO Deepinder Goyal is looking to hire someone who has a second brainZomato CEO Deepinder Goyal is back with a new job posting, seeking candidates who use artificial intelligence (AI) as their "second brain." Here are the details.
Content: Zomato CEO Deepinder Goyal is back with a new job posting, seeking candidates who use artificial intelligence (AI) as their "second brain." In a post shared on X (formerly Twitter), Goyal announced this AI-focused job role, asking interested individuals to apply by sending an email with the subject line: "I have a second brain." While the details of the job role remain under wraps, the quirky requirement has garnered a lot of attention. In response to his latest post, many social media users have lauded the concept of a "second brain," referring to the growing role AI plays in today’s professional environment. One user commented that AI can improve decision-making, automate tasks, and open new opportunities for professionals. Goyal responded to such comments, revealing that AI has boosted his own productivity, and he believes this technology is becoming indispensable in leadership roles. This new job posting follows a similar trend from Goyal, who has previously used social media platforms to advertise key roles at Zomato. Notably, Goyal’s prior listing for a Chief of Staff position sparked widespread debate due to its unconventional conditions — requiring candidates to pay Rs 20 lakh upfront and offering no salary for the first year. The controversial move led to mixed reactions online, with some questioning the fairness of the terms, while others praised the innovative approach. For this role, Zomato attracted over 18,000 applicants. Of these, 150 were interviewed, and 30 candidates received offers. Goyal also confirmed that 18 individuals have already joined Zomato and its group companies, including Blinkit, taking on high-impact roles. Although the salary for these roles was not officially disclosed, there were indications that it could reach up to Rs 50 lakh annually, based on the official job postings. As for the current AI job offer, Goyal hasn’t shared specific details on what the role entails or the salary structure. However, given the focus on AI and Zomato’s history of offering competitive packages for important positions, it’s expected that the compensation will be good for the right candidate.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: After calling India's AI efforts hopeless, Sam Altman now says India should be a leader in AIOpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who previously dismissed India's ability to develop large-scale AI models, has now said the country should play a leading role in artificial intelligence. Here is the full story.
Content: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who previously dismissed India's ability to develop large-scale AI models, has now said the country should play a leading role in artificial intelligence. Speaking at an event attended by Union Minister for Railways and Electronics & IT, Ashwini Vaishnaw, Altman highlighted India's growing role in AI and revealed that it is OpenAI’s second-largest market globally.   His latest comments stand in contrast to his 2023 comments, where he had called India's chances of building competitive AI models "totally hopeless." At the time, he was responding to a question about whether a small team with a limited budget of $10 million could create a strong AI foundation model. Now, he has clarified that his earlier statement was taken out of context, saying that AI models are still expensive to train but are becoming more feasible, and India should take a leadership role in this space.   Altman’s change in perspective likely comes as India prepares to introduce its own AI model in the coming months. Minister Vaishnaw recently announced that the country is working on an indigenous AI model designed to be safe, secure, and cost-effective. The initiative is part of the larger IndiaAI mission, which aims to develop AI solutions suited for India’s specific needs, including support for multiple Indian languages.   The government has already set up a high-end computing infrastructure to support AI development. The project is starting with 10,000 GPUs, with an additional 8,693 GPUs to be added soon. This will provide affordable access to AI computing power for researchers, developers, and students. While using global AI models can cost between $2.5 and $3 per hour, India’s AI computing resources will be available for less than Rs 100 per hour after a 40 per cent government subsidy.   Altman, who recently announced OpenAI’s massive $500 billion ‘Stargate’ AI infrastructure project in the US, acknowledged that while AI development is costly, it offers a big long-term economic value. He said AI model training will continue to be expensive, but it is no longer out of reach for countries like India.   Vaishnaw, meanwhile, compared India’s AI ambitions to its achievements in space technology, such as the Chandrayaan mission. He asserted that just as India made remarkable progress in space exploration, it could achieve similar success in AI development. Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: Retired govt employee loses Rs 35 lakh after call from fake anti-corruption bureau officerA retired government official from Vijayawada lost Rs 35 lakh to cyber fraudsters posing as Anti-Corruption Bureau officers. The victim was threatened with a legal case and asked to pay money to save himself and his family.
Content: India is currently battling with the growing menace of cyber frauds. Each day, we are witnessing new cases where victims share their ordeal of losing money. While initially these cases felt a bit harmless—at least in terms that only financial damage was done—lately, scammers are even harassing the targeted individuals and extorting money from them by posing as CBI or other high-ranking officials. In the latest case, a retired government official from Vijayawada ended up losing Rs 35 lakh after getting calls from individuals posing as officials from the Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB). According to the case reported by the Times of India, the victim is a retired Mandal Educational Officer (MEO) from Kottapeta. His ordeal started when he received a phone call from individuals claiming to be ACB officers. The callers falsely alleged that legal cases had been registered against his wife and two sons. When the victim sought more details, the fraudsters refused to share any, claiming the information was confidential and would only be disclosed after the case was officially registered. To appear convincing, the scammers even made a video call, adding to the victim’s fear and confusion. As the victim asked for more details around the case and ways to come out clean from the charges, the scammers initially demanded Rs 1 lakh to supposedly prevent legal action. When the victim informed the scammers that he couldn’t arrange that amount immediately, the scammers abruptly ended the call. This made the victim panic, and he dialed the scammers back, agreeing to meet their demands and send money. Fearing for his family’s safety, the victim reportedly transferred Rs 50,000 to the bank account provided by the fraudsters. After receiving the first payment, the scammers did not stop and started escalating their threats. They even warned the victim that the case was severe enough to warrant the seizure of his properties. And to help him with the case, the scammers then demanded Rs 50 lakh, leaving the victim overwhelmed with anxiety. Desperate to protect his family, he agreed to transfer the money in smaller installments over the next ten days. To meet the demands, the victim even contacted his son. He borrowed Rs 2 lakh from his son to meet their demands, eventually sending a total of Rs 35 lakh through multiple transactions. It was when the son questioned his father—given that the father never asked for large sums and the sudden reason for needing money—that the victim shared the details. Upon learning about the case, the son rushed and filed a complaint with the local police. A case has been registered under relevant cybercrime laws, and an investigation is currently underway to trace the fraudsters. While the case seems to be a new trick of fraudsters to threaten people and extort money, the trick is similar to the ongoing fake parcel scam where scammers call people about an illegal parcel detained in their name. Later, in the name of removing legal action, they demand money. In these cases, they even ask the victim to be under "digital arrest" and not to share anything with anyone. To stay safe from such scams, remember that no official body will threaten you about serious cases on call and demand money. If you get such calls, hang up and report them to the cyber cell. If you have doubts, you can go to the nearest police station to get more details. Most importantly, never share any sensitive information online, including OTPs, banking details, and more. Remember that vigilance is the only safety measure that can save you from growing cyber frauds.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also Read |  ChatGPT on WhatsApp can now see your images and listen to your voice messagesAlso Read |  Indian Railways launches SwaRail app: What it is, how to use and everything you need to knowAlso Read |  iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Here is how Apple may replace the Plus variant for slimmer iPhone

Headline: Apple Invites app for iPhones is cool and an organised way to plan a partyApple has launched a new app called Invites for iPhones. If you are a social butterfly, and you are already a part of the Apple ecosystem, you are going to love it.
Content:
We’ve been hearing about Apple working on an invitation app for a few days now. Honestly, it didn’t catch my attention at first — I assumed it would just be another app for sending event reminders. But when Apple officially launched and rolled out the app last night, I downloaded it to confirm my assumptions. I was pleasantly surprised. The app is intuitive, fun, and a cool way to create invites. If you search for Apple Invites on the App Store, you will see that the app is available to download for free. The app weighs about 58MB, and it is available in Hindi, English and 31 other languages. Just make sure that you check that Apple is listed as the app developer, just in case some dupe Invites apps also show up on the App Store.  Apple Invites is currently only available on iOS, but it lets iPhone users share the invite with both iOS and Android users.  Now, to the fun part –– using Apple Invites.  Once you have downloaded the app, you don’t require any logins. If you are looking to create an invitation, the app pretty much takes you through the process itself. So I am not going to delve much into that. But what I want to talk about is the level of customisation that the app offers. Apple Invites not only lets you add a background –– you can choose between some Apple backgrounds or use your own pictures from the Photos app –– add an event title, date, time and location, but what I thought was cool is that you can create a shared album for an event, so that everyone you invite to an event, can post their images all in one place. You don’t have to go around asking people for pictures later on.  (If you organise events or parties often, you know how hard it is to find time to click pictures. After the party, you’re usually left chasing people to share photos — and they take forever to do it. It’s always a hassle. I got married three months ago, and my friends still haven’t shared all the pictures they took at my wedding.) The Invites app also lets you create a playlist or use an existing one to attach to the invite. The playlist can be like a little feeler you put out before the party. Ahead of the event, people understand exactly the vibe you are going for. 

 



Getting started on the app is easy and does not require any log-ins
Tiny little thoughtful features in the app Additionally, just how reminders work, you can choose if you want the invite reminder to be an all-day thing, or if you want to set an end-time to it. You can also pick a start and end date and time for the event reminder.  There are other little customisations as well. You can choose from four different typefaces. You can preview the invite before sending it out, so you know what the final look of the invite will be like.

 



You have a bunch of little customisation options on the app
Works for both iOS and Android users You can share the invite via Messages (to both Android and iOS users) or Email. Or you can simply copy the link and share it with whoever you want, on whichever platform. Android users will be able to access the invite via a web version of the app on iCloud. Another feature on the app that will really help you in organising an event better is an option to Approve Guests, so that you can send out a public link for guests to RSVP. When they respond to the invite by tapping on “Going”, they will appear in your guest list in the app. You can create multiple invites on the app at one time. You can see them all on the main screen of the app. You can see your upcoming events, past events, drafts of invites that you have saved, the events that you are hosting, and also the events that you are attending.  Also, once you have created an invitation and sent it out, you can also send notes to all the invitees. You can also send a separate calendar invite of the event to your guests. After creating an invitation, you can always go back and edit the details. And if you are really proud of an invitation you created, you can also duplicate it, so that you can just make some changes and re-use the same thing again.  I love the amount of detailing in the app. It also lets you pick additional guests, which is basically giving invitees to get +1s. You can choose to allow up to +5 guests per invite.  

 



Here is how the Invites link looks like on an Android phone
advertisementWhy is it an app we didn’t know we needed?Until now, the easiest way to do all this –– create invites, create a shared album, have a pre-party playlist, get RSVPs, etc –– was to create a WhatsApp group and just dump all that information in one place. That way is inconvenient, but we have all been doing that for years with/without cribbing. And if I am being very honest, I also didn’t think there could be a better alternative. Until last night, I didn’t even know I needed an app like Invites, and now I can’t stop thinking about how, if Apple had launched this app a few months earlier, I could have used it for my wedding invites. That said, there are some limitations to the app. The app works perfectly if you are completely part of the Apple ecosystem, and so are all the people around you. Headline: Don't use AI tools like ChatGPT and DeepSeek, Indian Finance Ministry tells its employees India's finance ministry has advised its employees to avoid using AI tools like ChatGPT and DeepSeek for official work to avoid risking data confidentiality. This advisory comes ahead of OpenAI chief Sam Altman's scheduled visit to India.
Content: India's finance ministry has asked its employees to avoid using AI tools including ChatGPT and DeepSeek for official purposes, citing risks posed to confidentiality of government documents and data, an internal department advisory showed. Countries like Australia and Italy have placed similar restrictions on the use of DeepSeek, citing data security risks. Reports of the advisory surfaced on social media on Tuesday, ahead of a scheduled visit to India by OpenAI chief Sam Altman on Wednesday, when he is also due to meet the IT minister. "It has been determined that AI tools and AI apps (such as ChatGPT, DeepSeek etc.) in the office computers and devices pose risks for confidentiality of (government) data and documents," said the advisory by the Indian finance ministry dated Jan. 29. Representatives for India's finance ministry, ChatGPT-parent OpenAI and DeepSeek did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Three finance ministry officials said the note was genuine and the note was issued internally this week. Reuters could not immediately confirm whether similar directives have been issued for other Indian ministries. OpenAI is facing heat in India due to a high-profile copyright infringement battle with the country's top media houses, and has said in court filings that it does not have its servers in the country and Indian courts should not hear the matter.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also Read |  Retired govt employee loses Rs 35 lakh after call from fake anti-corruption bureau officerAlso Read |  ChatGPT on WhatsApp can now see your images and listen to your voice messagesAlso Read |  Indian Railways launches SwaRail app: What it is, how to use and everything you need to know

Headline: 3 countries have already banned Deepseek AI, here is whyDeepSeek AI has come under scrutiny as three countries — Australia, Italy, and Taiwan — have taken measures to ban its services. Here is why these countries blocked this Chinese AI platform.
Content: DeepSeek AI, a rapidly growing Chinese artificial intelligence startup, has come under scrutiny as three countries — Australia, Italy, and Taiwan — have taken measures to ban its services. Here is why these countries blocked DeepSeek AI, which is more popular in comparison to OpenAI's ChatGPT.  Australia recently made headlines by becoming one of the first countries to ban DeepSeek AI from all government systems and devices, according to a report by Bloomberg. The country’s Home Affairs Minister, Tony Burke, announced the decision, highlighting that a national intelligence assessment found the AI platform to pose an unacceptable security risk. Effective immediately, all DeepSeek products and services will be removed from Australian government infrastructure.  While this ban does not apply to personal devices, Burke urged Australians to be cautious about their online data usage and to protect their digital privacy. DeepSeek, which was founded just 20 months ago in China, gained massive attention earlier this year with the launch of its AI chatbot app. It claims to simulate human-like reasoning. The app's popularity skyrocketed quickly, but concerns about data security also emerged soon. The platform’s privacy policy states that all user data is stored in servers located in China, raising fears that the information could be accessed by Chinese authorities under local laws that mandate data sharing with intelligence agencies. Italy followed suit, with its privacy regulator ordering a block on DeepSeek’s services to protect consumer data. The Italian government’s decision came amid increasing concerns about how the app collects and handles personal information. Ireland’s Data Protection Commission has also requested more details from DeepSeek, seeking clarity on its data protection policies. In Taiwan, the government has taken a strict stance, banning DeepSeek AI from use across all public sector organisations. Taiwan’s Ministry of Digital Affairs expressed concerns about the risk of cross-border data transmission and information leaks. The ban extends to public schools, state-owned enterprises, and critical infrastructure. In addition to government actions, private companies have also begun distancing themselves from DeepSeek. In the US, several federal agencies have instructed employees not to use the app, while hundreds of companies have reportedly requested cybersecurity firms to block access to the platform.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: Meta reportedly merging Facebook and Messenger teams ahead of layoffs next weekMeta is reportedly merging its Facebook and Messenger teams ahead of the layoffs next week, which will apparently target low performers.
Content:
Meta is reportedly merging its Facebook and Messenger teams to make a single unit. This restructure comes on the heels of scheduled job cuts next week, which will apparently target low performers in the organisation. According to a report by The Information, in this shake-up in the organisation, Messenger chief Loredana Crisan will move to Meta's generative AI (genAI) team, while Tom Allison, who is currently heading Facebook, will reportedly oversee some additional responsibilities in the Messenger team. As per the report, the restructuring isn’t just taking place in the Facebook and Messenger teams, but also at Meta’s generative AI team. The Information reports that the lead engineers at Meta’s genAI department, which includes Ryan Cairns and Ning Li will also be assigned new roles in Meta. It seems like the reshuffle is aimed at reiterating the company’s AI-first focus.  The news about the internal reshuffle comes just weeks after an internal memo from the company’s Director of People Development Growth Programmes revealed Meta’s plans to achieve 10 per cent non-regrettable attrition by the end of this fiscal year. For the uninitiated, non-regrettable attrition basically refers to employees in the company who Meta thinks can be fired without any negative impact on the company’s objective or overall performance.  According to the purported memo, Meta employees with low assessment ratings –– which includes both those who did not meet expectations and the ones who met some expectations –– will be laid off. In fact, according to the report, even some employees who are rated to have met most of the expectations may also face job cuts.  The news of the restructuring and job cuts comes after the company laid off 5 per cent of its workforce last year. In 2025, Meta is expected to make another 5 per cent job cuts.  If you noticed in the news article that while reports suggest that Meta plans to lay off another 5 per cent of its employees this year, the top executives are only being reassigned to new responsibilities. This could possibly be because of what Meta CEO Mark Zuckeberg recently said. "We have really ambitious goals, so we need to manage our workforce in a way that ensures we have the strongest talent working here and can move faster in managing our low performers," he said. The layoffs and reshuffle are part of Meta’s strategy to boost efficiency within the organisation, which, as per the company’s recent announcements, also includes pulling back on diversity and inclusivity initiatives. In an effort to increase organisational efficiency, Meta recently also announced that it is pausing its third-party fact-checking programme.  Silver lining: Meta says it will start re-hiring for the 10 per cent roles that will be eliminated in 2025, soon.

Headline: MacBook users beware, new malware posing as Google Chrome update can steal your dataComputer virus and malware often pose as legitimate piece of code and regular apps to hoodwink their victims. The latest in the series is a malware called Ferret is stealing data from MacBook users.
Content: MacBook users beware — there is a new threat in town and it is called Ferret. Researchers at SentinelLabs have flagged a new malware targeting MacBook users. This new Malware family is named Ferret and is said to be linked to North Korean hackers and cyber criminals. The latest Ferret malware, which is basically an evolution of the existing one, poses as a Chrome software update file. With its code spoofed to look like legitimate Google Chrome code, the Ferret bypasses security apps and scanning.  Researchers hint that Ferret gains entry into a MacBook once a user is hoodwinked into downloading a piece of app. This often happens through fake job interviews or similar other online interactions. During the interaction the person giving the interview is asked to download a piece of code — for example a “Chrome update” or a “zoom update”. As soon as the code is downloaded, the latest version of Ferret is installed on the system and it can in the background collect and steal all user data.  Apple is apparently aware of the Ferret threat. Reports note that MacBooks come with Apple’s XProtect feature. This feature has been recently updated to deal with Ferret so if you have not run an update on your MacBook system software, this might be a good time to do so.  According to reports, the Ferret malware family was first detected in December. It was identified as part of the North Korean Contagious Interview campaign, in which cyber criminals and hackers lure people through fake job interviews and con them into installing the Ferret. How does malware affect MacOS systems?  Researchers explains that once the users install the malware into their system, the malware starts executing several malicious activities. This includes  1- Disguise itself as legitimate software: Researchers note that they have found this malware runs a harmful shell script to install persistent programs disguised as Google Chrome updateZoom-related services. These agents ensure that the malware runs every time the user starts the system.  2- Data theft: While running in the system, the malware collects sensitive data and then sends it out using Dropbox.Stay safe While the Ferret family is in news, it is not the only computer virus and malware out in the open. But one thing that is common to almost all such malicious apps is that they rely on a user mistake to get into the system. And this mistake is user installing something on their computer because someone manipulated them into doing it.  In other words, one of the best way to stay safe online is never to click on a link some stranger has sent you, or never to download something that someone wants to you download even during job interviews or during IT troubleshooting. Headline: OpenAI announces major rebrand: Unveils new logo, typeface and colour paletteOpenAI has finally unveiled its first major rebrand, with a similar but new logo, a new typeface, and colour palette. This change aims to create a more organic and more human brand identity, according to the company.
Content:
OpenAI has recently unveiled a comprehensive rebranding initiative, introducing a refreshed logo, a new custom typeface named OpenAI Sans, and an updated colour palette. The redesigned logo retains the essence of the previous design but features subtle enhancements, such as a slightly enlarged central space and more streamlined, fluid lines. This effort was spearheaded by OpenAI's internal design team, aiming to create a more "organic and more human" brand identity, according to the Wallpaper report.  The Wallpaper interviewed OpenAI designer Moeller, who explained all the changes in detail. He noted that this change is a part of a rebranding effort.Refreshed logo  Designed to balance geometric precision with a warm, approachable feel, the typeface is now featured in OpenAI’s official wordmark. Notably, the "O" in the logo has a perfectly round exterior, while its interior is intentionally imperfect, adding a subtle human touch to counteract an overly mechanical appearance.  At the heart of OpenAI’s new visual identity is “the point”, a black circle symbolising the cursor, the starting point of ChatGPT’s responses, and the foundation of the brand’s design language. This simple yet powerful motif shapes the letterforms, grid, and spacing throughout the identity. The report further explains how this point is the foundation. “It became an essential element, naturally emerging from the visual language of research papers, graphs, and diagrams," it stated. New typeface  The Wallpaper also spoke to another designer, Shannon Jager stated, "OpenAI Sans is a love letter to typography." For the new typeface, OpenAI partnered with ABC Dinamo with a vision to seamlessly integrate ‘the point’ into the letterforms. Through close collaboration, this vision took shape, culminating in the creation of OpenAI Sans.

 



Credit: OpenAI
 OpenAI is still working as it expands the typeface to include global scripts and a monospaced version, ultimately replacing the six or seven different typefaces previously used across its products. The designers say that this way OpenAI can create a more cohesive and unified typographic identity. 
 


Different colour palette The new visual identity is complemented by a refined colour palette, anchored in shades of grey and blue that evoke horizons, open skies, and vast spaces, enhanced by bold primary contrast colours for added depth and clarity, according to the report.  A key element of the rebrand is the Emotive Point, a pulsing disc set against a watercolour-inspired backdrop of swirling blue abstract forms. Designed as an interactive visual cue for AI engagement, Moeller explains that it is intentionally "non-human", devoid of any distinct features or emotions, reinforcing the AI’s neutrality. When asked whether AI-powered tools like ChatGPT played a role in the design process, Moeller clarified that the team only used AI to assist in calculating type weights. OpenAI’s designers emphasised that their approach blends human expertise with AI-driven insights, collaborating with top professionals in typography, photography, motion, and spatial design. By integrating AI tools like DALL·E, ChatGPT, and Sora as creative partners, OpenAI aims to craft a brand identity that is not just cutting-edge—but deeply human.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also read |  Don't use AI tools like ChatGPT and DeepSeek, Indian Finance Ministry tells its employeesAlso read |  After calling India's AI efforts hopeless, Sam Altman now says India should be a leader in AIAlso read |  ChatGPT on WhatsApp can now see your images and listen to your voice messagesMust Watch

Headline: Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Here is how to get them backIf you've upgraded to OneUI 7 on a Samsung phone, you might have noticed something odd — lockscreen notifications seem to be missing. However, with a simple tweak in settings, you can restore lockscreen notification cards for a more familiar experience.
Content:
Have you pre-ordered the spanking new Galaxy S25? Or did you recently upgrade to OneUI 7 on an eligible phone, such as the Galaxy S24? Did you notice something strange? Where I’m trying to get at here is that, as part of my job and the privilege of being a reviewer who gets to test new devices, I recently made the switch to the Samsung Galaxy S25 and instantly noticed something odd. After using it for a couple of days, I realised that while my phone’s notification drawer was full of notification cards, the phone’s lockscreen displayed none of them. In fact, the moment I first realised this, I thought I had encountered a bug in OneUI 7. Thankfully, that wasn’t the case. Over the years of using smartphones — whether Android or iOS — one thing that has remained constant is lockscreen notifications. The cards that appear on the lockscreen signal that an app has received a notification that needs to be checked, or you can swipe to ignore it. The point is, the notification cards tell us that something is there. However, for some reason, this basic functionality is disabled by default in OneUI 7. Fortunately, you can easily enable lockscreen notification cards by heading over to Settings, something I did in an instant after my sudden realisation. But what about the average consumer? They could easily think that something’s wrong with their phone. By default, if you receive a notification on a Samsung phone (probably the Galaxy S24, as the Galaxy S25 hasn’t yet started seeding to the public) running OneUI 7 — and if you miss the message tone or vibration — there’s a high chance you’ll miss the notification. I know I did. I also understand that while the app icons in the notification drawer (on the lockscreen) do signal that a notification has arrived, a basic notification card is, without a doubt, better. So, if you’ve also faced this issue where your notification cards aren’t appearing on your Samsung phone running OneUI 7, here’s how you can get them back. Just follow these steps:
Head to Settings, scroll down a bit and tap Notifications.
Tap the second option, Lock screen notifications.
From the three available options: Dot, Icons (the default one), and Cards, select the last one.
Also, make sure to select Hide Content below, so your phone’s lockscreen displays a notification card but not its content. This is especially useful when it comes to personal messages on WhatsApp.
 Well, that’s all. This simple yet strange — not exactly an — issue in OneUI 7, regarding the notification cards on the lockscreen, will be solved.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 5, 2025Also read |  iQOO 13 is available under Rs 40,000, but is it worth buying?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  DeepSeek AI: What is it, how it works and is it better than ChatGPT?
