Headline: MacBook Air and MacBook Pro with M5 chip launching soon? Here is everything to knowApple is working on its latest MacBook Pro models, which will be powered by the next-generation M5 chip. The tech giant has reportedly begun mass production of the M5 chip, with a report suggesting that these new devices might arrive as early as late 2025.
Content: Apple is likely working on its latest MacBook Pro models, which will be powered by the next-generation M5 chip. The tech giant has reportedly begun mass production of the M5 chip, with a South Korean media report suggesting that these new devices might arrive as early as late 2025. However, the MacBook Air M5 model could take a little longer than that to debut. Here is everything to know. The leak, originating from ET News, claims that Apple commenced the packaging process for the M5 chip last month, hinting that the company is well into the production phase. Packaging is one of the final steps in semiconductor manufacturing, following the fabrication of the chips. Taiwan's ASE Group has reportedly started mass production for the base model of the M5, with other manufacturers like Amkor and China's JCET expected to join soon. The M5 chip is said to be manufactured using TSMC’s advanced 3-nanometer technology, which offers notable improvements in efficiency and performance compared to previous chips. However, Apple has reportedly opted to skip the more advanced 2nm process for now, likely due to cost considerations. However, the high-end M5 Pro, M5 Max, and M5 Ultra chips are still expected to offer big performance boosts through innovative design technologies. But, how will this happen? It is being reported that the 3D chip-stacking process, also known as System on Integrated Chip (SoIC) technology, will allow Apple to improve thermal management and reduce power leakage in the higher versions of the M5 chip, a move aimed at boosting both battery life and performance. While the base model of the M5 is in production, the high-end variants will reportedly follow soon as Apple ramps up its production facilities. Interestingly, MacRumors suggests that the first device to be powered by the M5 chip might not be a MacBook at all, but rather a new iPad Pro, slated for release in late 2025 or early 2026. The MacBook Pro is expected to follow in late 2025, while the MacBook Air with M5 variants could debut by early 2026. There's also speculation about an upgraded version of Apple’s Vision Pro headset integrating the M5 chip, possibly launching in 2026. As of now, Apple has not officially confirmed these developments. But with mass production already underway, the company could be preparing for the next-gen Mac devices which will be powered by the M5 chip.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 5, 2025

Headline: Galaxy S25 vs Galaxy S24: Which Samsung flagship is right for you?Samsung Galaxy S25 vs Galaxy S23 Comparison: If you have to choose between the Galaxy S24 and Galaxy S25, which one should you go for? Should you save your cash and buy the Galaxy S24, or should you go all in and get the Galaxy S25? We try to help you make the decision.
Content:
Samsung recently released the Galaxy S25 series to the world. While most of the love and attention is being garnered by the Galaxy S25 Ultra, we need to remember that two other phones have also been released alongside the Ultra model — the Galaxy S25+ and the vanilla Galaxy S25. Now, the standard Galaxy S25 is a one-of-a-kind phone in today’s day and age. If you’re looking for a top-tier compact flagship smartphone — with all due respect to the Xiaomi 14 — the only popular option out there is a Galaxy S device. Of course, you can always buy a standard iPhone, like the iPhone 15 or 16. But if you specifically want an Android flagship — again — Samsung’s vanilla Galaxy S is your best bet. Case in point, the recently released Galaxy S25 and its predecessor, the Galaxy S24. With both phones available at different price points, if you have to choose between the S24 and S25, which one should you go for? Should you save your cash and buy the Galaxy S24, or should you go all in and get the Galaxy S25? We try to help you make the decision.Galaxy S25 vs Galaxy S24: Price difference For the sake of keeping things equal, we are going to compare the 256GB storage options of both phones, since the Galaxy S25 is only available in 256GB and 512GB storage variants. Of course, people content with a 128GB storage phone can always buy it; the Galaxy S24 is available with that option. However, it’s high time that 256GB storage becomes the standard base storage in all high-end phones. And anyway, 128GB storage doesn’t cut it any more, as the need for more is always there. With that said, when it comes to price — the Galaxy S24 is currently listed at Rs 70,999 on Samsung’s official website, while the Galaxy S25 is listed at Rs 80,999. With an HDFC Bank card, you can get a flat Rs 10,000 instant discount, bringing the effective price of both phones down to Rs 60,999 and Rs 70,999, respectively. So, with a Rs 10,000 price difference between the Galaxy S24 and Galaxy S25, which one should you buy?Galaxy S25 vs Galaxy S24: What’s the Difference? The obvious reason for choosing the Galaxy S24 over the S25 is the price. If you don’t care about the latest and greatest and want to save some cash, go with the Galaxy S24 — you won’t be disappointed. But the question is — for the extra Rs 10,000, what does the Galaxy S25 bring to the table? Here are the upgrades. Subtle design changes Alright, this might not be a big change to justify the price difference, but probably the easiest way to tell apart the Galaxy S25 from the older model is the new available colours. The Navy and Icy Blue shades, especially the latter (which I have received as my review unit), look great. Apart from that, the Galaxy S25 sports blacked-out rear camera rings and slimmer bezels on the front, but that’s about it. The Galaxy S25 still has Gorilla Glass Victus 2 protection, which is great, though Gorilla Armor 2 glass would’ve raised the bar. That said, the Galaxy S25 is now 7.2mm thick versus the S24’s 7.6mm thickness. While the 0.4mm difference might not seem like much, after experiencing both phones, I can say that the Galaxy S25 offers a much better grip over the already comfortable and ergonomic Galaxy S24. 12GB RAM as standard This should have been a long time coming, and it’s good that Samsung is finally offering 12GB RAM on its vanilla Galaxy S25. In fact, 12GB RAM is standard across the Galaxy S25 series. Now, the Galaxy S24 is only available in 8GB RAM options. The difference between 8GB RAM and 12GB RAM on a phone comes down to multitasking, gaming, and long-term performance. 8GB RAM is good for everyday use like social media, browsing, and casual gaming, but it may reload apps if too many run in the background. 12GB RAM handles heavy multitasking better, keeps more apps open, and improves gaming performance by reducing stutters and reloads. It also helps with smoother UI, faster camera processing, and future-proofing. If you use your phone casually, 8GB RAM is enough, but if you multitask a lot, game heavily, or want a phone that stays fast for years, 12GB RAM is a better choice. Snapdragon 8 Elite + larger vapour chamber cooling Probably the biggest upgrade on the Galaxy S25 is the Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, which is not only a giant leap over the Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 but an even bigger leap over the Exynos 2400, inside the Galaxy S24. Pair that with a 15 per cent bigger vapour chamber cooling system, and the Galaxy S25 becomes a performance monster. While I didn’t have any major issues during my time with the Galaxy S24 regarding overheating — apart from the fact that the phone got pretty hot when connected to Android Auto — those sorts of issues are sorted with the S25. Everything flies on this phone with fast performance, buttery smooth animations, and almost no lag or frame drops, even while gaming. The battery is still 4,000mAh, but this time around, I can at least use the phone for a full day before it discharges, which was not the case with the S24. Of course, a bigger battery or maybe a silicon-carbon battery would’ve helped, but for now, the chipset’s efficiency and optimisation are definitely doing the work here. More camera features Finally, the camera — which, again, one can argue has the same hardware as last year’s model. But having used the S24 last year and using the S25 now, I can assure you that the performance has definitely improved, primarily because of the superior ISP. Photos in various lighting conditions — despite having the same hardware — now appear more detailed, and the colour tone, especially human skin tones, is also closer to accurate. Apart from this, features such as smoother lens switching while recording videos and the new zoom slider are great, thanks to the next-generation Pro-Visual Engine. The Expert RAW mode also gets a few settings that may appeal to professionals, including two exposure monitoring controls, a couple of ND filter strengths, and a virtual aperture meter to adjust the depth of blur in real time.Galaxy S25 vs Galaxy S24: Which One to Buy? The decision between the Galaxy S25 and Galaxy S24 ultimately boils down to your priorities and budget. You should choose the Galaxy S25 if you want the latest Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, which offers a solid performance boost over the Galaxy S24’s Exynos 2400. The 12GB RAM as standard ensures better multitasking, smoother gaming, and future-proofing. The improved cooling system, refined design, and improved camera features (thanks to the superior ISP and Pro-Visual Engine) make the Galaxy S25 a more capable and polished device. However, if you’re on a budget and don’t necessarily need the latest specs, the Galaxy S24 still offers a great experience with its 8GB RAM, capable Exynos 2400, and the same camera hardware as the S25. It’s a reliable choice for everyday use, casual gaming, and social media browsing. Plus, with the HDFC Bank card discount, the effective price of Rs 60,999 makes it a more (relatively) affordable option without compromising too much on performance. Overall, the Galaxy S25 is the better phone, no doubt, but the Galaxy S24 is no slouch either. If the Rs 10,000 price difference isn’t a dealbreaker for you, the S25’s upgrades in performance, RAM, and camera refinements make it the more future-proof and premium choice. However, if you’re looking to save money and still want a top-tier Android flagship, the Galaxy S24 is an excellent value-for-money option that won’t disappoint.

Headline: Qualcomm CEO says Arm has withdrawn threat to end license agreementQualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon has confirmed that Arm has withdrawn a threat to end its license agreement with the chip maker.
Content: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon has confirmed that Arm has withdrawn its threat to end Qualcomm’s licensing agreement. For a very long time, the threat of the licensing agreement between Qualcomm and Arm being terminated has been the key point of contention. Amon revealed this while speaking to analysts during a conference call. He said that Arm had withdrawn the October 2024 notice of breach and currently has no plans to terminate the licensing agreement with Qualcomm.  "Arm recently notified us that it was withdrawing its October 22, 2024 notice of breach, and indicated that it has no current plan to terminate the Qualcomm architecture license agreement," Amon said, according to a report by Reuters. advertisementWhat was the Qualcomm vs Arm legal battle about?Arm’s threat to end the licensing agreement with Qualcomm is rooted in a disagreement over the technology behind Qualcomm’s custom computer chips. Qualcomm has for a long time been working with Arm for its architecture for chip design. However, the company has also been working on its own custom computer chips in order to reduce its dependency on Arm. That’s where Nuvia comes in. But to understand this, we will have to rewind to 2021. That is when Qualcomm acquired Nuvia. That is also when the legal tensions between Qualcomm and Arm began. Nuvia was founded by former Apple engineers and Qualcomm bought the company –– with the plans of making custom PC chips in mind –– for $1.4 billion. However, this made Arm unhappy. The company said that Qualcomm using Nuvia’s design violated their licensing agreement. Arm wanted Qualcomm to destroy all Nuvia technology that was developed under a previously terminated license. Qualcomm did not agree with Arm’s suggestion and claimed that Nuvia’s technology was within the bounds of its agreement with Arm.advertisement Arm’s threat to end the licensing agreement with Qualcomm is rooted in a disagreement over the technology behind Qualcomm’s custom computer chips. Qualcomm has for a long time been working with Arm for its architecture for chip design. However, the company has also been working on its own custom computer chips in order to reduce its dependency on Arm.  That’s where Nuvia comes in. But to understand this, we will have to rewind to 2021. That is when Qualcomm acquired Nuvia. That is also when the legal tensions between Qualcomm and Arm began. Nuvia was founded by former Apple engineers and Qualcomm bought the company –– with the plans of making custom PC chips in mind –– for $1.4 billion. However, this made Arm unhappy. The company said that Qualcomm using Nuvia’s design violated their licensing agreement. Arm wanted Qualcomm to destroy all Nuvia technology that was developed under a previously terminated license. Qualcomm did not agree with Arm’s suggestion and claimed that Nuvia’s technology was within the bounds of its agreement with Arm. Last year in December, a jury ruled in favour of Qualcomm –– they came to a decision that Qualcomm’s computer chips were properly licensed under its agreement with Arm. However, the jury could not reach a unanimous decision, and Arm filed a motion for a new trial. Is the legal battle over now? For now, Arm’s decision to withdraw the threat to end the licensing agreement would for sure bring some relief to Qualcomm. However, is the legal battle over? We can’t say. Looking at how long and intense this legal battle has been, this only seems like a temporary de-escalation of the matter. Headline: Google rolls out new flagship AI model with thinking capabilitiesGoogle has listed a number of new models, including Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking and Gemini 2.0 Pro Experimental.
Content:
Google has finally released its reasoning AI model for its users. The Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking model is trained to break down prompts into a series of steps to strengthen its reasoning capabilities and deliver better responses. It shows the thought process, so users can see why it responded in a certain way, what its assumptions were, and trace the model's line of reasoning.
 


 This comes after OpenAI unveiled its o3 and o3-mini in the reasoning series last week. While it is a little late to the party, Google claims that it is currently ranked as the world's best model. Google Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking  Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking is now available in the model dropdown options on both desktop and mobile apps, starting today. Initially launched in December 2024, this model is designed to compete with other advanced reasoning AI systems like OpenAI’s o1 and DeepSeek’s R1.
 


 In addition, Google is introducing another variant, 2.0 Flash Thinking Experimental with Apps, which can reason and seamlessly interact with services like YouTube, Search, and Google Maps. These integrations aim to create a more dynamic and personalised user experience, positioning Gemini as a uniquely capable AI assistant. Both versions are rolling out now to all Gemini users across web and mobile platforms. These models utilise a problem-solving approach that breaks down complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps, enabling them to "think" through prompts before providing a solution. While this method delivers more accurate and reliable results, it may require slightly more processing time. With these updates, Gemini continues to evolve as a powerful tool for AI-powered assistance, enhancing user engagement and functionality.Google Gemini 2.0 Pro Experimental According to Google, this upgraded model is designed to excel at coding and managing complex prompts, offering significantly improved reasoning and understanding of world knowledge compared to its predecessors.  A standout feature of Gemini 2.0 Pro is its ability to interact with tools like Google Search and execute code on behalf of users, enhancing its versatility and functionality.  Gemini 2.0 Pro is now available to Gemini Advanced subscribers through the Gemini app.   The model also boasts a massive 2-million-token context window, allowing it to process approximately 1.5 million words in a single session. With these advancements, Gemini 2.0 Pro sets a new benchmark for AI models, delivering exceptional performance for users who require advanced capabilities. Headline: After Meta, Google scraps diversity-based hiring programmeGoogle had for years been among the most vocal companies pushing for more inclusive policies, but now its comes to an end.
Content: Alphabet's Google is scrapping its goal to hire more employees from under-represented groups and is reviewing some of its diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, joining a slew of U.S. businesses scaling back diversity initiatives. "In 2020, we set aspirational hiring goals and focused on growing our offices outside California and New York to improve representation," Fiona Cicconi, Alphabet's chief people officer, said in an email to staff on Wednesday, a copy which was reviewed by Reuters. "...but in the future we will no longer have aspirational goals." Google had for years been among the most vocal companies pushing for more inclusive policies in the wake of protests against the police killings of George Floyd and other Black Americans in 2020. In 2020, CEO Sundar Pichai set a goal to have 30 per cent more of its leaders from underrepresented groups by 2025. At the time, about 96 per cent of Google's US leaders were white or Asian, and 73 per cent globally were men. In 2021, it began to evaluate executive performance on team diversity and inclusion after a prominent leader of artificial intelligence research said the company abruptly fired her after she criticised its diversity efforts. Google's chief diversity officer Melonie Parker said in a 2024 interview with BBC that the company had hit 60 per cent of its five-year goals. On Wednesday, an Alphabet spokesperson said the company did not have updated figures regarding Pichai's goals. Alphabet's annual filing with the US SEC on Wednesday showed it omitted a line saying it was "committed to making diversity, equity and inclusion part of everything we do and to growing a workforce that is representative of the users we serve." That statement appeared in annual reports from 2021 to 2024. The spokesperson said the line was removed to reflect its review of DEI programs. "This is a real attack on gains that workers have made in the tech industry through movements fighting against racism, gender and LGBTQ discrimination, going all the way back to the civil rights movement. This is part of a troubling right-wing, anti-worker trend developing within tech companies that AWU (Alphabet Workers Union) is committed to fighting against," said Parul Koul, a software engineer and the union's president, in a statement.Federal Contractor  Google, which sells cloud computing and other services to the US government, also said it was reviewing policy changes by President Donald Trump aimed at curbing DEI in the government and among federal contractors. "Because we are a federal contractor, our teams are also evaluating changes to our programs required to comply with recent court decisions and US Executive Orders on this topic," Cicconi said in the email. The company will maintain internal employee groups such as "Trans at Google," "Black Googler Network" and the "Disability Alliance," which the company has said inform decisions around products and policies. The Wall Street Journal first reported on Wednesday about the memo. Facebook parent Meta Platforms said in January in an internal memo it was ending its DEI programs, including those for hiring, training and picking suppliers. Amazon also said it was "winding down outdated programs and materials" related to representation and inclusion, in a memo to its employees, seen by Reuters. Conservative groups, fortified by a 2023 US Supreme Court ruling that invalidated affirmative action in university admissions, have condemned DEI programs and have threatened litigation against companies implementing them.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also read |  Google rolls out new flagship AI model with thinking capabilitiesAlso read |  Meta is reportedly merging Facebook and Messenger teams ahead of layoffs next weekAlso read |  After calling India's AI efforts hopeless, Sam Altman now says India should be a leader in AITrending Reel

Headline: A new crypto-stealing malware is targeting iPhones and Android smartphonesA new cybersecurity threat is targeting users of both Android and iOS devices. This SDK, dubbed SparkCat, is designed to steal cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases using OCR technology.
Content: A new cybersecurity threat is targeting users of both Android and iOS devices. According to a Kaspersky report, a malicious software development kit (SDK) has been spotted embedded in several apps available on Google Play and the Apple App Store. This SDK, dubbed SparkCat, is designed to steal cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases using optical character recognition (OCR) technology. The campaign has already affected hundreds of thousands of users, with over 242,000 downloads recorded on the Google Play Store alone. The malicious SDK operates differently on Android and iOS devices. On Android, it uses a Java component called Spark, which serves as an analytics module. This component retrieves encrypted configuration files from GitLab, which contain commands and updates for the malware. On iOS, the framework goes by various names, such as Gzip, googleappsdk, or stat, and uses a Rust-based networking module called im_net_sys to communicate with C2 servers. The primary function of this malware is to scan images on a user’s device for cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases. These phrases, often stored as screenshots or photos, are used to restore access to cryptocurrency wallets. The malware uses Google ML Kit OCR to extract text from images, targeting specific keywords in multiple languages, including Latin, Korean, Chinese, and Japanese. Once it identifies a recovery phrase, the stolen data is sent to the attackers’ servers, allowing them to access the victim’s cryptocurrency funds without needing a password. Kaspersky’s investigation revealed that the malware is region-specific, with different keywords and targeting strategies for areas like Europe and Asia. However, the researchers caution that the apps could still function outside their intended regions, posing a risk to a broader audience. So far, 18 Android apps and 10 iOS apps have been identified as infected. You can find the list of affected apps in Kaspersky's report here. One notable example is the Android app — ChatAi — which had been downloaded more than 50,000 times before being removed from the Google Play Store. However, many of the other infected apps remain available on both platforms, which is still a matter of concern. If you suspect you’ve installed any of the malware-infected apps, you must uninstall them immediately. According to experts, it is also recommended to install a reputable mobile antivirus tool to scan your device for any lingering traces of the malware. In severe cases, a factory reset may be necessary to ensure complete removal. Headline: New import tariffs could make Apple products more expensive in USApple faces a new 10 per cent tariff on Chinese imports, which could raise device prices. Meanwhile, China has responded to this by launching an antitrust probe into Apple's App Store policies.
Content: Apple fans in the US might soon have to dig deeper into their pockets as the company faces a new 10 per cent tariff on products imported from China. The tariff, imposed by the Donald Trump-led US government, applies to all goods arriving from China and could lead to price hikes for iPhones, iPads, Macs, and other Apple devices. While Apple has been working to diversify its supply chain, a large portion of its products are still assembled in China, leaving the company vulnerable to these new trade policies. As per the tariff, which came into effect earlier this week, Apple now has to pay an additional 10 per cent on the cost of bringing its products into the US. This extra expense could either be absorbed by the company, cutting into its profit margins, or passed on to consumers through higher prices. Historically, Apple has taken a mixed approach, sometimes absorbing costs and other times raising prices. However, with the current uncertainty surrounding trade policies, the company may hold off on making any immediate decisions. Apple has been making efforts to reduce its reliance on China by expanding production in countries like India. Recently, the company began manufacturing iPhone Pro models in India, a shift from its earlier strategy of only producing non-Pro models there. Additionally, Apple is preparing to manufacture the iPhone 17 series in India, taking advantage of the country’s decision to remove import fees on key smartphone components. Despite these moves, only about 25 per cent of Apple’s production is expected to shift to India by the end of this year, meaning the majority of its devices will still be subject to the new tariffs. The timing of the tariff implementation could work in Apple’s favour, at least temporarily. The first quarter of the year is typically a slower period for Apple, following the holiday rush when new iPhones drive sales. This lull might give the company some breathing room to assess the situation before making any pricing changes. However, if the tariffs remain in place, Apple will eventually have to decide whether to raise prices or take a hit on its profits. Meanwhile, China has responded to the US tariffs by announcing potential antitrust investigations into Apple and Google. The investigation into Apple will mainly focus on its App Store’s 30 per cent commission on in-app purchases. Led by the State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR), the probe will also examine Apple’s restrictions on third-party payment systems and alternative app stores. Chinese tech companies like Tencent and ByteDance argue that these policies hurt local competition and limit consumer choices.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Headline: Xiaomi 15 Ultra may launch by the end of February: Price, specs and all you need to knowXiaomi is expected to launch its upcoming flagship phone, the Xiaomi 15 Ultra, alongside its SU7 Ultra car, later this month.
Content:
Xiaomi is expected to launch its upcoming flagship smartphone, the Xiaomi 15 Ultra, alongside its new SU7 Ultra car, later this month. The announcement comes as Xiaomi resumes operations following the Chinese New Year holidays, with CEO Lei Jun kicking off the new year by handing out red envelopes to employees. These envelopes featured the word Ultra, hinting at the upcoming releases. Another leaked poster suggests that Xiaomi will hold a launch event on February 26 at 7 pm in China (4:30 PM IST), where both the Xiaomi 15 Ultra and SU7 Ultra are expected to be officially revealed. The company is likely to confirm the official event details in the coming days. Additionally, both products are expected to make an appearance at MWC 2025 in Barcelona, Spain, which kicks off in early March.

 



Source: Gizmochina
 According to leaks and rumours, the Xiaomi 15 Ultra will be powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8 Elite processor and will feature a Leica-branded quad-rear camera system. The setup may include a 50-megapixel one-inch main sensor, a 50-megapixel ultra-wide lens, a 50-megapixel 3x periscope telephoto lens, and a massive 200-megapixel periscope telephoto lens. The device is also expected to feature a 6.8-inch AMOLED LTPO display with a 2K resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate.  A 91Mobiles report also hinted at the possibility of at least a 16GB RAM + 512GB storage option for the phone in the international market. The phone is expected to be available in black, white, and silver colours. In comparison, the Xiaomi 14 Ultra only came in black and white colour options. In terms of performance, the Xiaomi 15 Ultra will come with up to 16GB of LPDDR5x RAM and up to 1TB of UFS 4.0 storage in China, while global markets might see a single variant with 16GB of RAM and 512GB of storage. The phone will run on Xiaomi’s HyperOS 2.0, based on Android 15, and will include features like an ultrasonic in-screen fingerprint sensor, eSIM support, and satellite communication capabilities. A massive 6,000mAh battery with 90W wired and 50W wireless charging support will ensure the device stays powered throughout the day. The Xiaomi 15 Ultra is expected to be priced starting at around CNY 6,499, which is roughly Rs 78,000 or $892. The phone will be positioned as a direct competitor to other flagship devices like the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra and the iPhone 16 Pro Max. However, it remains to be seen if the device comes to the Indian market and how Xiaomi plans to price it. Headline: Google aims to launch quantum computing applications in the next five yearsGoogle's head of quantum says that the company plans to release commercial quantum applications within five years.
Content:
Google aims to release commercial quantum computing applications within five years, Google's head of quantum told Reuters on Wednesday, in a challenge to Nvidia's predictions of a 20-year wait. "We’re optimistic that within five years we’ll see real-world applications that are possible only on quantum computers," founder and lead of Google Quantum AI Hartmut Neven said in a statement. Real-world applications Google has discussed are related to materials science - applications such as building superior batteries for electric cars - creating new drugs and potentially new energy alternatives. Google's prediction arrives amid wider uncertainty about when such a breakthrough will occur. Predictions from investors and experts range from several years to at least two decades. For decades, scientists have been discussing quantum computing, which promises to deliver machines that are thousands of times more powerful than traditional computers. Traditional computers process information one number at a time, whereas quantum computers use "qubits" that can represent several numbers at once. Governments and businesses have kept a close eye on quantum computing's potential to disrupt modern cybersecurity and other fields such as finance and healthcare. Quantum computing resembles artificial intelligence in some ways. AI before ChatGPT's launch in 2022 was understood mostly by scientists. Scientists had been quietly producing breakthroughs to accelerate the field but there was no firm understanding of when AI would be commercially useful.Two decades out Nvidia's Jensen Huang has said that quantum computing is much farther away than five years. At an analyst event at the CES trade show in Las Vegas in January, Huang predicted practical uses for quantum computers are about 20 years away. "If you kind of said 15 years... that'd probably be on the early side," Huang said, "If you said 30, it's probably on the late side. But if you picked 20, I think a whole bunch of us would believe it." Huang's comments ripped about $8 billion in market value from a handful of quantum computing stocks. The sector was given a boost in December when Google announced it had cracked a key challenge in the field with its new chips. Google has been working on its quantum computing program since 2012 and has designed and built several quantum chips. By using quantum processors, Google said it had managed to solve a computing problem in minutes that would take a classical computer more time than the history of the universe.
Google's quantum computing scientists announced another step on the path to real world applications within five years on Wednesday. In a paper published in the scientific journal Nature, the scientists said they had discovered a new approach to quantum simulation, which is a step on the path to achieving Google's objective.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Apple may turn iPhone into a super remote control that can manage all electronic devicesApple has patented a new technology --- a wireless controller-- possibly to turn an iPhone or iPad into a universal remote, allowing users to control devices with simple gestures.
Content: Apple keeps its employees busy churning new ideas and possible innovations across its ecosystem. In fact, the Cupertino giant not only brainstorms ideas but also rushes to get the patent as soon as something comes to the table. That’s the reason that, as of December 2024, Apple has reportedly filed 95,500 patents globally, including 78,104 active patents. Following Apple’s continued work on innovation, the company is now seemingly planning to make a new device that could be an all-in-one remote control. This control could manage a variety of electronic devices—or possibly give the iPhone all these superpowers. One of Apple’s newly granted patents, titled "Controlling Electronic Devices Based On Wireless Ranging," first reported by Apple Insider, suggests that Apple is working on a new technology that could allow users to control everything from TVs and smart home appliances to vehicles and gaming consoles—all with a simple wave of their device. And this device could be the iPhone or the iPad. Controlling devices with an iPhone is not new. Right now, Apple has integrated remote-control functionality into its ecosystem, from Apple TV’s remote app to the ability to unlock and start cars with Apple Car Key. However, in these controls, users need to manually select on the iPhone what they want to control and how. Apple argues that this can lead to "frustrating user interactions, which can degrade the user experience." However, the proposed system in the patent suggests that the tech would possibly allow an iPhone or iPad—referred to in the patent as a "wireless communication device"—to automatically detect the user's intent and control the correct device. The new patent suggests a more seamless connection, allowing users to simply point their device in the direction of an electronic appliance, and the wireless controller would recognize what the user intends to control.How will the wireless controlling work? In its patent, Apple explains that in this wireless controlling system, the device—let’s say an iPhone—will detect when a user wants to control a device and determine which one is being targeted. This could involve factors such as proximity, orientation, and possibly even gesture-based commands. “For example,” the patent explains, “a user may no longer need to open or unlock the wireless communication device (e.g., by providing a passcode or a biometric identifier, such as a fingerprint) in order to control the object... By facilitating control of the object from a distance, this user-interface technique may eliminate the need for a user to be in physical contact with a user interface on or associated with the object,” Apple explains. Now, let’s not forget that this is still just a patent, and a lot of times, Apple files patents and never actually uses them. However, if this technology comes to life, it could significantly enhance how users interact with their devices. In the smart home space, an iPhone could serve as a universal remote, adjusting lighting, thermostats, or even kitchen appliances with a simple wave. Headline: ChatGPT faced global outage for the second time this year This is the second time that OpenAI's ChatGPT has faced a global outage in 2025. While the majority of users reported issues with the app, a few suffered trouble logging-in.
Content:
OpenAI's ChatGPT has recently faced a global outage across the world, according to the Downdetector website. The company has also acknowledged and stated that its products, including ChatGPT, Sora and API were facing increased errors. The surge in errors has been reported since 9.19 AM on Wednesday morning. OpenAI has recently updated on its Status page that the issue has been resolved as well. 
 


advertisementChatGPT global outageOver 26,000 users worldwide have reported issues with ChatGPT, according to Downdetector. Complaints began surging around 9:19 AM and continued to rise as more users encountered problems.  Approximately 92 per cent of the reports were related to ChatGPT app itself, while 7 per cent experienced website errors, and 1 per cent faced API issues. 
 


 Over 26,000 users worldwide have reported issues with ChatGPT, according to Downdetector. Complaints began surging around 9:19 AM and continued to rise as more users encountered problems.   Approximately 92 per cent of the reports were related to ChatGPT app itself, while 7 per cent experienced website errors, and 1 per cent faced API issues. 
 


 The cause of the outage remains unknown, and the company is actively investigating the issue. A fix has already been implemented, leading to partial recovery, but efforts are still underway to fully resolve the problem. This isn't the first time ChatGPT has suffered issues. OpenAI previously acknowledged a similar outage. Last time, in January, both the ChatGPT app and the website version faced issues. During the outage, users were facing "Bad Gateway Error", while trying to work with ChatGPT. According to the reports, this error occurred as the company was trying to launch its first AI agent Operator. 

And just like always, as soon as the issues arrived, users took to X (formerly Twitter), sharing memes and reactions. OpenAI AI agents One of the reasons why outages are rising is that OpenAI is working for its AI agents more rigorously now, especially after the DeepSeek launch. The company has recently launched two of its AI agents: the Operator and the Deep Research. While the Operator can be tasked with a wide range of repetitive browser activities, such as completing forms, ordering groceries, or even creating memes, it cannot perform in-depth research like the new AI agent. On the other hand, Deep Research builds on the reasoning capabilities to bridge the gap, allowing it to take on the types of problems people face in work and everyday life. Both the agents are a significant step toward the broader goal of developing AGI, which OpenAI has been pointing out for a long period.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also read |  New import tariffs could make Apple products more expensive in USAlso read |  Google aims to launch quantum computing applications in the next five yearsAlso read |  After Meta, Google scraps diversity-based hiring programme

Headline: Boult BassBox X625 review: All about the bass, no treble If you are looking for a home theater system with good bass, you should definitely check out Boult's BassBox X625. Priced at Rs 39,999, it offers clear and loud sound with thumping bass. But if you want more than just good bass, this may not be an ideal option for you.
Content:
Bass Weight  Design Build quality  Remote Boult has lately been launching one audio device after the other in the market –– and we are not complaining. India Today Tech we reviewed the BassBox 180 soundbar, and the Retro Amp X60 speaker, and we loved both the products. Not just because we are vocal for local, but also because of the quality and pricing Boult’s products offer. And that’s true for the latest Boult device I have tested as well –– the Boult BassBox X625. It is a home theatre system. It offers a powerful bass that makes you feel like you are sitting in a movie theatre.  I have been testing the Boult BassBox X625 for a month. I connected it with my TV, a tablet, and my phone, and tried out different genres of movies and music, and my experience with it has largely been positive –– though not perfect. While I absolutely loved the bass it offers, the overall sound profile seems a bit lacking. There are also a few other flaws in the device, which I believe keep it from being an ideal home theater device.Boult BassBox X625: A quick look at its specs The Boult BassBox X625 is a 5.1-channel home theater system that delivers an audio output of 625 watts. It features a dedicated Digital Signal Processor (DSP) for better sound quality and comes with a wired subwoofer to produce deep, thumping bass. The system also offers multiple EQ modes, including Movie, Music, and News, allowing you to customise the audio experience based on your preferences. It is compatible with all Bluetooth devices and supports various connectivity options such as Bluetooth v5.3, AUX, USB, Optical, and HDMI (ARC). Additionally, it comes with a remote for better control and supports both wall mounting and tabletop placement.Boult BassBox X625: Design  The Boult BassBox X625 is a multi-device speaker system. Surprisingly, despite its size, it is lightweight and easy to set up. It took me just about 10 minutes to unbox and connect it to my TV. The design is simple yet elegant. It features a classic black finish that leans towards minimal aesthetics. The soundbar has controls on the top. The speakers are small and sport a clean look with a speaker grill and the Boult logo. The subwoofer box is also neatly designed. It can easily blend into a modern decor.  However, while the product looks nice, I found the build quality lacking. The woofers and the sound bar have a glossy surface on one end, which is visually appealing, but it feels somewhat cheap. I found that it is also quite prone to scratches and smudges. 
 


Boult BassBox X625: Performance Right at the start of this review, I mentioned that the Boult BassBox X625 delivers impressive bass. If you're searching for a home theater system that lets you feel the intensity of action scenes — like the rumble of trains, the gallop of horses, the crash of thunder, or the bang of gunfire — this one is a great choice in the sub-Rs 40,000 budget.I placed the subwoofer on the floor, and while watching an action movie, the vibrations were palpable. In fact, when I cranked up the bass, it even caused the windows to rattle.That said, I wish the overall sound quality were better. While the audio is clear, it lacks depth, and the treble isn’t sharp enough. When listening to melodies with high pitch, the speakers muffle the vocals, even with the bass turned down. The sound could have been clearer and more balanced.Another issue I faced was with the home theatre’s remote. It’s not very responsive, and it’s worse if you're sitting slightly far from the unit –– even at a distance of just 3 to 4 feet. It was honestly quite irksome that I had to move really close to the unit every time I needed to change any controls. 
 


advertisementHowever, if I look at the overall experience, I really liked the connectivity options, especially the Bluetooth connectivity, which is quick, easy, and allows you to connect multiple devices, not just the TV.Boult BassBox X625: Should you buy it? I have been using the BassBox X625 for weeks, and during my testing, I found the device to be more or less good. Its design is sleek, lightweight, and the bass is undoubtedly its standout feature. However, the overall sound quality is just decent. Priced around Rs 40,000, the BassBox X625 isn't exactly affordable. Whether it's a good buy depends on your priorities. If you're after a relatively budget-friendly speaker system that fits well with your decor, is easy to set up, and delivers excellent bass, BassBox X625 could be a good choice. However, if balanced sound quality is a priority, you may want to explore other alternatives.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also Read |  Apple may turn iPhone into a super remote control that can manage all electronic devicesAlso Read |  Indian Railways launches SwaRail app: What it is, how to use and everything you need to knowAlso Read |  iPhone 17 Air vs iPhone 16 Plus: Here is how Apple may replace the Plus variant for slimmer iPhone

Headline: Realme P3 Pro to feature Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chip, to launch on February 18Realme P3 Pro smartphone: Realme has recently confirmed the launch date and a few more details around its upcoming launch, the Realme P3 Pro.
Content: Realme is ready to launch its next-gen P-series on February 18. The company has confirmed that the P3 series, which may include P3 and P3 Pro, are to launch next month. Recently it has also been revealed that the Pro variant will pack a Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chipset. The company claims that it is the first phone in this segment to feature this chipset. The Flipkart microsite also confirmed that the phone will be powered by 6,000mAh battery with large vapour cooling chambers.  The Realme P3 Pro is set to be the first in its segment to feature the Qualcomm Snapdragon 7s Gen 3 chipset, built on TSMC’s advanced 4nm process. Designed for an optimised gaming experience, the handset will incorporate GT Boost technology, developed in collaboration with Krafton, offering AI-powered ultra-steady frames, Hyper Response Engine, AI ultra-touch control, and AI motion control.  One of its standout features is the segment-first quad-curved EdgeFlow display, ensuring an immersive and visually striking experience. Powering the device is a massive 6,000mAh Titan battery with 80W fast charging support, a notable upgrade over the 5,200mAh battery found in the Realme P2 Pro. To prevent overheating during intense usage, the phone is equipped with an advanced Aerospace VC Cooling System, company claims that it is the largest vapour chamber for efficient heat dissipation. Realme P3 series launch  Realme is set to launch the P3 and P3 Pro in India on February 18, 2025. The event will commence at 12 PM and will be live-streamed on the company’s official YouTube channel. Fans can also stay updated with real-time announcements and highlights from the launch by following Realme’s social media platforms, including X and Facebook.Realme P3 Pro price expectations  The Realme P3 Pro is expected to launch at a starting price of approximately Rs 25,000. Headline: Elon Musk's Tesla is hiring engineers to work on its Optimus humanoid robotIf you are an engineer, Elon Musk's Tesla has a great job opportunity for you.
Content:
Elon Musk’s Tesla is ramping up hiring for the mass production of its Optimus humanoid robot, also known as the Tesla Bot. The company has listed a hiring alert for several manufacturing roles, and most of these are based out of the company’s California facility. The job listing was brought to everyone’s attention by @SawyerMerritt on X, which was then also retweeted by Elon Musk. The same is also listed on Tesla’s career page on the website.  The job listing makes one thing clear and that is that Tesla is actively looking to hire. The listings include openings for positions such as Manufacturing Engineering Technician, Production Supervisor, and Process Engineer, all of which are focused on Optimus. 
 


 Another LinkedIn post from a senior sourcer at Tesla, Karissa Thein, also hints at the mass hiring at the company. She wrote in the post: “My team is turning Tesla Bot into a reality! We're building Tesla Bot in our Fremont Factory in California, and we're looking for engineers up for the challenge of getting this product ramped up for high volume production.”
 advertisement


 The huge number of hirings possibly means that Tesla is working towards boosting production of the Optimus, especially considering the job postings focus on manufacturing roles.   The Optimus or the Tesla bot was first unveiled in 2021 at Tesla’s AI Day event. Since the launch, Musk has been positioning it as one of the key products in the company’s future. “I believe this will be the most significant product ever created,” Musk said at the Tesla AI event 2024.  Tesla, since the humanoid’s launch, has been demonstrating various iterations of the Teslabot, showcasing its ability to walk, carry objects, and hold conversations with humans around it. Tesla has been taking advantage of its expertise in self-driving technology to improve Optimus. Last time when Musk showcased the humanoid robots, which was in October 2024, he said that the Tesla bot can now do anything you can think of. In fact, Musk also described the capabilities of the humanoid robots as virtually limitless. The Optimus can now walk your dog, babysit, mow the lawn, and even serve drinks. Musk has said that we can expect the robot to be available commercially very soon, and the mass production seems to be a step in that direction. He had also estimated the price of the bot to range between $20,000 and $30,000.  Last month, Elon Musk put out another call for hiring software engineers for his Everything app. He made a call for hardcore software engineers to join his ambitious project, and said he doesn’t care about the degree or the absence of one, all he cares about is a solid code. Musk posted on X: “We don’t care where you went to school or even whether you went to school or what 'big name' company you worked at. Just show us your code", he says.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also read |  Elon Musk is hiring for software engineer role, says there is no need for a degreeAlso read |  Elon Musk says Tesla humanoid Optimus can now do anything that you can think ofAlso read |  Elon Musk unveils Tesla's Optimus Gen 2 Robot, it can boil eggs, dance, and moreMust Watch

Headline: ChatGPT Search now available to all, no longer requires sign upsOpenAI has announced that ChatGPT's search feature is now available to everyone on chatgpt.com. Users will no longer be required to sign up to use the feature.
Content:
OpenAI has announced that the ChatGPT search feature is now available for all on chatgpt.com. To use the feature, users no longer need to sign in. Until now, to access the feature, when users opened chatgpt.com, they needed to sign up via either a Google, Apple or a Microsoft account. However, the company has now eliminated that step in the process of using the feature. Responding to the announcement posted by OpenAI on X, the company’s CEO Sam Altman jokingly wrote: “make search great again”.  OpenAI launched the ChatGPT search feature in November last year. However, it was then limited to only paid users. But at the time of writing the story, the feature was available to everyone, including the ones using the unpaid version. We checked both the web and the mobile app, and the search feature was available in the standard ChatGPT version. 
 


 The ChatGPT search feature was first tested as SearchGPT. However, in November 2024, OpenAI launched it as a feature called Search. OpenAI describes it as a tool to get fast, timely answers to queries shared on ChatGPT, which are supported with links to relevant web sources. Until now, for some queries that needed a web search, users still needed to switch to Google or some other browser for information. ChatGPT on its own has limitations to the dataset it has, and may not always be accurate –– the app also warns about it.  But with the search feature, based on the query you ask, ChatGPT will search the web for you, or you can choose to use the search feature by clicking the web icon that shows just below the text box. "This [ChatGPT search] blends the benefits of a natural language interface with the value of up-to-date sports scores, news, stock quotes, and more," said OpenAI about the feature at the time of launch. With this the probability of accuracy of information increased. You should still always verify it on your end though. This is also why the ChatGPT search feature was seen as a direct competitor to Google at the time of launch –– especially with the news of Google working on its own AI search tool.  ChatGPT Search is powered by an enhanced version of OpenAI's GPT-4 model. Besides searching the web for you, the feature also allows users to ask follow-up questions in the search mode in order to refine their searches. Headline: Tech Layoffs 2025: Meta, Microsoft, Salesforce continue job cuts amid restructuring effortsTech giants like Microsoft, Meta, Amazon, Google, and Salesforce continue their streak of job cuts in 2025, citing restructuring and performance optimisation. According to reports, till date, over 10,800 employees have already been affected, with more job cuts expected throughout the year.
Content:
The year 2022 ended with the quakes of mass layoffs, which continued their tremors in 2023 and even 2024. However, uncertainties and job cuts are showing no signs of slowing down, even in the new year, 2025. Though not as big as the mass layoffs, these short-phase layoffs continue to bring uncertainties this year as well. As the year started, major companies including Meta, Microsoft, Amazon, Salesforce, and Google announced more downsizing, citing restructuring efforts and performance optimisation—all while expanding roles in artificial intelligence.  According to layoffs.fyi, 42 tech companies have laid off around 10,833 employees so far, with more job cuts expected throughout the year.Microsoft announced performance-based layoffs Microsoft became one of the first major companies to announce layoffs this year. The company confirmed job cuts across multiple divisions, with the security division reportedly being among those affected. Microsoft stated that these layoffs primarily targeted employees who did not meet performance expectations.  However, despite the global restructuring, Puneet Chandok, Microsoft’s India and South Asia head, reassured that the company’s India operations would remain unaffected by these job cuts.Meta aims to cut 3,600 jobs  Meta, the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, also announced plans to lay off approximately 3,600 employees. This count represents about 5 percent of its workforce adding to the earlier 5 per cent job cuts the company announced in December 2024.  According to Bloomberg, CEO Mark Zuckerberg, in an internal memo explained these job cuts as a part of “raising the bar on performance management” and expediting the removal of low-performing employees. He stated that the layoffs come as Meta navigates what he described as an “intense year” of restructuring and operational shifts.Amazon also announces job cuts Amazon is also among the tech giants continuing its streak of layoffs, which began in 2022. The company recently announced job cuts within its communications and sustainability divisions. Although the exact number of affected employees is still not revealed.   According to an internal memo obtained by CNBC, Amazon’s leadership justified these recent layoffs as an effort to eliminate narrowly defined roles and unnecessary organisational layers. Notably, over the past three years, Amazon has cut around 27,000 jobs, with restructuring efforts still underway.Salesforce to cut over 1,000 jobs Most recently, Salesforce has also joined the list of tech companies downsizing their workforce in 2025. According to Bloomberg, the company plans to eliminate over 1,000 positions as part of an ongoing restructuring initiative. However, these layoffs come amid Salesforce’s plans to hire more employees to support its expansion into AI-driven products. The report also suggests that laid-off employees will likely be given the opportunity to apply for other internal roles.Google also pushing voluntary exits for employees While Google has not announced direct job cuts, it has introduced a voluntary exit program for employees in its Platforms & Devices division. This division is responsible for key products such as Android, Pixel, Chrome, Nest, and Fitbit.  Senior Vice President Rick Osterloh announced the program via an internal memo, offering U.S.-based employees severance packages if they choose to leave.

Headline: Infosys is said to release annual salary hike offers at the end of MarchInfosys is said to release annual salary hike letters to its employees by the end of March. The company is reportedly working on finalising the compensation revisions based on performance reviews and recommendations from its delivery units.
Content: Infosys, one of India's leading IT services companies, is said to release annual salary hike letters to its employees by the end of March. People familiar with the matter told Economic Times, the company is currently working on finalising the compensation revisions based on performance reviews and recommendations from its delivery units. Shaji Mathew, Chief Human Resources Officer at Infosys, recently addressed employees during a town hall meeting at the Bengaluru campus. He shared that employees at Job Level 5 (JL5) and below will receive their salary hikes effective from January 1. Those at Job Level 6 (JL6) and higher will have their revised salaries kick in from April 1. Mathew also indicated that performance ratings have already been communicated to employees, and these evaluations will play a crucial role in determining the percentage of individual salary hikes. However, he did not specify details regarding the overall appraisal cycle period. Last year, Infosys did not issue compensation letters in June for hikes starting in April, a practice followed in previous years. The company’s last salary revision occurred in November 2023 after a salary freeze during FY22 to conserve cash. The appraisal cycle restarted in October 2023, with salary revision letters issued in December for that cycle. This new announcement aligns with previous comments made by Infosys CFO Jayesh Sanghrajka during the company’s earnings call last month. Sanghrajka had mentioned that employees in India could expect a salary increase of 6-8 percent, while those overseas would see more modest hikes in line with earlier trends. He added that higher performers could expect more significant increments. The company is likely to implement the salary hikes in two phases — one from January 1 and another from April 1. Senior-level employees in the JL6 category and above will see their salary increases linked to Infosys' revenue performance.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: OnePlus 13 Mini camera details leaked ahead of rumoured March launchThe OnePlus 13 Mini's camera details have surfaced, hinting at a dual-camera setup with 50-megapixel sensors. Expected to launch in March, it could rival Apple's iPhone 17 design with its horizontal bar-shaped camera module.
Content:
OnePlus industrial designer, Lao Haoran, recently announced on Weibo that the company is planning a major overhaul for its phones in 2025. Following this, rumours have started hinting that OnePlus is working on compact high-end phones powered by MediaTek and Qualcomm chips. The Qualcomm chip in question is said to be the Snapdragon 8 Elite, and the phone it will power could be called the OnePlus 13 Mini. This phone is reportedly launching soon, and fresh leaks about its camera and other hardware specs have started appearing online.

Source: Digital Chat Station
 According to Digital Chat Station, the OnePlus 13 Mini will feature a dual-camera setup, contradicting earlier rumours of a triple-camera system. The rear camera module — expected to come in a horizontal bar-shaped island — is said to include a 50-megapixel primary sensor and a 50-megapixel telephoto lens with 2x optical zoom. The OnePlus 13 Mini is expected to be powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset. This puts it in direct competition with other compact flagships, such as the Galaxy S25 and even the Vivo X200 Pro, which is powered by the MediaTek Dimensity 9400 processor. As for the display, the phone is rumoured to sport a 6.31-inch LTPO OLED panel with a 1.5K resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate. The flat screen is expected to feature ultraslim bezels, offering an immersive viewing experience. Additionally, the device is expected to feature an optical in-display fingerprint sensor. As mentioned earlier, design-wise, the OnePlus 13 Mini is going to be a big departure from its predecessors. Lao Haoran has confirmed that the company is working on a major design overhaul for its 2025 lineup. The 13 Mini is likely to showcase this new direction, with a focus on being a compact flagship phone, rather than the usual large phones the company is typically known for. Now, it’s not like OnePlus hasn’t attempted a compact phone before — case in point, the OnePlus X — but it’s been a while since that phone launched, and it will be interesting to see what the 13 Mini brings to the table in 2025. Reports suggest it will feature a metal frame and a glass back. Apart from this, battery details remain under wraps, but the phone is expected to support wireless charging, a feature that has become a staple of flagship devices. The OnePlus 13 Mini is rumoured to launch as early as March. However, it’s still unclear whether the device will be available globally or limited to specific markets.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 6, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Here is how to get them back

Headline: Sonos fires 200 employees, says company wants to focus on smaller teamsSonos, a well-known audio technology company, has reportedly fired 200 employees as part of a company-wide restructuring effort. Here are the details.
Content: Sonos, a well-known audio technology company, has reportedly laid off 200 employees as part of a company-wide restructuring effort, The Verge reports. This move comes as Sonos wants to reduce layers of management and focus on smaller, more efficient teams to improve decision-making and streamline collaboration. The announcement was made by interim CEO Tom Conrad in a communication with employees, highlighting the need for the company to become more agile in the face of ongoing challenges. Conrad reportedly asserted that Sonos had become entangled in complex organisational structures, making collaboration more difficult than necessary. "One thing I’ve observed first-hand is that we’ve become mired in too many layers that have made collaboration and decision-making harder than it needs to be," he stated in his message to the employees.  The layoffs are part of Sonos' plan to reorganise its workforce into more compact, focused teams, ensuring that the company is better equipped to prioritise essential projects moving forward. This round of layoffs is bigger than the earlier reduction in August, when the company eliminated around 100 jobs. Sonos has faced various challenges, including declining demand for its products and setbacks from last year's controversial mobile app update. The app rollout was poorly received due to technical issues, leading to dissatisfaction among users. The impact of this event was big enough that it contributed to the departure of former CEO Patrick Spence last month. As Sonos prepares to release its upcoming quarterly earnings report, this wave of job cuts has raised concerns about the company’s immediate outlook. However, Conrad has committed to addressing past missteps, particularly focusing on improving the mobile app experience. In addition to the layoffs, Sonos plans to restructure its product teams, dividing them into dedicated groups for hardware, software, design, and operations, rather than organising around individual product categories. While the company faces difficult times, its recent successes, such as the Arc Ultra soundbar, provide some optimism. Sonos is also preparing to launch a new high-end streaming device, expected to include advanced features like an HDMI switch. Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 6, 2025

Headline: iPhone SE 4 launch timeline tipped, likely to debut next weekApple is on its last leg to announce its next-gen iPhone SE4. According to Bloomberg's Mark Gurman, the iPhone's toned-down version is coming as soon as next week.
Content:
The iPhone SE 4 has been making the headlines for a few months now. While Apple is yet to announce the launch date, there have been several leaks and rumours around the phone. For example, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to be the most affordable iPhone to offer Apple Intelligence. Not just that, it is also rumoured to bring several updates over its predecessor. That said, the latest tip indicates that all the rumours will come to rest soon. According to Bloomberg's Mark Gurman, Apple is planning to release the iPhone SE 4 as soon as next week. 
 


 Gurman highlights that the company is not interested in hosting a dedicated event. Apple might just launch the iPhone SE 4 via press release. He further adds, the sale is to go live later this month. iPhone SE 4 to debut in just a few days: What to expect  Design: The iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to adopt a design similar to the iPhone 14, replacing the thick bezels and Touch ID Home button seen in the current iPhone SE. With its launch, Apple is expected to phase out Touch ID entirely from the iPhone lineup. 

 



Credit: X/@MajinBu
 According to the leaked images, the iPhone SE 4’s rear panel will feature a single- camera lens (a traditional design language). 

 



Credit: X/@MajinBu
advertisementHere, the iPhone SE 4 appears to have a boxy frame with rounded edges, similar to the iPhone 14 and retains the power button on the right side. Display: The display is likely to be a 6.1-inch OLED panel with a 60Hz refresh rate, offering a big upgrade over the LCD screens used in previous SE models. Rumours have been divided over whether the iPhone SE 4 will sport a notch or a dynamic island. It looks like the confusion will soon be over. 

 



Credit: X/@MajinBu
Processor: Under the hood, the iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to be powered by the A18 chip, the same processor that’s also in the latest iPhone 16, along with 8GB RAM. 
 


Camera: The camera setup is expected to include a 48-megapixel primary rear camera and a 24-megapixel front-facing camera.iPhone SE 4: Price expectations The iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to start at $499 (approximately Rs 43,200), a significant increase from the iPhone SE 3’s launch price of $429. In India, the SE 3 debuted at Rs 43,900 but saw a price hike to Rs 49,900 within a few months. With the SE 4's upgraded features, the key question remains: will it stay under the Rs 50,000 mark in India? Only time will tell.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 7, 2025Must Watch

Headline: US now wants to ban DeepSeek, will punish and fine those who use itUS lawmakers are pushing a bill to ban the Chinese AI chatbot, DeepSeek, from government devices.
Content:
Lawmakers in the US are now planning to ban DeepSeek. And anyone who uses it will be fined and imprisoned for it. This was first reported by the Wall Street Journal. According to the report, some US senators are pushing a bill to ban the Chinese AI chatbot from government devices. The bill reportedly reads that it will “prohibit United States persons from advancing artificial intelligence capabilities within the People’s Republic of China, and for other persons”. Another report by The Independent reveals that according to the bill, when it comes to effect, if anyone (who this law applies to) is found using DeepSeek, they may face a fine of up to $1 million, which is around Rs 6.5 crores. Violators may also have to face prison for up to 20 years. The Independent report also suggests that the bill proposes the ban extending beyond just government devices. Because the report mentions that, as per the bill, businesses found using DeepSeek AI may get fined up to $100 million, which is more than Rs 8 billion.  The bill was reportedly proposed by Republican senator Josh Hawley. The reason for the proposed ban is the same as the one behind TikTok’s ban in the US –– the app sending data of Americans to the Chinese government. Hawley has raised questions about the “security, privacy, and ethics” offered in the DeepSeek AI app.  Interestingly, this would not even make the US the first country to ban DeepSeek, if it does. Italy has already banned the Chinese AI chatbot stating privacy reasons. Even in the US, Texas has banned DeepSeek already. Additionally, Taiwan has also banned the AI chatbot, and Australia is also on its way to do so. Meanwhile, the union minister of information technology, Ashwini Vaishnaw said that DeepSeek will soon be hosted on Indian servers in order to address privacy concerns. Experts have raised serious concerns about DeepSeek, particularly regarding data security and potential information transfer to China.
Last week, DeepSeek got a lot of attention from around the world. Even though the AI chatbot was launched in 2023, it was only after the release of its R1 model, which took place in the last week of January 2025, that the Chinese AI chatbot really caught everyone’s attention. But why did it get so popular suddenly? Amid the US-China trade war, and the US blocking exports of AI chips to China, DeepSeek is an AI chatbot that does everything that ChatGPT does but it was built at a fraction of the cost. What is DeepSeek AI? DeepSeek AI was founded by Liang Wenfeng in May 2023. It has recently gained a lot of attention thanks to its latest large language models — DeepSeek-V3 and DeepSeek-R1, of which the V3 is a general-purpose model, whereas the R1 model specialises in reasoning tasks.  Both models are standout for delivering great results while using fewer resources than competitors. DeepSeek also follows the Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture, which is basically aimed at increasing efficiency by only activating the portion of parameters at one time. DeepSeek AI chatbot, as per the company, also gets better as it interacts more with a human. However, that is true for most AI models as well.

Headline: Foldable iPhone detailed in an extensive leak: What should you expectThanks to a detailed writeup shared on X (formerly Twitter), we might have a clearer picture of what Apple's first foldable device could look like, its features, and its potential release timeline.
Content: If the latest leaks are to be believed, Apple is reportedly working on a foldable iPhone. Thanks to a detailed writeup in Chinese, sourced from zwz, and its translation shared by Jukanlosreve on X (formerly Twitter), we might have a clearer picture of what Apple’s first foldable device could look like, its features, and its potential release timeline. While Apple has remained tight-lipped about its foldable plans, this leak provides an interesting glimpse into what could be one of the most — if not the most — innovative smartphone launches of the decade. The foldable iPhone is said to feature a large folding mechanism on the left rear side, with a folded thickness of 9.2 mm and a single-side thickness of 4.6 mm. The internal screen is expected to be massive, comparable to two 6.1-inch phones folded together, resulting in a total screen size of over 12 inches. This suggests that Apple is aiming for a tablet-like experience when the device is unfolded, which could make it a versatile tool for both productivity and entertainment.  One of the most critical components of any foldable device is the hinge, and Apple seems to be taking a unique approach. The hinge design is entirely Apple’s own, with an assembled cost of approximately $110. Key suppliers for the hinge components include Amphenol and Taiwan’s Xinyiheng, while Lingyi is involved in the internal components. The midframe, made of aluminium, is priced at $80 to $90 and is being developed exclusively by Foxconn’s Fulin division. During mass production, secondary suppliers like LanSi and BYD Electronics are expected to join the process. The display technology for the foldable iPhone is said to be exclusively developed by Samsung, which is no surprise given Samsung’s expertise in foldable screens. The device will reportedly use UTG (ultra-thin glass) Blue, which is currently priced at around $90 to $100. The screen support frame is still under consideration, with options like titanium alloy, stainless steel, or carbon fibre being explored. Lingyi, a key supplier, has already provided samples, but the final decision is yet to be made. The leak also sheds light on the camera and battery technology. The front camera will reportedly use Meta Lens ultra-thin technology, with lenses supplied by Largan, Sunwoo, and Lantega. The rear camera will feature a hybrid glass-plastic structure for both the primary and ultra-wide lenses. As for the battery, the foldable iPhone is expected to use two stainless steel-cased batteries with a combined capacity of around 5000mAh. These batteries will reportedly feature 3D-stacked cells, exclusively developed by ATL. According to the leak, Apple plans to launch the foldable iPhone in the fall of 2026, followed by a foldable iPad or MacBook in 2027. Foxconn, Apple’s long-time manufacturing partner, is reportedly handling the exclusive NPI (New Product Introduction) process, with mass production expected to begin by late 2025 or early 2026. This timeline indicates that Apple is in no hurry to jump the gun and the company will instead take its sweet time to perfect the design and functionality of its foldable devices. Initial sales estimates suggest that Apple could sell 8 to 10 million units in 2026, with that number doubling to 20 million units in 2027. Foxconn will reportedly be the sole manufacturer in 2026, but Luxshare is expected to join the production process in 2027.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 7, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Here is how to get them back

Headline: OpenAI updates o3-mini with transparent reasoning and chain of thought displayJust a few days after launching its new flagship model, o3-mini, OpenAI has updated the way it responds to queries. Now, the model will show you the insights of how it has deduced the answer.
Content:
OpenAI rolled out its flagship AI models, o3 and o3-mini, a week ago. For the first time, OpenAI grants free-tier users access to its reasoning models through o3-Mini, though with rate limits comparable to GPT-4o. This marks a significant shift in OpenAI’s strategy, making advanced AI tools more accessible to a broader audience. It also comes at a time when DeepSeek attracted several headlines for its advanced performance and low-price rates. In order to make it even better, OpenAI has recently updated the way o3-mini communicates and responds. In the new design, the model will showcase its chain of thought before concluding its answer. advertisementOpenAI o3-mini updated OpenAI has announced an update to the o3-mini model that enhances transparency for both free and paid users by displaying a refined "chain of thought," revealing more of the model’s reasoning process behind its answers. Premium subscribers using o3-Mini in the "high reasoning" mode will also benefit from this improved insight, according to the company.In the preview, posted by OpenAI, it was previewed that now the model not only answers, but also shares insights into its thought process. Here, to answer a simple question, "how is today not a Friday", o3-mini gave it thought before answering. Not just that, the displayed chain of thought shows that this AI model understands when the user is being humourous and just wants a fun answer. It also predicts the feelings of the user, based on the question they ask. For instance, it says, "seems like a humourous remark. May be they're feeling like the week is almost over, even though it's not!" 
 advertisement


The o3-mini's chain of thought and conclusion gives us an idea that it is an AI model which can be witty but also gives logic to the answer. Additionally, when OpenAI released the model, it highlighted that a major enhancement in o3-Mini is its capability to retrieve real-time data from the web, delivering answers with source links for greater reliability. The preview also showed that the model took only 6 seconds to to think about the question and then respond. Moreover, o3-Mini is also being integrated into Microsoft’s Azure OpenAI Service, GitHub Copilot, and GitHub models, expanding its presence in enterprise applications. Free-tier users can access O3-Mini within ChatGPT by selecting the ‘Reason’ feature in the chat bar, though with usage limits.OpenAI o3-mini VS DeepSeek R1 modelDeepSeek’s R1 model, like OpenAI’s O3-Mini, is designed for advanced reasoning. However, R1 fully reveals its thought process, a method many AI researchers consider preferable. This transparency not only makes the model easier to study but also enhances the user experience by clarifying when the model is on the right or wrong track.
