Headline: Google introduces digital watermarks for AI-edited photos using Magic EditorGoogle Photos will now add a SynthID watermark to the images edited using the Magic Editor. It aims to promote transparency and make it easier for people to identify AI manipulation.
Content:
As the AI-world is catching up, it leaves a very thin line between reality and artificially generated content. This is especially true for the images created using AI. To combat this, Google has been watermarking AI-created, but now it has recently announced that it will also watermark the images edited using AI. The company will use SynthID, which was also seen in the Imagen tool, to mark images edited with generative AI using Reimagine in Magic Editor. This step aims to help people identify AI-generated content quickly and easily. 
 


advertisementGoogle Photos to use SynthIDSynthID technology is available to Vertex AI customers using Google's text-to-image models, Imagen 3 and Imagen 2, which generate high-quality images across diverse artistic styles. Additionally, SynthID is applied to image outputs on ImageFX and has been integrated into Veo, our most advanced video generation model. Veo is currently accessible to select creators on VideoFX.
 


It can also scan a single image, or the individual frames of a video to detect digital watermarking. Google says, "We’ve designed it so it doesn’t compromise image or video quality, and allows the watermark to remain detectable — even after modifications like cropping, adding filters, changing colours, changing frame rates and saving with various lossy compression schemes."advertisement SynthID technology is available to Vertex AI customers using Google's text-to-image models, Imagen 3 and Imagen 2, which generate high-quality images across diverse artistic styles. Additionally, SynthID is applied to image outputs on ImageFX and has been integrated into Veo, our most advanced video generation model. Veo is currently accessible to select creators on VideoFX.
 


 It can also scan a single image, or the individual frames of a video to detect digital watermarking. Google says, "We’ve designed it so it doesn’t compromise image or video quality, and allows the watermark to remain detectable — even after modifications like cropping, adding filters, changing colours, changing frame rates and saving with various lossy compression schemes." The company explains that in some cases, edits made using Reimagine may be too small for SynthID to label and detect — like if you change the colour of a small flower in the background of an image. To learn more, you can use "About this image," which shows if a SynthID watermark is present as well as an image’s metadata. 
 


 For perspective, released in 2024, Reimagine uses generative AI to modify digital photos, much like other Magic Editor tools designed for on-device enhancements. However, its advanced capabilities enable more extensive edits, further blurring the line between traditional photography and AI-generated imagery.  As AI-generated images grow increasingly realistic, digital advocates are calling for a standardised method to help the public differentiate between authentic and synthetic photos. One widely suggested solution is digital watermarking, which can be embedded in a file without modifying the image itself. This said, while it is a step toward responsible AI, the watermarking alone is not enough. This feature rollout is part of a broader initiative to enhance transparency in AI-powered editing within Google Photos. Headline: Mumbai man loses Rs 11 lakh after getting call about illegal parcelA 28-year-old corporate employee from Mumbai lost Rs 11 lakh to an illegal parcel scam. The victim received several calls from fraudsters posing as law enforcement officers. The scammers tricked him into believing he was involved in a money laundering case.
Content:
A 28-year-old corporate employee from Worli became one of the latest victims of an illegal parcel scam. The victim received calls from unknown individuals who introduced themselves as law enforcement officials. They informed him about an illegal parcel confiscated in his name and convinced him that he was involved in a money laundering case. Through threats and persistent calls, the scammers managed to dupe the victim of Rs 11 lakh. The ordeal reportedly began when the victim received a call from a woman claiming to be from the Mumbai Post Office. The callers alleged that a package addressed to him had been flagged for containing six passports, multiple ATM cards, a laptop, and 150 grams of MDMA. When the victim denied any connection to the parcel, the scammer transferred his call to another individual who introduced himself as a cybercrime officer for further questioning, as reported by The Times of India. During the conversations, the scammers impersonated officials from the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), the Enforcement Directorate (ED), and Mumbai Cyber Crime to escalate the case and pressure the victim. To make the scheme more convincing, they even video-called the victim, showing a man dressed in a police uniform who claimed to be a senior officer and warned that he was implicated in a high-profile money laundering case. Additionally, the scammers sent three forged letters bearing fake seals and case details, making the victim believe he was under investigation. Another fraudster, identifying himself as IPS officer Bal Singh Rajput, instructed him to transfer funds to an “escrow account” for verification. Fearing legal trouble, the victim fell for the trap and started following the scammers’ instructions. He prematurely liquidated a Fixed Deposit (FD) worth Rs 5 lakh at Canara Bank and transferred the funds as directed. Subsequently, he sent Rs 99,000 to a Bandhan Bank account and another Rs 10 lakh to a Federal Bank account. However, after transferring Rs 11 lakh, the victim tried calling the alleged officers back, but none of them answered. Realising he had been deceived, the victim blocked the fraudsters' numbers and reported the incident to the Cyber Helpline (1930) and Mumbai Police. Notably, this is not a new form of cyber fraud, where individuals receive calls from fake police officials about an illegal parcel and end up sending large sums of money to scammers in an attempt to clear their name. In the past few months, many individuals have lost lakhs and crores to this scam. The Government of India has been actively issuing safety advisories, warning people about such scams and urging them to stay vigilant. Yet, scammers continue to find ways to trick and threaten individuals into giving them money. To protect yourself from such scams, remember:
No legitimate agency will demand bank details or fund transfers over a call or message.
If you receive such a call, hang up immediately.
If you think the call might be genuine, always cross-check suspicious claims by contacting the relevant department through official channels.
Never disclose bank details, passwords, or OTPs to unknown callers.
If something seems suspicious, block and report the caller.

Headline: Samsung Galaxy F16 tipped to launch soon under Rs 15,000Samsung is reportedly preparing to introduce the Galaxy F16 in India, and a recent leak has hinted at its rumoured price and availability.
Content:
Samsung is reportedly preparing to introduce the Galaxy F16 in India, and a recent leak has hinted at its rumoured price and availability. While the company has not confirmed an official launch date, multiple leaks suggest what to expect. According to tipster Debayan Roy on X (formerly Twitter), the Galaxy F16 is likely to be priced under Rs. 15,000 in India. For comparison, the Galaxy A16 5G, launched in October 2024, started at Rs. 18,999 for the 8GB RAM + 128GB storage variant. This suggests the Galaxy F16 could bring similar specs at a more competitive price.

 



Source: Debayan Roy/ X (formerly Twitter)
 The Galaxy F16 is expected to feature a 6.7-inch full-HD+ AMOLED display with a 90Hz refresh rate. It will likely be powered by a MediaTek Dimensity 6300 chipset, built on a 6nm process. The phone is tipped to come with 8GB of LPDDR4X RAM, which should provide decent performance for everyday tasks and light gaming.  In terms of cameras, the Galaxy F16 is rumoured to feature a triple rear camera setup, headlined by a 50-megapixel primary sensor. It is also expected to include a 5-megapixel ultra-wide-angle camera, though details about the third sensor remain unclear. For selfies, the phone might sport a 13-megapixel front-facing camera. Battery life is another area where the Galaxy F16 could shine. It is said to pack a 5,000mAh battery — the same capacity as the Galaxy A16 — which should easily last a full day on a single charge. Additionally, the phone is expected to support dual-band Wi-Fi (2.4GHz and 5GHz), for fast and stable internet connectivity. You see, we keep mentioning the Galaxy A16 throughout the article because, interestingly, the Galaxy F16 is rumoured to be a rebranded version of the A16, which was launched last year in October. This strategy isn’t new for Samsung, as the company has often released slightly modified versions of existing models under different series to cater to varying markets and price segments. Flipkart has already teased the arrival of a new Galaxy F-series phone in India, and all signs point to it being the Galaxy F16. Headline: Govt issues high risk warning for all users on Android 12 and laterThe ministry has issued a high severity warning for Android users due to multiple security vulnerabilities. This affects certain users with Android 12 and later. Here is what you can do to protect your data.
Content: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeiTy) has issued a warning for Android users, citing multiple vulnerabilities that are being reported. The Indian Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In), working with the ministry, reported that the Android 12 and later software have been affected. The warning claims that these users could face a high-severity cyberattack. The government agency shares that these multiple vulnerabilities on Android are due to flaws in the framework but, there could also be faults in the chipset components.  It states, "Multiple vulnerabilities have been reported in Android which could be exploited by an attacker to obtain sensitive information, gain elevated privileges, execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service (DoS) conditions on the targeted system."  This warning is among the most severe of security issues. The agency explains that the severity assessment is based on the effect that exploiting the vulnerability would possibly have on an affected device.   Hence, CERT advises Android 12, Android 13, Android 14, and Android 15 users to update their devices to prevent any attack. How to prevent such cyberattacks Keeping your software up to date is a crucial step in protecting your devices from potential vulnerabilities, but there are additional measures you can take to enhance security.   Regularly check for updates and enable automatic updates whenever possible to safeguard against newly discovered threats. Avoid clicking on suspicious links or downloading unverified apps, as these can serve as entry points for malicious attacks. Always install apps from the official App Store to reduce risk.   Strengthen your security by using unique, robust passwords for your Apple ID and other accounts. Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) for an extra layer of protection. Additionally, periodically review and manage app permissions to ensure they have only the necessary access to your data.   Stay vigilant against phishing attempts that may try to steal your personal information or credentials. If you receive unexpected prompts requesting sensitive details, always verify the source before providing any information.   By implementing these precautions, you can significantly enhance your device’s security and minimise the risk of falling victim to cyber threats.Published By: Unnati GusainPublished On: Feb 7, 2025Also read |  Top DOGE engineer in Elon Musk team leaves after racist comments, wanted hate normalised against IndiansAlso read |  Google introduces digital watermarks for AI-edited photos using Magic EditorAlso read |  Mumbai man loses Rs 11 lakh after getting call about illegal parcelMust Watch

Headline: DOGE engineer in Elon Musk team leaves, made racist comments against IndiansA top engineer at Elon Musk's DOGE has resigned after his racist comments against Indians resurfaced.
Content:
A top engineer at Elon Musk’s DOGE, (Department of Government Efficiency) –– 25-year-old Marko Elez –– has resigned after a flurry of his racist posts against Indians surfaced. “Normalise Indian hate,” he wrote in a post on X. He, of course, faced a lot of backlash after his old posts on X resurfaced and caused a global outrage. But this has also led to the Elon Musk initiative coming under scrutiny once again. Elez has also worked as a software engineer at Musk’s X and SpaceX. The news about his resignation was first reported by The Wall Street Journal, which highlighted the myriad of controversial posts that he had made online. The posts, now deleted, had statements particularly racist against Indians, such as “Normalise Indian hate”. There was another that read that Indians in the US on H-1B visas are “going back don’t worry guys”. He has also made other controversial comments, like “Just for the record, I was racist before it was cool.” Another one from September 2024 read: “You could not pay me to marry outside of my ethnicity.” Elez was part of the US Treasury Department and was one of two temporary members of DOGE — an initiative aimed at improving government efficiency by cutting costs and eliminating fraud –– who were posted there. The White House was notified about his post, after which Elez resigned from his post. The 25-year-old, due to his position at the Treasury, is believed to have access to highly sensitive financial data, including systems that process trillions of dollars in payments annually. The former DOGE engineer has also advocated for rescinding the Civil Rights Act in a post.“I just want a eugenic immigration policy, is that too much to ask?” 
These resurfaced posts prompted calls for his immediate removal from DOGE, which is an official government service. While all of these posts were removed from his account, screenshots of them are still circulating on the internet. And as people on the internet raised their voices against his racist opinions, which is especially troubling for someone in government services, questions were also raised about the level of access he had at the Treasury Department. The issue of access to government data has been an issue from the beginning, anyway. Several lawmakers have pointed out in the past that private-sector individuals should not be able to access sensitive public data.  According to reports, a US judge has now limited DOGE members’ access to the Treasury’s payment systems and says they will only be granted “ready-only” access. Headline: iPad is leading tablet market with over 42% market share, sees impressive annual growthApple reportedly dominated the tablet market in Q4 2024, capturing 42.3 per cent market share all thanks to its strong iPad sales, led by the M4 iPad Pro and refreshed iPad Mini.
Content:
Apple is again leading the tablet market with its iPad lineup. A new report by Canalys reveals that Apple managed to capture 42.3 percent of the entire tablet market in the fourth quarter of 2024. During this quarter, the Cupertino giant shipped an estimated 16.9 million iPads, growing from 14.8 million units in Q4 2023. According to the report, Apple’s iPads are continually becoming the preferred tablet option for users, both for personal and professional use. With powerful hardware, seamless software integration, and long-term software support, iPads across the ecosystem are managing to offer users reliable machines with powerful hardware while offering options across several price points.   While Apple has been getting attention from users every year, in 2024 specifically the reason for the rise in iPad popularity is said to be the arrival of new gen models. The M4 iPad Pro, featuring the M4 chip, and the refreshed iPad Mini with the A17 Pro chip reportedly contributed significantly to Apple’s continued growth. Meanwhile, the budget iPad Air also received a boost in sales with the M2 chip, making it a preferred choice for users looking for a balanced machine with powerful hardware while keeping the budget in place. While Apple is leading the charts in sales, its Android competitor, Samsung, is reportedly following behind. However, the gap between the first and second positions in the race is significant. Samsung shipped only 7 million tablets in Q4 2024. This count, however, translates to a 17.8 percent market share, which is less than half of Apple’s. Following Samsung, other brands, including Lenovo, Huawei, and Xiaomi, are also growing, but the difference in market share remains significant.

 



Source: Canalys PC Analysis
advertisementWhile the tablet market is growing with Apple in the lead, the company is also strengthening its presence in India. In fact, India is currently a rapidly growing market for premium tablets and smartphones, and Apple is all hooked on to leverage this growth to expand its consumer base. The company has even expanded its retail footprint and supply chain operations, in order to hold on to long-term growth in the region.Meanwhile, in the year 2025, to maintain its dominance, Apple is expected to refresh its entry-level iPad and update the iPad Air in 2025. The new iPad Air is rumored to arrive in the first half of 2025 with a new chip—possibly the M3 or M4, depending on Apple’s cost considerations—a 90Hz display, and Wi-Fi 7 support. The new iPad Air is also said to launch with a new Magic Keyboard and additional color options.To recap, Apple refreshed its lineup of high-end iPad Pro models with the M4 chip in 2024. Additionally, it introduced a new-generation iPad Mini with the A17 Pro chip and upgraded the iPad Air with the M2 chip. Headline: Vivo V50 series to launch on February 17, camera and design details revealedVivo has confirmed that its next camera-first V-series smartphone, the Vivo V50, will launch in India on February 17.
Content:
Vivo has confirmed the launch of its next camera-first V-series smartphone on February 17 at 12 noon. At the event, the company will launch its Vivo V50 series, which will most likely include two smartphones, the Vivo V50 and the Vivo V50 Pro. Ahead of the launch event, Vivo has shared a bunch of teasers about the V50 series. One thing is common in all these teasers, and that’s the “so pro” detail. This clearly hints at improvements to the smartphones’ cameras. Vivo’s V-series has always been a camera-centric series, so expect the same with the V50 series as well. The V-series has also been using Zeiss lenses for a long time.  In the teasers shared by Vivo, the company has shown a part-view of the front and back panel of the new smartphones. This has confirmed some camera and design details. For instance, we now know that the Vivo V50 series continues to use Zeiss lenses for the cameras. We also know that the smartphone will feature a dual-camera system, which will be housed inside a small round module, under which is a slight design extension that sports a small LED ring for flash. 
 


 The teasers also confirm what we already know: the smartphones will feature the volume rocker and the power button on the right edge of the phone. Also, the images show that the Vivo V50 series sports slightly rounded edges, which seems like it would have a very nice and soft in-hand feel. The display also looks almost flat with just a slight curve at the end. If our estimate is right then the display will be able to offer the best of both worlds: a flat display and a curved one.  Finally, the phone shown in the teaser image sports a beautiful wine colour, which is quite unusual. Vivo, in the teaser, has also revealed that the Vivo V50 series will come with AI features.  While we are still waiting on many details about the devices, we will know all official information only on the day of launch, which is Monday, February 17. The pricing of the phone will also be known on that day. But to get a perspective on what kind of pricing we can expect from the Vivo V50 series, if we look at last year’s Vivo V40 series, which were priced in India at a starting price of Rs 34,999, we could expect similar pricing this year. As for the purported Vivo V50 Pro, expect that to be priced under Rs 50,000.

Headline: Tinder is using AI to make online dating creep-proofAhead of Internet Safety Day on February 11, Tinder talks about how it's using AI to keep the creeps at the bay.
Content: I have been using online dating apps for a few years, and honestly, if you’re a girl on these platforms, it’s almost impossible to avoid inappropriate messages. The experience is largely the same across all apps. Unfortunately, Tinder has an especially bad reputation in this regard — and for good reason. Maybe it is because Tinder is far more popular than most dating apps — so much so that the name itself has become synonymous with online dating –– that you end up encountering inappropriate messages on Tinder than on other platforms. Ahead of Internet Safety Day on February 11, Tinder is collaborating with the Centre for Social Research (CSR) to create a safer online dating experience. Today, Tinder has released its Dating Safety Guide in four Indian regional languages, including Hindi, Marathi, Kannada, and Bengali. “For Safer Internet Day, we’re launching the Tinder Dating Safety Guide in multiple languages, empowering young daters in India with essential tools and tips,” says Dr Yoel Roth, Vice President of Trust and Safety at Match Group. “Partnering with the Center for Social Research, we’re raising awareness of practical steps people can take for safer dating, reinforcing our commitment to stronger safety standards across our platforms and communities, and industry,” he added.  But the problems with dating apps are much bigger than just inappropriate texts. With AI tools becoming more easily accessible, the platform is now having to deal with deep fakes, and related frauds and scams. Dr Roth says that even though research has identified that currently a very small proportion of accounts are using AI to create deep fakes, even if it’s a small number, the company wants to deal with it like it’s a big threat. Tinder Dating Safety Guide  Dr Roth shared a list of threats and how Tinder has turned its way to combat such risks. The first and foremost challenge (and the oldest) is the content and interaction. The inappropriate messages have been my personal fear on Tinder. In addition to the existing techniques like photo verification, option to unmatch and block contacts, Tinder has also released a handful of new AI-powered features.  – Are you sure: Using Tinder, I have always wondered if there could have been a way to just people using inappropriate words or something related. And guess what, this feature actually prompts the sender to re-read his/her text before sending. Essentially, “Are you sure” feature is powered by AI that identifies bad or creepy messages and informs users to rethink it. While it cannot hold the user back from sending it, it definitely helps in some parts.  – Does it bother you: Even after the Are You Sure prompt, if the sender decides to send the text anyway, the receiver has always had an option to report or unmatch the person. Now renamed as “Does it bother you”, the feature helps space out the users who you think are bothering you. But these are just the first degree threats. The severity increases when the users move-out of Tinder and meet face-to-face. The increased number of adversities and several Crime Petrol episodes later, all of us have realised how meeting a Tinder match can go into a different direction. And so has Tinder. And that’s where the new Share my date feature comes in.  – Share my date: Tinder has rolled out a feature that lets you share details about your upcoming dates with trusted contacts like friends and family, including the location, date, time, and a photo of their match. This feature essentially acts as a safety tool by letting others know where you will be and who you are meeting up with. And it does not stop here. If by any chance, things go wrong, Tinder has a global law enforcement and legal investigation team that work with the local prosecution. Citing this, Dr Roth shared that during the meet-up, one of the most prominent cases is the restaurant scam.  He explains how the users work in-collaboration with the restaurants and use Tinder to scam people. Basically, these users cheat on their victims by making them believe that it is a real date, but in fact they were working for the restaurant. On the date, they order in large proportion and leave the bill of their victim. In this case, the legal team can help even if this scam has been reported after the culprit has been unmatched.  Dr Roth says that if reported on time, it can not only help the victim but also the future targets. He claims that Tinder has technology to remove “44 fake accounts per minute”. Now, even after such advanced tech, users’ steps matter the most. It is of utmost importance how the user is handling the platform. And to make it better, Tinder is providing a course on how to approach in a healthy way.  – Let’s Talk Consent: The Dating Safety Guide teaches why consent is key to making dating experiences better, whether online or in person. Basically, this guide is to make you a better person and teach you how to treat others with respect (the basic stuff). Let’s Talk Consent is a course that is available on Coursera by Tinder and Yuvaa NGO. Published By: Published On: Feb 7, 2025Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Headline: Pixel 9a price leaked ahead of March launchGoogle Pixel 9a is set to launch soon, bringing a Tensor G4 chip, a 48-megapixel camera, and a 5,100mAh battery. It may also come with free Google service subscriptions for early buyers.
Content: Google will reportedly launch its next smartphone, the Pixel 9a, in March. Reports suggest that the handset will arrive in Europe and the US on the same day, March 19, with sales beginning a week later on March 26. According to a report from Dealabs, the Pixel 9a will start at EUR 549 (roughly Rs. 50,000) in Europe for the 128GB model, while the 256GB version will cost EUR 649 (roughly Rs. 58,000). In the UK, the phone is expected to be priced at GBP 499 (roughly Rs. 54,000) for 128GB and GBP 599 (roughly Rs. 65,000) for 256GB. According to an earlier report by Android Headlines, the US pricing of the Pixel 9a is tipped to start at $499 (roughly Rs 43,200) for the 128GB storage option, while the 256GB storage will cost $599 (roughly Rs 51,900). For those opting for Verizon’s mmWave model, an additional $50 will be added to the aforementioned prices. These prices are in line with the Pixel 8a’s starting price in the USA, though the higher storage option is slightly more expensive this time around. Of course, the Pixel 9a price should be different once it launches in India. For perspective, the Google Pixel 8a launched in India for Rs 52,999 and Rs 59,999 for the 128GB and 256GB storage variants respectively. The Pixel 9a is expected to be powered by Google’s Tensor G4 processor, the same chip found in the flagship Pixel 9 series. Along with 8GB LPDDR5X RAM, it is likely to offer 256GB of internal storage. A Titan M2 security chip is also rumoured to be included for added protection. The device is said to feature a 6.3-inch AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate and Gorilla Glass 3 protection. On the camera front, the Pixel 9a is tipped to sport a 48-megapixel primary sensor and a 13-megapixel ultra-wide camera. Battery life could also see an upgrade, with reports suggesting a 5,100mAh battery that supports 23W wired charging and 7.5W wireless charging. The phone is also expected to come with an IP68 rating, meaning better dust and water resistance than previous Pixel A-series models. The 128GB model is tipped to launch in four colours — Iris, Obsidian, Peony, and Porcelain — while the 256GB variant will only be available in Iris and Obsidian. In an interesting move, Google might bundle free service subscriptions with the Pixel 9a, similar to what it offers with its flagship models. Headline: OnePlus 13 mini expected to arrive next month with Snapdragon 8 Elite processorThe OnePlus 13 Mini is rumoured to launch soon, featuring a powerful Snapdragon 8 Elite chipset, compact design, and dual camera setup at the rear.
Content: The OnePlus 13 series, including the flagship OnePlus 13 and the affordable sibling OnePlus 13R, are currently one of the top Android phones in their respective price markets. The reason for this is the overall package of powerful hardware and a solid performance that OnePlus is offering with its flagship smartphones. But the series is not completed yet. Whispers suggest that OnePlus is planning to launch a new mini variant, and this speculated that the OnePlus 13 Mini could become a compelling option for users seeking high-end features in a smaller form factor. OnePlus industrial designer Lao Haoran, in his recent post on Weibo, announced that the year 2025 will be a major overhaul for its phones. Following his announcement, rumours flooded the internet, suggesting that OnePlus is developing a new mini variant—OnePlus 13 Mini. This new variant is expected to be powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 8 Elite with 7 cores—the same chipset that fuels the flagship OnePlus 13. This also hints that the OnePlus 13 Mini—though a relatively smaller device in size, as suggested by its name—will not compromise on power and will be equally capable as the flagship variants, while rivaling compact flagships like the Galaxy S25.  Along with a powerful display, the OnePlus 13 Mini is also speculated to feature a 6.31-inch LTPO OLED panel with a 1.5K resolution and a 120Hz refresh rate. Design-wise, the OnePlus 13 Mini is likely to be the first to embody OnePlus’s new design philosophy, featuring a glass back and a metal frame for a premium look and feel. The flat screen design, combined with ultra-slim bezels, is expected to offer an immersive viewing experience to users despite its compact form factor. For security, the display is also said to include an optical in-display fingerprint scanner. In addition to its compact design, powerful processor, and immersive display, the OnePlus 13 Mini is also said to offer equally capable photography features. Initially, leaks suggested that the OnePlus 13 Mini would come with a triple-camera setup. However, fresh reports from tipster Digital Chat Station suggest that the phone will instead feature a dual-camera system. This dual-camera setup in the OnePlus 13 Mini will reportedly include a 50-megapixel primary sensor and a 50-megapixel telephoto lens with 2x optical zoom. The rear camera module is expected to be arranged vertically in a bar-shaped design, giving the phone a distinctive aesthetic. Headline: What is zero-click hack that can can compromise your WhatsApp accountWhatsApp recently revealed that nearly 90 of its users across more than two dozen countries have been targeted by hackers using zero click hack.
Content: We are living in a digital age and spending hours juggling between apps and platforms to get our personal and professional work done. However, with our growing presence in digital spaces, the threat is also increasing. We are seeing scams, hacking attempts, and whatnot. To stay safe, netizens are always advised not to click on suspicious links, open suspicious files, or download anything that looks fishy. But what if we tell you there's a new hacking scheme where attackers steal credentials without even asking the target victim to click a link or download a file? Well, this is called a Zero-Click Hack. WhatsApp recently revealed to Reuters that nearly 90 users across more than two dozen countries have been targeted by hackers using advanced spyware developed by the Israeli company Paragon Solutions. This spyware allowed attackers to access the target system's information without needing any clicks from the victim. In fact, the spyware targeted all sorts of individuals, including journalists and members of civil society. According to WhatsApp, the company has sent Paragon a cease-and-desist letter following the hack. "We will continue to protect people's ability to communicate privately," said the Meta-owned company in a statement to Reuters. But how is this even possible—being attacked by malware without clicking any links or downloading anything malicious? What exactly is Zero-Click Hack? As the name suggests, a zero-click hack is a sophisticated cyberattack that allows hackers to infiltrate a user's device without any interaction from the target. Unlike traditional phishing attempts that require users to click malicious links or download infected files, zero-click attacks exploit software vulnerabilities to gain access stealthily. hackers reportedly exploited weaknesses in messaging apps, email clients, or multimedia processing functions. They sent malicious electronic documents that compromised devices without requiring users to open or interact with them. In WhatsApp’s case the hackers exploited the messaging app’s vulnerabilities.  This sneaky method makes zero-click attacks particularly dangerous and difficult to detect. These attacks are sometimes referred to as zero-click exploits, interaction-less attacks, or fully remote attacks.How Zero-Click attacks work When targeted individuals receive these malicious files, the device’s operating system or application unwittingly processes them, giving hackers access to sensitive data, including messages, calls, photos, and even the microphone and camera. The hackers then easily steal all the required data from the infected system. How to stay safe WhatsApp has assured users that it successfully disrupted the hacking effort and sent a cease-and-desist letter to Paragon Solutions. The company reaffirmed its commitment to protecting user privacy. However, it is still important to remain aware and vigilant about growing threats online and follow necessary security precautions across apps and platforms. While zero-click attacks are difficult for individuals to prevent, here are a few safety tips to reduce the risk: – Always keep your apps updated. New updates not only bring new features but also fix bugs and vulnerabilities.  – Also enable automatic updates to ensure security patches are installed as soon as they are available. – Stay vigilant for signs of device compromise, such as sudden battery drainage, unexpected app behavior, or strange messages from unknown users. – If you suspect your device has been compromised, report it to the Cyber Cell immediately.Published By: Divya BhatiPublished On: Feb 7, 2025Also Read |  OnePlus 13 mini arriving next month? Snapdragon 8 Elite processor, dual camera bump and more to expectAlso Read |  iPad is leading tablet market with over 42% market share, sees impressive annual growthAlso Read |  Mumbai man loses Rs 11 lakh after getting call about illegal parcel

Headline: Oppo Find N5 aka OnePlus Open 2 teased in new imagesThe Oppo Find N5 aka the OnePlus Open 2 is expected to launch soon. According to the latest teasers, the phone's inner display will feature a nearly invisible crease, which is a big claim from the company.
Content: Oppo is expected to launch the Find N5, aka the OnePlus Open 2, in a couple of weeks, and the teasers keep coming. The OnePlus Open 2, expected to be a rebranded version of the Oppo Find N5 for global markets, will likely share the same advancements. A recently shared image of the Find N5 places it side by side with what appears to be the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold6, highlighting the difference in the visibility of the creases. Based on leaked images, the Find N5 will retain the relatively thick bezels of its predecessor. The selfie camera is expected to stay in the top-right corner of the inner display. Headline: iPhone SE 4 to launch this week? India price, key features and all we expectApple is expected to launch the affordable iPhone SE 4 smartphone as early as this week. Ahead of the expected launch, several details about the device have leaked. Here is everything we know about the fourth-generation iPhone SE, so far.
Content: After the iPhone 17 Air, if there is another iPhone generating a similar level of anticipation, then it’s not the 2025 Apple flagships, but the iPhone SE 4. Apple fans have been waiting a long time for the tech giant to update the iPhone SE, but this has taken a while. However, there have been so many rumours and leaks along the way, that the anticipation for the upcoming iPhone SE 4 has only grown. Especially with the kind of upgrades that have been rumoured, including a shift to FaceID (finally!), an OLED panel, an iPhone 14-like design, and the fact that it is believed to be the most affordable iPhone to feature Apple Intelligence. Affordable being the operative word here. Apple has yet to confirm anything about the iPhone SE 4’s launch timeline, but there was a report by Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman last week that suggested that the affordable iPhone SE 4 could launch as soon as this week. We still don’t have a single date yet. The report also suggests that the new iPhone will become available for purchase by the end of this month. That said, unlike the usual Apple fanfare, this is not expected to be a grand event. Instead, like Apple launched the iPads quietly with just a press release, the iPhone SE 4 may also see a soft launch. iPhone SE 4: Key features expected One of the biggest changes expected with the iPhone SE 4 is its design. When you think of the iPhone SE-series, you think of that tiny iPhone with thick bezels, and a TouchID home button at the bottom of the screen. However, this year, the iPhone SE 4 is expected to get a major design overhaul. The iPhone SE 4 is believed to look like the iPhone 14. It is also expected to replace TouchID in favour of FaceID.  Some iPhone SE 4 images have also leaked in the past, which show that the iPhone could come with a single-camera setup, which will imitate the typical SE design. However, the camera is also expected to get a big upgrade, but we will come to that in a minute.  The iPhone SE 4 is also expected to leave behind the round edges design. Instead, it will have a more boxy design with rounded edges. The power button on the phone is expected to remain on the right side, just like the iPhone 14. Coming to the camera upgrade we mentioned, the iPhone SE 4 is believed to get a substantial upgrade in that department. The iPhone rear camera is expected to be bumped up to a 48-megapixel sensor from the iPhone SE 3’s 12-megapixel camera. On the front, the iPhone SE 4 is said to sport a 24-megapixel camera. The iPhone SE 4 will reportedly also get a much-needed upgrade in the display department. Improving from the LCD screen in the iPhone SE 3, the iPhone SE 4 is rumoured to feature an OLED display. The display is also going to get bigger, apparently. The iPhone SE 3 had a 4.7-inch display, but the iPhone SE 4 is said to sport a 6.1-inch OLED screen, with support for 60Hz refresh rate.  Rumours are mixed on the dynamic island. Some reports suggest that, like the Pro variant of the iPhone 14 series, the iPhone SE 4 will also feature a dynamic island. However, many reports suggest there would be no dynamic island. However, we believe the dynamic island could be a possibility, considering the iPhone SE 4 is expected to pack the powered A18 chip, which we saw in the iPhone 16 series last year. The affordable iPhone is also expected to come with 8GB RAM. With the new A18 chip, the iPhone SE 4 is also believed to feature Apple Intelligence, which is another expected highlight of the purported phone, considering this would make it the most affordable iPhone to feature Apple Intelligence.iPhone SE 4: Expected price in India Pricing remains a critical part of the iPhone SE 4’s appeal. Some reports suggest that the iPhone SE 4 will be priced starting at $499, which is about Rs 44,000. Which is pretty much the same as the launch price of the iPhone SE 3 in India that debuted at Rs 43,900. However, the smartphone later saw a price hike to Rs 49,900 due to increased taxes. Headline: Meta plans to layoff 5 per cent of employees starting todayMeta might begin its layoff plan of "performance termination" starting today. Meanwhile, it will also accelerate the hiring of machine learning engineers.
Content: Facebook’s parent company, Meta Platforms, is set to initiate company-wide layoffs this week. Reuters has reported that the company will send notices to employees starting at 5AM PST, starting today. According to the internal memos obtained by Reuters, Mark Zuckerberg's company will also accelerate the hiring of machine learning engineers, simultaneously. It also states that the layoffs will affect most countries, including the US.  That said, employees in Germany, France, Italy, and the Netherlands will be exempt from these layoffs due to local labor regulations. In contrast, employees in more than a dozen other countries across Europe, Asia, and Africa will receive their notifications between February 11 and February 18.   Meta previously confirmed that it planned to cut approximately 5 per cent of its workforce, targeting "lowest performers," with some positions being refilled. In the memo, the company referred to the cuts as “performance terminations,” a term first reported by The Information.    Unlike previous rounds of company-wide layoffs, Meta has decided to keep its offices open on Monday and will not issue any further details on the decisions, according to a memo from Meta’s Head of People, Janelle Gale.  Meanwhile, in a separate memo posted on Friday, Peng Fan, Meta’s VP of Engineering for Monetization, urged employees to assist in an expedited hiring process for machine learning engineers and other “business-critical” engineering positions. This accelerated hiring push is scheduled to take place between February 11 and March 13.   The wave of job cuts extends beyond Meta, impacting several major tech companies in 2025. Google implemented a voluntary exit program for employees in its US Platforms and Devices division, affecting teams within Android and Pixel. The company, just like Meta, sent a memo to its team, stating, "This comes after we brought two large organisations together last year." It added, "There’s tremendous momentum in this team and with so much important work ahead, we want everyone to be deeply committed to our mission and focused on building great products, with speed and efficiency.” Microsoft has also ramped up performance-based layoffs, reportedly dismissing underperforming employees, in some cases without severance. The terminated employees under this round of layoffs were facing a range of consequences, with some reportedly indicating that they might not have received severance pay. According to the reports, at least three employees confirmed that they were told they would not be compensated upon their exit from the company. Additionally, their healthcare benefits were also immediately cut off, raising questions about Microsoft's approach to handling these layoffs, especially in terms of financial and post-employment support. Amazon has eliminated approximately 200 positions in its fashion and fitness divisions as it refocuses priorities within its North America Stores team. The move is Amazon's part of a broader strategy to cut bureaucracy and improve the company's efficiency, helping teams move faster and get closer to customers. Headline: DeepSeek R1: Recent findings reveal multiple security flaws in iOS appAs per a report, DeepSeek R1 for iOS has several flaws, including the disabling of key security protections and the use of outdated encryption methods. These concerns intensified after it was discovered that a database containing sensitive user information was left exposed without authentication.
Content: DeepSeek is once again facing scrutiny — this time over multiple security vulnerabilities that could put users’ privacy at risk. According to a report by mobile security firm NowSecure, DeepSeek R1 — DeepSeek’s iOS app — has several flaws, including the disabling of key security protections and the use of outdated encryption methods. These concerns intensified after it was discovered that a database containing sensitive user information — including chat logs and secret keys — was left exposed without authentication. This meant anyone could access the data without needing credentials, raising concerns over how the company was handling private user information.  One of the major issues highlighted in the report is the app’s failure to use Apple’s built-in App Transport Security (ATS), a system designed to ensure that personal data is transmitted securely over encrypted channels. Instead, DeepSeek has completely disabled this protection, allowing unencrypted data to be sent over the internet. According to NowSecure, “The DeepSeek iOS app globally disables App Transport Security (ATS), which is an iOS platform level protection that prevents sensitive data from being sent over unencrypted channels. Since this protection is disabled, the app can (and does) send unencrypted data over the internet.” Additionally, even when data is encrypted, the app relies on the outdated Triple DES (3DES) encryption algorithm, which is widely considered insecure. "The encryption algorithm chosen for this part of the application leverages a known broken encryption algorithm (3DES) which makes it a poor choice to protect the confidentiality of data," the report states. Experts warn that even seemingly harmless user data, when collected over time, can be used to identify individuals. "While none of this data taken separately is highly risky, the aggregation of many data points over time quickly leads to easily identifying individuals," the report explains. A recent example of this was the data breach of Gravy Analytics, where information collected from various apps was used to de-anonymise users on a large scale. This raises serious questions about how DeepSeek handles data security, particularly since much of the collected information could be cross-referenced with data from other apps. "Bear in mind that not only are 10’s of data points collected in the DeepSeek iOS app but related data is collected from millions of apps and can be easily purchased, combined and then correlated to quickly de-anonymize users," the report warns. Given the scope of these security flaws, NowSecure is urging businesses, government agencies, and individuals to reconsider using the app until significant improvements are made.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Headline: Sam Altman says AI agents will soon be able to do jobs of human software engineersOpenAI CEO Sam Altman has started rolling out AI agents, which he says will eventually become virtual co-workers of humans. He also confirmed that the AI agents will soon perform many of the tasks that software engineers with a few years of experience currently handle.
Content: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has started rolling out AI agents, which he says will eventually become virtual co-workers of humans. He also confirmed that the AI agents will soon perform many of the tasks that software engineers with a few years of experience currently handle. This bold vision was outlined in a recent blog post where Altman discussed the rapid progress in artificial intelligence and its potential to transform industries.advertisementOpenAI Sam Altman rolling AI agents to do jobs of software engineersAltman gave the example of a software engineering agent that could accomplish tasks typically assigned to a software engineer at a top company. However, he clarified that while these AI agents could perform tasks over a couple of days, they wouldn’t come up with groundbreaking ideas and would require human supervision.In the long term, Altman imagines a world where AI agents are deployed across various fields of knowledge work. "Now imagine 1,000 of them or 1 million of them," he said, highlighting the scale at which these agents could operate. He compared AI's impact on the economy to the transistor, which revolutionised industries but is now so embedded in daily life that it often goes unnoticed. Altman gave the example of a software engineering agent that could accomplish tasks typically assigned to a software engineer at a top company. However, he clarified that while these AI agents could perform tasks over a couple of days, they wouldn’t come up with groundbreaking ideas and would require human supervision. In the long term, Altman imagines a world where AI agents are deployed across various fields of knowledge work. "Now imagine 1,000 of them or 1 million of them," he said, highlighting the scale at which these agents could operate. He compared AI's impact on the economy to the transistor, which revolutionised industries but is now so embedded in daily life that it often goes unnoticed. Altman’s comments come at a time when artificial general intelligence (AGI) is nearing reality. He believes AGI could handle complex problems at a human level across multiple fields, driving economic growth and enabling people to achieve more in their personal and professional lives. He further stated that in the next decade, every individual could accomplish more than the most impactful people today. Altman also expressed concerns about the balance of power between capital and labour, suggesting that early intervention might be needed to prevent inequalities. He floated the idea of giving people access to more AI resources, though he acknowledged it could sound unconventional.Meta recently confirmed plans to replace mid-level engineers with AI Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg just recently announced that AI at Meta and other tech companies will effectively replace mid-level engineers who currently write code this year. This would likely change how tech companies approach software development. "We will get to a point where all the code in our apps and the AI it generates will also be written by AI engineers instead of people engineers," he said. For context, a report recently claimed that mid-level software engineers at Meta currently earn salaries in the mid-six figures — a cost AI could significantly reduce.Google is already using AI to generate codes Just a few months back, Google CEO Sundar Pichai also announced that over 25 per cent of all new code at Google is now generated by AI, with human engineers stepping in for final reviews.  While all the big tech companies are assuring that this won't impact humans, only time will tell whether human jobs will be reduced because of AI. The companies are already firing thousands of employees in the name of cost-saving or performance issues. If AI successfully manages to take the place of humans, the companies won't likely take a lot of time to replace them with virtual AI models. But, of course, this might only affect the people who do mid-level engineering jobs. All these AI developments suggest that it might be time for humans to upskill themselves to remain employed at big tech companies.Published By: Ankita GargPublished On: Feb 10, 2025

Headline: Amazon and Microsoft eye TikTok acquisition, Elon Musk says not interestedAs per plan, US President Donald Trump is actively discussing ways to bring TikTok under American control.
Content: The uncertainty over TikTok’s future in the US is looming. Meanwhile, a somewhat battle has intensified with tech giants like Amazon, Microsoft and Oracle showing interest in acquiring the company’s US operations. This comes after the US president, Donald Trump, while extending the TikTok ban in the US, said he would like TikTok’s US operations to remain under American control. And the way to do that is that the company’s operation in India is acquired by another US tech company. To foolproof the plan, Trump also signed an executive order this month to create a sovereign wealth fund that is aimed to facilitate the purchase of TikTok. According to reports, Amazon, Microsoft, and Oracle have privately explored ways to either acquire TikTok or take over its US operations, but that’s not the option TikTok is looking for apparently. TikTok is reportedly looking for an alternative option that would avoid an outright sale of its US operations. Reportedly, TikTok is talking about a plan to protect American data –– which is the key contention in this case –– through an independent US-based entity. TikTok CEO reportedly met with senior White House officials last week to suggest a plan to form a joint venture with US investors, that could be headquartered in the US, to oversee data security. This way, the company would have management that is based out of the US, and its board of directors would primarily be Americans. With the whole sovereign fund involved, it is still unclear if the US government would also be an investor. Meanwhile, US vice president JD Vance is now in charge of overseeing negotiations, making use of his background in venture capital and ties to Silicon Valley, to help find a solution to the TikTok problem.Elon Musk says he has no interest in acquiring TikTok Ever since the talk of the TikTok ban and Trump’s solution of keeping its operations in the US began, there have been rumours that Elon Musk will eventually buy the platform. However, recently speaking at a virtual summit, Musk dismissed rumours that China was willing to sell TikTok to him. This came after reports in January suggested that officials in China were discussing the possibility of offloading TikTok to Musk as a means of avoiding a US ban. ByteDance, however, has repeatedly denied these reports. A company spokesperson called these reports “pure fiction.”  The Trump administration is doing everything to keep TikTok in the US while addressing the national security concern. As soon as Donald Trump took over as the new US president, one of the first things he did was to extend the TikTok US ban by 75 days. Originally set to take effect in January, the deadline for the ban has now been extended to April 2025. Headline: OnePlus announces Photography Awards 2025, shoot with any phone and winner to get Rs 8 lakhOnePlus has officially announced the launch of its fifth annual OnePlus Photography Awards (OPA). For the first time, the contest is open to all smartphone users, and not just OnePlus device owners.
Content: OnePlus has officially announced its fifth annual OnePlus Photography Awards (OPA), inviting mobile photography enthusiasts from around the world to participate. The competition, which runs from February 7 to June 30, 2025, encourages photographers to submit their work under the theme — Make the Moment. One of the standout features of this year’s OPA is its inclusivity.  For the first time, OPA is open to all smartphone users, and not just OnePlus device owners. Entries will be divided into two groups: the OnePlus Group, exclusively for OnePlus users, and the Public Group, which welcomes submissions from all smartphone brands. A panel of judges, including OnePlus founder Pete Lau, Hasselblad ambassadors, and renowned photographers, will evaluate the entries to ensure a fair and comprehensive selection process. Participants can submit their entries for the 2025 OPA across three categories: Movement, Night and Low Light, and Faces. Each category is designed to challenge photographers to capture unique aspects of life.  — The Movement category focuses on the essence of motion, whether it’s the thrill of speed or the subtle movements of daily life.  — Night and Low Light encourages photographers to explore the beauty of the world after dark, from vibrant cityscapes to serene starlit skies.  — Meanwhile, the Faces category invites participants to tell emotional stories through portraits, capturing everything from joyful smiles to heartfelt moments and expressions. The winners, set to be announced on August 19, 2025, will receive generous rewards. The overall winner will take home a cash prize of $10,000 (roughly Rs 8,76,000), while all category winners will be awarded the flagship OnePlus 13 smartphone. Additionally, winners may have the opportunity to collaborate with OnePlus on future projects. Winning entries will also be showcased on global platforms like OnePlus and 500px, giving photographers a chance to gain international exposure and connect with a wider community. Harisanker Sasikumar, a category winner from the 2024 OPA, shared his experience: “Winning the 2024 OnePlus Photography Awards has been a massive milestone. It’s not just recognition, but also a reminder to keep pushing my creative boundaries. It’s motivated me to explore new ideas and stay curious. To everyone participating in the 2025 OnePlus Photography Awards, good luck. Embrace your unique vision, keep experimenting, and most importantly, have fun with it.” Entries for the 2025 OnePlus Photography Awards are now open. Photographers can submit their work and find more details at www.oneplus.com/photography-awards-2025. The last date for submitting entries is June 30, 2025.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore? Headline: OnePlus next flagships to feature iPhone-like action button? Here is all we knowAccording to the latest report, the upcoming OnePlus flagships will no longer feature an alert slider. But, the upcoming phones might come with an iPhone-like action button.
Content:
For years, OnePlus has been launching its smartphones with an alert slider, which is used to switch notification settings to ring, silent or vibrate. But now, the upcoming flagships might do away with it. A new report indicates that the next-gen OnePlus flagships will do away with the toggle bar and bring a button for these tasks. The rumour has it that this button will function just like the iPhone's action button. A tipster, Digital Chat Station on Weibo has stated that the three-stage button (the toggle bar) will be replaced on the next flagship phone. This could debut in March, which could mean the OnePlus 14. 
 


advertisementOnePlus to launch iPhone-like action buttonThe upcoming OnePlus button is expected to be multi-functional, allowing users to customise it for various tasks. Similarly, Apple's Action Button on the iPhone 16 can be remapped beyond its default settings. Originally introduced with the iPhone 15 Pro models as a replacement for the traditional ring-silent switch, the Action Button enables users to toggle between silent, vibrate, and ring modes, activate Do Not Disturb and Focus modes, launch the camera or flashlight, trigger Shazam, and access favourite shortcuts in Control Center.  Following the same philosophy, OnePlus seems to be moving toward a more versatile approach with its new button. While longtime fans of the classic three-position alert slider may be disappointed, just like iPhone users were. But a customisable button could prove more practical for a broader audience.advertisement The upcoming OnePlus button is expected to be multi-functional, allowing users to customise it for various tasks. Similarly, Apple's Action Button on the iPhone 16 can be remapped beyond its default settings. Originally introduced with the iPhone 15 Pro models as a replacement for the traditional ring-silent switch, the Action Button enables users to toggle between silent, vibrate, and ring modes, activate Do Not Disturb and Focus modes, launch the camera or flashlight, trigger Shazam, and access favourite shortcuts in Control Center.   Following the same philosophy, OnePlus seems to be moving toward a more versatile approach with its new button. While longtime fans of the classic three-position alert slider may be disappointed, just like iPhone users were. But a customisable button could prove more practical for a broader audience. Notably, this isn’t the first time OnePlus has moved away from its signature mute switch. The OnePlus 10T also lacked the alert slider, with the company justifying its removal as a necessary engineering trade-off to accommodate faster charging, a larger battery, and an improved antenna system. It remains to be seen what rationale OnePlus will provide for this latest change. That said, the OnePlus Open 2 is most likely to come with a slider. According to previous trends, the recently announced Oppo Find N5 will be rebranded as OnePlus Open 2. And the latest official images of the Oppo foldable show that the phone has a toggle bar.  On that note, Oppo Find N5 is confirmed to be unveiled on February 20. The company claims that the foldable will be the slimmest foldable so far. Apart from the launch date and a video, the company is yet to reveal more information. But the rumours and leaks have got us covered. Read all about the upcoming Oppo Find N5 here. Headline: DeepSeek excessively collects personal data, says Korean spy agencyAfter Taiwan, Australia and Italy, some government ministries in South Korea have blocked access to the app citing security concerns.
Content: South Korea's spy agency has accused Chinese AI app DeepSeek of "excessively" collecting personal data and using all input data to train itself, and questioned the app's responses to questions relating to issues of national pride. The National Intelligence Service (NIS) said it sent an official notice to government agencies last week urging them to take security precautions over the artificial intelligence app. "Unlike other generative AI services, it has been confirmed that chat records are transferable as it includes a function to collect keyboard input patterns that can identify individuals and communicate with Chinese companies' servers such as volceapplog.com," the NIS said in a statement issued on Sunday. Some government ministries in South Korea have blocked access to the app citing security concerns, joining Australia and Taiwan in warning about or placing restrictions on DeepSeek. The NIS said DeepSeek gives advertisers unlimited access to user data and stores South Korean users' data in Chinese servers. Under Chinese law, the Chinese government would be able to access such information when requested, the agency added. DeepSeek also provided different answers to potentially sensitive questions in different languages, the NIS noted. It cited one such question as asking for the origin of kimchi - a spicy, fermented dish that is a staple in South Korea. When asked about it in Korean, the app said kimchi is a Korean dish, the NIS said. Asked the same question in Chinese, it said the dish originated from China, it said. DeepSeek's responses were corroborated by Reuters. The origin of kimchi has at times been a source of contention between South Koreans and Chinese social media users in recent years. DeepSeek has also been accused of censoring responses to political questions such as the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, which prompt the app to suggest changing the subject: "Let's talk about something else." DeepSeek did not immediately respond to an emailed request for comment. When asked about moves by South Korean government departments to block DeepSeek, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson told a briefing on February 6 that the Chinese government attached great importance to data privacy and security and protected it in accordance with the law. The spokesperson also said Beijing would never ask any company or individual to collect or store data in breach of laws.Published By: Nandini YadavPublished On: Feb 10, 2025

Headline: What is satellite connectivity on smartphones that Airtel and Jio are working onSeveral smartphones and telecom providers are working to provide satellite connectivity. This feature aims to provide better connections even in remote areas.
Content: Satellite connectivity on smartphones is a hot topic these days. It started with iPhone 14 in 2022 when Apple introduced satellite communication to phones. Since then, companies have been trying to work around it. But what is this feature, and how does it work? The satellite connectivity feature is designed to enable users to contact emergency services via SOS messages, even in locations without cellular coverage. While brands like Google and Samsung have also adopted the technology, it remains a niche offering, limited to specific regions and a handful of smartphone models. Let's look at it in detail. advertisementWhat is satellite connectivity and how does it work? First things first, mobile satellite connectivity is not the same as using a satellite phone, also known as a satphone. While satphones rely entirely on satellites to make calls and send messages, they are bulkier, more expensive, and designed for people travelling to extremely remote areas where traditional networks don’t work.  In India, BSNL is among the satphones sellers. However, smartphones are solely dependent on cellular networks. But with satellite connectivity, a regular smartphone will also work as a satphone. This means that it can easily connect users to a satellite network in emergencies when there’s no cellular coverage.  First things first, mobile satellite connectivity is not the same as using a satellite phone, also known as a satphone. While satphones rely entirely on satellites to make calls and send messages, they are bulkier, more expensive, and designed for people travelling to extremely remote areas where traditional networks don’t work.  In India, BSNL is among the satphones sellers.  However, smartphones are solely dependent on cellular networks. But with satellite connectivity, a regular smartphone will also work as a satphone. This means that it can easily connect users to a satellite network in emergencies when there’s no cellular coverage.  Currently, most satellite connectivity features on smartphones are limited to SOS messaging. However, in the near future, two-way messaging is expected to become available, and eventually, internet data transmission may also be possible. While satellite connectivity is yet to come, when it does, smartphones will not depend on ground-based cell towers. It will directly connect to a network of low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites to transmit data.Satellite connectivity in India In India, telecom giants Airtel and Jio are actively working to introduce satellite-based services. Airtel has joined forces with OneWeb, while Jio has partnered with SES. However, the rollout faces challenges due to an ongoing debate over satellite spectrum allocation. Companies like Starlink support administrative allocation for quicker deployment, whereas Airtel and Jio advocate for an auction-based system to promote fair competition. But US is a step ahead. After launching satellite connectivity in beta phase, T-mobile in collaboration with Elon Musk’s Starlink is set to release the Satellite texting feature for all. But, according to a Bloomberg report, it comes at a cost. It has been confirmed that T-mobiles and Elon Musk’s Starlink will soon launch a satellite texting feature for everyone, but at a price. The program is available only in the US for now, unlike Apple’s Globalstar service, which works in multiple countries.  The report states that starting in July, direct-to-cell Starlink service will be free for T-Mobile's priciest Go5G Next plan, and $15 per month for everyone else. On AT&T and Verizon, however, it'll be pricier, $20 per month per line. Smartphones with satellite connectivity in India  While the telecom companies are working for satellite connectivity, it is also important to know which smartphones have this feature and which are also in progress.  Apple introduced satellite connectivity with the iPhone 14 series and later models through a partnership with US-based satellite provider Globalstar. This feature allows iPhones to connect with emergency services using specialised antennas.   Similarly, Google launched the Satellite SOS feature on the Pixel 9 series last year in collaboration with Skylo. The Pixel 9 series supports satellite connectivity thanks to Samsung’s Exynos 5400 modem.   Samsung has also been working on satellite technology. While the Galaxy S24 series includes the same Exynos 5400 modem as the Pixel 9, it does not yet support satellite communication. However, the newly released Galaxy S25 series is built with Qualcomm’s Snapdragon X80 5G modem inside the Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, making it capable of supporting the feature. Reports suggest Samsung may soon enable a satellite-based SOS function on these devices.  That said, it all boils down to users and is it really needed? For now, satellite connectivity seems like an attractive option-- and for good reasons. This feature will be a great help, especially in remote areas. It looks like this is not only an achievement in the tech area, but for safety purposes as well. Headline: Future AirPods tipped to get integrated camera supportMark Gurman suggests that Apple wants to use small cameras in AirPods to analyse the environment and provide information to users. Instead of pulling out your iPhone to ask Siri about something, you could simply ask your AirPods while wearing them.
Content: Apple is working on a version of AirPods Pro that may feature integrated cameras, as per Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman. While this tech won’t be part of the upcoming AirPods Pro 3 expected later this year, it could arrive as early as 2027. But why would Apple want to put cameras on a pair of wireless earbuds? There seem to be two main reasons: AI-driven features and better spatial audio integration. Apple recently introduced Visual Intelligence with the iPhone 16 lineup. This feature helps users interact with their surroundings in new ways, such as identifying objects, reading event flyers, and adding information to apps. The idea is that AirPods with cameras could take this even further. Gurman suggests that Apple wants to use small cameras in AirPods to analyse the environment and provide information to users. Instead of pulling out your iPhone to ask Siri about something, you could simply ask your AirPods while wearing them. This could bring a new level of convenience for hands-free interactions, whether you’re looking for directions, identifying landmarks, or even getting real-time translations. While this might sound like smart glasses without the glasses, Apple reportedly sees it as a way to improve everyday usability while keeping the technology discreet. For users who aren’t ready to wear augmented reality glasses like Meta’s Ray-Bans or Apple’s own Vision Pro, this could be a middle-ground solution. Well-known Apple analyst Ming-Chi Kuo has also weighed in on the AirPods camera rumour but from a different angle. He suggests the cameras could improve Apple’s spatial audio technology, particularly when paired with Vision Pro and other future AR/VR devices. The idea is that the cameras could track a user’s head movements and adjust the sound accordingly. If you turn your head while watching something on Vision Pro, the sound could shift to emphasise audio from that direction, making the experience more immersive.  Ming-Chi Kuo also speculates that these cameras could allow users to control their devices with in-air gestures. Imagine adjusting the volume or switching songs just by moving your hands — no need to tap your AirPods or use Siri. If Apple does go ahead with this concept, it won’t be anytime soon. Bloomberg reports that the earliest we might see AirPods with cameras would be in 2027, possibly alongside AirPods Pro 4. Apple is also reportedly working on a set of smart glasses to rival Meta’s, which could launch around the same time.Published By: Aman rashidPublished On: Feb 10, 2025Also read |  Poco X7, X7 Pro review: Which is best for you?Also read |  Snapdragon 8 Elite for just Rs 55,000: Is iQOO 13 too good to be true?Also read |  Can't see notifications on your Samsung phone anymore?
